webTitle: Best go for Georgie and sack Good Time Charlton

fields.headline: Best go for Georgie and sack Good Time Charlton
fields.trailText: Martin Kelner calls for the national sport to ditch Bobby Charlton and be a tad more imaginative in its choice of ambassadorial presence in world football's corridors of schmooze - George Best would be ideal.
fields.body:
Now that Chas and Dave have launched their campaign to be London's mayor with a manifesto behind which the whole capital can unite ("I've got my beer, I've got my beer, I've got my beer on the sideboard here"), and the golfer Colin Montgomerie has been chosen to travel the world to speak up for Scotland, is it not time for English football to follow suit and be a tad more imaginative in its choice of ambassadorial presence in world football's corridors of schmooze?

I mean, Bobby Charlton. I ask you. Bobby is, of course, a national treasure and all that, but, let us be honest, he doesn't add a great deal to the gaiety of nations.

Have you ever heard Bobby Charlton tell a joke, or indeed say anything vaguely amusing? I have heard jokes about Bobby Charlton ("I hear your lad's at the Bobby Charlton School of Excellence - how's he doing?" "Great. Only 16 and he's bald already.") but never one from him.

While Ron Atkinson's assessment of Bobby is probably scandalously unfair - "His reputation as a grizzlin' old miser was legendary," Ron said of Sir Bob - even the staunchest Manchester United fan would find it hard to escape the conclusion that when you put the footballing knight with thunder in his boots into a lounge suit he is as dour as porridge.

Every time the camera seeks him out standing there in his suit at one of those Fifa occasions - and my God, does the camera seek him out - I am reminded of Barry Humphries, who used to open his Les Patterson act by appearing on stage in a double-breasted grey suit, saying, "You're probably wondering what I'm doing here, all dressed up like a pox doctor's clerk."

Still, sportsmen often look awkward in civvies, and the fact that Sir Bobby is not exactly Eddie Izzard should not matter. He is after all transparently a gentleman, whose every pore oozes decency.

These days, though, that is not enough. Branding is the new thing. Colin Montgomerie, for instance, has been appointed, according to Scotland's first minister Donald Dewar, to shake hands, kiss babies and speak to businessmen in the cause of "promoting Scotland the Brand".

So Scotland the Brave is clearly "oot the windy", as those few Scots clinging on to the old ways might say, in favour of the new image as a forward-looking European technocracy. Dewar knows a shortbread-hungry world will sit up and take notice of Montgomerie.

The point is that while Charlton is criss-crossing the globe building up his collection of complimentary shower caps, and handing round artists' impressions of what St James' Park will look like when it is finished, he needs to be establishing World Cup 2006 as a brand, preferably a brand that speaks of fun and good times.

If those who have to vote on where the tournament should be held have in their mind two images, one of a Fifa dinner where they are eating rubber chicken in the company of Sir Bobby and Lady Charlton, and one of bronzed young people in those dental-floss trunks on Copacabana beach, guess where the World Cup will go.

They need to be convinced that Manchester in June can be as much fun as Rio, and Sir Bobby is not the man to do it. He has many fine qualities, as discussed, but he is no Good Time Charlton.

The man for the job, and you need not look beyond the great United team of the 60s, is clearly Sir Bobby's former team-mate Georgie Best, living proof - just about - that it is possible to have a good time in Manchester. "He was Roy of the Rovers on the field, but sadly Roy of the Ravers off it," reads the International Football Hall of Fame website.

I don't know. He doesn't look that sad to me. As he says, "I laugh when I see 'fallen idol'. These people who are writing it are sitting in an office nine to five, but I'm going out and sometimes getting paid £5,000 for an interview. And I'm thinking, who's fallen here?"

The Hall of Fame website may well rue the squandering of "one of the rarest football talents ever seen in favour of a self-indulgent merry-go-round of birds and booze" but the guys planning their summer holidays around the 2006 World Cup are most likely to want to know what time the merry-go-round starts.

Georgie Best, then. Keep him away from live chat shows, and make sure most of the space in the mini-bar is taken up by Toblerone and tins of salted peanuts, and you have British football's ideal international ambassador.

webTitle: Wright facing lengthy ban for outburst

fields.headline: Wright facing lengthy ban for outburst
fields.standfirst: Celtic striker is back in dock for comments over sending-off
fields.trailText: Celtic striker Ian Wright is back in the dock for comments made following his altercation with the fourth official and post-match sending-off at Kilmarnock on Sunday.
fields.body:
Ian Wright's long and troubled disciplinary record seems certain to be extended when the Scottish Football Association meets next month to question the English striker over statements made in a newspaper about his post-match sending-off at Kilmarnock on Sunday.

The SFA revealed yesterday that the referee Kenny Clark had red-carded Wright in the dressing room after he adjudged that he had manhandled the fourth official Willie Young in the tunnel at the end of the draw.

But the authorities are more concerned about Wright's unrepentant attitude in his column. "This silly fourth official kept hassling me," Wright claimed. "He kept pushing me, telling me to go to the changing rooms. He wouldn't leave off. He did this to me four times. I said I wouldn't move and pushed him back, just the once. He looked at me and said 'Right, you're done'."

Those remarks are sure to attract the attention of the SFA's general purposes committee which has the power to bring separate charges on top of the automatic suspension for the red card.

Wright was booked after the final whistle following a scuffle with Kilmarnock's Jim Lauchlan and Celtic, who have seven days to respond to the referee's report, may well claim that it was Lauchlan's last-minute lunge on Wright which started the trouble.

The subsequent red card means that the striker misses Celtic's Scottish Cup tie against Inverness Caledonian Thistle on Saturday, but the push on the official could lead to a heavy fine and a much lengthier ban.

The Rangers manager Dick Advocaat was set to recall the striker Marco Negri for the first time in 20 months for a friendly against Sparta Rotterdam last night. The Italian scored 36 goals in half a season at Ibrox, but has not played since falling out with Walter Smith, then the manager, in April 1998.

The FA have decided not to charge Sol Campbell and Colin Calderwood over allegations of a tunnel bust-up with a security guard after a match between Derby and Tottenham last season.

Sunderland's manager Peter Reid has assured Chris Makin and Nicky Summerbee they still figure in his plans despite both players being dropped after a training-ground row.

fields.headline: Dream script for Kenwright
fields.standfirst: Theatre impresario takes control of Everton for £20m as Johnson's gamble backfires
fields.trailText: The theatre impresario Bill Kenwright yesterday finally assumed control of Everton at a cost of £20m when he met yesterday's non-negotiable deadline for completion of the deal with five hours to spare.
fields.body:
The theatre impresario Bill Kenwright yesterday finally assumed control of Everton. After more than 14 months of fundraising and at times acrimonious negotiation, Kenwright finally struck an irrevocable deal for the majority shareholding of the former chairman Peter Johnson.

Kenwright met yesterday's non-negotiable deadline for completion with five hours to spare and will pay just over £20m for Johnson's 68% stake - a deal which values one of football's oldest and most respected clubs at only £30m.

The club announced that the chain of events had been triggered by the completion of due diligence, a scrutiny of the club accounts by Kenwright's legal advisers.

As Kenwright pondered how best to approach the task of transforming the fortunes of a sporting giant fallen on hard times, Johnson was left to rue a calculated gamble which backfired so spectacularly.

The deal means that the Jersey-based businessman has not only received substantially less than he had been anticipating, but that he has also taken a loss of between £4m-5m on his investment when he seized control.

Less than two years ago, when the billionaire Joe Lewis was showing an interest in Everton, Johnson, who took over in 1994, was quoting a price in excess of £70m.

Indeed, during the course of his pre-Christmas talks with Kenwright and other interested parties, Johnson was adamant that he would not do business at less than £1,200 a share, which would have valued his stake at around £29m.

Despite coming under pressure from the football authorities to offload his controlling interest in either Everton or the First Division club Tranmere Rovers, Johnson was content to extend his game of brinkmanship until a prospective buyer agreed to meet his price.

However, the plan was to be undone just before Christmas when his bankers, anxious to recoup a loan he had taken out to buy Everton, insisted he accept any reasonable firm offer. Kenwright offered £857 per share, a bid which Johnson believed to be inadequate yet one which he had no option but to accept.

With his bankers unhappy and the future of his primary business concern, the Park Food hamper group, very much on the line, Johnson gambled all believing that Kenwright would be unable to raise the funds to meet yesterday's deadline.

As it approached, rumours began to suggest that Kenwright was struggling to pull together the strands of his consortium, meaning Johnson's gamble would have paid off.

It did not. With the sort of flourish Kenwright normally reserves for his West End productions, he came up with the money to buy, at a rock-bottom price, the club he has always called his "life's passion".

"Obviously, I am very, very happy," he said. "It has been a very long road but I am thrilled and relieved that it is now done.

"Acquiring Peter Johnson's shares is only the first step to restoring a great club to where it belongs - to where it should be. If you are going to run a successful football club you need two qualities: you need to be realistic and you need a plan. I'm realistic and I have a plan," he added.

Kenwright's consortium is made up of Paul Gregg, the head of the US entertainment company SFX, the Everton director Arthur Abercromby and John Woods, a member of the Everton Shareholders' Association.

"I do have tremendous confidence in my partners," said Kenwright, who will continue as Everton's vice-chairman. Sir Philip Carter is to remain chairman.

To reduce a debt of about £14m Everton will seek to sell a 9.9% stake to a media company such as NTL, Sky or Granada. There is also likely to be a new rights issue followed by discussions about the possibility of resurrecting Johnson's shelved plan to demolish Goodison Park and build a new stadium on the outskirts of the city.

"We have much hard work ahead of us but we are now on the way," said Kenwright.

The Everton manager Walter Smith can expect little benefit from the deal; he is likely to be informed that he must continue to run the team on a shoestring budget.

fields.headline: Bradford shun £3m Collymore
fields.trailText: Bradford City yesterday pulled out of the race to sign Stan Collymore when it became apparent that Aston Villa want around £3m for the player.
fields.body:
Bradford City yesterday pulled out of the race to sign Stan Collymore when it became apparent that Aston Villa want around £3m for the player.

"The only way we could sign Collymore is on a free transfer; anything else causes an insurmountable problem," the Bradford chairman Geoffrey Richmond said.

Leicester City's manager Martin O'Neill has held preliminary talks with Collymore's advisers, although he is also unlikely to match Villa's valuation of a 29-year-old striker who has been conspicuous by his absence this season.

Silvio Maric, an expensive legacy of Ruud Gullit's tenure at Newcastle, yesterday joined Croatia Zagreb on loan until the end of the season. Eleven months ago he moved in the opposite direction for £3.5m in a deal believed to be worth £30,000 a week. Sunderland's want-away winger Allan Johnston has joined Bolton on loan.

Southampton's record signing David Hirst has retired at the age of 32 after failing to recover from a long-standing knee injury. The striker, who scored one goal for England in his three games, was a £2m buy from Sheffield Wednesday but never got over a freak accident while training in June 1998. He last started a first-team game 20 months ago.

fields.headline: Villa stall on Leicester grit
fields.trailText: There is no doubt what Aston Villa ought to concentrate on in preparation for next week's second leg: plenty of penalty practice, making sure Gareth Southgate keeps a low profile.
fields.body:
There is no doubt what Aston Villa ought to concentrate on in preparation for next week's second leg: plenty of penalty practice, making sure Gareth Southgate keeps a low profile.

Despite a flurry of late pressure which produced two clear chances, John Gregory's side otherwise disappointed a far from capacity crowd at Villa Park last night as they failed to find a way past a typically gritty Leicester.

If this generally tight encounter was anything to go by, spot-kicks will decide who motors on to play Bolton or Tranmere at Wembley. Having seen off Leeds and Fulham from 12 yards, Leicester will fancy their chances.

Gregory cannot have expected an easy time. Two weeks ago he left Leicester's quarter-final in London 10 minutes early convinced that Fulham, leading 2-0, would be Villa's opponents last night. Typically, Leicester scored twice in the last five minutes and went through on penalties. The next morning he received a mocking phone call from Martin O'Neill.

Leicester's hopes of progress seemed to be bolstered by the return from injury last night of several key players, among them Muzzy Izzet, Gerry Taggart and Robbie Savage.

Resurgent Villa's main worry was always going to be in attack, where injuries and the ineligibility of Benito Carbone meant Paul Merson was pushed forward to partner Julian Joachim in a pairing lacking the height Gregory favours.

Certainly they looked lightweight despite applying most of the pressure during a predictably cagey and dull opening. Steve Stone began well on the right flank but clear-cut chances were rare. The night's first shot, by George Boateng in the 18th minute, threatened mainly the executive boxes.

Leicester's lack of attacking ideas at once showed why they arrived without a win in 90 minutes since late November, a run of 13 matches. They looked happy to keep things tight and strike with long passes to Emile Heskey and the makeshift striker Matt Elliott on the counter.

Then, after half an hour, they produced a flurry of activity. First, after Heskey was fouled by Ugo Ehiogu, Stefan Oakes curled in a free-kick from the right edge of the area which David Jones palmed clear. Then the goalkeeper had to move quickly off his line and save at Heskey's feet as the striker chased Izzet's neat pass.

The boos that greeted Heskey's every touch suggested he is not as popular with the Villa fans as he is with their manager. His initial misdemeanour was to lead with an elbow in a challenge with Gareth Barry, for which he was booked.

Not surprisingly, the sparse crowd seemed to lose enthusiasm as the game dragged on. The home fans' biggest cheers were reserved for the sight of Heskey collapsed in pain as he pulled up chasing a Steve Guppy pass. "Let him die," the fans chanted. The match looked to be dying itself.

Not that anyone could have been surprised by Leicester's grit. It was that quality which helped them past superior sides such as Leeds and Arse nal in cup matches this season, and they enjoyed the better of the early stages of the second half.

But Villa burst into life just before the hour when Gregory, seeing Wembley slipping away, gambled with a double substitution. On came Mark Delaney and the 22-year-old Richard Walker, who joined Merson and Julian Joachim in a three-pronged attack.

Not long after Delaney had shot wide, Villa came agonisingly close to taking the lead. Merson's cross from the right was met with a glancing header by Ian Taylor but the ball flashed inches wide of the far post as Walker stretched in vain for a touch.

And when Walker headed on Merson's free-kick, Flowers made a brilliant one-handed save to keep out Southgate's low volley.

fields.headline: Ganguly gives India a lift
fields.standfirst: India beat Pakistan by 48 runs
fields.trailText: Sourav Ganguly made 141 from 144 balls yesterday in Adelaide where India recorded their first win of their triangular one-day tournament.
fields.body:
Sourav Ganguly made 141 from 144 balls yesterday in Adelaide where India recorded their first win of their triangular one-day tournament.

They defeated Pakistan by 48 runs to maintain a slim hope of meeting Australia in the final. India made 267 for six before dismissing Pakistan for 219.

India's Under-19s will play Sri Lanka in the World Cup final after beating Australia by 170 runs in Colombo. Australia managed only 114 in reply to 284 for six.

fields.headline: Harbouring doubts
fields.standfirst: The dockside site in Bristol is an architect's dream, but there are fears that  its development could be a nightmare. Mark Espiner reports
fields.trailText: The dockside site in Bristol is an architect's dream, but there are fears that its development could be a nightmare. Mark Espiner reports.
fields.body:
It is the harbour from which Long John Silver set sail for Treasure Island and where Daniel Defoe met the castaway who inspired him to write Robinson Crusoe. But the dockside in Bristol is now at the centre of a different kind of story. It highlights the conflicts between business and building development - government utopian directives and funding, the city council's need to realise its land assets, and the wishes of the people of Bristol to see their city shaped in a way that they can enjoy as a community.

Cannon's Marsh, a 16-acre patch of land running along the dockside, complete with listed industrial buildings and in the shadow of the city's cathedral, is up for development. It is the kind of site architects dream about - the ultimate brownfield site ready for urban regeneration to inject life into the city, in line with Lord Rogers' Urban Taskforce document, Towards an Urban Renaissance.

The city council, one of the landowners of the site, was anxious to see it developed. It had to raise matching funding for the millions of Millennium Commission money the city received to build its educa tion and museum complex, adjacent to the site. In the wake of Michael Heseltine's initiatives to encourage public and private partnership for inner city regeneration, the council formed a cartel with, among others, the building and housing developer Crest Nicholson to devise a scheme.

They answered the council's brief with a commercial solution, including 360 waterfront homes, prestigious office blocks, a leisure complex, a quality hotel, a Millennium Mile promenade and conversion of listed buildings into studio-style flats.

But the proposed buildings, while following some of the Rogers directives, seem to pay lip service to the spirit of his urban regeneration proposals. The housing is likely to be expensive, and so unlikely to introduce the social mix that Rogers recommends. There is a heavy dependency on cars - for the 173 flats in the scheme, there are 282 parking spaces - and little indication of how public transport might assist. The site has three "zones" of offices, housing and leisure, and the imposing cathedral risks being dwarfed by the new development.

Lord Rogers' report warned: "The concept of zoning is increasingly losing its meaning. With the barriers between home, work and leisure continuing to break down, the future emphasis of development plans should be on promoting flexible designations which enable mixing of uses and the ability to change the mix over time."

But Richard Burton, of ABK, the architect of the scheme, defends the "blockiness" of the scheme, arguing that it would be undesirable to have housing next to nightclubs and that it would be easier to build the scheme in sections. The office complex, he says, could house 2,000 workers and so attract a large business concern, which would benefit Bristol.

The economic grounds for the scheme are certainly imperative to the developers. Speaking in a local television report, Ian Cawley, of Crest Nicholson, warned: "To do a mixed use development you do need to hit markets absolutely right. And if we are not careful, if there is further delay, then unfortunately the market will go and this site will never be developed."

George Ferguson, of Bristol's Ferguson-Mann architects, is a fan of public-private partnership, but sees the conflict that making money from the site has had with Rogers' urban regeneration objectives. Ferguson, who has been commissioned by a rival developer to produce an alternative scheme, puts the fault down to an over-keenness of the council to make things happen at any cost.

Although he is strongly opposed to the scheme, which he calls an "environmental disaster", the eminent architect Sir Hugh Casson feels sympathy for the developers, acknowledging the work they have done in researching how to clean the polluted site. But he judges their scheme as badly timed, with what he calls a change in attitudes to what people want from their built environments and what will make the city feel comfortable and deliver a sense of well-being.

Vital economic injection, or planning disaster? The development in Bristol shows that if Lord Rogers' ideas of urban renaissance are to be brought to life, they will need a sensitive midwife.

webTitle: Caddick at one with the new regime

fields.headline: Caddick at one with the new regime
fields.trailText: When Andrew Caddick described himself yesterday as "part of the furniture", he prompted the notion that he had spent much of his career as some discarded tallboy, with prominent cornices, left outside for Harold Steptoe and Hercules to collect.
fields.body:
When Andrew Caddick described himself yesterday as "part of the furniture", he prompted the notion that he had spent much of his career as some discarded tallboy, with prominent cornices, left outside for Harold Steptoe and Hercules to collect.

The transformation of Caddick from fringe Test player to world-class strike bowler represents, perhaps, the finest achievement to date of the new management team of the captain Nasser Hussain and the coach Duncan Fletcher.

Graeme Hick, one senses, is the next major challenge for the metamorphosis men. If Fletcher, in particular, can get a little more out of England's most gifted batsman, which is all that is needed for him to become a major Test player, his reputation will be assured. Fletcher captained Hick when Zimbabwe were in England for the 1983 World Cup.

Caddick, 31, who remarkably will be playing in only his 11th one-day international when England meet South Africa under lights here today, is scarcely recognisable from the troubled man who toured New Zealand three years ago, which was when he last played in a limited-over series.

For some years Caddick has been England's best fast bowler. But for too long his image has been that of a disconsolate loner, carping from the sidelines. Off the field, shy and awkward of manner, he did not mix easily with his fellows. On it he did not bowl consistently well.

Poor management did not help. Caddick has missed several Test matches, including last winter's tour of Australia, because England did not have a captain or coach clever enough to coax the best from him. That has changed.

"I was disappointed I didn't go to Oz. It was a tour I really wanted to go on. I thought I had put my case to the selectors pretty strongly.

"But these days I feel more relaxed. I don't see the point in getting stressed out, in worrying about whether I'm going to play in the next match or not.

"The great thing about Nasser and Duncan is that the attitude is great. They have kept things very simple. We are not running our heads off for the sake of it. We are not worried about being seen to do the right things.

"We did not train today. We have had some quality time off. It has been a long tour. I feel tired. We have had nine months of non-stop cricket with just three weeks off before this tour.

"The last thing I want to do is run my knackers off in training. We worked under the lights last night and I bowled for 10 or 15 minutes. In the past that would have been more like 40. Duncan's been good to me. He knows how I think."

Such an attitude is difficult to reconcile with recent years, when captains such as Graham Gooch and Alec Stewart employed a rather Calvinistic work ethic to rally the troops.

It did not work and some players found it a chore. Touring has always been about having a little fun and relaxation along the way and this tour management is intelligent enough to realise it. Intelligence, not highfalutin psychobabble but pragmatic common sense, is a feature of the current regime.

Caddick, meanwhile, having established his Test place, is looking forward to doing the same thing with his one-day international career.

"I've always enjoyed one-day cricket and it's great to be back in the frame. I don't think they wanted a strike bowler like me. I think England looked at sides like South Africa, with their long batting, and went for all-rounders. But I've always felt that even in one-day cricket the best batsmen should face the best bowlers.

"I bowl a slower ball now, which is important in one-day cricket. Five years ago you might see one every two overs. Now you can see three or four in one over." Caddick, born-again bowler, was smiling and shaking his head with an enthusiasm that has not always illuminated his dark features.

webTitle: Atherton calls for end to county game

fields.headline: Atherton calls for end to county game
fields.trailText: Michael Atherton has said he believes county cricket "serves no purpose" to anyone involved and would like to see a regional tournament replace the county game.
fields.body:
Michael Atherton believes county cricket "serves no purpose" to anyone involved.

The former England captain would like to see a regional tournament replace the county game but sees no hope of reform while the county clubs retain power in the government of first-class cricket.

"I do not have an argument in defence of county cricket," he said. "Very few people turn up to watch; it does not prepare people for a higher level of cricket, and it does not attract TV deals or sponsorship. It is living on borrowed time."

Atherton, recently returned from South Africa, where England suffered their fourth successive Test series defeat, sympathises with the selectors.

"There are so many players playing county cricket that there is always someone getting 200 and putting their name to the selectors," he said. "But it is very difficult to pick out the right people because county cricket does not really give a good indication of who is going to be successful at a higher level.

"There are around 400 players at 18 clubs - and that is too many. The quality gets diluted, and the intensity you need to prepare people for the Test game is not there.

"If you could reduce the number of players and clubs, that may work, but I do not think it will happen. It is very difficult to see things changing when the counties control what happens at Lord's. They are hardly going to vote themselves out of existence."

The Lancashire opener, speaking on Radio 5 Live, added the problem is that English cricket has failed to move with the times since its last period of true domination in the late 50s.

"If England want to be the best side in the world in the next 10 or 20 years," he said, "the system has to change."

webTitle: Labour sets pace for far-reaching change

fields.headline: Labour sets pace for far-reaching change
fields.standfirst: Government makes radical progress on constitution, but its fate will be decided by bread and butter issues
fields.trailText: If Tony Blair were to fall under the proverbial prime ministerial                                                    bus today, his admirers can rest assured that he will be                                                    remembered as one of Britain's most remarkable leaders. In the                                                    short space of time since he strode into Downing Street, the                                                    youngest prime minister of the twentieth century has forced                                                    irreversible change on the country which easily rivals the great                                                    constitutional reforms of the nineteenth century.
fields.body:
If Tony Blair were to fall under the proverbial prime ministerial bus today, his admirers can rest assured that he will be remembered as one of Britain's most remarkable leaders. In the short space of time since he strode into Downing Street, the youngest prime minister of the twentieth century has forced irreversible change on the country which easily rivals the great constitutional reforms of the nineteenth century.

Hereditary peers have at last been given their marching orders, Scotland has its own parliament and - perhaps most significantly of all - Northern Ireland appears to be heading towards a constitutional settlement.

80 years on

Judged simply on the basis of his constitutional reforms, Mr Blair stands at least as high as some of the great prime ministers of the last century. It took more than 80 years for a government to summon the will to face down the hereditary peers, while the prime minister has used Labour's massive majority to press on with the Northern Ireland peace process started - but then stalled - by John Major.

Constitutional reforms may secure Mr Blair a prime slot in the history books, but his future in Downing Street will be decided on bread and butter issues. For the moment, he is well on course to establishing a record of economic competence, something which has eluded most Labour governments.

Gordon Brown, who revels in his reputation as the "iron chancellor", has achieved this by ruthlessly sticking to the last government's spending plans for the first two years in office and maintaining Labour's pledge not to raise income tax.

Core worries

But while the prime minister and his chancellor have been feted in the city for their austerity, core Labour voters remain severely disappointed. Downing Street is said to be growing alarmed at supporters who complain that they have yet to see the promised improvements in public services.

The key reason for the slow pace of change, ministers admit, is the government's self-imposed Tory spending straitjacket. Conservatives now cheerfully confess that such targets would never have been kept to had they won the election; the Labour government stuck to them with grim determination and is now paying the price.

On health, in particular, the two-year squeeze merely stored up problems for later. So far, few patients recognise any improvement in the NHS, where government achievements to date have been largely structural: abolishing the internal market; introducing primary care groups to plan local care; launching the nurse-staffed helpline NHS Direct. The effect of those reforms has yet to be tested, together with the effectiveness of consumer power in boosting improvements in the service.

Education reforms, likewise predominantly structural, have yet to make a real impact on parents, though the government escaped an expected backlash over introducing tuition fees until the Liberal Democrats pushed the issue in Scotland. Cash is the real ingredient needed to convince voters and teachers, but the government's spending on education nudged below Tory spending as a proportion of GDP in the first two years after the election, and may not average out higher than the Tories over the whole parliament, despite a relatively steep increase now under way.

Crime conundrum

The home secretary, Jack Straw, has maintained his reputation for toughness during Labour's first 1,000 days, but crime has not proved the success story on which Labour hoped to out-Tory the Tories. While the Conservatives have still to get a foothold on attacking the government on law and order, the latest figures show the first increase in recorded crime for six years.

Transport, meanwhile, has proved an unexpected beartrap for Labour, as the Tories have seized on "anti-car" proposals such as congestion taxes being introduced before improvements are made in public transport.

Downing Street weighed in to ensure motorists were not unduly penalised, to the fury of the green lobby.

But, while core voters may feel disappointed at the lack of investment in cherished public services, there is no doubt that the government is the stronger for establishing a reputation for economic competence. This has had the double benefit of allowing the chancellor, behind the scenes, to be quietly redistributive, although Labour's fear of upsetting middle England "switchers" has meant that the government seeks credit for redistribution while shrinking away from boasting of it.

Key achievements of the Blair administration include the minimum wage - now virtually a consensual political issue with even the Tories reluctant to oppose it in the next manifesto - and the working families tax credit, the basis for the Blair-Brown mantra that the benefits system should reward, not penalise, those who work.

Backlash risk

The new deal for the young unemployed and lone parents also boasts strong results, though the government may yet face a backlash, particularly if the Tories exploit the issue, over seeming to coerce mothers away from their children and back to work.

The government also has more radical thinking to do over welfare - few believe it has achieved the promised fundamental reform, and vulnerable groups including the disabled and pensioners are still felt to have gained a rough deal.

In foreign policy, an area which is likely to have little impact on the election, Labour has shown both its radical and cautious sides. The prime minister became one of Nato's most decisive leaders during last year's operation in Kosovo, bolstering the alliance when other leaders took fright at the daily bombings. But he has struggled to live up to his promise to place Britain at the heart of Europe - by sounding enthusiastic over the euro - because of his fear that he would lose a referendum.

Low-key

Labour will mark its 1,000 days in office today with low-key celebrations, in contrast to the fanfare which greeted the government's first 100 days in August 1997. "Getting on with the job" is the uninspiring theme of the day as Labour steers clear of another glitzy relaunch to avoid upsetting heartland supporters so soon after the government's worst NHS crisis.

Labour MPs will welcome the celebrations, expressing delight that their party should be in such a strong position with less than two years to go until the next general election.

They will also be relieved that Labour has not so far become mired in scandals despite Ron Davies's "moment of madness" on Clapham Common and Peter Mandelson's difficulties over his home loan. Behind the back-slapping, however, is a growing feeling that the prime minister must be prepared to act more radically in the next 1,000 days if he is to capture the imagination of voters once again.

MPs reluctantly accepted the need for the chancellor to embrace "prudence" with such fervour for the first two years in office, but they are now saying he must be prepared to relax the purse strings. Whether their calls are falling on deaf ears in Downing Street will probably only be answered when Labour publishes its manifesto for the next election.

Public services

One school of thought hopes that, having proved himself as a radical over constitutional reform, the prime minister will consolidate his place in history by presiding over a massive increase in support for the public services.

Gloomy Labour MPs fear that Mr Blair is instinctively a conservative - his constitutional reforms were largely inherited - and that he will once again opt for the cautious route.

Every time that the prime minister reminds his MPs that Labour has never won a full second term in office, they fear that he will opt once again for a manifesto which is aimed primarily at middle England.

Downing Street weighed in to ensure motorists were not unduly penalised, to the fury of the green lobby. But, while core voters may feel disappointed at the lack of investment in cherished public services, there is no doubt that the government is the stronger for establishing a reputation for economic competence. This has had the double benefit of allowing the chancellor, behind the scenes, to be quietly redistributive, although Labour's fear of upsetting middle England "switchers" has meant that the government seeks credit for redistribution while shrinking away from boasting of it. Key achievements of the Blair administration include the minimum wage - now virtually a consensual political issue with even the Tories reluctant to oppose it in the next manifesto - and the working families tax credit, the basis for the Blair-Brown mantra that the benefits system should reward, not penalise, those who work. Backlash risk The new deal for the young unemployed and lone parents also boasts strong results, though the government may yet face a backlash, particularly if the Tories exploit the issue, over seeming to coerce mothers away from their children and back to work. The government also has more radical thinking to do over welfare - few believe it has achieved the promised fundamental reform, and vulnerable groups including the disabled and pensioners are still felt to have gained a rough deal. In foreign policy, an area which is likely to have little impact on the election, Labour has shown both its radical and cautious sides. The prime minister became one of Nato's most decisive leaders during last year's operation in Kosovo, bolstering the alliance when other leaders took fright at the daily bombings. But he has struggled to live up to his promise to place Britain at the heart of Europe - by sounding enthusiastic over the euro - because of his fear that he would lose a referendum. Low-key Labour will mark its 1,000 days in office today with low-key celebrations, in contrast to the fanfare which greeted the government's first 100 days in August 1997. "Getting on with the job" is the uninspiring theme of the day as Labour steers clear of another glitzy relaunch to avoid upsetting heartland supporters so soon after the government's worst NHS crisis. Labour MPs will welcome the celebrations, expressing delight that their party should be in such a strong position with less than two years to go until the next general election. They will also be relieved that Labour has not so far become mired in scandals despite Ron Davies's "moment of madness" on Clapham Common and Peter Mandelson's difficulties over his home loan. Behind the back-slapping, however, is a growing feeling that the prime minister must be prepared to act more radically in the next 1,000 days if he is to capture the imagination of voters once again. MPs reluctantly accepted the need for the chancellor to embrace "prudence" with such fervour for the first two years in office, but they are now saying he must be prepared to relax the purse strings. Whether their calls are falling on deaf ears in Downing Street will probably only be answered when Labour publishes its manifesto for the next election. Public services One school of thought hopes that, having proved himself as a radical over constitutional reform, the prime minister will consolidate his place in history by presiding over a massive increase in support for the public services. Gloomy Labour MPs fear that Mr Blair is instinctively a conservative - his constitutional reforms were largely inherited - and that he will once again opt for the cautious route. Every time that the prime minister reminds his MPs that Labour has never won a full second term in office, they fear that he will opt once again for a manifesto which is aimed primarily at middle England.

fields.headline: Student dismay at fees 'sell-out'
fields.trailText: January 26 2000: The Scottish executive was yesterday accused of selling out students and its principles, as opposition leaders and students denounced the Labour-Liberal Democrat deal on university tuition fees.
fields.body:
The Scottish executive was yesterday accused of selling out students and its principles, as opposition leaders and students denounced the Labour-Liberal Democrat deal on university tuition fees.

The executive was attacked on all flanks for weakening measures to alleviate student hardship which were drawn up by the independent Cubie inquiry into student finance.

The deal, worked out over the Christmas period and agreed by the Scottish cabinet and Labour and Lib Dem backbenchers yesterday, sheds around £20m from the cost of Cubie's proposals.

But, while the Lib Dems claimed to have abolished tuition fees and Labour said it had broken the impasse which threatened to bring down the coalition, both were accused of caving in to Westminster.

Under the new deal, up-front tuition fees will be abolished from September for all Scottish and EU - but not English or Welsh - students studying in Scotland . Fees will be replaced by graduate contributions.

Graduates will pay £2,000 into the scheme once they are earning £10,000 a year. Under Cubie, graduates would have had to pay higher contributions, but not until they were earning £25,000.

The deal will not be offered to Scottish students elsewhere in the UK, ministers said, because of problems with EU legislation. Ministers say they may have been forced to extend the benefit to all EU students studying in Britain at an annual cost of up to £100m. That would be unacceptable to Tony Blair and the education secretary David Blunkett.

A spokesman for the executive yesterday denied there had been any interference from Westminster, but there was anger in Scotland from opposition parties over the terms of the compromise.

'At London's instigation the executive has watered down the Cubie report,'' said shadow lifelong learning minister John Swinney. 'This has nothing to do with EU law.''

Richard Baker, president of NUS Scotland , said: 'We supported a contribution from wealthier graduates, not a payback scheme for every graduate. This deal serves the politicians but not the students.''

From next year, Scottish students whose parents earn less than £23,000 will be eligible for grants of up to £2,000 and the poorest students will also be offered access to £500 more in loans. The Scottish secretary, John Reid, said yesterday that funding for the deal must come from existing Holyrood funds.

As cross-party unrest grew at Westminster over the better deal for Scots, Mr Blunkett announced a £68m package for England and Wales targeting mature students, disadvantaged young people and parents on low incomes with children in higher education.

Mr Blunkett intends to set aside £17m for non-repayable bursaries for mature students in 2000-01.

webTitle: Blunkett to beat drum for party's achievements

fields.headline: Blunkett to beat drum for party's achievements
fields.trailText: Tony Blair's government marked its first 1,000 days in office by focusing on its achievements since May 1 1997 while William Hague revived the Saatchi advertising agency's classic 1979 election poster with the long queue, this time directed not against unemployment but NHS queues.
fields.body:
Tony Blair's government will today mark its first 1,000 days in office by contrasting its achievements since May 1 1997 with the turbulent 1,000 days ushered in by Margaret Thatcher's election in May 1979.

Since the prime minister is avoiding any personal hint of triumphalism by having a normal working day, the task of blowing the government's trumpet will fall to the education secretary, David Blunkett, a trusted Blair lieutenant.

Sweeping aside the fainthearts, he will characterise the Blair administration as "more confident, more radical, delivering more than we said we would".

Mr Blunkett will parade the Blairites' pro-business, pro-European credentials by making his speech to the German/British chamber of industry and commerce at Claridge's Hotel in Mayfair.

That may niggle patient Labour loyalists and in the present climate of voter disappointment over key public services, Mr Blunkett will stress that there is still "a lot more to do".

William Hague will today liken the government to a vacuous Millennium Dome, saying: "It has all turned out to be talk." Last night shadow ministers attacked the government over stealth taxes, NHS waiting lists and Labour's "audit of failures, lies, sleaze and hypocrisy".

Yesterday Mr Hague revived the Saatchi advertising agency's classic 1979 election poster, the long queue and the slogan Labour Isn't Working. This time the jibe was directed not against unemployment but NHS queues.

Mr Blunkett will say that after 1,000 days in office, "the Conservatives were already dividing the country while we are working to bring the country together. I believe that after 1,000 days we can see this: that Tony Blair's New Labour government is changing more for the better than Margaret Thatcher did".

Mr Blunkett will cite social inclusiveness, constitutional reforms, welfare to work and competence in managing the economy - pointing to low inflation, falling unemployment and rising inward investment.

He will contrast all that to doubled inflation and unemployment (to 2.4 million) between May 3 1979 and January 28th 1982. Crime was up by a quarter, the country had been riven by strikes - including IRA hunger strikes - and was poised to face an Argentine invasion of the Falklands triggered by ill-considered defence cuts. There was even a U-turn in the face of militant miners.

The likely Tory retort will be that Mrs Thatcher inherited a country in deep economic and social crisis culminating in the winter of discontent - and that she set about creating the conditions for restored growth that Labour has inherited. But the narrow range of Mr Hague's complaints underline how Laboiur remains a hard a target to hit.

"For every day since (May 1 1997) an extra 264 people have joined the waiting list to see a hospital consultant; for every day an extra 39 people have become victims of violent crime, for every day £22 million has been added to taxes," Mr Hague will say.

There has also been lots more red tape and Whitehall special advisers, the Tory leader will tell an audience at the Centre for Policy Studies, the think tank behind the Thatcher Revolution, hatched when he was still in school. New Labour is like the Greenwich Dome because it has "an obsession with looking modern without actually doing anything modern in practice", he will say.

Labour published a modest "First 1000 Days in Context" paper.

The Lib Dems treasury spokesman, Matthew Taylor, said: "By tying themselves from day one to Conservative spending plans, the Government's 'early' pledges have not been worth the credit card they were written on. The pledges were modest in ambition and wrong in aspiration."

webTitle: No poison supply at Auschwitz, says Irving

fields.headline: No poison supply at Auschwitz, says Irving
fields.standfirst: Special report: the David Irving libel trial
fields.trailText: Eyewitness evidence of the existence of homicidal gas chambers at Auschwitz was "totally demolished" because there were no holes in the roof through which to insert poison, historian David Irving told the high court today.
fields.body:
Eyewitness evidence of the existence of homicidal gas chambers at Auschwitz was "totally demolished" because there were no holes in the roof through which to insert poison, historian David Irving told the high court today.

Mr Irving, the 62-year-old author of Hitler's War, who is seeking libel damages for being called a "Holocaust denier", said that his theory "blows holes in the whole gas chambers story".

He said that a number of "revisionist" researchers had entered the ruins of Crematorium Two at Auschwitz, in which Holocaust historians say 500,000 died, and photographed the collapsed underside of the roof - but found no holes.

"I do not accept that the Nazis in the last frantic days of the camp, when they were in a blue funk, would have gone around with buckets of cement filling the holes that they were going to dynamite."

Mr Irving, who is representing himself, made the comments during his cross-examination of Professor Robert van Pelt, who has said that there was a "massive amount of evidence" of the camp's use for mass extermination. Prof van Pelt has said that the gas chambers were first dismantled and then dynamited when the gassings stopped in November 1944 as the Russians advanced.

Giving evidence for American academic Deborah Lipstadt and Penguin books, who are fighting Mr Irving's action, he says that the evidence for gassing included eyewitness accounts, photos and drawings from memory of a sonderkommando - a Jewish inmate selected to work in the crematoria.

He referred Mr Justice Gray to a photo taken by an SS man in February 1943 which showed openings above ground on the newly completed roof of Crematorium Two with a kind of cover on top of them. The defence case is that these projections were from four introduction columns through which Zyklon B pellets travelled.

Mr Irving, who says that the gas chambers were only used to de-louse corpses and objects, claimed that the picture was taken in December 1942 during building works and that the objects on the roof were drums containing sealant.

Prof van Pelt also relied on an aerial photo taken by the Americans in the summer of 1944 which showed "four dots" on the roof of Crematorium Two. He said that this showed very clearly that there were "introduction devices" on top of the building.

Mr Irving questioned the authenticity of the photo and said that whatever the dots were, they were too big for the purpose put forward by the defence.

Prof van Pelt also cited the drawings, undertaken in 1945-46, of surviving sonderkommando David Olere, which showed openings for the introduction of the pellets into the gas chamber at Crematorium Three in Auschwitz. Olere, he said, was a "very experienced draughtsman and painter" who had a good visual memory and was a credible witness.

Mr Irving is suing over Prof Lipstadt's 1994 book, Denying The Holocaust: The Growing Assault On Truth And Memory. Accused by the defendants of being "a liar and a falsifier of history", he depends on a 1988 report by a man called Fred Leuchter, who had taken samples from ruins at Auschwitz and concluded that there were never homicidal gas chambers there.

Mr Irving says Prof Lipstadt's book has generated "waves of hatred" against him.

Mr Irving said that the defence's "so-called" eyewitnesses were a relatively small number for the large proposition at stake. Apart from that, he added, there was not "a single document of any credible worth" which explicitly set out the defence case in all the "hundreds of thousands" of papers in the Auschwitz museum and the Moscow archives.

He submitted that his position on the Holocaust was justifiable and not perverse.

He went on to question Prof van Pelt's reliance on the evidence of sonderkommando Henryk Tauber which included descriptions of gassings in Auschwitz's crematoria.

He said that some of Tauber's accounts "test a reasonable historian's credulity" and "should be open to more than normal scrutiny". He questioned the validity of Tauber's evidence as he had wrongly asserted that four million had died at Auschwitz.

Prof van Pelt said that he considered that Tauber was "an absolutely amazingly good witness... I find his power of observation very precise and don't have any general reason to doubt his credibility as a witness".

Mr Irving suggested that at the time of his evidence Tauber would have been furnished with drawings and documents by the interrogating Polish authorities.

webTitle: Day of reckoning nears as Glenda is accused of 'collaboration'

fields.headline: Day of reckoning nears as Glenda is accused of 'collaboration'
fields.standfirst: The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: The battle to become Labour's official candidate for London mayor entered its final phase today as ballot papers were sent out to party members.
fields.body:
The battle to become Labour's official candidate for London mayor entered its final phase today as ballot papers were sent out to party members.

Just over 48,000 voting slips are being posted to eligible rank and file members of the London Labour Party for the election which will decide between the three short-listed candidates Frank Dobson, Ken Livingstone and Glenda Jackson.

Ballot papers will also go out to London MPs, MEPs and candidates for the Greater London Authority as well as to affiliated trade unions and socialist societies which make up the electoral college which will choose the party's candidate in the May 4 mayoral election.

If neither of the two frontrunners, Mr Livingstone and Mr Dobson, achieves an overall majority when votes are returned by the February 16 closing date, the second preference votes of Ms Jackson's supporters are expected to decide the election in favour of Mr Livingstone.

Prime Minister Tony Blair and his deputy John Prescott were expected to launch a new attack on Mr Livingstone today after a Guardian survey earlier this week showed their preferred candidate, Mr Dobson, trailing in the polls behind the left-wing Brent East MP.

The survey found that Mr Livingstone could win more than 65% of the party members' votes and could be within reach of an outright victory.

But Mr Dobson insisted he is "increasingly confident" of victory and, in his latest mailshot to Labour members, the former health secretary renewed his attack on his left-wing rival, saying: "Those across the party who know him best don't trust him. Be in no doubt that Ken, who has used this campaign to attack our government, would do so even more vigorously as mayor."

The Prime Minister's official spokesman said voting was a matter for Labour party members but "if they have any sense" they would take note of the opinions of senior figures like Mr Blair and the Chancellor Gordon Brown - who have made plain their support for Mr Dobson - rather than the views of newspapers.

Meanwhile, Glenda Jackson was accused of "collaboration" with Ken Livingstone by the one Labour MP in the capital who had planned to support her in the ballot.

Ealing North MP Stephen Pound announced today he would be switching his allegiance to Frank Dobson after consulting with members of his constituency party.

The party's general secretary, Margaret McDonagh, told the ruling National Executive Committee this week that the party would review the system of selecting a candidate for future mayoral elections and consider a move to a one-member, one-vote ballot.

fields.standfirst: Stephen Moss assesses the critical verdict on Zadie Smith's epic, serio-comic debut novel
fields.trailText: Stephen Moss assesses the critical verdict on Zadie Smith's epic, serio-comic debut novel
fields.body:
Zadie Smith appears to be keeping her feet on the ground - and in earthy Willesden too - but heaven knows how. Her debut novel, White Teeth (Hamish Hamilton, £12.99) has received an astonishing chorus of praise. Smith, a 24-year-old just out of Cambridge, had been given a £250,000 advance and hailed as "the new Salman Rushdie" by her publisher. "For once", said the usually testy Hugo Barnacle in the Sunday Times, "here is a Big New Literary Find that hasn't been oversold."

That was echoed everywhere. "Hamish Hamilton's publicists have made much of the fact that Smith is herself part of this entrepreneurial, multicultural Britain - she is young, she is half-Jamaican and she wrote the novel in quiet moments while revising for finals at Cambridge," wrote Melissa Denes in the Daily Telegraph. "But it would not matter if she were a he, white and the wrong side of 40: Smith can write. Her novel has energy, pace, humour and fully formed characters; it is blissfully free of the introversion and self-conscious detail that mar many first novels. Smith has stories to tell and, in the tradition of Peter Carey and Salman Rushdie, she just gets on with them; the dialogue is pitch-perfect, the comedy neat and underplayed."

Denes had a half-hearted quibble: "There is a false climax that attempts to unite far too many characters and storylines: here Smith is only spelling out themes - about family and belonging and history - already implicit in the narrative. And there is something too pat (and too punning) in the conclusion that we should not perpetuate 'the myth, the wicked lie, that the past is always tense and the future, perfect'." But, she concluded, "these are small weaknesses in what is a bounding, vibrant, richly imagined and thoroughly engaging whole."

Those much-mentioned Hamish Hamilton publicists will have no shortage of encomia for the paperback. "The 'mongrel' nation that is Britain is still struggling to find a way to stare into the mirror and accept the ebb and flow of history that has produced this fortuitously diverse condition and its concomitant pain," wrote Caryl Phillips weightily in the Observer. "Zadie Smith's first novel is an audaciously assured contribution to this process of staring into the mirror. Her narrator is deeply self-conscious, so much so that one can almost hear the crisp echo of Salman Rushdie's footsteps. However, her wit, her breadth of vision and her ambition are of her own making. The plot is rich, at times dizzyingly so, but White Teeth squares up to the two questions which gnaw at the very roots of our modern condition: Who are we? Why are we here?"

It wasn't easy for critics to explain what this dizzying book was actually about. Detailing plotlines is the bane of fiction reviewing; boiled down to 300 words, plots sound confusing or ludicrous or, more often, both. Phillips had a lengthy go, but it defeated him. "This multi-layered, deeply-plotted novel resists easy categorisation, which is precisely the author's point." (And a useful get-out clause for reviewers.)

So, epic serio-comic saga following the fortunes of two families from Bangladesh and Jamaica who have fetched up in the melting pot that is Willesden will have to do plot-wise. Too much detail just gets in the way. Maya Jaggi's more lateral approach in the Guardian certainly made the book sound engaging: "Its characters embrace Jehovah's Witnesses, halal butchers, eugenicists, animal-rights activists and a group of Muslim militants who labour under the unfortunate acronym KEVIN." I'd buy that.

Jaggi picked up on the symbolism of the final image: "the escape of a small brown laboratory mouse, which may be genetically programmed to turn albino-white, but which gladly seizes its freedom and runs with it". That freedom - along with greater tolerance and a sense of a society increasingly at ease with itself - was mentioned elsewhere: "Her attitude to the complications and conflicts, loves and hates that inevitably result from living in a cultural melting pot is not only post-imperial but post-racial," wrote Anne Chisholm in the Sunday Telegraph. "One of the endearing qualities of her sharp-eyed but warm-hearted book is that it makes racism appear not only ugly and stupid but ludicrously out of date, like the politician referred to as 'E. Knock someone or other'."

A "post-racial society" is a controversial notion and could have been mined more: there are plenty of people who would disagree with that description of Britain and it would be interesting to hear their view of Smith's "warm-hearted" novel. Smith herself, in an interview in the Observer, hinted that she was keen not to be seen as a writer of baggy, generous, all-life-is-here novels. "When I was little, we'd go on holiday to Devon, and there, if you're black and you go into a sweetshop, for instance, everyone turns and looks at you. So my instinct as a child was always to over-compensate by trying to behave three times as well as every other child in the shop, so they knew I wasn't going to take anything or hurt anyone. I think that instinct has spilled over into my writing in some ways, which is not something I like very much or want to continue."

There was one less than ecstatic review, in the literary magazine Butterfly. "This kind of precocity in so young a writer has one half of the audience standing to applaud and the other half wishing, as with child performers of the past (Shirley Temple, Bonnie Langford et al), she would just stay still and shut up. White Teeth is the literary equivalent of a hyperactive, ginger-haired tap-dancing 10-year-old." The review, according to Sam Wallace in the Daily Telegraph, was written by Smith herself.

webTitle: Looking for glamour at the Whitbread ceremony

fields.headline: Looking for glamour at the Whitbread ceremony
fields.trailText: Pity poor David Cairns, author of the Whitbread Biography Award winner with the second volume of his study of Berlioz. Probably assuming that a nineteenth-century composer wouldn't triumph over a schoolboy wizard or a man-eating monster, he had consoled himself with the thought of meeting the ever more glamorous JK Rowling at the Awards ceremony. Cairns, like other eager Potter fans, was out of luck, as the children's author some expected to be the first ever to win the overall prize was tucked up in bed with the Sydney flu.
fields.body:
Pity poor David Cairns, author of the Whitbread Biography Award winner with the second volume of his study of Berlioz. Probably assuming that a nineteenth-century composer wouldn't triumph over a schoolboy wizard or a man-eating monster, he had consoled himself with the thought of meeting the ever more glamorous JK Rowling at the Awards ceremony. Cairns, like other eager Potter fans, was out of luck, as the children's author some expected to be the first ever to win the overall prize was tucked up in bed with the Sydney flu.

But the evening's glamour quotient was amply provided, of course, by model Jerry Hall - which is why many thought she had been invited in the first place. Much is being made of the fact that Hall backed Heaney rather than Rowling: "You never can tell," said Mark Lawson on the BBC's live coverage. Never can tell what? That being tall and blonde doesn't rule out being able to read poetry? That life with Mick Jagger doesn't render you incapable of reading about anything but kiddies' books?

The TV pundits themselves were unusually civilised and boringly prone to agreement. Only once did Ian Hislop lob a barbed comment at David Baddiel, when commenting on Tim Lott's novel, White City Blue - remarking that he, Ian, didn't watch much football or drink beer in pubs with his friends, so perhaps it wasn't such an everyman tome after all.

The controversy, such as it was, had already taken place, as the judging panel split between Potter and Heaney, with an apparently furious battle between Anthony Holden and Robert Harris. Hislop, Baddiel and Rosie Boycott all got it wrong however, plumping for a Rowling win, with Tim Lott, David Cairns and Rose Tremain never garnering much support.

But for Faber, it was another jubilant night, as Seamus Heaney and his entourage slipped away for a quiet celebration drink at the Savoy. And an even better morning, with orders for 20,000 copies of Beowulf arriving first thing on Wednesday morning. All of which was comfort enough for Faber's marketing director, Joanna Mackle, who suffered the indignity of being made to walk in and out of the Whitbread brewery five times to be filmed in her elegant Philip Treacy hat - only to be nearly crushed by the stampede of photographers when Jerry Hall arrived a few minutes later.

fields.headline: Land of plenty
fields.standfirst:
Derek Brown examines the two sides of the argument in the debate on asylum seekers
Plus: Section 28 storm rages on
fields.trailText: The disclosure that refugees are seeking asylum in Britain at a rate of more than 6,000 a month has set off a number of discordant alarm bells.
fields.body:
The disclosure that refugees are seeking asylum in Britain at a rate of more than 6,000 a month has set off a number of discordant alarm bells.

Liberal opinion is outraged that more than 100,000 human beings are now in limbo, waiting for a cumbersome government machine to tell them whether they can stay.

Less worthily, there are cries of woe from those who believe our crowded little island is being swamped by indigent refugees, bankrupted by benefit bludgers, and culturally undermined by foreigners.

The latter arguments are specious to say the least. Britain has thrived on migration for at least 400 years. Countless millions have sought better lives in the wider world, and rather fewer millions have sought and received a welcome on our shores. Huguenots, Flemings and Jews from a dozen countries have added immeasurably to our communal prosperity.

More recently, a tide of immigration from the West Indies, the Indian subcontinent and Africa has made another huge contribution to all our lives. It is a perpetually shifting pattern: London had a black population of up to 60,000 in the 1700s, and a similarly huge proportion of Irish in the following century.

The idea that countries belong exclusively to an indigenous population is out of date by half a millennium, but remains as insidiously powerful as ever. That argument is as spurious as all the other folk myths about "foreign" infiltration. The lesson of countless generations, that immigration boosts the economy, has never been more relevant.

Our population is static and ageing. We are told, over and over again, that the ratio of dependents to earners is remorselessly rising. We must, we hear, increase our productivity to protect our futures. Our labour force, we are constantly reminded, must be more flexible (ie cheap).

The refugees, whether they are genuinely fleeing in fear or simply looking for a better life, are a godsend to the advocates of market forces in a global economy, for they are in themselves a global market force. Those who argue that they should be turned away are by definition denying the new economic orthodoxy. Or else they are crude old-fangled racists.

Related documentary
Refugees in Britain: special report

Section 28 storm rages on

Both big parties are in a tizz over section 28, the device in the 1988 local government act which is supposed to discourage the advocacy of homosexuality in schools. Labour MPs who want to repeal this section are upset that the government is thinking of allowing a free or "conscience" vote. Tories are likely to be whipped into line to defend the clause, which William Hague links to his party's belief in marriage and the family.

This is all very, well, queer. Surely, even in the House of Commons, there is no longer anyone who believes that homosexuality can be caught in the classroom, like flu or the mumps. Yet that is apparently what Hague and others are seriously arguing, in their Victorian disapproval of open discussion of gay issues.

One of the main blots on our school system is its refusal to contemplate sex education. One result is the boom in under-age pregnancies. Another is the spectacle of MPs sounding off about something they cannot possibly legislate for, or against.

Section 28 explained
Blair offers free vote on gay clause
New Labour in power: special report

webTitle: Vandevelde offers fresh upheaval for M&S board

fields.headline: Vandevelde offers fresh upheaval for M&S board
fields.trailText: Luc Vandevelde, the incoming chairman of ailing retail group Marks & Spencer, is threatening another overhaul of the company's boardroom in order to secure the loyalty of top directors.
fields.body:
Luc Vandevelde, the incoming chairman of ailing retail group Marks & Spencer, is threatening another overhaul of the company's boardroom in order to secure the loyalty of top directors.

Mr Vandevelde, who stands to make £19m on salaries and options over the next five years if the M&S share price doubles, said he expects two of the most senior non-executive directors to quit this year.

He said he will also consider changing some of the executive directors, even though chief executive Peter Salsbury only recently presided over a purge of the M&S boardroom and the company has seen seven of its executive directors leave in the last year.

"He appears to think he will have quite a lot of influence over the changes and who comes in," said one insider. "He seems determined to create a board in his image."

The non-executive directors likely to leave the group are Sir Martin Jacomb, who is now 70, and Sir Ralph Robbins who is in his late sixties although not yet at the unofficial M & S retirement age.

"This year a couple of directors will be retiring so we can strengthen the board," Mr Vandevelde said. Denying that he planned a boardroom "shake up", he nonetheless admitted that he welcomed the chance to introduce new blood.

His plans for the boardroom will heighten current speculation that Mr Salsbury will have to play a very lowly second to the new chairman and may well be earmarked as the "fall guy" if a turnaround of the business takes longer than expected.

Some major shareholders have already put Mr Salsbury on notice that they will try to have him removed if the spring fashion collection, unveiled this week, does not feed through into a stronger sales performance.

This is the first clothes range which has the explicit imprimatur of Mr Salsbury and his reputation will be riding on the outcome.

Mr Vandevelde said although M&S had a strong board at the moment, it was always possible to improve. "I don't know a board that doesn't need to refresh itself and M&S cannot be an exception to that. If necessary there will be changes," he stated.

Shares in M&S slipped back further yesterday following Mr Vandevelde's disclosure that he could promise no quick fixes at M&S and that investors might have to wait another year for major improvements in the trading performance. A spokeswoman for the company denied, however, that shareholders had been angered by the remuneration package secured by Mr Vandevelde.

The deal is believed to include a "golden hello" of £2.2m worth of M&S shares, a basic salary of £650,000 which can double with a full bonus and share options with a current market value of £10.4m.

The M&S spokeswoman insisted that there had been no adverse comment from any of the 400,000 shareholders in the company, nor from its customers or staff.

webTitle: Watchdog moves to curb racist websites

fields.headline: Watchdog moves to curb racist websites
fields.standfirst:
Internet Watch Foundation
Race issues in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: Internet sites which publish criminally racist material are to be targeted for the first time in Britain by the internet watch foundation under plans backed yesterday by the government's e-commerce minister, Patricia Hewitt, and Whitehall's e-envoy, Alex Allan.
fields.body:
Internet sites which publish criminally racist material are to be targeted for the first time in Britain by the internet watch foundation under plans backed yesterday by the government's e-commerce minister, Patricia Hewitt, and Whitehall's e-envoy, Alex Allan.

The move marks a major extension of the activities of the industry-financed foundation, which up to now has concentrated on advising the main internet servers, such as BT, Aol, Demon Internet and LineOne, to block access to illegal child pornography sites. It is also involved in developing systems of labelling and rating to enable parents to screen the sites their children visit.

The foundation's assistant chief executive, Ruth Dixon, said yesterday that it is to extend its self-regulation approach to racism on the internet. "We are concerned about sites with criminally racist content as opposed to those that people might simply find offensive and which would not be subject to prosecution. We are asking people to report material they believe is illegal to us.

"We will make an assessment and then liaise with the industry and law enforcement agencies. We would tell the internet service providers that it is possible to access potentially illegal content through their servers. Our experience with child pornography has been that they remove it."

The foundation's chairman, Roger Darlington, said there were about 20 British-based internet sites which propagate fascist white supremacist views, including hard-core Nazi material. They included sites maintained by organisations such as Blood and Honour and Combat 18. There were more than 500 websites based in the US which propagated white power, race hate, anti-semitism, and holocaust denial. The home secretary, Jack Straw, has already declared his intention that the internet cannot exist in an anarchistic free speech environment. The home office minister Lord Bassam said yesterday that although the government supported freedom of expression it was more important to protect the public.

Mr Darlington said he was to meet Lord Bassam to clarify the exact extent of the law on the net, but he believed that the 1986 public order act, which makes it an offence to publish material designed or likely to stir up racial hatred, would outlaw offensive sites.

The foundation includes nearly all the internet companies which provide "dial-up access" for British web subscribers. It has been running a successful hotline for the public to report potentially illegal child pornography sites for three years. Figures published yesterday show that last year it handled 5,000 complaints on its hotline and advised internet companies to take action over 11,500 child porn items.

"Racist content is a much more difficult area than child pornography," said Mr Darlington. "The definition of what is criminally racist material is much more complex. Unlike child pornography, mere possession of such material is not illegal and it has to be proved that there is an intention to publish the material to others. It is not always easy to prove individual responsibility for racist material."

Ms Hewitt said yesterday: "We need to ensure that people can use the internet without fear of finding offensive and illegal material. The IWF plays a vital role in combating criminal material on the net, and developing systems so that people can filter the material."

The home secretary, Jack Straw, has already declared his intention that the internet cannot exist in an anarchistic free speech environment. The home office minister Lord Bassam said yesterday that although the government supported freedom of expression it was more important to protect the public. Mr Darlington said he was to meet Lord Bassam to clarify the exact extent of the law on the net, but he believed that the 1986 public order act, which makes it an offence to publish material designed or likely to stir up racial hatred, would outlaw offensive sites. The foundation includes nearly all the internet companies which provide "dial-up access" for British web subscribers. It has been running a successful hotline for the public to report potentially illegal child pornography sites for three years. Figures published yesterday show that last year it handled 5,000 complaints on its hotline and advised internet companies to take action over 11,500 child porn items. "Racist content is a much more difficult area than child pornography," said Mr Darlington. "The definition of what is criminally racist material is much more complex. Unlike child pornography, mere possession of such material is not illegal and it has to be proved that there is an intention to publish the material to others. It is not always easy to prove individual responsibility for racist material." Ms Hewitt said yesterday: "We need to ensure that people can use the internet without fear of finding offensive and illegal material. The IWF plays a vital role in combating criminal material on the net, and developing systems so that people can filter the material."

fields.headline: Hanged men 'victims of racists'
fields.standfirst: Race issues in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: A black man, who was found hanged six months before his nephew was discovered dead in similar circumstances, was the target of the far-right group Combat 18, his family's lawyer said yesterday.
fields.body:
A black man, who was found hanged six months before his nephew was discovered dead in similar circumstances, was the target of the far-right group Combat 18, his family's lawyer said yesterday.

Harold McGowan, 32, a doorman from Telford, Shropshire, had been warned he was on the organisation's "death list" after he stopped a barred person from entering a pub, said solicitor Errol Robinson.

He was found dead in a friend's home with a flex around his neck on July 2 last year, after what his family describe as a two year campaign of racial harassment.

His nephew, Jason McGowan, 20, a newspaper production manager, was found dead on January 1, hanging from railings outside a leisure centre in Telford. A few hours before he had been celebrating the millennium.

The men's family believe they were the victims of racist killings. Mr Robinson said yesterday: "Whether some third party was involved cannot be discounted."

West Mercia police have prepared a report for the inquest into Harold McGowan's death, due to be held next month. But police said yesterday: "Our exhaustive inquiries have not revealed any evidence to suggest the direct involvement of a third party." Although the inquiry into Jason McGowan's death has not been completed, there is also no evidence so far suggesting he was killed either, police said.

The family will be represented at the inquest by Michael Mansfield, QC.
