webTitle: Great Grannies, Greek gripes and Gregory Grant

fields.headline: Great Grannies, Greek gripes and Gregory Grant
fields.trailText: IN THE BAGGIO
fields.body:
IN THE BAGGIO

With Michael Owen in no way seriously injured, and Robbie Fowler basically having a sit down (admittedly for the last five months), Liverpool have no need to sign a new striker. Particularly not a 32-year-old Buddhist with a Craig Johnston tribute haircut. Which is just as well really, because reports this morning suggesting that Roberto Baggio is on his way to Anfield appear to be wider of the mark than a Vladimir Smicer 'piledriver'.

It all started this morning when an Inter official was quoted in the Mirror as saying, "We are aware of interest in Roberto Baggio from a representative of Liverpool." But when asked for their view on events, Liverpool could only manage a dismissive "we never comment on media speculation". In fact, latest reports suggest that the representative was Ron Dixon, trying to hire some new cleaning staff for Great Grannies.

As for Baggio himself, he is happy in Milan. Despite being bottom of the pecking order at Inter - behind Ronaldo, Christian Vieri, Iain Dowie, and Frank Spencer - the Divine Ponytail notched the winner against Verona on Sunday, his first goal in eight months. "I believe this is another positive period for me at Inter," he said afterwards. "I hope this is the case because without creativity there is no fun in football. Fans look for the exciting moves, that is the salt of football." And we are your chips, Roberto.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TURKEY SHOOT

When someone says "Turkey", what do you think of? A yummy Yuletide treat? Speed 2? Or maybe a Mediterranean country that spans the divide between Europe and Asia, contains the best of both cultures, and an enlightened attitude to everything Greek? Sensible responses all, but not the one that Muzzy Izzet would pick. For Leicester's bequiffed midfielder Turkey means three things: bombs, guns, and 100 press-ups before dawn.

You see Muzzy, thanks to his dad, is entitled to play international football for Turkey. But while any spell in the famous white and red shirt came with military service attached (not to mention his own laminated "Welcome to Hell" sign), Muzzy wasn't interested. The other day however, the Turkish FA got in touch, asked Muzzy to play in Euro 2000, and told him he wouldn't have to shoot anybody if he did. At which point his little ears pricked up.

"Originally when Turkey sounded me out in the past I would have had to do national service," said Muzzy today. "But that is no longer the case. Although part of me wants to find out how far I could go with England, playing in Euro 2000 sounds like it would be a great experience." So, to recap, Muzzy has the chance to play in Euro 2000 for a well-organised outfit, brimming with national pride and no little skill, or have a run-out as a substitute under Kelvin Koogan. As Muzzy says himself, "It will not be an easy decision."

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"It's always very difficult to come on as a sub. I hate it. I know I have come on as sub quite a lot lately but I really do hate it." - Teddy Sheringham elicits sympathy from fans all over the country.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

LISTS-U-LIKE

Ralf Loose loves Zinedine Zidane. Gregory Grant fancies Michelle Akers. And Soutskhone Oudompet thinks Michael Owen is the business. And do you care? You do not. But you should, because these people were allowed to influence the result of Fifa Player of the Year.

Mind you, that's not much of a scandal, given that 140 international coaches were asked to vote for the award and Ralf of Liechtenstein, Gregory of the British Virgin Islands and Soutskhone of the Laos Under-20s side were three of them. We now know how they all voted because Fifa has published an exhaustive list on www.fifa.com. It makes fascinating reading if you're into lists and football (although if you are, you should be getting on with writing the follow up to About A Boy instead of wasting your time on the Fifa website).

For example, the list informs us that Brazil coach Wanderley Luxemburgo thinks Andy Cole is better at football than Frank De Boer (presumably because De Boer has yet to master the subtle art of controlling the ball with his shin), and that the boss of Burkina Faso thinks Paul Scholes has no peer. Luckily, there's always one nutter to liven these things up. God knows what the bloke from Belize is on, but Paolo Wanchope is not number three in the world whichever way you look at it. Manuel Reinaldo Bilches, the world awaits your explanation.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

Arsenal have been linked with a summer move for Barcelona's Patrick Kluivert. Marc Overmars could be offered in exchange for the Dutch international striker.

Bradford have approached Benfica with an offer to take former Celtic striker Jorge Cadete on loan. "Jorge is thinking it over," said a spokesman for the Portuguese club.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

Scotland will begin their World Cup 2002 qualifying campaign with three away games. Craig Brown was delighted with the way the fixtures worked out: "We always want to start with difficult aways," he said. Full fixtures: Latvia v Scotland (Sept 2), San Marino v Scotland (Oct 7), Croatia v Scotland (Oct 11), Scotland v Belgium (Mar 24, 2001), Scotland v San Marino (Mar 28), Scotland v Croatia (Sept 1), Belgium v Scotland (Sept 5), Scotland v Latvia (Oct 6).

Everton manager Walter Smith has signed a new contract which commits him to the club for a further three-and-a-half years.

Esteban Fuertes will never play for Derby again, according to manager Jim Smith. The Argentinian striker played just 10 games for the Rams before being deported in November after it was found he had a forged passport. "Branko Strupar has come in now and Esteban belongs to the past," insisted Smith.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

ITV: The Big Match (11.30pm)

Tranmere v Bolton. "I've got the biggest moustache," says John Aldridge.

Sky Sports 1: You're On Sky Sports! (10.15pm, 2.45am)

We asked you if you knew what McCaff does out of both sides of his mouth. You seem to favour one answer in particular. However we can't print it.

Sky Sports 2: Worthington Cup Football - Live (7.30pm, 12.45am SS1)

Tranmere v Bolton. "Rubbish. My moustache is massive," counters Sam Allardyce.

Sky Sports 3: Futbol Mundial (7pm)

A football magazine with a fairly wide remit.

Eurosport: Football (7.30pm)

A meaningless match between Galatasaray and the winners of some cup or other. Thanks, Eurosport.

Radio 5 Live: 5 Live Football (7pm)

You spend three long hours waiting for David Mellor...

David Mellor (10pm)

...and when he arrives, you feel like an complete fool for doing so.

talkSPORT: It's Just Like Watching Brazil (8.30pm)

It's not like watching anything, though, is it? It's on the radio.

fields.headline: A virtual life
fields.standfirst: Is it possible never to venture outside and live life almost entirely online? A former computer worker from Texas is taking up the challenge...and capturing the imagination of an increasingly internet-obsessed society in the process
fields.trailText: There's no place like home for DotComGuy, alias Mitch Maddox, a 26-year-old former computing systems manager, who has moved into an empty house  in suburban Dallas, Texas, where he plans to stay holed up until 2001 - with the aid of the world wide web.
fields.body:
There's no place like home for DotComGuy, alias Mitch Maddox, a 26-year-old former computing systems manager, who has moved into an empty house in suburban Dallas, Texas, where he plans to stay holed up until 2001 - with the aid of the world wide web.

Since taking up residence on January 1, with little more than a laptop, DotComGuy has found his 15 minutes of fame...and more. He has been giving interview after interview - by phone, camera and online chat room - and spreading the word about e-commerce to TV stations and newspapers as far away as Japan and India.

And the cyber dweller has become a hit with the ladies since his site - A virtual life - was launched, with marriage proposals pouring in from all over the world. But DotComGuy does not believe in virtual dating, describing himself as an "old-fashioned kind of guy".

"I don't think a virtual date would be appropriate," he told CNN. "Instead, I would have a limo pick her up and bring her to my home, where we would have a nice romantic dinner."

In classic American style, DotComGuy has turned to sponsors to finance his company, DotComGuyInc. With the aid of a PR firm specialising in product placement, he has succeeded in persuading a variety of e-commerce businesses to donate goods, services or money.

In return, DotComGuy serves as a virtual billboard - displayed across the world - and repeatedly makes pitches for sponsors in his media interviews, web site reviews and daily journal entries.

Although he never goes out, relatives, friends and sponsor reps drop into his DotCompound, so the life of this cyber recluse is not devoid of human contact.

And the longer he stays, the more money DotComGuy makes. His first month's stipend of $24 is doubled every month, so, if he manages to stay the course until January 1, 2001, he will pocket almost $100,000.

DotComGuy's stunt has put a few noses out of joint, however. Eric Zorn, a Chicago Tribune columnist, launched a counterstunt in protest, proclaiming himself NotComGuy. Unplugging almost everything for a week, Mr Zorn filled his suddenly quiet life with reading, writing by hand and researching without the aid of a computer.

Scoffing at the exploits of the biggest internet celebrity since Mahir Cagri - the Turkish journalist who found fame with his "I kiss you" greeting at his whimsical home page - Mr Zorn said: "I think it's a big silly stunt. Whereas mine was a little silly stunt.

"I think DotComGuy is doing what a lot of people are more or less already doing, spending most of every day either sleeping or being online. He just gets a little less sun and a lot more publicity."

DotComGuy insists, however, that he is out to show "the ease of e-commerce, how it can simplify our lives."

fields.headline: The kiss of death
fields.standfirst: Bad news. Affairs hit children as badly as parents fear.  Joanna Moorhead  reports
fields.trailText: If it's hard telling your partner you've been cheating on him or her, it's a damn sight harder telling the kids. "It's the hardest thing I've ever had to do," says Sally of the moment when she had to break the news to her son and daughter, aged six and seven. "I felt I was taking away their innocence, stripping them of their childhood."
fields.body:
If it's hard telling your partner you've been cheating on him or her, it's a damn sight harder telling the kids. "It's the hardest thing I've ever had to do," says Sally of the moment when she had to break the news to her son and daughter, aged six and seven. "I felt I was taking away their innocence, stripping them of their childhood."

According to Julia Cole - whose book, After the Affair, is published this week - affairs hit children as badly as their parents fear. And her conclusions are backed up by a recent survey, which reveals a string of negative effects on children after the disclosure of a parent's affair.

According to the survey, by Relate and Candis magazine, more than half the 1,000 respondents believed children would be damaged if one or both of their parents were involved in an affair. Those who had either had affairs, or witnessed them in families they were close to, described three main problems they observed in the children afterwards: becoming withdrawn (35%), a tendency to cry more (31%) and a tendency to aggression (25%). Other problems included truancy from school, eating disorders and running away from home.

Even where affairs are supposedly clandestine, or at least hidden from the children, they are rarely completely unaffected, says Cole. "Children are often far sharper emotionally than adults give them credit for. I've met couples who have described the affair as being like a cancer eating away at the heart of their family - a child will have an awareness of that.

"The way people think of affairs, typically, is of the relationship triangle. But it's more accurate to think of it like a stone being thrown into a pool. The ripples flow out. When a couple have an affair, many others are affected - and those who are affected the worst are their children."

Occasionally, a child becomes aware of a parent's affair before the other parent. This can be devastating, says Dr Brenda Robson, a psychologist who specialises in family break-ups. "In this situation children feel very guilty, completely torn. They know it might mean the break-up of their parents marriage, and they don't want that."

If the marriage does end, the children often blame themselves, even many years on, for not keeping the affair secret - even if they didn't disclose it. "In fact, it's common for children to blame themselves whether or not they knew what was going on," says Cole. "I've had adult clients who describe a parent's affair, then say, 'I was being very difficult at the time so it's not surprising she had an affair.'"

There's guilt, too, on the part of the philanderer. Five years on, Sally - who, after separating from her husband, went back to live with him - still feels bad about the effect of her affair on her children. "In many ways, we're the family we always were. But underneath the appearances I think it has changed all of us," she says. "Maybe it's just my guilt, but I think the children don't have faith in us any more. They still think about the time we split up, and they worry it might happen again."

Others say you can't separate the affair from everything else that was going on in the relationship. "Of course, my kids were affected by my affair, and that of my husband. But they were also affected by all the rows, the screaming, the terrible atmosphere," says Sue. "It was a whole package of disasters."

Given this, isn't it understandable if unhappily married parents think an affair may be a way of squaring the circle - allowing them a snatch of happiness, while enabling the family to remain together? Cole understands this, but counsels against it. Far better, she says, to try to put the original relationship back on track than to think it can co-exist alongside an affair. "A lot of the people I see say, in talking about an affair, that they could see it coming," she says. "They see that, looking back, they were open to the idea. If you feel that you've got to think, 'Why?' You need to get some professional help to sort out what is going wrong. You need to talk to your partner.

"The idea of saving your children the agony of the marriage splitting up by taking a lover sounds attractive, but all you're doing is opening the way to further difficulty, because you're letting in this new factor, the lover. And also, I'd say, you're not treating this new person at all well - you're simply using him, or her, to keep your relationship intact and your family together. It's not a fair way of dealing with the problem."

Some couples, of course, patch things up after an affair. But, says Cole, doing this for the sake of the children isn't a good enough reason. There has, she says, to be at least a spark of love, as illustrated by this respondent in the Relate survey: "It [the affair and its aftermath] has devastated my life," the respondent wrote. "All my values are shattered. Yet I'm hanging on in there for the sake of the children. Who wants to be a single mum? And the boys need a dad. But my idea of a partnership for life has gone, and love flew out of the window a long time ago."

And it is not only the cuckolded who suffer. Richard, 53, had an affair when his three children were in their early teens. "My marriage was in pieces. There was nothing left except animosity," he says. "Sarah, my lover, was the love of my life." After weeks of agonising - "I genuinely wanted to do what was best for the children" - Richard decided to move out to live with Sarah. "I knew my wife and I could never put our marriage together again, and I thought the children would suffer living with all our rows."

What Richard hadn't reckoned with, though, was the attitude of one of his daughters. "She absolutely hated Sarah and made life difficult for us all the time. In the end, Sarah couldn't stand it any longer, and she left. I know if it hadn't been for my daughter we'd still be together, and I know I'm unhappy because of her. But the truth is, looking back, that I can also see that, from Sarah's point of view, I let her down because I was always putting the children first."

Others leave initially, but return when they realise not only how much their children need their other parent, but how inadequate their new partner is: "As a lover, life was great. We got on really well, I loved him," says Jane. "But when we started living together, with my daughter there too, I realised he wasn't very good at being a father-substitute. He just wasn't interested in what she was doing, in the little person she is. In the end, it was enough to end the relationship, and I went home."

When the old relationship still has a spark, says Cole, the presence of children can provide an extra boost to a couple wanting to put things back together again. But, she cautions, there's no such thing as going back after an affair: you can rebuild a relationship, but you can never rebuild exactly the relationship you had. But from the point of view of the children, there's little doubt that the relationship rebuilt is a good deal preferable to no relationship at all.

"It's the hardest thing I've ever had to do," says Sally of the moment when she had to break the news to her son and daughter, aged six and seven. "I felt I was taking away their innocence, stripping them of their childhood." According to Julia Cole - whose book, After the Affair, is published this week - affairs hit children as badly as their parents fear. And her conclusions are backed up by a recent survey, which reveals a string of negative effects on children after the disclosure of a parent's affair. According to the survey, by Relate and Candis magazine, more than half the 1,000 respondents believed children would be damaged if one or both of their parents were involved in an affair. Those who had either had affairs, or witnessed them in families they were close to, described three main problems they observed in the children afterwards: becoming withdrawn (35%), a tendency to cry more (31%) and a tendency to aggression (25%). Other problems included truancy from school, eating disorders and running away from home. Even where affairs are supposedly clandestine, or at least hidden from the children, they are rarely completely unaffected, says Cole. "Children are often far sharper emotionally than adults give them credit for. I've met couples who have described the affair as being like a cancer eating away at the heart of their family - a child will have an awareness of that. "The way people think of affairs, typically, is of the relationship triangle. But it's more accurate to think of it like a stone being thrown into a pool. The ripples flow out. When a couple have an affair, many others are affected - and those who are affected the worst are their children." Occasionally, a child becomes aware of a parent's affair before the other parent. This can be devastating, says Dr Brenda Robson, a psychologist who specialises in family break-ups. "In this situation children feel very guilty, completely torn. They know it might mean the break-up of their parents marriage, and they don't want that." If the marriage does end, the children often blame themselves, even many years on, for not keeping the affair secret - even if they didn't disclose it. "In fact, it's common for children to blame themselves whether or not they knew what was going on," says Cole. "I've had adult clients who describe a parent's affair, then say, 'I was being very difficult at the time so it's not surprising she had an affair.'" There's guilt, too, on the part of the philanderer. Five years on, Sally - who, after separating from her husband, went back to live with him - still feels bad about the effect of her affair on her children. "In many ways, we're the family we always were. But underneath the appearances I think it has changed all of us," she says. "Maybe it's just my guilt, but I think the children don't have faith in us any more. They still think about the time we split up, and they worry it might happen again." Others say you can't separate the affair from everything else that was going on in the relationship. "Of course, my kids were affected by my affair, and that of my husband. But they were also affected by all the rows, the screaming, the terrible atmosphere," says Sue. "It was a whole package of disasters." Given this, isn't it understandable if unhappily married parents think an affair may be a way of squaring the circle - allowing them a snatch of happiness, while enabling the family to remain together? Cole understands this, but counsels against it. Far better, she says, to try to put the original relationship back on track than to think it can co-exist alongside an affair. "A lot of the people I see say, in talking about an affair, that they could see it coming," she says. "They see that, looking back, they were open to the idea. If you feel that you've got to think, 'Why?' You need to get some professional help to sort out what is going wrong. You need to talk to your partner. "The idea of saving your children the agony of the marriage splitting up by taking a lover sounds attractive, but all you're doing is opening the way to further difficulty, because you're letting in this new factor, the lover. And also, I'd say, you're not treating this new person at all well - you're simply using him, or her, to keep your relationship intact and your family together. It's not a fair way of dealing with the problem." Some couples, of course, patch things up after an affair. But, says Cole, doing this for the sake of the children isn't a good enough reason. There has, she says, to be at least a spark of love, as illustrated by this respondent in the Relate survey: "It [the affair and its aftermath] has devastated my life," the respondent wrote. "All my values are shattered. Yet I'm hanging on in there for the sake of the children. Who wants to be a single mum? And the boys need a dad. But my idea of a partnership for life has gone, and love flew out of the window a long time ago." And it is not only the cuckolded who suffer. Richard, 53, had an affair when his three children were in their early teens. "My marriage was in pieces. There was nothing left except animosity," he says. "Sarah, my lover, was the love of my life." After weeks of agonising - "I genuinely wanted to do what was best for the children" - Richard decided to move out to live with Sarah. "I knew my wife and I could never put our marriage together again, and I thought the children would suffer living with all our rows." What Richard hadn't reckoned with, though, was the attitude of one of his daughters. "She absolutely hated Sarah and made life difficult for us all the time. In the end, Sarah couldn't stand it any longer, and she left. I know if it hadn't been for my daughter we'd still be together, and I know I'm unhappy because of her. But the truth is, looking back, that I can also see that, from Sarah's point of view, I let her down because I was always putting the children first." Others leave initially, but return when they realise not only how much their children need their other parent, but how inadequate their new partner is: "As a lover, life was great. We got on really well, I loved him," says Jane. "But when we started living together, with my daughter there too, I realised he wasn't very good at being a father-substitute. He just wasn't interested in what she was doing, in the little person she is. In the end, it was enough to end the relationship, and I went home." When the old relationship still has a spark, says Cole, the presence of children can provide an extra boost to a couple wanting to put things back together again. But, she cautions, there's no such thing as going back after an affair: you can rebuild a relationship, but you can never rebuild exactly the relationship you had. But from the point of view of the children, there's little doubt that the relationship rebuilt is a good deal preferable to no relationship at all.  Names have been changed. fields.headline: The panel
fields.standfirst: The Question:  Working mothers have been pilloried yet again - this time by a Panorama programme claiming their children grew up to be low-achievers. We ask: is it right to ignore the behaviour of fathers?
fields.trailText: The Question: Working mothers have been pilloried yet again - this time by a Panorama programme claiming their children grew up to be low-achievers. We ask: is it right to ignore the behaviour of fathers?
fields.body:
Dan Levy Father of three, who does 50% of the childcare

I'm more than 50% the main carer of my children, and my partner works full-time. And yes, I think research is ignoring the role fathers like me play: in general, I think our situation is good, and I feel very involved in my children's lives. I think research is failing to see the reality of people's lives: for example, we hear a lot about single parents, but the reality is that a lot of mothers are bringing up their children single-handedly. A lot of dads are around so little, the mothers are virtually single parents - but research only recognises parents alone as single.

Bob Huggins Stay-at-home father of three children, now aged 15, 17, 19

My children are 15, 17 and 19, and for 12 years I've been their main carer and, for most of it, a full-time, non-working father. Fathers like me are still in the minority, but a lot of the research we're hearing about now is out of date: the study this week about academic achievement being affected by a mother being out at work relates to children born in 1970, and things have changed a lot. Also, it isn't enough just to look at whether the mother is out at work: who's caring for the child when she isn't around? If it's the father, then his input is interchangeable.

Heather Joshi Co-author of the report Panorama was based on

It's not that we ignore fathers so much as we're constrained by the data. If looking at child outcomes over a number of years, you're restricted by what studies are available and what questions were asked. This study originated in the 70s; researchers then didn't think of asking fathers questions that might seem pertinent today. Even if they had, the answers would have been different from today's. So what's the point of these studies? You don't get a complete picture of what's going on, but you do get suggestions. And you get enough information to see that it's a complicated story.

Colin Campbell Father of one who is the primary carer

I'm the main carer of our 19-month-old daughter Morag, and I'm flabbergasted that the researchers behind such studies get away with it. In other areas of life we've moved on, but when it comes to children, the norms of research seem set by a sexist framework that assumes there are some roles only mothers can fulfil. Apart from breastfeeding, a father's input can be exactly the same as a mother's. There are some things my partner does better, and I hope there are some things I'm really good at. We shouldn't pay attention to these studies that make women feel guilty about what they're doing.

Sue Monk Spokeswoman for campaign group Parents At Work

UK fathers work the longest hours of any workers in Europe, so it's hard for them to play much of a role in their children's lives. That makes it harder for women to balance home and work. This isn't taken much account of by researchers. Even when men are unemployed or part-time while their partner is in work, studies show it's still women who do the housework - that cuts down further the time they can spend with the children. We need more research to how men could play a bigger role in their children's lives, and we need to look at how men are pressured to work long hours.

webTitle: 'Dear Dilys, are you really this selfish?'

fields.headline: 'Dear Dilys, are you really this selfish?'
fields.standfirst: The diary of a part-time father
fields.trailText: I wrote an angry letter to my ex-partner Dilys. It started off like this: "Dear Dilys, I've known for a long time that you think you have some divine right to do what the hell you like and that you just can't understand why anyone would disagree. But could you make a special effort just this once? I am referring, of course, to you persuading our three children to stop calling me 'Dad'.
fields.body:
I wrote an angry letter to my ex-partner Dilys. It started off like this: "Dear Dilys, I've known for a long time that you think you have some divine right to do what the hell you like and that you just can't understand why anyone would disagree. But could you make a special effort just this once? I am referring, of course, to you persuading our three children to stop calling me 'Dad'.

"Of course, given your special talent for blinkered self-obsession, it seems horribly possible that it never crossed your mind that you should have secured my agreement before such a change was made. And I suppose, on reflection, it is frighteningly likely that you never once considered that doing such a thing would hurt and anger me. On balance, though, I am presuming that these things did occur to you, but you decided to go ahead and twist Gloria, Jed and Billy around you little finger anyway, and never mind the consequences for me; or, more importantly, for them."

A low-key intro, I admit. But I was just warming up...

"Are you really as crass and selfish as you seem? Is it a talent you were born with, or have you been on a special course? I realise, naturally, that this blatant attempt to undermine me in the children's eyes is motivated not by any wish to make life easier for them, but by your nauseating longing to please Chris at any expense. It's one thing for that pillock to go around parading my children - my sons in particular - as if they were his own so he can kid himself he's some kind of sperm bank with body hair. It's something else entirely, though, when you take it upon yourself to try to reduce me by comparison with Mr Masculinity by pretending he could ever love them as deeply as I do... "

And so it continued in the same tender vein. I sat up half the night writing it, and in the morning got up early and read it all again. It gave me a good feeling. Shooting from the hip! Telling it like it is! I handed the letter proudly to Angie as she got dressed for work, and headed downstairs with baby Estelle on my hip. Gloria was just leaving for school: "Bye Dad, er, Joe," she said.

"Bye, er, Gloria."

She shot me an edgy look and slipped swiftly out of the door.

In the kitchen I was joined by Jed and Billy. They sat up at the table and Estelle, as usual, demanded to be wedged adoringly between them. Breakfast was served: juice, cereal, milk...

"Dad, er, Joe," piped up Billy, the younger of the boys.

"Yes, er, Billy," I replied.

"If Chris is our dad, too, does that mean Angie is our mum? You know, the same as, er, Dilys?" "Well, er, Billy," I said crisply, "as far as I'm concerned, Chris is not your dad and never will be. I am your dad, and that is that. And, er, Dilys, as you call her, is your mum. Angie, meanwhile, is your stepmum - and your special grown-up friend. As for Chris, he is a ... "

The pause I mustered at this juncture required superhuman strength. I longed to slag him off, my ludicrous usurper, but I knew I mustn't do it in front of the kids. And I knew that Jed, apparently so absorbed in his own unfathomable thoughts, was listening like a hawk.

"Chris," I sidestepped lamely, "is a bowl of Coco Pops. Now both of you eat yours. And you, Princess Estelle."

Angie walked in at this point.

"Don't do it," she said, looking meaningfully at me.

"Don't do what?"

"Don't send... that thing."

Uh oh. "That thing" was my letter.

"What thing?" Billy asked.

"The thing that's going to get your dad nowhere."

"Which dad?" Billy inquired.

At that point, Jed's eyes rolled up and fixed themselves on mine.

"Perhaps," I suggested, utterly deflated, "it's time to get on with the day."

My letter wasn't sent. Angie was insistent. Later on, she explained why: "Dilys is in the wrong. Gloria knows it, Jed knows it and even Billy will work it out one day. So don't be provoked to anger. Don't give her the chance to tell the kids that you've been nasty. Write her a polite letter about it all instead."

I know Angie was right. I know I mustn't blow my top. But something's got to give. Bet your life it won't be me.

webTitle: 'They thought he was my granddad - I was furious'

fields.headline: 'They thought he was my granddad - I was furious'
fields.standfirst: As Saul Bellow becomes a dad at 84,  Susanna Glaser  describes what it was like to have a senior citizen for a father - and to lose him so young
fields.trailText: As Saul Bellow becomes a dad at 84, Susanna Glaser describes what it was like to have a senior citizen for a father - and to lose him so young
fields.body:
I never really knew my father. He died when I was seven. It was a sudden thing. My mother was at work in the evening, as usual, being a violinist in the Norwegian Opera Orchestra. My father had put me and my little brother to bed. I always read my comics in bed and was used to getting a 10-minute reprieve after "lights out, night night". But this particular night he didn't come back to switch my bedside lamp off. After half an hour I put it down to his normal absent-mindedness and switched the light off myself. The next morning my life changed irrevocably. My mother shook when she held me on her lap and told me my father was never coming back. The sun shone through my net curtains but I felt cold.

Yet, in hindsight, his death shouldn't have been such a surprise. He was 75 years old, after all.

Saul Bellow, 84, has just had a child. He's much older than my father was when he had me, at 68. Others will no doubt congratulate him. In our society an old father is still thought of as an amazingly virile man. I tell my peers about my father and the male ones, especially, react with undisguised admiration. Think of how many years you can play the field before having to settle down! But I wonder, has Bellow really thought it through? And did my father?

I remember the kind kindergarten ladies telling me that my granddad had arrived to pick me up. I'd be indignant, furious. He was my father, couldn't they tell? Well, probably not. His shock of white hair, his kind, worn face, and his deep smile lines probably confused them. Like any seven-year-old, I would be petulant when my father refused to take part in my active games. Was he really too frail, too old, as he said - or just not interested? I have a vivid memory of him pouring orange juice on his cornflakes by mistake. I regarded this absent-minded clumsiness as a personality trait, but now I wonder - how much of it was simply the behaviour of an old man?

He was also an incredibly intelligent person. He was witty, had a hugely positive outlook on life and was prodigiously gifted. But I never got to know that. I just have to second-guess from what people tell me.

I never knew my grandparents on his side. When I was born they'd died years ago. Even if my father had lived a little longer, there is a whole family, a whole world, my younger brother and I will never know. Apparently I look like his mother. The one photograph we have tells me nothing. What was she like? Would we have got on? Where do I fit in, what have I inherited, what haven't I, where is my father hidden inside me?

I do have family on his side, though. His daughters, born to him during his first marriage, before the second world war. They're my sisters, but they're older than my mother, so they feel more like aunts.

My father got a second go at parenthood with myself and my brother. First time around, I've been told, he was distant and strict. He didn't waste it this time. He watched us grow and enjoyed our company until the day he died. He was truly patient, gentle and giving, unlike many first-time fathers of a younger age. I only remember being told off once. I had disturbed the news on television just once too many times. An old man likes his news.

They say the older the parent, the more intelligent the child. I don't know about that, but I do know that I have suffered from a lack of guidance. Dad's not here to advise me. Lately, when I've been worried about what direction my career is taking, when I've wanted a second opinion, there has been nobody to ask. Would he have been disappointed that I didn't choose classical music as a career? Reassurance from my mother doesn't feel enough. It's frustrating knowing that your father knew so much yet you will never know the half of it.

Had he lived to 90, I would have still been just 22 when he died. And by then there might not have been much "daddy" left. How many 90-year-olds do you know who're completely cogent? How is a child supposed to relate to somebody always frail, always about to die?

I used to get angry about it. I'd ask myself, did it ever occur to my parents before they had me, that it was bound to end like this? Whether at seven or 17, I was bound to lose my father at a young age. Was it fair of them?

But they were in love, and love is blind. Like all lovers they probably felt they could overcome anything and everything. They didn't think too far ahead. And as my mother still says: "Look at your granddad. He's had three strokes and he's still alive at 84." She's got uncles that are up and at it, despite being in their 90s. She never thought of my father as an "old" man. He was active, totally "with it" and full of positive energy. There is no point being angry.

Of course, everybody's dad might die at any time, but mine must have known he was going to die before I grew up. I don't regret what my mother and father chose to do. I just wish I'd had the chance to know my father better. His amazing life. A well-known conductor, he wrote extensively about classical music in the Norwegian press and was an ardent promoter of music among young people. How many younger fathers can boast a career which saw him take a little known orchestra in Oslo and pretty much shape it into today's world-class Oslo Philharmonic? A Jewish Hamburg-born boy, he escaped Nazi Germany before the war started, made a life for himself in Norway.

He lost much of his family and most of his inheritance. But he never lost his lust for life. And he gave life - my brother and myself and my two half-sisters live on. I'll always have that to thank him for. And we haven't turned out too badly, considering. I just wish he knew that.

fields.headline: Tears, tantrums and other experiments
fields.standfirst: How do babies think?  Alison Gopnik, professor of developmental psychology, explains
fields.trailText: How do babies think? Alison Gopnik, professor of developmental psychology, explains
fields.body:
When my son was a toddler his first question about a meal was always: "What's for dessert?" One day, we had pineapple in kirsch. He spat it out, then looked at the grown-ups devouring the stuff, and said: "Pineapple: it's yucky for me but it's yummy for you." For weeks afterwards, he would stop suddenly in the middle of a game and say, "Pineapple: yucky for me but yummy for you", as if he had discovered the most extraordinary fact of life. And in a sense he had: the realisation that people think and feel differently is a profound one.

When we look around a room full of people, we don't see bags of skin and cloth draped over the furniture. We see other people, people with thoughts and emotions, desires and beliefs, sometimes like our own, sometimes not. And by the time they are 18 months old, this is what toddlers see, too. But how do such tiny children get from bags of skin to "other minds"?

In the past 30 years, we have learned more about what young children know and how they learn than we did in the preceding 2,500 years. And this has revolutionised our view of children. For centuries, psychologists and philosophers agreed that babies were the opposite of adults. They were emotional and passive, dominated by perception and incapable of rational thought. John Locke said they were "blank slates", William James thought their lives "a buzzing, blooming confusion".

Today, scientists have only recently begun to appreciate just how much even the youngest babies know - and how much and how quickly they learn. There are three elements to this new picture. First, that children know a great deal, literally from the moment they are born. Second, that they are born with extremely powerful learning abilities, more powerful than the most sophisticated computer. And, finally, that grown-ups appear to be "programmed" to unconsciously teach babies and young children just the things they need to know.

In How Babies Think, my co-authors and I argue that very young children use the same strategies as scientists. They think, observe, formulate theories, make predictions, and do experiments. They also change their theories as they accumulate counter-evidence to their predictions.

But where scientists focus their attention on distant stars and invisible microbes, babies concentrate on everyday things: blocks, pet dogs, words and, most important, Mum and Dad and Aunt Ethel. In fact, understanding other people seems to be one of the most crucial items in the scientific agenda of childhood, and it's a good illustration of how early learning takes place.

To begin with, children are born knowing that people are special. Newborn babies (the youngest tested was only 42 minutes old) can imitate facial expressions. There are no mirrors in the womb; newborns have never seen their own face. These tiny babies must somehow already understand the similarity between their own internal feeling (of, say, sticking out their tongue) and the external face they see (a round shape from which something pink protudes). Newborn babies not only prefer faces to things - this we've known for years - but also recognise that those faces are like their own face. Nature, it seems, gives human beings a jump start on the Other Minds problem.

And what a jump start. By the time they are nine months old, babies can tell the difference between expressions of happiness, sadness and anger, and understand something about the emotions that produce those expressions. By the time they are one, they know that they will see something by looking where other people point; they know that they should do something by watching what others do; and they know how they should feel about something by seeing how others feel. For instance, a grown-up can look in two boxes. She looks into one with an expression of joy and into the other with disgust. The baby will happily reach into the box that made her happy, but won't touch the box that disgusted her. The baby has discovered that its initial emotional rapport with other people extends to joint attitudes towards the world. In a simple way, one-year-olds already participate in a culture. But as babies learn that people usually have the same attitudes towards objects as they do, they are setting themselves up to learn something else, something more disturbing: they discover that sometimes people don't have the same attitudes.

Observe what happens when a baby reaches for a forbidden object - a lamp cord, say. It must seem perverse to the one-year-old: the more clearly she indicates her desire, the more adamantly her carer keeps it away. Even though the baby and the grown-up are reacting to the same object, their attitudes toward the object seem to be different.

By the time babies are about one and a half, they start to understand the nature of these differences between people and become fascinated. If you offer a baby two bowls, one of biscuits, the other of raw broccoli, all the babies prefer the biscuits. But if the researcher indicates to the baby that she hates biscuits and loves broccoli, then hands the bowls to the baby and says, "Could you give me some?" something interesting happens. Fourteen-month-olds, with their innocent assumption that we all want the same thing, give her biscuits. But the wiser 18-month-olds give her broccoli, even though they themselves despise it. These tiny children have learned that other people's desires may conflict with their own.

This is also dramatically apparent in everyday life. Parents all know, and dread, the "terrible twos". While one-year-olds seem irresistibly drawn to forbidden objects (that lamp cord again), the two-year-olds seem deliberately bloody-minded. She doesn't even look at the lamp cord. Instead, her hand goes out to touch it as she looks, steadily, gravely, at you.

This demonic behaviour is quite rational, though. Our broccoli experiments show that children only begin to understand differences in desires at 18 months. The terrible twos seem to involve a systematic exploration of that idea, like an experimental research programme. Toddlers are testing the extent to which their desires and those of others may conflict. The grave look is directed at you because you and your reaction, rather than the lamp cord, are the interesting thing. The terrible twos reflect a clash between children's need to understand other people and their need to live happily with them. If the child is a budding scientist, we parents are the laboratory rats.

Two-year-olds have to learn how visual perception works, too. Toddlers love hide and seek but aren't very good at it - a toddler will bury his head under the table with his bottom in view. In our lab, we explored when children learn how to hide things. Suppose I put a child on one side of a table and sit on the other. Then I put a screen and a toy on the table and ask the child to hide the toy from me. At 24 months, a toddler will put the toy on my side of the screen, so that it is actually hidden from them, but not from me. But 36-month-olds get this right. In fact, they'll often tell me they can see the toy but I can't. In the months in between, we observed many children experimenting. They would switch the toy from one side to the other, or come around to my side of the screen to make sure the toy really was hidden.

But this isn't the end of the story. Three-year-olds still have trouble with another important fact about people. They know that we can see different things, but not that what we think about the world may be wrong. They don't know that I may think I hear a burglar in the yard when really it's just a racoon.

In a classic experiment, you can give three-year-olds a shut chocolate box. They open it and it turns out to have pencils inside. Then you ask them about another child in the nursery: "What will Nicky think is in the box: pencils or chocolates?" Three-year-olds report that Nicky will say there are pencils inside. They don't understand that Nicky will probably make the same mistake they made. Four-year-olds know that Nicky will be misled by the picture on the box.

Like scientists, children change their theories precisely because they make the wrong predictions. In "mistaken belief" experiments, simply telling children the right answer makes no difference. Like scientists, children at first resist counter-evidence. Virginia Slaughter and I visited three-year-olds over several weeks and gave them examples of mistaken beliefs: a golfball that turned out to be soap, a yellow duck that looked green when put behind blue plastic. Each time the child made the wrong prediction, we presented them with counter-evidence. After two weeks, these three-year-olds understood a brand new "mistaken belief" task, one they had never seen before, much better than a control group.

This experiment shows that even very young children are naturally able to alter their predictions in the light of new evidence. But it also shows how important other people can be: our adult behaviour had helped the children to work out the correct answer. Of course, we're developmental psychologists. Do grown-ups naturally help children learn in their everyday lives? The new research suggests they do. One of the most dramatic examples of this is the funny sing-song voice grown-ups use when they talk to young babies. This rather embarrassing speech style helps children sort out the sounds of language. Similarly, the way that parents talk about the mind seems to influence their children's everyday psychology.

What are the consequences of this new view? The research doesn't mean there is some set of flashcards that will help babies be brighter. Babies are already as bright as can be. They learn through everyday play, and through the care and attention of grown-ups around them. It also doesn't mean there is some "critical period" for learning in the first three years or some set of experiences children must have. Children and even adults keep learning throughout life. It definitely doesn't mean mothers should quit their jobs. Anyone who cares for small children and is sensitive to what interests them can teach them what they need to know.

On the other hand, the research does suggest that the everyday, unrenumerated, unremarkable work of caring for babies and young children is the most important work in the world. Humans have managed to learn so much because generations of grown-ups put effort into caring for children. Ironically, this new scientific perspective comes when young children and parents are under enormous pressure. We still penalise parents for taking time off work to be with their children, instead of rewarding them. Childcare workers get little pay and less respect. Most parents face agonising dilemmas as they balance jobs and children. If we really want babies to learn, we should ditch the videotapes and flashcards and work for paid parental leave, flexible work arrangements and publicly supported, high-quality childcare.

How tiny minds tick

At birth
Babies imitate different facial expressions; know that a happy tone of voice goes with a smile.

At 3 months
They understand cause and effect. Tie one end of a ribbon to their toe and the other to a mobile; they learn to move the mobile.

At 5 months
Babies can lipread simple vowels. They can match silent video footage of talking faces with the right sound.

At 6 months
Babies understand objects. Given a can which moos, they will test it for other unexpected behaviour.

At 9 months Babies know general rules about their language. They can distinguish English from Polish.

At 1 year
Babies point, and look to where others point - this implies an understanding of how others see and think.

At 18 months
Younger babies assume everyone feels the same as them. Now they know that people may have different desires.

At 2 years
Little babies cry when others cry, but by 2, they will provide comfort. Empathy requires a deep knowledge of other minds.

 Alison Gopnik is professor of psychology at the University of California and co-author of How Babies Think: The Science of Childhood, with Andrew Meltzoff and Patricia Kuhl, published this week by Weidenfield and Nicolson at £20. webTitle: Conservation: Swinging in the rain forest

fields.headline: Swinging in the rain forest
fields.standfirst:
Lisa Buckingham on a woman who teaches orangutans to be themselves
The Sumateran Orangutan Society
fields.trailText: Lisa Buckingham on a woman who teaches orangutans to be themselves.
fields.body:
Lucy Wisdom used to swing on the trapezes in a circus big top. Now she swings among the trees of the Sumatran rain forest, teaching orphaned orangutans what should have come naturally.

Helpless young orangutans have arrived almost daily into Wisdom's care at the Bohorok rehabilitation centre, usually after they have been in captivity for a couple of years or more. Regarded as charming pets when tiny, they soon outgrow their cruelly constrictive cages and are often close to starvation and lacking almost all muscle tone when they are removed from their "owners". Some of the tiniest babies arrive still waking three times a night and crying for a feed from a mother who has, in all probability, been shot out of the nest she made nightly for her suckling youngster.

Wisdom says it is now accepted that the lives of 15 orangutans are lost for every live "pet" captured. Many of the deaths occur when mothers crush their young as they fall victim to the hunters' bullets.

Being a surrogate mother to a growing proportion of one of the world's most endangered species is not for the faint hearted, particularly in a country such as Indonesia, where the current troubles have underlined the dangers and political threats which face high profile campaigners.

And Wisdom's battle to save the remaining 5,000 to 7,000 Sumatran orangutans brings her into direct conflict with the illegal logger barons, whose chopping and burning of the Indonesian rain forest is rapidly destroying the apes' habitat.

Yet it is a crusade in which she clearly revels. "I feel so lucky when I'm surrounded by the apes," she says. "I feel safe in the jungle with the apes when I'm doing hands-on stuff."

Her mission is nothing if not hands on. She has been setting up a website, trying to gain global charity status and recruiting rock celebrities in her evangelical campaign to save the orangutans, whose numbers have fallen by three-quarters since the mid-1970s.

But Wisdom's unique contribution to saving and rehabilitating infant apes lies in the fact that most of her adulthood has been spent as a performing artist and acrobat. She may not talk to the animals, like Dr Doolittle, but she climbs the vines to show young orangutans what they should be doing. Now lacking her wild pink dreadlocks - they fell victim to the chemotherapy she recently underwent to treat a renewed bout of cancer - this diminutive woman thinks nothing of scaling 20m-high trees, peeling patches of bark with her teeth and gnawing at a sugary subcutaneous substance to initiate her charges into one of the most popular of orangutan treats.

"There is an intensely strong bond between mother and baby, and if that's broken the infants don't learn anything," she explains. "I go into the forest and use my trapeze skills to help teach the small apes how to climb."

It is little wonder that Wisdom feels she has arrived at her life's calling. There can be few jobs which call for acrobatic training and stage experience - another skill she is about to harness to mount a touring show to educate youngsters and villagers to the dangers of destroying the rain forest.

Yet as the need intensifies to provide an ever stronger safety net for the dwindling population of orangutans, the Bohorok centre - the only rehabilitation site for apes in Sumatra - was forced to close its doors to new entrants. Part of the difficulty was the proximity of a wild orangutan population, which made the local release of apes impossible. But further afield the trees have fallen to loggers.

Wisdom says there may be hundreds of apes in captivity within a 100-mile radius of Bohorok, but unless funding is raised for a new centre the Indonesian authorities are reluctant to confiscate the "pets" - even though owners are willing to give them up.

Wisdom now argues that financial help for Indonesia from organisations such as the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund should be linked to reforestation programmes. Other groups of campaigners were recently in the UK trying to persuade managers of big pension funds, such as Norwich Union and Legal & General, to scale down their investment in the country to encourage an end to illegal logging. Companies such as the mobile phone group, Orange, which frequently uses an orangutan picture to promote its wares, are being lobbied to take a more proactive stance. British Gas may be similarly targeted as the wildlife photographer of the year competition, which it sponsors at the Natural History Museum, is being advertised with the shot of an orangutan infant.

Orangutans tend to be solitary animals, noticeably so in older age. This is one of the reasons they have been less studied than other apes such as chimps - even though they are 96.4% genetically linked to humans and appear to share copious traits with us.

They even suffer from the same diseases as us. Indeed, Lucy may soon have to decide whether to end the life of a 10-year-old ape, Kiki, who suffers from Down's syndrome and is too big to remain at Bohorok but too handicapped to survive in the wild. Without the offer of a home from a friendly zoo, Kiki seems destined to die. Unlike so many of her kind, however, she has at least had 10 years.

There can be few jobs which call for acrobatic training and stage experience - another skill she is about to harness to mount a touring show to educate youngsters and villagers to the dangers of destroying the rain forest. Yet as the need intensifies to provide an ever stronger safety net for the dwindling population of orangutans, the Bohorok centre - the only rehabilitation site for apes in Sumatra - was forced to close its doors to new entrants. Part of the difficulty was the proximity of a wild orangutan population, which made the local release of apes impossible. But further afield the trees have fallen to loggers. Wisdom now argues that financial help for Indonesia from organisations such as the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund should be linked to reforestation programmes. Other groups of campaigners were recently in the UK trying to persuade managers of big pension funds, such as Norwich Union and Legal & General, to scale down their investment in the country to encourage an end to illegal logging. Companies such as the mobile phone group, Orange, which frequently uses an orangutan picture to promote its wares, are being lobbied to take a more proactive stance. British Gas may be similarly targeted as the wildlife photographer of the year competition, which it sponsors at the Natural History Museum, is being advertised with the shot of an orangutan infant. Orangutans tend to be solitary animals, noticeably so in older age. This is one of the reasons they have been less studied than other apes such as chimps - even though they are 96.4% genetically linked to humans and appear to share copious traits with us. They even suffer from the same diseases as us. Without the offer of a home from a friendly zoo, Kiki seems destined to die. Unlike so many of her kind, however, she has at least had 10 years.

fields.headline: Savage arenas
fields.standfirst:
Setting birds or dogs to fight each other to the death was outlawed in the first half of the 19th century. Nearly 200 years later, the RSPCA has a fight on its hands to catch the criminals perpetuating clandestine slaughter for money. Chris Arnot reports on some people's leisure pursuits
The hunting debate: special report
fields.trailText: Setting birds or dogs to fight each other to the death was outlawed in the first half of the 19th century. Nearly 200 years later, the RSPCA has a fight on its hands to catch the criminals perpetuating clandestine slaughter for money. Chris Arnot reports on some people's leisure pursuits.
fields.body:
The background scenery could be anywhere in suburban or inner-city Britain. A jerky video offers a glimpse of the neighbours leaning over the garden fence. A football lies abandoned at one end of a scrubby lawn, close to the footings of an old shed. A small child comes into view, his anorak hood pulled up and his back turned towards the middle of the lawn, where two fighting cocks are trying to peck and claw each other to death.

The date on the bottom of the screen is clear: 14.3.1999. But the location remains a mystery to members of the RSPCA's Special Operations Unit. Since more than six months have elapsed since the film was made, they can no longer bring a prosecution - even if they could find out where the cock fight took place. The video is one of several unearthed after a raid on a house in Birmingham.

The west Midlands, along with west Yorkshire and the west country, seems to be something of a blackspot for a so-called "sport" which was officially - if rather ineffectually - made illegal in this country as long ago as 1835.

It remains, though, a popular pastime in Pakistan, and there's little doubt that the Asian community has provided more than its fair share of the 62 convictions which have been secured in Britain since 1985.

But there have been no convictions among those members of the landed gentry who feel that they can carry on like Regency bucks at the cockpit, albeit with considerably more discretion. How does the RSPCA know what's going on in hidden corners of remote country estates? "We just do," says the unit's head, chief superintendent Barry Fryer, who is understandably cagey about revealing the surveillance techniques of special operations or the numbers involved.

They've had more success with raids on camps of travelling families. Five years ago, they went in with a heavy police backing and broke up a mid-morning cock-fight on a caravan site at Belvedere in south-east London. Both birds were injured and exhausted. Of the 47 fighting cocks removed from the site, 14 were already dead.

The special operations unit was set up around 25 years ago, primarily to monitor the transportation of live farm animals. But increasingly its resources have been diverted towards combating cock-fighting, dog-fighting and badger-baiting.

"It's disappointing that a large majority of the unit's time is spent trying to root out activities that were outlawed many years ago," says RSPCA spokeswoman Julie Briggs.

She is well aware of a cruel irony in all this. Some time in the 21st century it seems likely that parliament will find time to ban the hunting of foxes. Yet blood sports which were banned in the 19th century still have a dedicated following. According to one RSPCA inspector, several cock-fights take place every week in Birmingham alone.

Fryer finds it impossible to say whether activity is increasing or his unit is simply finding out more about it. "It goes in cycles," he says, "and we're getting a run of information at the moment." About dogs as well as cocks.

There have been 139 convictions in the last 10 years for dog-fighting, an activity which was also officially banned in 1835, when Staffordshire bull terriers were the most common participants.

Pit bull terriers, longer of leg and even stronger of bite, arrived in this country in the early 1980s. By 1985, the RSPCA was mounting its first prosecution of recent times for illegal fighting.

"It's now pursued only by the serious criminal element," says Fryer. "Anybody who was just playing at it dropped out after the dangerous dogs act of 1991. Every pit bull had to be registered and neutered. In theory, the breed should be dying out, but it isn't."

Thirteen heavily scarred pit bulls were recently discovered in one semi-detached house in rural Lincolnshire. There was enough evidence to confirm that they had been used for organised fights and to secure a six-month prison sentence for their owner, a 34-year-old man with the words "fuck off" inscribed into the stubble at the back of his closely-cropped head. He was given another year for breaking the nose of an RSPCA inspector and three years for possession of £100,000-worth of illegal drugs which police discovered in the course of the raid.

"A pit bull," says Fryer, "will fight, fight and fight again if it's game, whereas a fighting cock will just be used for breeding after its first year." That's a winning bird, of course. Losers almost invariably die in fights, which can last anything from 20 seconds to 20 minutes.

Sometimes they are pecked to death. Sometimes the heart is punctured by the sharpened spurs attached to the claws.

Fights take place in sheds, gardens, upstairs bedrooms or living rooms. They're videoed so that owners can show off the prowess of champion birds to would-be purchasers. The special operations unit has a stock of seized film at RSPCA headquarters in Horsham, Sussex, and grisly viewing it makes.

Here's a man in a grubby vest, on his knees in an industrial unit near Doncaster, urging on his pit bull to tear the throat out of its opponent. There a couple of rock partridges with sharpened beaks on a plastic sheet laid down to keep splashes of blood off the ghastly carpet beneath. There again, two men in a shed in Derbyshire taping spurs on to their birds to the accompaniment of background laughter.

Every now and then, it becomes evident that somebody - a child, perhaps - has tried to tape over part of the video. A particularly gruesome scene is suddenly interrupted by an almost surreal burst of Del Boy and Rodney in Only Fools And Horses.

Comedy and cruelty, fiction and fact, sharing the same jerky video that could have been recorded anywhere in suburban or inner-city Britain. Or even a country estate.

fields.headline: Patient progress
fields.standfirst: David Gilbert on how professionals  are beginning to listen to the public
fields.trailText: David Gilbert on how professionals are beginning to listen to the public.
fields.body:
Better late than never, the NHS has woken up to the fact that it has to listen to the patient's voice. Some health professionals even concede that there is something in it for them if they do so. At an individual level, letting patients take more control of their own health problems can lead to better outcomes. At a collective level, if professionals stop to think about what patients really need, then better care and better use of resources can result.

One hospital redesigned its patient leaflets about MRI scans - where patients have to lie still within a large cylinder - after realising that patients were not turning up because they were scared of the claustrophobic nature of the tube and the noise it made. The trust had told people about the mechanics of the procedure, but hadn't thought to describe how it might feel or what they could do about it if they panicked.

Elsewhere, an open conference on "discharge procedures" was renamed "coming home" after one of the public participants said that the phrase "discharge" seemed somehow offensive to patients because it implied that the hospital simply wanted to be rid of them. Using the term "coming home" also allowed everyone to think of the issue in a more personal way.

Nowadays, NHS trusts, health authorities and primary care groups want to know "how" to involve patients and the public, rather than simply "why". But professionals are often scared. They do not want to be faced by an angry lynch mob objecting to hospital closures, nor are they wild about being confronted by a patient in a focus group who wants to rant at the quality of care.

Any process for capturing the views of patients and the public needs to be practical and effective in terms of delivering the organisation's objectives.

Above all, patients and professionals alike need to feel safe. NHS staff require reassurance that user involvement will not raise unrealistic expectations, while patients need to be supported throughout the process.

In Lambeth, Southwark and Lewisham (LSL) health authority, London, patients who had suffered heart problems acted as teachers of doctors and nurses. Patients drawn from practice lists were brought on to focus groups and asked what, in their experience of heart disease management, had been most helpful.

Ten delegates from these groups met 20 primary care professionals in a half-day event.

Dr Brian Fisher, a local GP and HA representative who oversaw the process, says: "It was remarkable. For the first time, patients were saying what they thought worked. And professionals listened. They also used the patient panel as a sounding board for their own ideas about how to change services."

Even more importantly, at a six month follow-up, the professionals had changed their way of dealing with patients. They had improved the way they gave out the results of tests and investigations and had involved families more. A cardiac rehabilitation nurse was brought in because patients and carers found the first month after discharge particularly difficult. The patients' views were incorporated into clinical guidelines.

The experiences gained at the Office for Public Management (OPM), an independent centre that supports management practice in the NHS, show that a sound patient involvement strategy requires being clear about the reasons for involvement. There is also the need to involve the appropriate stakeholders - whether users, community representatives or the general public - and to adopt the right methods and be "up-front" about difficult decisions concerning money.

Senior managers need to be on board. In the Princess Alexandra Trust, in Harlow, Essex, the LSL "patients as teachers" model has been adopted by the trust in secondary care. The work comes under the umbrella of clinical governance - the system being set up to ensure high quality services.

Mona Walker, director of nursing and quality, says: "The aim is not to let the patient involvement work be marginalised. The senior team of cardiologists, medical director and chief executive has been primed on the results of the work and it will mesh with our clinical governance reporting arrangements."

The patients are enthusiastic, too: 23 out of the 32 patients in the first wave of focus groups wanted to go forward to meet the professionals. Their views on care and treatment were focused, balanced and clear. For example, one patient said: "They do tend to treat you as if you wouldn't understand anyway. I said, 'Let's be honest, it's my body, and I want to know what's going on with my body.' I was told that a lot of people don't want to know. So I said, 'I'm not a lot of people, I'm me, and you could at least have the courtesy to ask whether I wanted to know.'"

Professionals can be supported in other ways too. In City & Hackney community trust, east London, the child health directorate recently held a workshop for professionals on how to involve children and young people in their work. Two ideas came up: to develop better information for children, parents and professionals in the area of special needs and to find out ways to make mental health services better suited to children and adolescents in Asian families.

Even controversial topics can be tackled. In Kent, patients' views on service changes in haemophilia and renal services have been incorporated into decision-makers' plans. Another approach is being tried in a large acute hospital trust. Here, there is a three-pronged strategy that involves the community in identifying health concerns and informing service development. Three rounds of "community issues groups" - reconvened focus groups that assess and give informed judgments on complex information - have been set up, three with users of services, three with community representatives and three with members of the public. The results will be fed in alongside the views of trust staff. Another way in to this kind of work is customer care work. At Guy's and St Thomas's hospital trust, London, workshops have been run to train staff volunteers to review how their directorates treat patients, carers and visitors.

This "conduct of care" work is accompanied by a trust-wide communications strategy that aims to alert all staff, patients and the public to the initiative through posters and the trust newspaper.

Positive examples like these provide a riposte to the sceptics who feel it's not worthwhile to involve patients and the public in the running of the NHS.

 David Gilbert is fellow at the Office for Public Management.

fields.headline: Off cuts
fields.trailText: Laurie Taylor
fields.body:
So far, the new millennium has been remarkably free of political sexual scandals, but it surely won't be long before we pick up our favourite tabloid and learn that yet another married male politician has been found indulging his homosexual predilections. This is the moment when tradition dictates that the "outed" politician should be photographed alongside his wife and children on the steps of the family home and when, ideally, short but sincere statements should be made by both partners attesting to their enduring love for each other.

Our general cynicism about the man's role in this drama is usually complemented by sympathy for the wronged wife. When the couple turn from the cameras and disappear into the family home, how will she cope with the knowledge of her partner's homosexuality? According to some fascinating new research carried out for the ESRC by Dr Gill Dunne, of the London School of Economics Gender Institute, our concerns may be misplaced.

When Dunne interviewed married gay fathers as part of her wider inquiry into gay parenting she was surprised to discover that 73% of them were quite open with their wives about their sexuality and described their marriages as "happy". The secret of such happiness, Dunne suggests, lies in the readiness of both partners to regard each other as "friends", rather than as a traditional romantic couple.

This surprising degree of amity between gay husbands and their wives even survived divorce. Most gay men got on well with their ex-wives and were actively engaged in looking after the children of their former union. They were, says Dunne, "particularly interested in extending their masculine identity to embrace nurturing qualities" and felt that one great gift they brought to the children was a sense of tolerance.

There's no shortage of myths and stereotypes about risks associated with gay parenting, but the traditional academic focus on female parenting and young gay men means this is one of the first objective inquiries into a highly contentious area.

Dunne believes it has profound implications. We should, she insists, abandon our preoccupation with the nuclear family and "open our imaginations as far as fathers go". Only then will we be prepared to consider the possibility that romantic heterosexuality may take second place to honest, enduring friendship when it comes to successful parenting. After all, "friends are there long after romantic partners".

 Laurie Taylor talks to Gill Dunne about gay parenting on Radio 4's Thinking Allowed at 4pm today.

fields.headline: Load of trouble
fields.standfirst: An armed force guarded a cargo of the world's most frightening substance on its voyage         from Cumbria to Japan - and into a nuclear storm.
fields.trailText: An armed force guarded a cargo of the world's most frightening substance on its voyage from Cumbria to Japan - and into a nuclear storm.
fields.body:
Europe's most heavily armed police are dressed from head to foot in black, the visors of their riot helmets down, ready for any form of attack. They carry rifles and have grenades and gas masks dangling below their body armour. In self-defence, they can use the 30mm rapid fire naval cannon or, at close quarters, shotguns.

This the elite cadre of the UK Atomic Energy Authority security force, Britain's least known police unit. They were trained and armed for a very particular task: to sail round the world in their double-hulled gunboats to deliver nuclear fuel to Japan.

Now they are back on the Cumbrian coast near their base at Sellafield, kicking their heels and awaiting a highly embarrassing order: to return to Japan and collect the fuel they have just delivered - a round trip of 40,000 miles.

The UKAEA security force is a pawn in a debacle that has brought Britain's nuclear industry to a new low. Last Wednesday, Kansai Electric Power Co Inc - the first company in the world to accept a shipment of reprocessed mixed-oxide (MOX) fuel from British Nuclear Fuels (BNFL) - announced it was to bar BNFL from supplying it. In a statement, Kansai said that BNFL's falsification of data relating to safety of records had seriously damaged public trust. Japan has now demanded that the shipment be taken back.

So the government has ordered a high-level delegation - including Anna Walker, director general of energy at the DTI, and Lawrence Williams, chief inspector of the Nuclear Installations Inspectorate - to fly to Japan to try to talk the Japanese government round.

The delegation's task is a difficult one and, even if it succeeds, there are serious questions to be answered about how BNFL came to spend hundreds of millions of pounds of public money on a disastrous plan to reprocess the world's plutonium, without consulting the public about what it was doing.

Mixed-oxide fuel was to be the salvation of the spent nuclear fuel industry based at Sellafield. MOX is a mixture of uranium and plutonium. It is not the sort of thing you can put in the post, return to sender: it is easily dissolved in acid and convertible into nuclear weapons, hence the extraordinary security measures demanded to escort it round the world. Nine thousand jobs depend on chopping up hot, used fuel, dissolving it in nitric acid and turning it into plutonium and uranium.

In the midst of the huge Sellafield complex is one of the most hi-tech industrial plants the world has seen. It cost pounds 300m and is the last word in robotics, with every speck of dust accounted for to make sure no plutonium goes astray. But it has been lying idle for two years while the government decides whether it should be dismantled before it is ever used.

By law, BNFL has to justify the extra nuclear contamination that opening the plant would cause by showing it is economically justifiable. Before the latest debacle, many thought this was unlikely and were willing to challenge any permission in the courts. Now it looks plain impossible.

The plant was built by BNFL with taxpayers' money, but without publicising what they were doing. The idea was to reprocess plutonium and uranium by making MOX fuel to be sold overseas. This would justify the continued existence of giant reprocessing plants for producing plutonium that no one otherwise needs or wants. The reprocessing system was developed in the dim days at the beginning of the cold war, when Britain urgently needed plutonium to make hydrogen bombs and keep its place as a world power. All that was 50 years and another century ago now, and the few pounds of plutonium that were needed to make the first nuclear weapons has become an embarrassing mountain of 40 tonnes - enough to obliterate all human life in the world around 100,000 times.

Every day we go on making more and more plutonium. Although the UK does not need it, it is not the sort of thing that can be let out of sight. For a start, it is the world's most toxic substance - a speck of dust in the lungs can cause cancer. It is also the substance every terrorist and dictator in the world would like to get his hands on. It is the most desired and most undesirable commodity on the planet.

It fell back on a technology developed years before but abandoned as too expensive and potentially dangerous. It would mix plutonium with uranium and make a new fuel called MOX, which could be burnt in traditional reactors.
