The mothballed plant can't open until it gets firm orders, BNFL is horrified at the PR disaster of having to bring the fuel back, and the whole future of Sellafield is in disarray. If MOX is the only remaining justification for reprocessing spent fuel, what happens now?

fields.headline: New mentality
fields.standfirst: Peter Relton is the first person in the UK to be  given power to help make clinical decisions  about fellow patients. Adam James reports
fields.trailText: Peter Relton is the first person in the UK to be given power to help make clinical decisions about fellow patients. Adam James reports.
fields.body:
A new ethos in mental health, which rejects the medical model of the illness, is being pioneered by Bradford's home treatment service (HTS). It is the first NHS service not to use psychiatric diagnoses, and uses five times less medication on its patients. It is also the first to employ a user with power to make decisions about patients.

Throughout its history, psychiatry has felt the collective wrath of dissatisfied patients. Past and present user groups have argued that, at best, psychiatry is over-reliant on medication and fails to address the social causes of distress - while, at worst, it is damaging and its powers of compulsory detention and treatment infringe patients' civil liberties.

Yet such criticisms have failed to bring any far-reaching changes to psychiatry-dominated mental health practice, particularly the allegiance to the medical model.

But Bradford's home treatment service has, over the past four years, pioneered a philosophy which takes on board user concerns. It is the first UK mental health NHS service to invest a user with powers to decide how clients are treated. Whereas mental health services increasingly employ users as general "user development" workers, Peter Relton is the first to be attached to a specific clinical team. In so doing, Bradford's HTS, supported by local user groups, has demonstrated how the buzz words of user/professional partnership can be turned into reality.

A user for the past 35 years, Relton sits alongside the team's two psychiatrists, eight nurses and three social workers at the three-weekly review meetings when clients are discussed. He has equal say on all matters - whether it be the progress of a client, how to spend the service's budget or team development.

"My position means I can make a direct impact on professionals' attitudes and the team's philosophy," explains Relton, who also serves on Bradford Mind's management committee. "Most power in mental health services lies in the hands of the psychiatrists. But, here in Bradford, psychiatrists have made the remarkable step of giving some of their power away to users."

Relton's appointment won the seal of approval from the trust because of the reputation of Bradford HTS team leader, consultant psychiatrist Dr Pat Bracken, who used to work with north Birmingham's innovative home treatment service.

Describing himself as a "critical psychiatrist", Dr Bracken works with a social model of mental illness rather than the orthodox medical one. He believes problems have their roots in experience rather than biology. He says Relton has brought benefits to his team which all psychiatric services could learn from.

"As a user, Peter knows what it is like to be talked about by professionals. He has helped shape the team's culture away from a feeling of them, the patients, and us, the professionals. He can also communicate with patients in a way the rest of us cannot."

The team, which takes referrals directly from GPs, only treats patients in their own homes, believing these to be a more appropriate environment to recover from distress, than the turbulent, and often impersonal, psychiatric ward. And with Relton's input, the team has made a further radical diversion from the medical model by not using psychiatric diagnoses. Rather than saying a client has schizophrenia or manic depression, team members will instead focus on the needs and events in their life.

"From the patient's point of view, there is nothing to be gained from a diagnosis - particularly schizophrenia, which is such a stigmatising label," says Dr Bracken."We prefer to say, for example, that people are having strange experiences, or are hearing voices."

For example, one woman was referred to the team with a diagnosis of schizophrenia and had "delusions" of being attacked. But, when the team's workers visited her at home, they discovered her husband was regularly beating her up.

It was this violent domestic environment which was the biggest problem in the woman's life.

"Yet, up to this point, other services had taken her husband's version of events that his wife was mad," says Relton, who takes charge of the team's training. "Bizarre behaviour can always be made meaningful if attention is paid to what is going on in an individual's life."

One consequence of Bradford's HTS rejection of the medical model is that it relies less on medication. Instead, it prefers non-physical treatment methods devised by user groups themselves. For example, a client experiencing problems with voices will be asked to discuss the voices' content and will be supported in devising ways of coping with them - strategies promoted by The Hearing Voices Network and Action Consultancy and Training, both user-led organisations.

In this way, five times less psychiatric medication is used on Bradford HTS clients than hospital patients. "We only use medication as a short-term effect to relieve anxiety, and in lower doses," says Bracken. He believes Relton's appointment, plus the team's commitment to treat clients at home, represents what it means to practise a fundament ally alternative mental health philosophy.

"We are showing that you really can do mental health work without using psychiatry and psychiatric concepts," he proclaims. "Critics have said our different philosophy could not work in real life. Well, we work in the inner city, not the leafy suburbs of London - and this is as real as it gets.

"We have received very positive reactions. Not just from user organisations, but a growing number of doctors who find traditional psychiatry failing to meet their patients' needs."

The Department of Health has also recognised Bradford HTS's achievements, and, earlier this year, awarded it a "beacon status" for good practice. With this accolade came an extra £25,000 over two years to promote its work to other mental health services around the country.

"This represents the importance of what we are doing here, and, if the mental health service wants to gain more credit from users, it has to give us more say in how things are run," says Relton.

fields.headline: Life and soul
fields.standfirst: Sceptics say the new lottery  grants body has yet to win its  spurs. But the same certainly  could not be said of the  fighter who chairs it. David Brindle reports
fields.trailText: Sceptics say the new lottery grants body has yet to win its spurs. But the same certainly could not be said of the fighter who chairs it. David Brindle reports.
fields.body:
When the New Opportunities Fund launches its "living with cancer" grants programme in the next few days, Jill Pitkeathley will have a special interest. She may now chair the fund and, as Baroness Pitkeathley of Caversham, serve as one of New Labour's working peers, but not so long ago she was fighting - and winning - her own battle with the big C.

Not that she knew she was living with cancer for very long. "I went to the GP, feeling a bit under the weather, on the Tuesday," she recalls. "On the Friday, I was in for surgery."

Pitkeathley, who has just celebrated her 60th birthday, reckons she owes her life to her family doctor. It was only his conviction that she had cancer of the colon, against a specialist's diagnosis of "some minor gynae problem", that forced the hospital to operate. When it did, the surgeon found a large, malignant growth.

Typically, Pitkeathley was back at work within a month of the operation. Then, she was chief executive of the Carers National Association, a charity with plenty of goodwill but rather less cash. Now, she leads an organisation with £1.5bn to spend over four years, but with something of a goodwill deficit to make up.

This stems from the way the New Opportunities Fund, or NOF as it has become known, was set up by the government to use national lottery money to further its policy priorities - in the first instance, healthy living centres, out of school child care and learning activities, computer training for teachers and school librarians, community learning for adults, "green spaces and sustainable communities" and, most controversially, cancer prevention, detection, treatment and care.

It is true that the NHS has long benefited from charitable donations. It is stressed, moreover, that all NOF spending will be additional to government funding and not a substitute for it. But there remains a certain scepticism and the fund has yet to win its spurs, certainly among voluntary sector leaders who had hoped the demise of the millennium commission would mean a bigger share of the lottery pot for the charities' grants board - not creation of a new funding vehicle.

Pitkeathley believes that what she calls the "early suspicions" of the NOF have largely gone. And she is looking to the £23m living with cancer programme to prove the fund's worth in stimulating badly needed projects in areas that would otherwise get no help. As with all the fund's schemes, the aim is to concentrate on deprived communities. But the particular focus this time is on cancer prevention, palliative care and information for minority ethnic groups, or communities including such groups, in response to evidence that existing provision has a bias towards the middle class white population. Up to eight times as many cancer patients are able to die at home in affluent areas as in poor neighbourhoods.

"I didn't know the first thing about the type of cancer I had, even though I had worked in health and social care," says Pitkeathley. "People have got to have as much information as possible to help them care for themselves. They have got to have the confidence to go to a group, or to go to the GP with the symptoms at a very early stage."

She cites a case, from her days with the carers, of a Bangladeshi woman looking after her incontinent mother in law and, because she had no machine, washing the sheets by hand. When put in touch with a local carers' group, the woman found there was a local laundry service specifically for such needs. "Sometimes it's just a matter of pointing people in the right direction," says Pitkeathley.

The grants programme, for England alone on this occasion, will seek to promote information about cancer and cancer services, home care and support for carers. It has been devised with the assistance of leading charities in the field and the NOF is convinced that the voluntary sector is best placed to achieve results.

Pitkeathley says: "I feel very strongly that groups like Bacup and Cancerlink are more sensitive in helping patients find their way through this rather horrendous situation than most doctors can ever be. I remember the young houseman who came to see me, about the second day after surgery, and said he was very sorry to tell me that I had had cancer, but that they had removed the mass and I was really not to worry because 30% of his patients made a full recovery. I thought I would get out just to spite him, actually."

Twelve years later, Pitkeathley is living proof of her own belief that cancer is not just about dying. "They said if I lived five years, I would probably be OK. But the fact is that every time I get an upset stomach, I think: 'Oh, my god!' I am certain I will die of cancer - it's what we do in our family - but I have absolutely no intention of doing it yet."

 The NOF is on 0845-0000120.

I remember the young houseman who came to see me, about the second day after surgery, and said he was very sorry to tell me that I had had cancer, but that they had removed the mass and I was really not to worry because 30% of his patients made a full recovery. I thought I would get out just to spite him, actually." Twelve years later, Pitkeathley is living proof of her own belief that cancer is not just about dying. "They said if I lived five years, I would probably be OK. But the fact is that every time I get an upset stomach, I think: 'Oh, my god!' I am certain I will die of cancer - it's what we do in our family - but I have absolutely no intention of doing it yet."  The NOF is on 0845-0000120.

fields.trailText: Nightly vows of silence meant that monks at a Cistercian sanctuary on Caldey Island, off the Welsh coast, were unable to protest when a visitor got drunk and spent all night singing.
fields.body:
Wedded bliss: A bet placed more than two years ago that Oasis star Liam Gallagher's marriage would last into the new millennium has paid off £1,250 for a punter in Andover, Hampshire.

Cost a packet: Taxpayers will have to foot a £700 bill for court costs after North Tyneside council failed in its prosecution of a man for throwing a crisp packet out of his van window.

Low returns: A cat burglar who climbed the steep roof of a church in Southampton then lowered himself 50 feet on a thin rope made off with less than £5 from the collection box.

Bottled up anger: An experimental course in stress relief at Tunbridge Wells, Kent, includes men smashing movie stunt bottles over each other's heads.

Friendly foe: The kennelman who looks after hounds for the Beaufort hunt, Gloucestershire, has befriended a vixen and feeds it on his doorstep.

One-way ticket: Workers at a garden centre in Crossford, Lanarkshire, stood and watched as thieves masquerading as repair workers loaded a £15,000 miniature Thomas the Tank Engine on to a lorry and drove off.

Zip-zapped: Listeners to Power FM radio in Hampshire were told that the regular DJ was unable to present his show because he had been taken to hospital after getting his private parts caught in his flies.

Swift exit: Speed cameras in Kegworth, Leicestershire, caught a hearse travelling at 98mph in a 60mph zone.

Unspeakably rude: Nightly vows of silence meant that monks at a Cistercian sanctuary on Caldey Island, off the Welsh coast, were unable to protest when a visitor got drunk and spent all night singing.

Pet complaint: An Edinburgh man is suing the local council because 23 of his pet tarantulas died of cold when flooding caused the electricity to be cut off.

Growing interest: More than 600 tourists have booked guided coach tours to see rhubarb growing out of season in sheds in Wakefield, Yorkshire.

Dead money: Housing officers in the royal borough of Kensington and Chelsea have written to a dead man asking for repayment of housing benefit mistakenly paid out to him since he died.

Wrong impression: Police raided a pub in Coventry after a tip-off about a stolen Cezanne painting, but found that it was a copy painted by the landlord.

Smart thinking: The owner of an animal sanctuary in Great Haseley, Oxfordshire, has ordered a Burberry dog coat for a badger whose fur didn't grow back after it moulted.

fields.headline: Beyond despair
fields.standfirst: Rosanna McGlone-Healey went home  after 16 months to find her mother didn't know  her
fields.trailText: Rosanna McGlone-Healey went home after 16 months to find her mother didn't know her.
fields.body:
My mother wears no knickers. Instead, she wears a back-to-front dress and a puzzled expression. I rush to greet her as she stands on the doorstep, seeing but not recognising who she sees. I introduce myself and fix a bright smile on to my face, a smile that remains in place (at least in public) for three long weeks. The lady on the doorstep was once my mother. Her hair has yellowed in the sun. Her wafer-thin skin sags loosely over once proud cheekbones.

And who am I? I'm the prodigal daughter, the one who sought a better life abroad but who can't keep away. Of course, when I left, my mother was like your mother, like all the other mothers in the world. She baked and laughed and wrote long, entertaining letters. But now she is an agitated stranger plucking at a wad of toilet paper held tightly between plum coloured fingers.

Much has changed since my last visit. Sixteen months is a long time when you're in your 80s. Yet, perhaps for my mother, it is no time at all. Days and nights merge into one, punctuated by the comings and goings of others whose lives touch my mother for infinitesimal moments and then are gone.

When I last saw her she was confused and lonely. She understood too much about the deterioration taking place in her mind and cried out in despair. She was a woman fighting to resist the ravages of age. It was a battle she could not win. At least she is no longer lonely. Rather, the table is littered with bread rolls with their tissue paper fillings, waiting for a party which will never happen, for friends who will never come.

My mother is confused. She swears that there are strangers in her house. I am confused. There are strangers in her house. A constant parade of them. Joan and Margaret and Cathy and Marion, Jane and Sue and Eileen. This is the "independent living programme" - the one designed to keep my mother in her own home, to retain her dignity.

It is a strange kind of independence. The knobs on the cooker have been dismantled and hidden. My mother is now a hazard to herself. Instead, she must rely on others for sustenance. Eight o'clock: it must be Joan (or is it Marion?). The grease on mother's chin has barely time to congeal before the arrival of lunch. The meals-on-wheels lady means well - they all do - but there is no time. She sets the table and pushes the unappetising foil containers towards my mother. "Eat up," she calls cheerily as the door slams behind her, caught by the wind. And some days my mother will open the cartons. She enjoys the desserts.

In the fridge is a box of shrivelled mushrooms and a jar of apricot jam. My mother hates apricot jam. I am suddenly enraged that these people, who profess to care for my mother, don't realise that she hates apricot jam. Yet, why should they? Who will tell them? My mother will simply smile, that enigmatic smile which would far outdo the Mona Lisa, and say nothing. Throughout all this my mother sits in her armchair, eyes fixed on a distant patch of green which beckons in the distance.

Carers are not the only ones to visit my mother. Now she speaks of visits by people long dead and of her hopes. It is time, she says, to go upstairs. The metaphor does not reduce the pain. I try not to let the tears start, knowing that if they do they will never stop. I hold her leathery hand and stroke the softened nails, cracked with age.

I even think of returning home. I phone my sister, Brenda."Don't come back," she says firmly. "What could you do?" she mutters. I wonder if she is embarrassed? I know that I'm not being fair, but I don't care. My sister has just recovered from a second heart attack. The doctor thinks it's stress. Of course, he's right. And that is why she tried to warn me and insists that I don't forsake my other life - my life of barbecues, publisher's parties and glasses of Chardonnay quaffed with the papers on a Sunday afternoon. My mind crawls with guilt.

There are happy times. We take my mother to Newstead Abbey, Lord Byron's home. She marvels at the flowers and the beauty in the world, and we marvel with her.

Then it is time to leave. An old lady stands on the doorstep watching curiously as a visitor departs, just one of many. I turn and smile brightly, my heart wet with tears. Inside this stranger, deep inside, is my mother.

fields.headline: Eco soundings
fields.trailText: Canned cod | Eye in the sky | A vet's life
fields.body:
Britain's burgeoning fish farms delivered their latest offering this week - cod fillets from creatures grown on-shore in tanks rather than the open sea. Marks & Spencer started selling the results at £10.39 a kilo, £4.10 a kilo less than conventionally caught cod. Although it will soon rise to £12.99 - about the same as salmon - that price still undercuts other cod by some way. The farm "catch" from the west of Scotland, even in a decade, may only reach 7,500 tonnes, pretty small compared to the 170,000 tonnes of cod we eat each year - just 60,000 caught from our own offshore waters and the rest imported - and well under the 115,000 tonnes of salmon production annually.

But halibut and turbot are also now being farmed. Should we get sniffy over all this, suggest that farmed fish can never taste any good, and warn that intensive aquaculture will soon be as hateful as intensive agriculture? Or should we just give thanks that such farms may help preserve sea supplies dwindling so rapidly that the Irish Sea has become virtually a no-go zone for some fishing? And if the North Sea is getting too hot for cod altogether, how else can we restock the larder for fish and chip shops?

Amid all the gloom at the threat to fishing ports from ever tighter landing quotas, and the despair caused by deaths such as those on the Solway Harvester, should we instead rejoice that at least some new jobs, maybe 100 in five years, are promised on dry land by these developments?

 The crucial question about the London Eye - the huge millennium wheel on the banks of the Thames that should at last start rotating passengers to a fabulous view across London shortly - was asked by the redoubtable Lady Trumpington in the Lords last week: "If the wheel gets stuck, is one meant to wait there for several days or is there a ladder long enough to get one off the top?" Transport minister Lord Whitty gave a rather boring answer about emergency procedures.

 Aren't our vets a gloomy lot? Are they happy at the thought of extra income flowing in from all those clients wanting to take advantage of the relaxation of quarantine laws next month as pet owners queue up to take their cats and dogs on holiday with all the necessary microchipping, anti-rabies jabs and blood tests done? Certainly not. They are instead pondering the consequences of an outbreak of rabies or some other nasty disease if the whole thing goes horribly wrong because cheats slip through spot checks. There really is no pleasing some people.

webTitle: Prisoners' rights: Expert eye on the minutiae

fields.headline: Expert eye on the minutiae
fields.standfirst: Grania Langdon-Down meets the new ombudsman who knows the ins and outs of life in jail
fields.trailText: Grania Langdon-Down meets the new ombudsman who knows the ins and outs of life in jail.
fields.body:
For Stephen Shaw, becoming a civil servant after nearly 20 years working for a penal reform charity has been like joining a "strange brotherhood". For the past three months he has been adjusting to life as the new prisons ombudsman, after 18 years as the tenacious director of the Prison Reform Trust.

While his job of providing prisoners with an independent and effective complaints system holds few terrors - a remit which could be extended to include people on probation under proposed Probation Service reforms - he has yet to feel entirely comfortable with his new working environment.

His capacious, central London office is "a bit of an embarrassment", and the feeling of being an outsider is strong. Shaw, 46, says: "For the first few weeks it felt like joining a strange brotherhood, with its own rules, its own formalities and its own codes - most of them unwritten. I was regarded as rather strange for asking for a two-week period shadowing my predecessor, Sir Peter Woodhead, before I officially started, yet that was invaluable. It's just assumed you will pick it up fairly quickly."

While he may not yet have mastered civil service procedures, the bureaucracy has its upside. "When you are running a charity, you spend a depressingly large amount of time on administration," he says. "Here, I can focus on the job itself."

Despite his impersonal office, he doesn't feel cut off from the reality of prison life. "In 20 years working in the voluntary sector, I didn't reduce the prison population by one," he says. "Now, if I quash an adjudication where a prisoner is serving extra days as a punishment, he can be released in 24 hours, and that is a wonderful feeling."

Shaw's office receives more than 2,000 complaints a year. However, nearly three-quarters are ineligible for investigation - usually because the prisoners, frustrated at delays in the internal complaints system, have failed to go through the correct procedures.

So far, Shaw's impression from the complaints that his office receives is that the Prison Service is "more careless than callous. The grievances that come to me are not about gross abuses of human rights or physical, mental or racial abuse, but about the minutiae of institutional life."

Shaw is concerned that the sort of allegations revealed in the Chief Inspector of Prisons' more damning reports do not come to his office. "Feltham (the young offenders' institution) is arguably the worst prison in the country - though much improved now - and yet we receive fewer than one complaint a year," he points out.

The top security Whitemoor prison has produced the most complaints - nearly 400 - since the ombudsman's office opened in 1994. Wormwood Scrubs, where inmates' allegations of assaults by prison officers are soon to come to trial, generated 124.

The major problem, Shaw says, lies with Prison Service HQ, which is taking six months to review decisions from individual prisons instead of a maximum of six weeks, so clogging up the complaints process.

"The best prisons are not the ones with the fewest complaints," he says. "What I have to do is make my office as relevant to the man serving a week, or to the 16-year-old boy, as it is to the man serving life."

Come October, Shaw will have to deal with the "uncharted territory" of the Human Rights Act, Article 3, for example, outlaws cruel, inhuman and degrading treatment.

"Is holding two people in a cell with a single toilet not screened off sufficiently degrading to breach Article 3?" he wonders. "If a complaint like that came to me, I would have to go on my own judgment as there is no domestic law to help me. It's a bit frightening, but human rights don't stop at the prison gates. If anything, they are more important inside because of inmates' utter dependence on the state."

For Shaw, his visits to prisons as ombudsman have provoked a puzzling depth of feeling about the impoverishment of inmates' lives.

"I don't know if it is because, after being so long in the last job, I became deadened to the reality of it all," he says. "I am not an abolitionist - I think prisons are an unfortunate social necessity. But I am surprised at how forcibly the pain of imprisonment has struck me."

webTitle: Department of Health Annual Social Care Awards

fields.headline: Department of Health Annual Social Care Awards
fields.trailText: A pioneering project to divert children from prostitution has been named overall winner of the first department of health annual social care awards. The multi-agency project, led by Nottingham social services, wins £10,000.
fields.body:
A pioneering project to divert children from prostitution has been named overall winner of the first department of health annual social care awards. The multi-agency project, led by Nottingham social services, wins £10,000.

Other winners, each receiving £5,000, are: the Drugs and Homeless Initiative, Bath; the London children's services inspectors group; Full Body and the Voice theatre company, Huddersfield; the Mencap-led Riverwood Project, London; the Esmi Weekend Day Centre, Stockport; Bristol city council's placement service for deaf children; the St Owen's centre student council, Hereford; Kensington and Chelsea social services dementia team, London.

• The Guardian is to sponsor a national conference on the winning projects in the early spring.

webTitle: Myners takes the helm of GMG

fields.headline: Myners takes the helm of GMG
fields.standfirst: Press release published today by the Scott Trust and Guardian Media Group
fields.trailText: The Scott Trust and Guardian Media Group (GMG) have appointed Paul Myners, 51, as the new chairman of GMG.
fields.body:
The Scott Trust and Guardian Media Group (GMG) have appointed Paul Myners, 51, as the new chairman of GMG.

Paul Myners is chairman of Gartmore Investment Management, an executive director of NatWest and deputy chairman of PowerGen. Until recently he was a non-executive director of Orange. He joins GMG as non-executive chairman on March 1, 2000.

Hugo Young, chairman of the Scott Trust, said: "Paul Myners takes over the chairmanship of GMG at a challenging time for all media businesses. The trust is very pleased to have found such an outstanding businessman, sympathetic to its unique purposes, to succeed Lord Gavron."

Bob Phillis, chief executive of GMG, said Mr Myners had a wealth of business, financial and organisational experience which would be invaluable to the development of GMG. "I am very much looking forward to working with him," he added.

Paul Myners said: "I am delighted to be joining a group which includes papers and magazines I admire and respect. GMG is in a strong position to respond to the challenges and opportunities in a rapidly changing media world. I am looking forward to taking up this position which is in part defender of the principles of the Scott Trust, particularly those of liberalism and independence."

Mr Myners graduated from the University of London in 1970 with a first class honours in education. He wrote on finance for the Daily Telegraph until 1974 when he joined merchant bankers N M Rothschild and Sons. He was appointed to the Rothschild board in 1979. He joined Gartmore as chief executive in 1985 and was appointed chairman in 1987.

He is a city disputes panellist, a member of the Financial Reporting Council and chairman of the Lloyd's of London investment committee.

His previously-held directorships include the Investment Management Regulatory Organisation (IMRO), the Lloyd's Market Board, Celltech, The Scottish National Trust and the Association of Investment Trust Companies, where he was chairman.

He is a member of the advisory council of the London Symphony Orchestra and of the Royal Academy Trust advisory board. He is a vice president of United Response - a charity which cares for people with disabilities - and a fellow of the Royal Society of Arts.

Mr Myners is married with five children and lives in London and Cornwall.

He succeeds Lord Gavron, who took on the chairmanship for three years in January 1997 and retires at the end of February.

 Hugo Young has been re-elected by the Scott Trust to remain as its chairman for a further five years.

 Guardian Media Group plc is a UK media business with interests in national newspapers, regional and local newspapers, magazines, television and radio. The company is wholly owned by the Scott Trust.

The Scott Trust, founded in 1936, exists to protect the independence and quality of its newspapers, and ensures that all the profits of GMG plc are reinvested in the business. Membership is evenly divided between those who work for GMG and a group of distinguished outsiders.

The trust is very pleased to have found such an outstanding businessman, sympathetic to its unique purposes, to succeed Lord Gavron." Bob Phillis, chief executive of GMG, said Mr Myners had a wealth of business, financial and organisational experience which would be invaluable to the development of GMG. "I am very much looking forward to working with him," he added. Paul Myners said: "I am delighted to be joining a group which includes papers and magazines I admire and respect. GMG is in a strong position to respond to the challenges and opportunities in a rapidly changing media world. I am looking forward to taking up this position which is in part defender of the principles of the Scott Trust, particularly those of liberalism and independence." Mr Myners graduated from the University of London in 1970 with a first class honours in education. He wrote on finance for the Daily Telegraph until 1974 when he joined merchant bankers N M Rothschild and Sons. He was appointed to the Rothschild board in 1979. He joined Gartmore as chief executive in 1985 and was appointed chairman in 1987. He is a city disputes panellist, a member of the Financial Reporting Council and chairman of the Lloyd's of London investment committee. His previously-held directorships include the Investment Management Regulatory Organisation (IMRO), the Lloyd's Market Board, Celltech, The Scottish National Trust and the Association of Investment Trust Companies, where he was chairman. He is a member of the advisory council of the London Symphony Orchestra and of the Royal Academy Trust advisory board. He is a vice president of United Response - a charity which cares for people with disabilities - and a fellow of the Royal Society of Arts. Mr Myners is married with five children and lives in London and Cornwall. He succeeds Lord Gavron, who took on the chairmanship for three years in January 1997 and retires at the end of February.  Hugo Young has been re-elected by the Scott Trust to remain as its chairman for a further five years.  Guardian Media Group plc is a UK media business with interests in national newspapers, regional and local newspapers, magazines, television and radio. The company is wholly owned by the Scott Trust. The Scott Trust, founded in 1936, exists to protect the independence and quality of its newspapers, and ensures that all the profits of GMG plc are reinvested in the business. Membership is evenly divided between those who work for GMG and a group of distinguished outsiders.

fields.headline: More interest rates hikes expected
fields.standfirst:
Minutes from the bank of England
Institute of fiscal studies green budget 2000
fields.trailText: Interest rates should rise or the economy will pay the price with inflation, a financial think tank warned today.
fields.body:
Interest rates should rise or the economy will pay the price with inflation, a financial think tank warned today.

The institute of fiscal studies (IFS) says that the economy has grown so quickly that recession fears at the start of last year has given way to concerns that the government will overshoot its inflationary target.

In a further blow to homeowners, the bank of England says that interests rates are likely to rise.

Minutes from the monetary policy committee, which set interest rates, say that members were torn between a big rise in January or a series of small hikes throughout the year.

Last week's 0.25% rise put interest rates at their current level of 5.75% and increased monthly mortgage repayments for homeowners with variable rate loans.

Inflation, however, is still low and the underlying rate of inflation in December, which excludes the cost of mortgage borrowing, was 2.2%, unchanged from last month. In a separate report, the council of mortgage lenders said that the number of property repossessions in 1999 was the lowest for 10 years.

Low interest rates and low unemployment have helped to minimise the risk of a return to the payment difficulties of the early 1990s, said director general Peter Williams.

The IFS report, called the Green Budget, predicts economic trends for the year ahead and sees scope for further spending increases or tax cuts as the chancellor Gordon Brown sits on an estimated £6.8bn spending surplus.

The chancellor can allow for a £3bn tax cut, the institute says.

Public spending is likely to fall as a proportion of GDP as the booming economy feeds larger tax returns into the treasury and the large number of people in work cuts welfare spending. It adds that if the government does meet its target of a 5% increase in spending on the NHS, healthcare spending will still be some way below the EU average.

fields.headline: Robinson denies TransTec impropriety
fields.standfirst:
Former minister insists collapsed company did not mislead government over grant applications

Listen to excerpts from Geoffrey Robinson's Today interview
Sound clip 1: 'These grants, quite properly, were subject to detailed review'
Sound clip 2: 'There has been no impropriety in any respect'
fields.trailText: Former treasury minister Geoffrey Robinson today denied that he had done anything wrong as the government widened its inquiry into the collapse of his engineering company TransTec.
fields.body:
Former treasury minister Geoffrey Robinson today denied that he had done anything wrong as the government widened its inquiry into the collapse of his engineering company TransTec.

In his first interview since the government launched an investigation into TransTec, Mr Robinson told BBC Radio 4's Today programme that there had been "no impropriety" in the way the company applied for government grants. He also dismissed any suggestion that he knew about a £12m legal action by the Ford motor company which precipitated TransTec's downfall last Christmas.

The former paymaster-general, who resigned from the government in 1998 over an undeclared home loan to then DTI secretary Peter Mandelson, admitted that he had no chance of rejoining the government until official investigations into TransTec had been completed. Last night the government said its investigation could be expanded to cover the company's entire history, including its links with the late Robert Maxwell. Initially, trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers said the inquiry would look specifically only at the collapse of TransTec.

The DTI inquiry will investigate allegations that TransTec misled the government about £1m in government grants it had received since 1987. The company's former accountant, Max Ayriss, claimed last week that TransTec had broken the "spirit" of DTI awards by deliberately inflating some of its applications.

Mr Robinson insisted today that the company's position had been set out in a letter released to the media by two directors last night. "They have made it absolutely clear that there was no impropriety concerned," he said. "We have carried through a thorough technical review ourselves. Most importantly, these grants - quite properly - were subject to detailed review, technically and in the amounts that were claimed, by the department of trade and industry itself and they were satisfied."

He said of Mr Ayriss: "He's incorrect, and it's as simple as that."

The letter released last night, signed by former TransTec directors including the managing director Sami Ahmed, denied accusations that the company had obtained government grants in an "irregular" fashion. They accused other senior staff at the firm of trying to "smear" Mr Robinson.

Grants "were correctly and fully accounted for and all procedures relating to them were properly observed", the letter said. "The DTI not only inspected and approved all claims submitted, which were in turn vetted by our auditors, as required, but also thoroughly evaluated the work carried out and the equipment developed."

Mr Ayriss claimed Mr Robinson had instructed him on how to "maximise" grant claims, boosting totals by a "five-figure sum". He also claimed Mr Robinson had obtained a £30,000 grant from the DTI to buy a factory building which he was not planning to occupy and simply wanted to let.

Mr Ayriss said that while the claim may not have been strictly illegal, it was clearly against the spirit of the DTI regional grants which were intended to help new businesses set up.

Today, asked whether he was prepared to swear in court that all the grants were correct, Mr Robinson said: "Insofar as TransTec is concerned the answer is an unequivocal yes."

fields.headline: Mortgage mis-selling
fields.trailText: Why is there so much concern about the mortgage industry?
fields.body:
Why is there so much concern about the mortgage industry?

A mortgage is the largest single purchase most of us ever make, yet the mortgage industry has had no single regulator and the complex range of packages on offer - from variable to fixed-rate, via endowment and repayment mortgages - means that many homeowners have bought home loans that are entirely unsuitable for their financial needs.

Complaints to the banking ombudsman about mortgages leapt by 46% last year, with disputes including grievances about early redemption penalties, allegedly poor advice, unacceptable tie-ins of insurance products and customers being penalised with unfair terms and hidden charges.

What have the main problems been?

The alleged large-scale mis-selling of endowment mortgages has been a major cause for concern in an industry which made £11bn profit last year. These are investment funds which are intended to mature at the end of the mortgage period, providing sufficient funds to cover the cost of the mortgage. Many homeowners have found that their endowment will not be enough to cover the mortgage and up to half a million homeowners will have to pay thousands of pounds extra to make up the difference.

What else?

Lenders have been tackled over punitive arrears charges, giving unclear product information and selling the unpopular mortgage indemnity guarantee insurance, which reimburses the lender if the borrower fails to meet repayments and it makes a loss, but does not benefit the homeowner.

Mortgage advisers have also been accused of giving biased and inaccurate advice to home loan customers. The treasury's website lists the "top 10 scams" by unscrupulous mortgage lenders, including hidden charges and small print that catches the homeowner out.

So what happens now?

Melanie Johnson, economic secretary to the treasury, has announced a new package of measures to protect borrowers from unfair or restrictive lending practices. Listen to her interview on the Today programme.

The plans for a shake-up in the regulatory system include tightening the rules governing the mortgage market and bringing the industry under the regulation of the UK's main financial watchdog, the Financial Services Authority (FSA), headed by chairman Howard Davies.

What will this mean for the mortgage industry?

The FSA will authorise all mortgage lenders, regulate mortgage advertising and require lenders to disclose all the main features of loans clearly and openly. Until now, complaints about mortgages were dealt with by the banking and building society ombudsmen.

The authority will have powers to fine lenders who mis-sell mortgages, force them to pay compensation to homeowners and even to ban them from selling mortgages. It will be illegal to sell mortgages without the approval of the FSA. The watchdog will have a statutory duty to improve public understanding of all financial products, by for instance providing information tables to help consumers to compare products.

What about direct help for consumers looking to buy a mortgage?

There will also be new voluntary CAT - or charges, access and terms - standards for the mortgage industry: a benchmark for basic standards of simple home loans, showing which products meet the minimum standards, including clear terms and conditions.

Among the other chief requirements are that variable rate mortgages must track the bank base rate and have no penalties for paying off the loan early; for fixed and capped-rate mortgages, early redemption penalties must not extend beyond the end of the offer period; interest must be calculated daily rather than annually; and there must be no obligation on the borrower to buy any other "tied-in" product.

Do the new regulations cover the entire home loan industry?

No they don't, and consumer groups, such as Which?, fear the regulations will not go far enough. They are unhappy that Britain's 43,000 mortgage advisers will not be regulated. Many consumers are unaware that while some mortgage advisers offer independent advice, others are employed to sell the investment products of only one company.

Also excluded are home loans below £25,000, which will remain covered by the existing consumer credit act, whether they are for a second mortgage or a personal loan secured on a property.

When will the new regulations come into force?

Not until the summer of 2001, to allow time for lenders to put their house in order as it were - although the voluntary CAT standards will come into force with almost immediate effect.

How has the mortgage industry reacted?

After a lengthy consultation process, major lenders are expected to welcome most of the changes, but the Council of Mortgage Lenders, the industry's trade association, has called for all mortgages to be regulated, arguing that the exclusion of loans below £25,000 is an "expensive anomaly".

The FSA's own consumer panel fears the regulations will not go far enough to protect consumers. There is also a danger that the proposed minimum standards could be misinterpreted by the public as amounting to a "government guarantee" of good value or suitability. Mortgage buyers are still advised to shop around, take professional advice and find a mortgage suitable to their financial needs.

Financial Services Authority

Council of Mortgage Lenders

webTitle: Straw's freeing of Pinochet 'unlawful and irrational'

fields.headline: Straw's freeing of Pinochet 'unlawful and irrational'
fields.standfirst: Belgium begins court bid to block dictator's return to Chile
fields.trailText: Home secretary Jack Straw would be acting "unlawfully and irrationally" if he allowed former dictator Augusto Pinochet to return to Chile on health grounds without allowing opponents to know the medical reasons and have a proper opportunity to mount legal challenges, a High Court judge was told today.
fields.body:
Home secretary Jack Straw would be acting "unlawfully and irrationally" if he allowed former dictator Augusto Pinochet to return to Chile on health grounds without allowing opponents to know the medical reasons and have a proper opportunity to mount legal challenges, a High Court judge was told today.

The accusation was made by Presiley Baxendale QC, who was applying on behalf of Belgium for permission to seek judicial review of the government's "failure" to assure the Belgian authorities that the 84-year-old would not be sent home before Britain had complied with its international legal obligations to co-operate with other countries wanting to extradite Pinochet.

Both Belgium and six human-rights groups are arguing that Mr Straw should have given them access to the findings of a team of medical experts who examined the Gen Pinochet earlier this month.

Belgium is claiming that as one of the states seeking Gen Pinochet's extradition, it should have been allowed to see the medical evidence behind Mr Straw's decision that he was "minded" to allow the former dictator to go home. It also contends that it should also be given the chance to have a Belgian doctor present at a further examination of Gen Pinochet.

Ms Baxendale said: "It's a breach of natural justice if Belgium could not make meaningful representations because they couldn't see the medical records.

"It was irrational because at one and the same time the secretary of state was asking Belgium to make representations and refusing to disclose the details of the report.

"There was no overriding principle of medical confidentiality. That was only one factor to be taken into the balance and could be overridden by the interests of justice."

The human-rights groups, including Amnesty International, Human Rights Watch, the Medical Foundation for the Care of Victims of Torture, the Redress Trust, the Association of Relatives of the Disappeared and Justicia also believe the panel of experts should have included an old-age psychiatrist and should have taken longer than seven hours to reach its diagnosis.

Belgium is trying to extradite Gen Pinochet on the basis of claims from Chileans living in Belgium that he was behind the jailing and killing of their relatives.

In a court packed with the world's press, Ms Baxendale told Mr Justice Maurice Kay that the home secretary, by halting extradition proceedings, was in danger of breaching international law and conventions.

The QC said mutual assistance was provided-for under the 1959 European Convention on Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters, under which signatories undertook to provide each other with "the widest measure of mutual assurance in proceedings in respect of offences, the punishment of which falls within the jurisdiction [of the requesting country]."

Mr Straw has undertaken not make a final decision on whether to allow Gen Pinochet to return to Chile while the current challenge is heard by the courts. A plane sent from Chile to bring him home is still in Bermuda awaiting a decision by the home secretary.

Before the hearing proper began today, Mr Justice Kay disclosed to the court a potential link between himself and one of the parties, Amnesty International.

He said 10 or more years ago, it had been suggested to him that he was on a list of counsel "approved" by the human rights organisation and there had once been a suggestion of him working on a case for it.

He said that was the "sum detail" of the connection, but added: "In case someone finds my name in a file I thought I ought to raise it now." No objections were raised to the judge continuing to hear today's application.

Mr Justice Kay's openness follows the unprecedented challenge to the House of Lords' first ruling in the Pinochet case when a judgment had to be set aside after it was disclosed one of the panel of law lords, Lord Hoffmann, had long standing links with Amnesty.

fields.headline: England's youthful problem
fields.trailText: One of the more desperate theories circulating after last summer's debacle is that England's youth system is wonderful. After all, say the dreamers, the A team has a superb record. And, until very recently, we were Under-19 world champions. If we could carry this success through to senior level, goes the argument, then the Barmy Army really would have something to sing about.
fields.body:
One of the more desperate theories circulating after last summer's debacle is that England's youth system is wonderful. After all, say the dreamers, the A team has a superb record. And, until very recently, we were Under-19 world champions. If we could carry this success through to senior level, goes the argument, then the Barmy Army really would have something to sing about.

One of the other straws that we are clutching to, now the establishment has cottoned on to the fact that British Asians actually are barmy about cricket, is that we might stumble upon our own Shoaib Akhtar or Sachin Tendulkar.

Asif Mulla, Shahid Hussain, and Ashish Bagai did indeed play in the Under-19 World Cup, and they weren't playing for the South Asian teams. Unfortunately, nobody with a name like that was playing for England either. They represented the Americas, one of the two sides that our reigning world champs managed to beat. The other was mighty Nepal.

So what is going wrong? It beggars belief that there isn't a young Asian cricketer who is up to it. This is the system that gave us Nasser Hussain, Mark Ramprakash, and Owais Shah, the Karachi-born Middlesex player who led England Under-19s to victory last time around, in South Africa.

My own theory is that the demise of cricket in state schools is to blame. Public schools and club cricket are not natural homes for Asian cricketers, and they remain the two main channels to representative level.

The other issue is whether Asian youngsters are less likely to get selected for, and from, trials. I suspect, regrettably, this is still the case. And, if Asians are getting missed then so are a whole generation of less privileged and less well-connected black kids and white kids.

Most of the top Indian and Pakistani players come from incredibly poor backgrounds, despite the huge inequalities in those societies. If they had been born in England, however, they might never have been picked for their club 1st XI, just because they wouldn't have fitted in.

'Aye, that Paki lad Akhtar's sharp but sprays it. He's better off in the seconds. He needs a haircut as well,' a sage of club cricket might have said.

You can't say that Asians are slow developers. India, Pakistan, and Sri Lanka were three of the semi-finalists in the current tournament. And Tim Boon noted how far ahead of our team they were, lamenting EnglandÕs inability to play spin. The Under-15 World Cup final in 1996 was between India and Pakistan. David English, vice-president of ESCA and founder of Bunbury's CC, spotted the same problem then in more or less the same bunch of players.

While English cricket, at all levels, has been short of solutions that reach out to the Asian community (and we wait optimistically for change after the ECB's report on racism), the national and junior teams have arrived at an identical conclusion: English cricketers can't play spin, and must play more often in South Asia. That would be a good move. We've spent too long paying for the legacy of Fat Gatt's finger-wagging: a continuous diet of South Africa and Australia. As Madhur Jaffrey would say, a touch of spice works wonders for a bland recipe.

Kamran Abbasi, born in Lahore, brought up in Rotherham, is assistant editor of the British Medical Journal. His Anglo-Asian View appears every other Wednesday on Cricket Unlimited and wisden.com. Next Wednesday Orin Gordon returns with his Anglo-Caribbean View.

Unfortunately, nobody with a name like that was playing for England either. They represented the Americas, one of the two sides that our reigning world champs managed to beat. The other was mighty Nepal. So what is going wrong? It beggars belief that there isn't a young Asian cricketer who is up to it. This is the system that gave us Nasser Hussain, Mark Ramprakash, and Owais Shah, the Karachi-born Middlesex player who led England Under-19s to victory last time around, in South Africa. My own theory is that the demise of cricket in state schools is to blame. Public schools and club cricket are not natural homes for Asian cricketers, and they remain the two main channels to representative level. The other issue is whether Asian youngsters are less likely to get selected for, and from, trials. I suspect, regrettably, this is still the case. And, if Asians are getting missed then so are a whole generation of less privileged and less well-connected black kids and white kids. Most of the top Indian and Pakistani players come from incredibly poor backgrounds, despite the huge inequalities in those societies. If they had been born in England, however, they might never have been picked for their club 1st XI, just because they wouldn't have fitted in. 'Aye, that Paki lad Akhtar's sharp but sprays it. He's better off in the seconds. He needs a haircut as well,' a sage of club cricket might have said. You can't say that Asians are slow developers. India, Pakistan, and Sri Lanka were three of the semi-finalists in the current tournament. And Tim Boon noted how far ahead of our team they were, lamenting EnglandÕs inability to play spin. The Under-15 World Cup final in 1996 was between India and Pakistan. David English, vice-president of ESCA and founder of Bunbury's CC, spotted the same problem then in more or less the same bunch of players. While English cricket, at all levels, has been short of solutions that reach out to the Asian community (and we wait optimistically for change after the ECB's report on racism), the national and junior teams have arrived at an identical conclusion: English cricketers can't play spin, and must play more often in South Asia. That would be a good move. We've spent too long paying for the legacy of Fat Gatt's finger-wagging: a continuous diet of South Africa and Australia. As Madhur Jaffrey would say, a touch of spice works wonders for a bland recipe. Kamran Abbasi, born in Lahore, brought up in Rotherham, is assistant editor of the British Medical Journal. His Anglo-Asian View appears every other Wednesday on Cricket Unlimited and wisden.com. Next Wednesday Orin Gordon returns with his Anglo-Caribbean View.

fields.headline: Boo sale risks sneers
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Boo.com, the global online sportswear retailer, will tomorrow start discounting merchandise by up to 40%.
fields.body:
Boo.com, the global online sportswear retailer, will tomorrow start discounting merchandise by up to 40%.

The company, which previously committed not to offer discounts to protect brands such as the North Face, Paul Smith and Helly Hansen, maintains that the sale is a long-planned opportunity that any off-line retailer would take to clear out goods from the autumn/winter 99 range in preparation for the arrival of spring 2000 clothing.

But the question being asked in London's internet scene is whether the sell-off is evidence that Boo.com is still struggling to overcome the technical problems that delayed its launch by five months. The hitches have prevented many potential customers from using its ambitious service.

No other British internet start-up has attracted quite the same attention and expectation as Boo.com. But then none has a story quite as glamorous.

Young, wealthy, ambitious and cosmopolitan, Boo - based in Regent Street, London - is much like the internet-savvy, fashion-conscious consumers it is targeting.

Its founders are Ernst Malmsten and former model Kajsa Leander, two 28-year-old Swedish veterans of the web who set up bookus.com, an internet bookstore.

Their backers include LVMH chairman Bernard Arnault, the Benetton family and Goldman Sachs who, with other shareholders, are rumoured to have invested as much as £80m in venture capital money - a record for a European start-up. Around 40 leading brands are for sale on the site.

Boo's target market is global, offering an interactive shopping service in seven languages that serves 18 countries and is supported by two logistics centres, one in Cologne, the other in Kentucky.

Combined with a slick marketing campaign, a front cover in Fortune magazine and television advertising directed by the man behind DJ Fatboy Slim's videos, Boo has never lacked profile. So when technological problems delayed its launch, rivals sneeringly claimed that the concept had been over ambitious and ill conceived.

Mr Malmsten admits that Boo has had its technical problems, but insists that they are being overcome and that the site's fulfilment record, one of the crucial measures of the success of any online retailer, is "world class".

"Selfridges and Harrods have sales just like this," he said.

"Boo has become a controversial company. Many people hate us but our customers love us. The expectations placed on us were enormous. We had problems with the front end of our website but those are now solved and new improved versions of the site will be unveiled soon."

Mr Malmsten added that a recent report by investment bank CSFB on Christmas online shopping ranked Boo.com as the No 1 retail site in the US in overall e-commerce terms. "Ninety-nine per cent of orders placed by December 21 were delivered by Christmas Eve," he said.

Mr Malmsten dismissed rumours that some of Boo's 400 plus staff have started to defect to other start-up ventures because of frustration with the technical problems.

"The person originally brought in to design the site has been replaced but if anything we have strengthened our team bringing in staff from major internationals like Adidas, GAP and BSkyB," said Mr Malmsten.

The critics say that Boo's refusal to reveal any details of revenues, user numbers or break-even targets contributes to the overall scepticism about the company. Mr Malmsten says that he is confident Boo's targets will be met. He says resources are plentiful.

"It's as if they have something to hide," said one leading internet entrepreneur.

Mr Malmsten says that it is company policy never to discuss its finances but acknowledges that until it does, the boos, unfair or otherwise, will continue.

webTitle: Thriller masks deeper problems for England

fields.headline: Thriller masks deeper problems for England
fields.trailText: This was the thriller that should never have been. When Chris Adams fell for 42 to leave England 152 for 7, the required run-rate was already seven an over. At the crease was one man who couldn't get the ball off the square and another who must have forgotten what a square looked like. But Mark Ealham improvised and Chris Read took out a tour-worth's frustration on the unsuspecting South African bowlers. And in the end England almost did it.
fields.body:
This was the thriller that should never have been. When Chris Adams fell for 42 to leave England 152 for 7, the required run-rate was already seven an over. At the crease was one man who couldn't get the ball off the square and another who must have forgotten what a square looked like. But Mark Ealham improvised and Chris Read took out a tour-worth's frustration on the unsuspecting South African bowlers. And in the end England almost did it.

By reducing the margin of defeat to one run, Ealham and Read did more than force every hack in the press box to revise their copy: they made us forget what had gone before. Because, ignoring for a moment Darren Gough's failure to hit the final ball to the boundary, the damage had been done earlier, when England's static middle order let things drift alarmingly. Between overs 31 and 38, no shot brought more than a single; and between overs 31 and 47, there was no boundary. Where did it go wrong?

England are over-reliant on their top three, Nick Knight, Nasser Hussain and Graeme Hick. South Africa know that if they can get rid of that trio, then the game is theirs. And England know they know. How they could have done with Alec Stewart.

England's excuse for omitting the Gaffer is that they are building for the next World Cup in 2003. (Presumably they feel that Adams will have become an international force by then.) So why drop one of the players who might be there (Graeme Swann) for another who will surely not (Mark Alleyne)? Vikram Solanki may be a move in the right direction, although he was overawed today. But a middle-order containing Adams, Craig White and Ealham is crying out for a pusher and a nurdler to keep the board ticking over. Between them, Solanki, Adams, Alleyne and White scored 67 runs off 134 balls. That's one run every other delivery when they needed to score twice as quickly. Graham Thorpe must return next summer.

The bowling is less of a concern, although White is flattered at first-change, and Alleyne can't always be relied upon for ten overs. But the gap between Gough and Caddick and the rest remains too big: an international side must be able to do more than muddle through the middle overs.

After the high of Bloemfontein, this wasn't quite a case of going from the sublime to the supine. But the warning signs are there.

Lawrence Booth is assistant editor of wisden.com

fields.headline: Government regulates mortgage industry
fields.trailText: The government today tightened regulation of the mortgage industry by bringing the sector under the purview of the financial services authority.
fields.body:
The government today tightened regulation of the mortgage industry by bringing the sector under the purview of the financial services authority.

Melanie Johnson, economic secretary to the treasury, announced that the FSA would regulate mortgage advertising and require lenders to disclose all the main features of loans clearly and openly, including the "small print". The FSA will now begin preparations to bring these changes into effect next year.

The decision follows widespread complaints about the industry on subjects ranging from misselling of endowment mortgages to costly tie-ins of insurance products to home loans. Under the plans outlined today, the government will also set benchmark standards for variable and fixed rate or capped home loans which will come into force with almost immediate effect. These standards will be voluntary and not all mortgages will, or necessarily should, meet them.

The standards will tell borrowers what they can expect of the products to enable them to make more informed mortgage choices. Ms Johnson said: "Our promise to homebuyers is this: 'You will know how much you have to pay every month. You will know up front what you will pay to move your mortgage and you will know how much it will cost to get out of your mortgage early'."

Until now, the mortgage industry had governed itself using a system of voluntary codes. Consumers have criticised the mortgage industry's charges and practices in recent years and the FSA, the financial sector's main regulator, is expected to control these areas more tightly.

Mortgage bank stocks have underperformed the wider market significantly in the last year amid fears that the regulators and new competitors could further squeeze profits in a sector already pressured by falling margins.

The government started to look at the £500bn mortgage industry last summer as part of its campaign against "rip-off Britain". It examined whether home buyers faced punitive lock-in terms, hidden charges and compulsory insurance when taking out mortgages.

The council of mortgage lenders, which operates the current voluntary code for the industry, favours putting the FSA in charge of regulation. The bigger players are apparently happy to see statutory regulation, but small independent operators are likely to find compliance expensive.

fields.headline: Barney and the beehive
fields.standfirst: Jonathan Romney on cinema as art
fields.trailText: Here's something truly novel - an art object that features credits for a buffalo wrangler and a bee trainer. Cremaster 2, by American artist Matthew Barney, is very much an object - an elaborately crafted, infinitely strange thing that you watch much as you might walk around a complex sculpture, puzzling out how the parts fit together. But it's also a movie - not a scrappy artist's video but a 79-minute film with special effects, stars and a story, or fragments of one.
fields.body:
Here's something truly novel - an art object that features credits for a buffalo wrangler and a bee trainer. Cremaster 2, by American artist Matthew Barney, is very much an object - an elaborately crafted, infinitely strange thing that you watch much as you might walk around a complex sculpture, puzzling out how the parts fit together. But it's also a movie - not a scrappy artist's video but a 79-minute film with special effects, stars and a story, or fragments of one.

Cremaster 2 - actually the fourth in the series - even has a pitch, of sorts. It's about the master escapologist Harry Houdini and Gary Gilmore, who committed two murders in Utah in 1976 and was subsequently executed at his own insistence. One connection is that Gilmore's grandmother, Baby Fay La Foe, claimed to have had a liaison with Houdini. Another is that Houdini is played by Gilmore's biog- rapher Norman Mailer, whose book The Executioner's Song appears to be one of Barney's sources.

The film begins with an ominously swelling organ chord, as the camera pulls out on what first appears to be a landscape, then proves to be a strange horned sculpture made out of small plates of glass or plastic. We cut to an ice floe, then to a meeting between Baby Fay and a couple who plunge their hands into a curious table, one of Barney's idiosyncratically sculpted objects, half art deco, half surgical. Then comes the strangest penetration shot ever - a close-up with shaven pudenda, transparent bondage girdle and a pair of bee wings.

In a recording studio, a drummer thrashes out a beat to the sound of 200,000 honey bees buzzing. The images unfold, getting progressively stranger and more lavish. Gilmore takes part in a rodeo on the Utah salt flats; Houdini does his act in a giant beehive; even the Mormon Tabernacle Choir make an appearance. So what does it all mean?

That's not really the question. The question is: how does Barney persuade us into fascinated speculation about what it might mean? This is the dazzling illusionist's trick of his intensely hermetic Cremaster films. They all partake of arcane ritual performance and are all based on a nexus of local culture or myth (here of Utah, elsewhere of Hungary or the Isle of Man), which is turned inside out, bent into an anagram of itself. So, apart from the tenuous Gilmore-Houdini connection, the film plays on Utah as a Mormon state that has a beehive as its emblem. The bees, if you like, cross-pollinate the imagery: hive structures, drone sounds, wax and pollen. But there are also references to other Barney motifs: notably the infinitely adaptable Cremaster logo, which forms the basis for 12 "Tribes of Israel" flags and the shape of the rodeo arena. The logo is everywhere - we're looking at a self-enclosed mythical world in which the existence of everything is determined by its part in the Cremaster project.

Barney boldly risks alienating his audience, yet the result proves irresistibly involving: you want to get to the bottom of the riddle, even while accepting that you never might, and that the riddle may have no bottom anyway. The films are so riveting because Barney uses cinematic resources as imaginatively as anyone currently working, from Peter Strietmann's lushly precise digital photography onwards.

Then there are all the questions Barney poses about the way a film fits together: are we getting fragments of an overall coherent story, or just a succession of bizarre images whose connections we have to take on trust? Is this a story with real relations of time and space, or are these ineffably weird tableaux linked like the cells of a beehive, parts of a bigger network?

The trade journal Variety, stumped for a category, classified Cremaster 2 as "experimental drama" - what else could you call a genre-crossing mixture that partakes of sci-fi, costume drama, real-crime TV movie, hard porn and tourist documentary? Cremaster 2 should finally establish Barney as not just an artist playing at film, but one of the most important new film-makers. But that's what infuriates me about Cremaster. Make films, as Barney does, with money from the art market, and categorise it as art, and there's no limit to where you can let your imagination go. But make them within the film industry, and call them movies, and you're obliged to saddle yourself with coherent narrative, proper characters and upbeat endings. If only the Cremaster series, and works like it, could have a knock- on effect in the film industry, the mainstream could profitably get a little stranger, and a lot freer.

 Cremaster 2 is at the Metro Cinema, London W1 (0171-734 1506), from Friday.

webTitle: War crimes conviction was based on unreliable evidence, appeal court told

fields.headline: War crimes conviction was based on unreliable evidence, appeal court told
fields.standfirst: Special report: Nazi war criminals in Britain
fields.trailText: The trial of a man convicted of murdering Jews in Britain's only successful war crimes prosecution should not have gone ahead because the evidence against him was unreliable and insubstantial, the appeal court heard yesterday.
fields.body:
The trial of a man convicted of murdering Jews in Britain's only successful war crimes prosecution should not have gone ahead because the evidence against him was unreliable and insubstantial, the appeal court heard yesterday.

Anthony Sawoniuk, 78, was sentenced to life imprisonment last April, 57 years after the alleged killings in his home town of Domachevo, Belarus, chiefly on the eyewitness accounts of two local men who said they had seen him shooting Jews

But one of the men who testified against him had been 12 at the time and had not mentioned the atrocity to anyone, including Soviet war crimes investigators, before detectives from Scotland Yard's war crimes unit interviewed him in 1996, the hearing heard.

Another witness who claimed he had seen Sawoniuk shoot 15 Jewish women, had been hiding in bushes 130 yards from the killing site. William Clegg, for Sawoniuk, said: "It's a distance greater than the length of a premier league pitch. This is evidence of observation in uncertain light, in difficult conditions and over a very great distance by a man anxious to remain hidden."

Mr Clegg said the prosecution of Sawoniuk, a retired rail worker from Bermondsey, south east London, had been an abuse of process.

He said the trial judge, Mr Justice Potts, had erred in law by allowing the case to proceed and had been wrong to allow the jury to hear allegations of criminal behaviour by Sawoniuk which were not related to charges he was facing.

Sawoniuk was convicted on two counts of murder, involving the death of 18 Jews, at the end of an eight-week trial at the Old Bailey. Two other charges were dismissed for lack of evidence.

The Old Bailey heard that Sawoniuk had been recruited by the Nazis to police Domachevo, a spa town near the Polish border, following the German invasion in 1941. He had turned from a peasant into "a lord, a master" and had led "search and kill" death squads to hunt down Jews.

Mr Clegg told the lord chief justice, Lord Bingham, sitting with Mr Justice Tucker and Mrs Justice Hallett, that a fair trial was not possible because evidence had been lost and witnesses had died since the alleged murders.

He referred to the account of Alexander Baglay, who told the jury he had seen Sawoniuk shoot two men and a woman.

Mr Clegg said three other witnesses to the incident had died, so his claims could not be tested properly. He said that Mr Baglay had not mentioned the shooting to Soviet war crimes investigators who visited Domachevo after the war.

Mr Clegg said the evidence against Sawoniuk on the second count was "disturbing". The witness, Fedor Zan, who had seen Sawoniuk allegedly shooting a group of 15 women in woodland, had been so far away that "it must have been on the very cusp of his powers to have recognised anyone."

Sawoniuk, who is blind in one eye and diabetic, watched from the dock.

The hearing continues.
