Mr Clegg said the prosecution of Sawoniuk, a retired rail worker from Bermondsey, south east London, had been an abuse of process. He said the trial judge, Mr Justice Potts, had erred in law by allowing the case to proceed and had been wrong to allow the jury to hear allegations of criminal behaviour by Sawoniuk which were not related to charges he was facing. Sawoniuk was convicted on two counts of murder, involving the death of 18 Jews, at the end of an eight-week trial at the Old Bailey. Two other charges were dismissed for lack of evidence. The Old Bailey heard that Sawoniuk had been recruited by the Nazis to police Domachevo, a spa town near the Polish border, following the German invasion in 1941. He had turned from a peasant into "a lord, a master" and had led "search and kill" death squads to hunt down Jews. Mr Clegg told the lord chief justice, Lord Bingham, sitting with Mr Justice Tucker and Mrs Justice Hallett, that a fair trial was not possible because evidence had been lost and witnesses had died since the alleged murders. He referred to the account of Alexander Baglay, who told the jury he had seen Sawoniuk shoot two men and a woman. Mr Clegg said three other witnesses to the incident had died, so his claims could not be tested properly. He said that Mr Baglay had not mentioned the shooting to Soviet war crimes investigators who visited Domachevo after the war. Mr Clegg said the evidence against Sawoniuk on the second count was "disturbing". The witness, Fedor Zan, who had seen Sawoniuk allegedly shooting a group of 15 women in woodland, had been so far away that "it must have been on the very cusp of his powers to have recognised anyone." Sawoniuk, who is blind in one eye and diabetic, watched from the dock. The hearing continues.

fields.headline: American Psycho hits Sundance
fields.standfirst: Also today, Redford's internet doom and gloom | French Catholics threaten 'blasphemous' Dogma | Jodie and Russell get cosy at the Globes, and Keanu Reeves to play a furniture salesman
fields.trailText: A preview screening at the Sundance Film Festival might have been greeted with polite applause and shuffling of feet but the word on the web is that American Psycho is going to be this year's Fight Club.
fields.body:
A preview screening at the Sundance Film Festival might have been greeted with polite applause and shuffling of feet but the word on the web is that American Psycho is going to be this year's Fight Club.

Mary Harron's adaptation of Brett Easton Ellis's novel about a misognynist yuppie who goes on a killing spree was this year's most anticipated event at Sundance, with queues forming for four hours before the film started. Like David Fincher who made Fight Club as a parable of the 90s, Harron, (whose previous work includes I Shot Andy Warhol), has played up the humour in the novel to create a satire on the 80s.

Actor Christian Bale (pictured) certainly got into the part of Patrick Bateman, a Wall Street broker who ends his evenings with violent sex and sadistic murders. In a Q and A session after the preview the actor reveals that he got so into the part no one would hang out with him: "I was such a convincing prick".

Harron now has to battle with the American censors who have given the film a prohibitive NC-17 certificate due to a three-way sex scene. The British censors have yet to rate the film, which is released in the UK on 21st April.

Redford's internet doom and gloom

Everyone in Hollywood is excited about the marketing capabilities of the internet after the phenomenal success of The Blair Witch Project. Everyone that is except Mr Sundance, Robert Redford.

The actor believes that the web is the industry's great white elephant. Says the star of The Horse Whisperer, "It's like a gold rush, with everyone leaving their positions and what they've been doing and heading for the California gold. It's an American trait to jump before we know what we're doing, because we don't want to miss out".

Pessimistically, the veteran actor adds, "but I suspect that we aren't too far away from the turn, and where are we going to be if we're committed to air and hype? If we're too unprepared for it, it truly will be Rome when the barbarians came down from across the borders and the empire really fell."

Needless to say Redford will not be attending the seminars offered at the Sundance Festival: Using the Internet to Market and Promote Your FilmÍ and the Future of Video on the Web.

French Catholics threaten 'blasphemous' Dogma

Dogma, Kevin Smith's "love letter" to God, has fallen foul of the French Catholic Church.

The film, a post-modern update of Christian mythology, starring popstar Alanis Morissette as God, opened in France last week and has immediately provoked the wrath of Catholics throughout the country.

In Versailles there were protests outside the town hall denouncing the film as blasphemous, while in Lille a previously unknown group calling itself the "defenders of Christian morality", has threatened to attack any cinema that screens the film. An official spokesman for the Catholic Church in Paris has called the film "derogatory" and instructed all Catholics to boycott it.

Jodie and Russell get cosy at the Globes

The rumour mill ground into action during Sunday's Golden Globes awards when avowedly single mum Jodie Foster was seen spooning with Russell Crowe. The star of Anna and the King, was seen nuzzling, slow dancing and holding hands with the New Zealand actor at numerous parties held after the awards ceremony.

Crowe, who is currently impressing critics with his performance in The Insider, denies there is a romantic liaison between the two - he claims that the pair's intention was merely to "cause a sensation".

News in brief

Characters from Antz and the Simpsons are to be brought to three dimensional life in a new deal struck by Imax with Fox, DreamWorks and Sony Picture. Imax's next 45-minute picture Cyberworld - a tour around a futuristic museum of animation - will feature clips from Antz and the Simpsons, plus a Pet Shop Boys video.

Casting couch

 Matt LeBlanc is to star in the feature version of CharlieÍs Angels. The unbilled Friends hunk will play an action movie star who is unaware that his girlfriend, Lucy Liu, is a private investigator.

 Keanu Reeves is to play a New Jersey furniture salesman with a terrible secret in a new comedy called The Ottoman Empire. Shooting is scheduled to start this summer with Andrew Bergman, who made Striptease, taking the helm.

 According to the French press, supermodel Naomi Campbell is being lined up to play Cleopatra in the French sequel to the cartoon Asterix and Obelix Take On Caesar. Apparently, the model has spent a lot of time in Paris and has a very good knowledge of the French language.

 No doubt fuelled by the success of Sam Mendes, veteran theatre supremo Richard Eyre is in final talks with Columbia to direct his first feature film, Elegy for Iris, based on John Bayley's memoir about his marriage to novelist and philosopher Iris Murdoch. Dame Judi Dench is said to be keen to play the writer.

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: Every last scrap of groundless paper talk, digested for you
fields.trailText: The Express
fields.body:
The Express

Liverpool are trying to bring Roberto Baggio to Anfield. Gerard Houllier has approached Baggio's club Internazionale with a view to taking the 32-year-old on loan until the end of the season. The Divine Ponytail is currently fifth-choice striker at the San Siro and would help solve Liverpool's current striker crisis.

The Sun

Arsenal will make another move to sign Patrick Kluivert this summer. The Dutch striker, who chose Barcelona over North London two seasons ago, has admitted he made a mistake in moving to Spain, and could be willing to move to London to play alongside close friend Dennis Bergkamp.

Newcastle full-back Alessandro Pistone could be set for a move back to Italy after he pulled out of the club's mid-season break in La Manga. Venezia, who took Pistone on loan last season, are at the front of the queue.

Teamtalk

Bradford have made a bid to sign former Celtic striker Jorge Cadete on loan until the end of the season. "They would like Jorge on-loan until the end of the season with an option to buy after that," said a spokesman for Cadete's current club Benfica. "Jorge is thinking it over."

The Mirror

Tottenham have offered Darren Anderton a contract worth more than £1m a season to keep him at White Hart Lane. Anderton has turned down previous contract offers from the club, and is rumoured to be considering a move to Old Trafford in the summer.

Danny Wilson is trying to sign PSV striker Luc Nilis and hopes that the presence of fellow Belgian international Gilles de Bilde will persuade him to come to Hillsborough. Nilis, 33, is keen on a move to the Premiership. "It would be nice to end my career in England," he said.

Daily Star

Ruud van Nistelrooy will be valued at £30m when he is put up for sale by PSV Eindhoven this summer. PSV president Harry van Raay said "We've already had bids of [£15.5m] from England - and we told them they were wasting their time." van Nistelrooy is himself said to prefer a move to Serie A.

webTitle: Author tells of 'massive' proof for gas chambers

fields.headline: Author tells of 'massive' proof for gas chambers
fields.standfirst: Special report: the David Irving libel trial
fields.trailText: The author of a book on Auschwitz told the high court yesterday that there was a "massive amount of evidence" of the use of the camp as a site for mass extermination.
fields.body:
The author of a book on Auschwitz told the high court yesterday that there was a "massive amount of evidence" of the use of the camp as a site for mass extermination.

Robert van Pelt, professor of architecture at the university of Waterloo in Canada and author of Auschwitz, 1270 To The Present, said evidence had become slowly available during the second world war through reports from escaped inmates.

It had become more substantial through witness accounts immediately after the camp's liberation and was confirmed by Polish forensic investigations in 1945-46 and the confessions of German camp personnel.

He said it was "highly implausible" that the existence of the gas chambers was a piece of "atrocity propaganda" fabricated by the British.

The evidence that Auschwitz was equipped with gas chambers which were systematically used between 1942 and 1944 had "emerged cumulatively from a convergence of independent accounts".

It had become possible to assert as "moral certainty" the statement that Auschwitz was an extermination camp where the Germans killed around 1m people with the help of gas chambers.

Prof van Pelt was giving evidence for Deborah Lipstadt, an American academic, and Penguin Books in their defence of a libel action brought by the historian David Irving.

The 62-year-old author of Hitler's War is seeking damages over a claim that he is a "Holocaust denier" in Professor Lipstadt's 1994 book, Denying The Holocaust: The Growing Assault On Truth And Memory.

Mr Irving, who is representing himself before Mr Justice Gray, denies the systematic extermination of Jews in gas chambers.

Accused by the defendants of being "a liar and a falsifier of history", he depends on a 1988 report by a man called Fred Leuchter, who had taken samples from ruins at Auschwitz and concluded that there were never homicidal gas chambers there.

Prof van Pelt described crematorium two at Auschwitz - where he said 500,000 people had died - as the "absolute centre of the atrocity".

Evidence for the killings included blueprints for building works, the buildings themselves, and accounts of camp officials and sonderkommandos - Jewish prisoners who worked in the crematoria.

He said that when he first saw the surviving original blueprints, he saw not just documents but part of "a state sponsored project to kill Jews".

He agreed with Mr Irving that a historian had a duty to remain unemotional when looking at a document.

"One's duty is to be unemotional and objective but also remain human in the exercise."

The hearing was adjourned until today.

webTitle: Fast track scheme aims to promote maths talent

fields.headline: Fast track scheme aims to promote maths talent
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Gifted children as young as nine are to be selected for special maths tutition outside the classroom, the government revealed yesterday, allowing them to take the subject at GCSE three years early as part of a national drive to raise standards of numeracy.
fields.body:
Gifted children as young as nine are to be selected for special maths tutition outside the classroom, the government revealed yesterday, allowing them to take the subject at GCSE three years early as part of a national drive to raise standards of numeracy.

The first step of the new scheme involves a £30,000 government-funded maths pilot, for which 500 youngsters will initially be hand-picked in selected parts of the country.

But ministers want this to be a first step towards a wider programme, which would build on existing initiatives for "gifted and talented" children which include summer schools.

Selection would be on the basis of teachers' assessment, as well as performance in national tests at age seven, and pupils would be taught out of hours and even at weekends by specially trained teachers.

But teachers' leaders expressed concern about intensive teaching for young children.

David Hart, general secretary of the National Association of Head Teachers, said: "Just because a child is good at maths doesn't mean they will be mature enough at nine or 10 for the kind of intensive course leading to GCSE. There is also the danger of losing social contact with their peer group."

Yesterday Tony Blair and the education secretary, David Blunkett, were helping to relaunch Maths Year 2000 at a London theatre, joined by an invited audience of around 300 schoolchildren.

Maths Year 2000 will underpin the national numeracy strategy, now in its second year, which is a programme of action to ensure that the government's target of 75% of 11-year-olds reaching the expected standard for their age in maths by the year 2002.

The year's activities will include the setting up of a fantasy football league for secondary schools and six "mathfests" throughout England.

fields.headline: £68m sweetener for student costs
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The government last night rushed forward promises of £68m a year in financial concessions to English and Welsh students in an attempt to head off a backlash south of the border against the settlement for Scottish students agreed yesterday by the Scottish executive.
fields.body:
The government last night rushed forward promises of £68m a year in financial concessions to English and Welsh students in an attempt to head off a backlash south of the border against the settlement for Scottish students agreed yesterday by the Scottish executive.

David Blunkett, the education and employment secretary, said he would adjust the means-testing of tuition fees to exempt a further 50,000 students from the £1,025 annual charge for a university education.

And from next year 10,000 of the poorest students in England and Wales will get bursaries, similar to the maintenance grants that were abolished last year as part of Mr Blunkett's reform of university funding. There will also be extra child care grants for students who are parents and assistance for mature students with the cost of their children's school meals.

But Mr Blunkett ruled out any prospect of English and Welsh students participating in the more radical overhaul of student funding approved yesterday by the Scottish executive, abolishing upfront tuition fees at Scottish universities for students from Scotland and other EU countries, but not from England, Wales or Northern Ireland.

Fees will be replaced by a graduate contribution scheme where graduates will have to pay back £2,000 when they start earning £10,000 a year.

The announcements heralded a period of political and academic turmoil as students from different parts of the UK receive different amounts of state support and face different tuition costs.

Although the National Union of Students welcomed Mr Blunkett's concessions as a first step towards recognising campus hardship, it said politicians in Edinburgh and Westminster were "creating farcical anomalies throughout the higher education system."

Diana Warwick, chief executive of the Committee of Vice-Chancellors and Principals, warned that the UK impact of the two-tier system would have to be monitored. "It is crucial that no student is put off attending the university or college of their choice by any differential funding arrangements," she said.

Theresa May, the shadow education secretary, said English students studying in Scotland would be discriminated against because they would pay fees while students from Scotland and Belgium would not.

"This will lead to students deciding where to study according to finance and not their chosen subjects."

fields.headline: Oxford Union goes pop
fields.trailText: The Oxford Union has played host to some of the world's leading statesmen but its new president thinks it needs more music, football and fashion.
fields.body:
The Oxford Union has played host to some of the world's leading statesmen but its new president thinks it needs more music, football and fashion.

Among the speakers lined up for this term are the Radio 1 DJ Chris Moyles, the designer Stella McCartney, the editor of Loaded magazine, Tim Southwell, the musician Brian May, and the international drug dealer Howard Marks.

The union's president, Lucy Aitkens, said her approach was intended to make the discussions more accessible for students and she denied the range of topics would lead to a drop in debating standards.

Motions up for discussion include "this house would rather play Wembley than Westminster" and "this house believes that British comedy is superior to American comedy".

Miss Aitkens, 20, of St Hilda's college, said: "We have got such a high workload in Oxford and while everybody likes intellectual debates on international finance every now and then, there should be debates about enjoyment and having fun.

"Sometimes we have put on really prestigious speakers but they don't attract the same number of students.

"We are keeping the same standard of intellectual speakers but there are other people who have all succeeded in their fields.

"My primary aim is to keep the place as popular and as central to student life as it always has been and I listened to my friends and asked them who they wanted to see."

She was particularly looking forward to hearing a discussion about Islam and the west which Benazir Bhutto will be taking part in.

The union was founded in 1823 as a forum for discussion and debate and former officers include William Gladstone, Harold Macmillan, Edward Heath, Tony Benn, Michael Heseltine and William Hague.

World figures including Archbishop Desmond Tutu, Mother Teresa, Malcolm X and the Dalai Lama have spoken at the union as have the US presidents Ronald Reagan, Richard Nixon and Jimmy Carter.

Last year Yasser Arafat made his first international speech after the Israeli elections and in February Ian Paisley, David Trimble and John Hume answered questions on Northern Ireland.

The novelist Tariq Ali, who was president of the union in 1965, said: "One cannot blame them for doing what everyone else is doing but I think it's appalling."

webTitle: Arms, human rights and a question of values

fields.headline: Arms, human rights and a question of values
fields.standfirst:
Hard sell government department that guarantees export payments finds itself at eye of storm over trade with questionable regimes

Labour's ethical foreign policy: special report
fields.trailText: The export credit guarantee department has become the centre of a Whitehall row over ethics, arms sales and environmental considerations, because of its pivotal role in underwriting billions of pounds of credit to British exporters.
fields.body:
The export credit guarantee department has become the centre of a Whitehall row over ethics, arms sales and environmental considerations, because of its pivotal role in underwriting billions of pounds of credit to British exporters.

The institution, dating back to 1919, offers huge credit insurance funds to British companies which export. In the past five years alone, it under wrote £17bn of exports, offering credit insurance at flat rates over a two to 10-year period.

The taxpayer picks up the bill only if the project collapses or the country where the project is based defaults. Taxpayers over the past eight years have had to fork out between £148m and £750m a year because of defaults.

The ECGD funded the Pergau dam in Malaysia in the 1980s, which was criticised because of environmental damage. A comparable row broke out under Labour over the funding of the Ilisu dam in Turkey.

The table reveals for the first time the scale of British exports involved. It shows that in the past 4 years some 6,659 firms asked for aid to back £298bn worth of business. The ECGD issued 821 export guarantees covering £14.6bn worth of business.

The country-by-country breakdown reveals that some of the biggest number of applications were for Turkey, the Russian Federation, China, Saudi Arabia and Oman - all likely to be deals involving arms sales or dealing with regimes where human rights are a significant issue.

Other tables show that demand for export credits to Arab states are so high that the department has run out of money to service them.

It is estimated that a third of the export guarantees issued by ECGD are for arms sales.

The row in Whitehall has been intensified because of pressures by environmental campaigners and third world debt groups demanding that Britain moves towards support for sustainable development to help the poorest nations.

This was a key part of the review ordered by Stephen Byers, the trade secretary, into the future role of ECGD. The aim was to bring Britain's policy in line with the World Bank, which takes a strong line on the environment, and other countries, like Sweden, which apply tough criteria to export aid. The new policy will be announced in March.

webTitle: Time to turn off the tap

fields.headline: Time to turn off the tap
fields.standfirst:
ECGD spending needs tighter control
Labour's ethical foreign policy: special report
fields.trailText: Most people know little of the export credit guarantee department (ECGD), and the department seems happy to keep things that way. That is why David Hencke's front page report today will be particularly unwelcome. This is the seamy underbelly of British foreign and development policy.
fields.body:
Most people know little of the export credit guarantee department (ECGD), and the department seems happy to keep things that way. That is why David Hencke's front page report today will be particularly unwelcome. This is the seamy underbelly of British foreign and development policy. Forget ethical foreign policy, forget all the department of international development's fine talk about sustainable development and environmental awareness. Forget even the chancellor of the exchequer's efforts to relieve the debts of developing countries. The department is there, as its mission statement makes clear, to promote UK business interests by offering loans to underwrite exports to risky countries. If that flies in the face of environmental considerations, human rights and regional stability, so be it.

That effectively was the story behind the Ilisu dam project in Turkey, for which Balfour Beatty received ECGD backing just before Christmas. It is there at the heart of almost every arms exporting scandal; 30% of its credits go on arms sales. Yesterday Charles Kennedy claimed that on average £239m a year over the last 10 years has gone on export credit for arms sales: this makes it one of the last of the great subsidised industries in the UK.

Will all this change? The documents leaked from the review of the ECGD expose a deep conflict within Whitehall. On one side, the ministry of defence and the department of trade and industry are anxious that the criteria for credit should not be tightened for fear of losing contracts to Britain's competitors; they insist that any action must be multilateral. On the other side, the department of international development (DFID) argues for the kind of environmental and sustainable development criteria which are standard among international institutions such as the World Bank. At present, ECGD's remit brings it into head-on conflict with activities in other government departments - for example, Gordon Brown's much praised debt initiative. What is needed when the report is finally published in March is some joined-up government. Bring the ECGD into line with this government's efforts on debt and international development. Cut its links with the DTI. And begin the awesome task - in which the role of the ECGD must be central - of dismantling Britain's role as one of the biggest arms exporters in the world.

webTitle: Schröder orders inquiry into missing slush row files

fields.headline: Schröder orders inquiry into missing slush row files
fields.standfirst:
Demand comes after fruitless hunt for papers at centre of CDU scandal
German corruption scandal: special report
fields.trailText: Chancellor Gerhard Schröder yesterday ordered an independent inquiry into missing government files which could shed light on allegations that the late French president, François Mitterrand, secretly bankrolled Germany's Christian Democrats with a £10m campaign donation.
fields.byline: Tony Paterson  in Berlin and  Paul Webster in Paris
fields.body:
Chancellor Gerhard Schröder yesterday ordered an independent inquiry into missing government files which could shed light on allegations that the late French president, François Mitterrand, secretly bankrolled Germany's Christian Democrats with a £10m campaign donation.

"Chancellery staff have been searching in vain for the missing files since December," a government spokesman said. "Chancellor Schröder decided that the next step must be an independent investigation, so that individuals can be questioned."

The files concern a deal at the centre of the German slush fund scandal - the 1992 purchase for £28m of the east German Leuna oil refinery and more than 1,000 petrol stations in the region by the French state oil company Elf Aquitaine

German and French television reported at the weekend that the transaction was used as a cover by Mitterrand for a secret £10m donation to help the then chancellor Helmut Kohl's Christian Democrats win the 1994 general election.

Mr Kohl immediately denied the allegations as a "smear campaign".

The two leaders enjoyed a close relationship and viewed the Franco-German alliance as the cornerstone of European integration.

German chancellery officials revealed in December that although they had a list of files relating to the Leuna deal, the files themselves had "gone missing".

France's justice minister, Elisabeth Guigou, who worked closely with Mitterrand as European affairs minister, said yesterday that inquiries would be carried out into the allegations.

But Ms Guigou said she did not believe that Mitterrand, who died in 1996, was personally involved in any illegal transaction. More than seven years of investigation by two magistrates had not produced any proof of presidential manipulation of funds provided by Elf Aquitaine, she said.

Mr Schröder meanwhile moved to counter growing international criticism. He told a meeting of his Social Democrats in Bonn that the affair had not undermined the credibility of German democracy. "Our democratic system is not in crisis," he said. "If anything, it [the affair] has strengthened our democratic institutions, which are doing everything to shed light on it."

A German parliamentary committee of inquiry started its own investigation into illegal funding of Mr Kohl's Christian Democratic Union last week, but its hearings - which will involve testimony from the former chancellor - are expected to take months.

On Monday, the CDU said that an independent auditors' report had been unable to explain the origins of more than £4m which was currently in the party's accounts. But complaints from the grass roots caused the CDU's leadership to retreat on earlier pledges to sue Mr Kohl.

He has admitted accepting more than £600,000 in illicit donations on behalf of the CDU and of channelling the cash into secret accounts. His dogged refusal to name the donors forced the CDU to strip him of his post as honorary chairman last week.

Latest opinion polls show that the CDU's popularity has slumped to one of its lowest levels on record as a result of the scandal. The party is now 11 percentage points behind the ruling Social Democrats. In an attempt to recoup lost ground, it yesterday announced plans for a "credibility offensive". Some east German CDU MPs have proposed setting up a breakaway conservative party in the region to avoid further political damage.

The CDU in the state of Hesse yesterday rejected demands to dissolve parliament and hold fresh regional elections as a result of the affair. Eleven days ago the Hesse party admitted using a secret Swiss bank account to channel DM10m (£3m) in illicit donations.

The former CDU leader in the state, Mr Kohl's former interior minister Manfred Kanther, resigned his MP's seat as a result of the scandal yesterday.

webTitle: Addicts fight curb on right to silence

fields.headline: Addicts fight curb on right to silence
fields.standfirst: Are your rights at risk? Find out here
fields.trailText: Curbs on suspects' right of silence in the police station were challenged yesterday at the European court of human rights in Strasbourg.
fields.body:
Curbs on suspects' right of silence in the police station were challenged yesterday at the European court of human rights in Strasbourg.

The 1994 criminal justice and public order act allowed juries to draw "adverse inferences" if defendants refused to answer police questions. William and Karen Condron, who were jailed in 1995 for supplying heroin and lost their appeal, claim they were denied a fair trial in breach of the European convention on human rights.

Ben Emmerson, their counsel, told the Strasbourg judges that it was "fundamentally unfair" and seriously undermined the right to legal advice if juries could draw adverse inferences even though a suspect had refused to answer questions on a solicitor's advice. He believed they were unfit to be interviewed.

The couple, from south London, who are heroin addicts, were seen by police to pass packets to a neighbour. Police found heroin in their flat. Mr Emmerson said adverse inferences should not have been permitted because they were suffering withdrawal symptoms during the interview.

fields.headline: The lure of the lucre
fields.standfirst:
Germany's slush fund scandal says more about the corrupting power of money than it does about Kohl

German corruption scandal: special report
fields.trailText: You don't have to speak German to get the message. "Dieses System ist korrupt," says the slogan splashed across a thousand banners in Berlin. The protesters are shaking their fists at Helmut Kohl, the man who ruled them for 16 years and who now stands accused of taking sackloads of illegal cash - and plotting with a foreign government to distort the course of German history.
fields.body:
You don't have to speak German to get the message. "Dieses System ist korrupt," says the slogan splashed across a thousand banners in Berlin. The protesters are shaking their fists at Helmut Kohl, the man who ruled them for 16 years and who now stands accused of taking sackloads of illegal cash - and plotting with a foreign government to distort the course of German history. The result is a scandal which goes beyond old King Kohl. The reputation of politics itself is on the line - and not just in Germany. For Kohl-gate has come just as voters all over the world are bombarded with evidence that their leaders are for sale. Those placards in Berlin could soon be brandished in Birmingham or Boston: "This system is corrupt."

The German scandal is getting bigger and bleaker every day, with all the elements of a classic political thriller: secret slush funds, missing files, global ramifications and now - a body. (Last week Christian Democrat financial officer Wolfgang Huellen was found hanged in his Berlin flat.) The nub of it is Mr Kohl's admission that he used to run a network of secret accounts - not for his own private gain, but to hide anonymous donations to the CDU. The cash was salted away by an official known only as "the Postman". The former chancellor has confessed to about a million dollars' worth of these illegal, undeclared gifts, but his accusers say the real figure is much, much larger.

Now a new, even more lethal bombshell has landed: on Monday news organisations in Paris and Berlin reported that former French president François Mitterrand had arranged roughly £10m in payments to the CDU via the French petrol company, Elf Aquitaine, to help Kohl get through a sticky 1994 election campaign. It is a staggering charge: a French socialist bankrolling a German conservative, one head of state using taxpayers' money (Elf was state-owned at the time) to help another. It is hard to think of a political scandal, anywhere, that is more serious. Even Watergate did not accuse Richard Nixon of fighting an election with cash provided by Harold Wilson.

If these charges stand up, the debris will scatter all across Europe. It will taint forever the architects of economic and monetary union, Kohl and Mitterrand - condemning them as a couple of corrupt old fixers, happy to resort to bribery to get their way. And if their personal standing is bruised, then so surely is their shared brainchild, the single currency. Norman Lamont was on the radio yesterday, spouting a lot of hysterical, xenophobic nonsense about the "contagion" of Teutonic-Gallic corruption spreading to our shores. "We are a clean country!" he insisted, in an exquisite, Captain Mainwaring moment. But on one claim, he had a point. He recalled that the French had approved of the Maastricht treaty in a knife-edge referendum in 1992: if Mitterrand was happy to bend German ballots with cash, might he have likewise twisted the process in his own country? The moral authority of the European project, already so badly shaken by last year's non-resignation resignations at the European Commission, could be about to vanish in a cloud of rancid smoke.

Even if the EU manages to escape unscathed from this increasingly pan-European scandal, German politics will not. Kohl has already admitted taking those 2m marks - but the CDU cannot pretend the problem began and ended with him. Corruption is part of the Christian Democrat present as well as its past. The current party leader, Wolfgang Schäuble, has had to confess to accepting $50,000 from a fugitive arms dealer, and the courts now say they want to look at last year's CDU victory in state elections in Hesse after the party boss there admitted he had funnelled money through Swiss bank accounts.

Alongside all this, our own outbreaks of sleaze seem almost quaint. Next to the Christian Democrats, Neil Hamilton and Jonathan Aitken look like amateurs. But we are not without the contagion, despite what Norman Lamont might say. His own party also used cash and back channels and foreign donations to influence our elections and change our laws. But, like the Germans, we too cannot pretend this is all in our past. The department of trade and industry has now expanded its investigation into the tangled business affairs of the former treasury minister Geoffrey Robinson, and his equally convoluted engineering firm TransTec. Over the weekend, two of TransTec's top former officials broke cover to declare they had filed false and misleading grant applications to the DTI in the 80s - fiddling the figures to get their hands on more public money.

In the United States, meanwhile, the hot breath of corruption is constantly there, misting up the mirror of democratic politics. Yesterday Americans heard the first results of the presidential contest of 2000. They learned that both Republican and Democratic front-runners, George W Bush and Al Gore, had won their respective battles in the farmland state of Iowa. But most Americans will also have known that both Bush and Gore were helped by colossal, multimillion dollar warchests, which enabled them to carpetbomb their rivals in the "air war" of television advertising. The voters will also be aware that most of those millions will have come from special interests and lobby groups who, when the time comes, will want a return on their investment. As the poster says: "Dieses System ist korrupt."

We cannot comfort ourselves that this is a German contagion or an American disease. It seems money washes around every democracy where money makes a difference, and that's most of them. But there is a price to pay. These constant revelations of corruption, even in such previously trusted figures as Helmut Kohl, corrodes public faith in the very business of democratic governance. That is clearly a problem in itself: the degradation of public discourse, the spread of cynicism, makes our collective life less civilised. But there is a more tangible, more bread-and-butter impact. For if we stop trusting politicians, then we will stop trusting them with our money. And that changes not just politics, but society.

It has become a truism of modern, post-Reagan, post-Thatcher politics that people will never vote to raise their taxes. The new year has seen the first signs of a thaw in that deep freeze. The NHS crisis seems to have set people wondering: is it time, in an age of cash-starved schools and hospitals, that we started paying more for the services we all share? That will be quite a taboo to break. It means asking people to hand over even more of their income to strangers, so that they can spend it on their behalf. For that, lest we forget, is what taxpaying is about: a relationship of trust. It breaks down if I, the voter, stop trusting you, the politician: I won't want to give you more of my money to spend. That's why these corruption scandals deserve our attention. They are not the small change of politics: they threaten the very purpose of it.

fields.headline: Hurricane Helmut
fields.standfirst:
A crisis not just for a party but for a nation

German corruption scandal: special report
fields.trailText: The ramifications of the Helmut Kohl affair, or Kohlgate as some have mischievously labelled it, grow more far-reaching and destructive by the day. Political scandals, especially where money is involved, have a tendency to do that.
fields.body:
The ramifications of the Helmut Kohl affair, or Kohlgate as some have mischievously labelled it, grow more far-reaching and destructive by the day. Political scandals, especially where money is involved, have a tendency to do that. When the main players, once challenged, refuse to come clean, preferring obfuscatory legal manoeuvres, stonewalling or cover-ups, escalating mayhem is to be expected.

Washington's Iran-contra scam, Britain's arms-for-Iraq affair, and last year's European commission imbroglio all followed a similar pattern, based on Richard Nixon's Watergate paradigm. Everything is denied until, piece by piece, media investigations, growing political pressure and legal inquiries force the truth, or some of it, into the open. The Kohl affair is no different. Although the former German chancellor has admitted accepting $1m in illegal, anonymous cash donations on behalf of his Christian Democrat party, it is now clear that vastly more money was involved, over a much longer time scale, and that many others within the CDU and beyond have been compromised. But still the principals, and not just Dr Kohl, withhold the whole story. And so, as it unfolds, with one shocking disclosure following another, the scandal, like a hurricane making landfall, gathers strength and momentum, visiting random, uncontrolled devastation upon all it touches.

Its impact on German politics cannot yet be fully assessed, but nobody doubts the damage is already serious. The CDU, which has held power for 33 of the past 50 years, may split in any of four ways - between Kohl loyalists, adherents of Wolfgang Schäuble's current leadership, alienated party members in the former East Germany, and the young guard which wants a total break with the tainted past. The party's national ratings have tumbled; it stands to lose forthcoming state elections; and may face re-run polls in Hesse, one of the affair's flashpoints. Gerhard Schröder's Social Democrats must adjust meanwhile to a new landscape in which the hard left, Greens, and rightwing extremists may exercise greater clout. More broadly, the scandal threatens the basis of Germany's consensual post-war democracy. Popular trust in a system which delivered the so-called German miracle had already been undermined by recession, unemployment and the myriad problems of reunification. Now it may prove to be the affair's biggest domestic casualty.

The potential damage has a pan-European dimension, as shown by newly-detailed allegations of a conspiracy between Dr Kohl and François Mitterrand, the late French president, to use slush funds to win over voters to the European single market and currency. Such revelations bolster the Eurosceptic view that the EU is, and always has been, a cosy Franco-German stitch-up inimical to British interests. The affair encourages the prejudice that transparency and accountability, let alone brash, raw, adversarial democracy, are concepts foreign to Europe's ruling elites. It will encourage those who seek to persuade us that the euro is itself just another con.

Yet for Tony Blair, watching the storm's trail of destruction from Downing Street, this shambles presents an opportunity. The prime minister has always made reform his top European priority. In Brussels, EC vice-president Neil Kinnock has made a valiant start. With Germany in political disarray and the French rightly appalled and embarrassed, what better time for Mr Blair to seize Europe's moral high ground - to recapture and refocus a European agenda which has been steadily slipping beyond his control?

fields.headline: Short's blueprint for poor
fields.standfirst:
Don't build barriers to globalisation, minister tells her 'well-meaning' critics

World Trade Organisation: special report
fields.trailText: Clare Short, the international development secretary, will announce plans today for a wide-ranging autumn white paper on managing globalisation as the centrepiece of a government strategy to ensure that the world's poor benefit from economic changes.
fields.body:
Clare Short, the international development secretary, will announce plans today for a wide-ranging autumn white paper on managing globalisation as the centrepiece of a government strategy to ensure that the world's poor benefit from economic changes.

Proposals for reform of the World Trade Organisation, backing for a global investment agreement, the need for new environmental agreements and the spread of new technology will all feature in the blueprint, details of which will be unveiled to MPs in the Commons this afternoon.

Despite the collapse of last month's world trade talks in Seattle, Ms Short will argue that globalisation can be good for development. "We have got to harness globalisation, not turn the clock back. If that becomes the view of caring people we will get more poverty. It would be a disastrous loss of a historic opportunity," she told the Guardian yesterday.

"A lot of well-meaning people think you can protect the poorest countries by protecting them from globalisation, putting up barriers around them. But that impoverishes them."

Ms Short's views on globalisation have upset some environmental pressure groups and aid agencies, who believe that a far-more sceptical view is needed of the environmental, economic and social impacts of recent changes. Non-governmental organisations would be consulted on the details of the white paper over the coming months, the international development secretary said.

Tony Blair, who has been looking for a way to extend his "third way" approach, has given backing to the idea of a white paper, the second on development during this parliament. "We can't talk about development in the old way," Ms Short said. "We need to make sure that globalisation doesn't lead to ever growing inequality. We have to be able to manage the next era of history."

The international development secretary said the white paper would look at the world trading system post-Seattle, putting forward proposals for greater democracy and the changes necessary for all countries to benefit from liberalisation. It will also reflect Ms Short's support for rules on global investment, which she says are needed to attract much-needed capital into poor countries from overseas. "The government also wants to look at the environment worldwide and investigate what sort of environmental agreements we need, agreements that don't penalise poor countries.

"We have got to include developing countries in the process. It should be developing countries screaming at the world to do something about global warming. But a lot of poor countries feel threatened rather than being in the vanguard of the process."

Ms Short said the white paper would be focused on hitting the UN's 2015 global poverty-reduction targets, with proposals to use debt relief and increased aid for "strategic economic management" in developing countries. "International institutions have been full of rhetoric, obsessed with inputs rather than outcomes. We need to have year-on-year figures for every country so that development stops being a political game.

"The bulk of the public knows that something big is changing in the world economy, that the crisis in Asia led to a loss of jobs in the north east. That's one reason politics is becoming marginalised. Some of the big issues don't feature in debates in the house. They have gone global."

webTitle: Gates tops the giving it all away league

fields.headline: Gates tops the giving it all away league
fields.standfirst:
Microsoft
E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Bill Gates, the world's richest man, yesterday emerged as the most philanthropic person on the planet after donating another $5bn to his charitable foundation.
fields.body:
Bill Gates, the world's richest man, yesterday emerged as the most philanthropic person on the planet after donating another $5bn to his charitable foundation.

The latest gift by the founder of Microsoft, the software giant, brings the total managed by the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation to $21.8bn (£13.2bn) - edging it past the UK's Wellcome Trust, which has assets of £13.0bn.

Yesterday's announcement coincides with the latest development in the long-running legal battle between Microsoft and the US justice department, which has accused the company of abusing its monopoly position in the world's software market.

Mr Gates and his wife have appeared to become far more generous since the US government's anti-monopolies case started in 1998.

Last year Mr Gates said he was committed to giving away the majority of his wealth, estimated at about $100bn and based on his 15% stake in Microsoft. The foundation has focused on health and education issues around the world including work to limit the spread of Aids in Africa.

Three months ago the foundation announced that it would donate $750m over five years to help vaccinate children in developing countries. To keep its tax-exempt status the fund must give away at least 5% of its endowment each year.

Government officials were yesterday preparing to present their rebuttal of Microsoft's defence in Washington. The response is expected to argue that the company has ignored the indictment of its behaviour already made by the trial judge, Thomas Penfield Jackson.

Bad weather on the east coast of the US was yesterday threatening to prevent the government from physically filing its 30-page rebuttal to a snowbound courthouse.

webTitle: Our sick healthcare system needs that cash injection

fields.headline: Our sick healthcare system needs that cash injection
fields.standfirst:
The chancellor may sulk but Tony Blair will keep his NHS promise
Special report: The future of the NHS
fields.trailText: When do you start to worry seriously about the health of the NHS? When top treasury officials go around publicly saying that persuading more people to take out private insurance is part of the solution.
fields.body:
When do you start to worry seriously about the health of the NHS? When top treasury officials go around publicly saying that persuading more people to take out private insurance is part of the solution. When erstwhile left of centre social policy gurus write pieces extolling private practice in the Daily Mail. When the Tories think that praising private health is a winner not a catastrophic loser. (But what do they know?) When even Labour's Lord Winston surprisingly starts to talk up private funding.

Suddenly everywhere you go the word is that the NHS is fading fast. Sad but inevitable. Post-war child of rationing and shortage, people just won't put up with its dilatory shabbiness any more. Tales are swapped of A and E queues, seedy mixed-sex wards, exhausted doctors and the lack of calm or privacy. The stampede is on. However often it is pointed out that on every measure the NHS treats more people and treats them better than ever before, few believe it. Well, they say, it's still not good enough - and that is also the truth.

It's a truth Tony Blair knows and it's why he promised a revolutionary increase in health spending the like of which the NHS has never seen. But this must be the worst-spun good news story in a very long time. How can the government commit itself irrevocably - everyone agrees there's no going back - to spending so much yet still get the worst possible press on health? Bad news management, or what?

It looks like just plain chaos. Treasury officials are saying quite openly that the target for health spending the prime minister set cannot be reached unless we also hugely increase the private sector to bridge the gap with the EU. Gordon Brown seems to be sulking in his tent instead of coaxing maximum good-news value out of what he will have to spend whether he likes it or not. It may make nonsense of his Comprehensive Spending Review but he could at least get some credit by loud public boasting about it. Tony Blair himself has let people think this was some panicky slip of the tongue on the Frost programme (which it wasn't). Alastair Campbell grumbles that he never did use the word "aspiration" to water down his master's pledge, but where is his campaign to blazon the good news from every hospital rooftop?

Politics are mainly reported as sport. The political commentators' game here is to calculate whether Blair fumbled and dropped the ball when he claimed a huge increase of 5% more a year would hit the EU health average. Game analysts plunged into the meta-complexities of a shifting goal ridden with variables. How do you measure the real EU average? What counts as some countries' compulsory tax and what a voluntary private contribution? What if a well-funded NHS leads to less private insurance making that EU target harder to reach, despite great success? To name that target may have been an unnecessary political own-goal. But that's all angels on pins game-playing. What does it matter?:

All that matters is whether or not in the real world the NHS will blossom as a result of all this new money. Although it has improved, none the less it has steadily declined relative to general living standards. Now average incomes are expected to rise sharply by 30% in 10 years, can the NHS keep up? Education may be a more important priority - but we can't afford to choose between these two. If the NHS were let slip because education matters more in the long run, Labour might not still be there to control what happens in that long run. (Fewer households have kids in school that use the NHS.) If the NHS can't offer prompt treatment in bright clinics with obliging staff who don't look more miserably tired than their patients, people will take their cheque books to the private sector.

Good, say top treasury officials. Good, say the Tories. Good, says Lord Winston. But bad says any health economist with any understanding of private health finance. Doctors in the private sector are paid 10 times more per hour than in the NHS. Private management costs are far higher, with the added bureaucracy of individual insurance and billing. Management of cost control in private treatment is non-existent with no oversight of needless treatments doctors sell to private patients. The private sector poaches and adds to the serious shortage of nurses and doctors instead of relieving pressure in the NHS. Fifty percent more cancer and heart specialists will come on stream soon. Why give any incentive to send them into the private sector where they will charge so much more for the same work?

New research from Bristol university shows that wherever doctors move into the private sector they create the demand as they go, not vice versa. Hardly surprising since they also control demand through their own NHS waiting lists. The Audit Commission tells the obvious truth that doctors who do more in the private sector do less in the NHS.

No one has ever accused this prime minister of being overly ideological about private/public provision. After all 31 new hospitals are (alas) being built under PFI by the private sector. So why is he adamant that extra private insurance is no answer to NHS failings? For purely pragmatic reasons. Any tax break incentive for private insurance spends a huge dead weight sum on nothing, and anything above that is badly spent compared with what it would buy in the NHS. Health authorities may sometimes buy a few hundred hips from a local private hospital. But how much more of that would lead the NHS to rely on the private sector? More doctors would soon transfer over to do the same work for 10 times more pay and private prices would rise uncontrollably.

The NHS is not quite on a respirator, but this is the last chance for a universal service. If, by the election after next all this extra money it doesn't bump it into the 21st century, to match private sector comfort and convenience, the NHS idea will be dead. Too many average earners will be privately insured to care what becomes of a rump service for the old and poor. Blair is so determined to stop that happening that he is prepared to warp all other spending. The primrose path of private insurance leads to just one result: everyone ends up paying more yet getting less value than they do now. When a Portillo-led Tory party gallops towards the polls in 2006, the NHS has to be working brilliantly as never before or else the Tory lie that private is always best will win the day, to the loss of rich and poor alike.

fields.headline: Railways' clock is running backward
fields.standfirst:
Train strike prompts passengers to ask awkward questions

More about transport
fields.trailText: The thousands of commuters who battled into London yesterday as the French-owned rail company, Connex, faced the first serious disruptive stoppage since privatisation must have experienced a sense of  déjà vu.
fields.body:
The thousands of commuters who battled into London yesterday as the French-owned rail company, Connex, faced the first serious disruptive stoppage since privatisation must have experienced a sense of déjà vu.

The years of making "alternative arrangements" to get into work were supposed to have been long gone. Since privatisation, drivers' pay has risen remarkably, from around £15,000 to £28,000, ending years of low wages for staff at the sharp end of the service. Dowdy trains have been given a splash of colour and people are flocking back to the railway, largely driven by increasing road congestion.

But appearances can be skin deep. Passengers are packed like sardines in overcrowded coaches because there is a dire shortage of new rolling stock.

Fares are erratically fixed, causing wide divergences. You may be able to book a £20 fare on a return from London to Manchester if you start several weeks in advance, but if you were boarding the 8.30am from Piccadilly, Manchester, to London yesterday you would have paid more than £100 for a standard return fare.

Almost three years into Labour's new government, the railway sector is in no better shape than it was before privatisation. This is not the view of angry commuters, but the findings of an independent report carried out for the rail regulator, Tom Winsor.

The 25 rail companies, rushed into birth by the outgoing Conservatives, are an amalgam of the good and the grotty.

The industry is in a state of flux. Four years from now, the number of companies will have been radically reduced. The big franchisees, including Stagecoach, National Express and Virgin, will always be prominent. But what of the struggling tiddlers, the minnows who are trying to operate a franchise with little investment and reducing numbers of staff?

Sir Alastair Morton, chairman of the strategic rail authority, says that five years on from privatisation, and the weaker rail companies are "buckling at the knees". Large cash inflows to the treasury from the sale of Railtrack and the rolling stock companies have been followed by a relentless reduction in the taxpayer contribution to a more or less static network.

It is inevitable that some of the smaller companies will go to the wall, leaving a handful of powerful companies to control most of the industry, much like the old private companies did until after the second world war.

The latest victim is MTL, formed in 1992 when drivers and other employees of the state owned Mersey passenger transport executive bought the business for a £1. For some months, the ailing organisation has been the centre of speculation that it would be swallowed up by one of the larger companies.

This week the bus and rail company, Arriva, bid £34.7m for the company. MTL risks losing its Merseyside and northern England franchises as a result of the SRA's plans for reorganisation of rail services.

Rationalisation of the privatised industry is openly encouraged by Sir Alastair. Naturally, the winners in this situation are the big companies. Only they have the capital to invest in much needed rolling stock and station improvements that will be needed if government forecasts of a 130% increase in passenger usage over the next 10 years are correct.

Surprisingly, Connex, with one of the worst reputations in the business for service and punctuality, has felt the touch of Sir Alastair's hand on its shoulder as it has been chosen as a preferred bidder for one of the first three re-franchises.

The SRA's strangest move so far has been to invite tenders from the rail companies, without setting out tough new guidelines to the industry on what the SRA expects from the companies. The initial franchises were drafted in such a way that they gave the passenger little protection over companies which failed to run normal services, overcrowded and and unpunctual.

The government sets great store on protecting the public interest, yet the SRA appears to set greater store on sorting out the re-franchising, rather than making sure that the companies are more effectively policed before they get the franchises.

fields.bodyText: The thousands of commuters who battled into London yesterday as the French-owned rail company, Connex, faced the first serious disruptive stoppage since privatisation must have experienced a sense of déjà vu. The years of making "alternative arrangements" to get into work were supposed to have been long gone. Since privatisation, drivers' pay has risen remarkably, from around £15,000 to £28,000, ending years of low wages for staff at the sharp end of the service. Dowdy trains have been given a splash of colour and people are flocking back to the railway, largely driven by increasing road congestion. But appearances can be skin deep. Passengers are packed like sardines in overcrowded coaches because there is a dire shortage of new rolling stock. Fares are erratically fixed, causing wide divergences. You may be able to book a £20 fare on a return from London to Manchester if you start several weeks in advance, but if you were boarding the 8.30am from Piccadilly, Manchester, to London yesterday you would have paid more than £100 for a standard return fare. Almost three years into Labour's new government, the railway sector is in no better shape than it was before privatisation. This is not the view of angry commuters, but the findings of an independent report carried out for the rail regulator, Tom Winsor. The 25 rail companies, rushed into birth by the outgoing Conservatives, are an amalgam of the good and the grotty. The industry is in a state of flux. Four years from now, the number of companies will have been radically reduced. The big franchisees, including Stagecoach, National Express and Virgin, will always be prominent. But what of the struggling tiddlers, the minnows who are trying to operate a franchise with little investment and reducing numbers of staff? Sir Alastair Morton, chairman of the strategic rail authority, says that five years on from privatisation, and the weaker rail companies are "buckling at the knees". Large cash inflows to the treasury from the sale of Railtrack and the rolling stock companies have been followed by a relentless reduction in the taxpayer contribution to a more or less static network. It is inevitable that some of the smaller companies will go to the wall, leaving a handful of powerful companies to control most of the industry, much like the old private companies did until after the second world war. The latest victim is MTL, formed in 1992 when drivers and other employees of the state owned Mersey passenger transport executive bought the business for a £1. For some months, the ailing organisation has been the centre of speculation that it would be swallowed up by one of the larger companies. This week the bus and rail company, Arriva, bid £34.7m for the company. MTL risks losing its Merseyside and northern England franchises as a result of the SRA's plans for reorganisation of rail services. Rationalisation of the privatised industry is openly encouraged by Sir Alastair. Naturally, the winners in this situation are the big companies. Only they have the capital to invest in much needed rolling stock and station improvements that will be needed if government forecasts of a 130% increase in passenger usage over the next 10 years are correct. Surprisingly, Connex, with one of the worst reputations in the business for service and punctuality, has felt the touch of Sir Alastair's hand on its shoulder as it has been chosen as a preferred bidder for one of the first three re-franchises. The SRA's strangest move so far has been to invite tenders from the rail companies, without setting out tough new guidelines to the industry on what the SRA expects from the companies. fields.headline: Chechnya's tales of the underground
fields.standfirst:
A rare glimpse of life in the basements of Grozny reveals the daily struggle to survive Russia's onslaught

Crisis in Chechnya: special report
fields.trailText: Rebel fighters in Grozny live in the basements of bombed-out buildings and travel underground through a network of tunnels. Doctors operate without anaesthetics. Civilians, afraid to venture out, bury their dead in the courtyards of their apartment buildings.
fields.byline: Mayerbek Nunayev in Grozny and  Richard Paddock in Moscow
fields.body:
Rebel fighters in Grozny live in the basements of bombed-out buildings and travel underground through a network of tunnels. Doctors operate without anaesthetics. Civilians, afraid to venture out, bury their dead in the courtyards of their apartment buildings.

The daily bombardment by Russian aircraft and artillery has so devastated the capital of Chechnya that when the war ultimately ends, there will be few homes left standing for those who wish to return.

For the rebels, life is guerrilla warfare. For civilians, it is a test of survival.

Despite heavy losses, morale appears high among the 2,500 to 3,000 rebel fighters encamped in Grozny. They swear they will not give in to the "Russian aggressors", and predict the war will continue for many months.

"The Russians can destroy our city, they can reduce it to rubble, but they will never be able to seize it and control it," said Vakha Israilov, commander of a Chechen battalion. "We will never lay down our arms."

The battle for Grozny began with a Russian assault on Christmas Day, but the troops have made little progress in driving out the rebels. As Moscow attempts to retake the separatist republic it lost in a bloody 1994-96 war, it risks repeating costly mistakes.

The Russians regularly claim they have captured various city districts, but it is unclear how much they actually hold.

Vladimir Putin, the acting president who rose in popularity while he was prime minister last autumn by leading Russia into the second Chechen war, is banking on a successful military campaign to help him become president this spring. This fact is not lost on the Muslim rebels, who are doing their best to wreck his plans.

"It is clear that the Russians are bogged down up to their ears in the war in Chechnya," said Ruslan Makhmayev, 35, a unit commander. "And there is no chance the war will be over before March 26, the day of the presidential elections in Russia. What Putin expected would bring him to power will in fact become his undoing."

Mr Putin portrays the Chechen rebels as "terrorists and bandits" who engage in kidnapping for profit and behead their victims when ransoms are not paid. The rebels cast themselves as freedom fighters struggling to liberate their republic from 150 years of repressive rule from Moscow.

In Grozny, the fighters appear upbeat, well-fed and well-groomed, given their circumstances. In one basement, they have built a sauna. They obtain water from natural springs nearby and heat their subterranean dwellings with wood-burning stoves.

Many of the rebels fought in the first Chechen war, unlike most of their young Russian opponents. They say they are prepared for a long siege and have enough food and ammunition to last indefinitely, adding to their stores with munitions taken from Russians.

The biggest shortage is of anaesthetics and medicine in the three hospitals where doctors operate on the wounded. "Over the past few days, our doctors have had to perform surgery without any anaesthetics," Mr Makhmayev said.

In the city's Oktyabrsky district, which is under the control of Chechen forces, no building has escaped damage from Russian bombs. Many have been reduced to shells. Smoke rises from fires, and a haze hangs over the city. Falling snow mingles with ash and turns grey before it hits the ground. Stray dogs and cats roam in search of food.

An estimated 8,000 to 25,000 civilians remain in the city, mostly hiding in basements. There is little food. Those who venture on to the streets do so only because they have to. Most of the civilians are elderly Russians who lack the means or connections that would help them to escape.

"The losses among civilians are tremendous, and most of them are ethnic Russians," said Avalu Saydayev, 30, commander of a rebel reconnaissance platoon. "The federals are killing their own people."

The rebels have turned blocks of flats and government buildings into fortresses, strengthening hide-outs with concrete and logs. Within each city block, they have connected adjoining buildings by breaking through walls, allowing the fighters to move freely from one building to another without going outside. They travel through a maze of utility tunnels and surface in unexpected places to ambush Russian soldiers.

"The Russians can't understand why they keep pounding the city but nothing happens to us," Mr Saydayev said. "The federal troops have turned the city into a pile of rubble - the people who used to live in Grozny will have nothing to return to. City courtyards have been turned into cemeteries."

While the Russians measure success by the districts they claim to have captured, the Chechens aim to inflict maximum casualties. Their strategy is to yield territory to the Russians and then pick them off as they advance. Russia says it was a Chechen sniper who killed a Russian general a week ago as he urged his nervous troops to move forward.

Both sides claim to have inflicted huge losses on their enemies while suffering few casualties themselves. Chechen commanders say they sustained the highest number of fatalities in a single day a week ago, when 63 guerrillas died in intense fighting. The biggest losses come from Russian bombing, not from combat, rebel unit commander Mr Makhmayev said.

"Russian troops prefer not to engage in close combat with us," he said. "As soon as a gun battle starts, they immediately back off and call in aircraft or artillery."

During the first Chechen war, the Russians stormed Grozny and seized the city, but at a huge cost in lives. They held the city for more than a year, until the rebels returned and drove them out.

The Chechens are preparing for this war to follow the same pattern. Sooner or later, they expect government troops to gain the upper hand in Grozny. Then the surviving rebels will retreat into the Caucasus mountains to the south, where other rebel forces are also fighting Russian troops. They will regroup and strike when the time is right.

The Islamic fighters deride Russian claims that troops have Grozny surrounded.

"We will suffer no losses while pulling out of Grozny because we know the roads that are not controlled by the Russians," said Mr Israilov, the battalion commander. "Their statements that Grozny is encircled and sealed are nothing but a figment of the imagination. We can enter and leave the city whenever we want. We send our wounded warriors out of Grozny every day."

Abusalman Akhyadov, head of Chechnya's national security service, said pulling out of Grozny would not constitute a rebel defeat, but would mark the beginning of "the real war".

"With the fall of Grozny, the war will enter its main stage, and this is when the Russian aggressors who have stayed alive will envy those who were already killed in combat," said Mr Akhyadov. "We will turn this land into real hell for Russians. The Russians should remember their lessons from the previous war - Chechens never surrender."

webTitle: US proof of Pakistan link to hijack group hijackers

fields.headline: US proof of Pakistan link to hijack group hijackers
fields.standfirst:
Musharraf asked to end aid for Kashmir militants
The India-Pakistan conflict: special report
fields.trailText: The United States has confirmed that men who hijacked an Indian airliner last month belonged to the Harkat-ul-Mojahedin, and has evidence to prove that the group receives some support from the Pakistani government, the state department spokesman, James Rubin, said yesterday.
fields.body:
The United States has confirmed that men who hijacked an Indian airliner last month belonged to the Harkat-ul-Mojahedin, and has evidence to prove that the group receives some support from the Pakistani government, the state department spokesman, James Rubin, said yesterday.

But the US does not believe the Pakistani authorities had prior knowledge of the hijacking, or that they supported it, the White House spokesman, Joe Lockhart, added.

"We do not have evidence that the Pakistani government was in any way involved in that hijacking," President Bill Clinton told reporters at the White House.

The US has asked Pakistan to crack down on the group, and the Pakistanis say that they are considering the request, Mr Rubin said.

"There is some credible evidence that the hijacking was carried out by the Harkat-ul-Mojahedin," he said. "We have long said that the government of Pakistan does provide general support to a number of groups operating in Kashmir, including the Harkat-ul-Mojahedin."

Harkat-ul-Mojahedin, a radical Kashmiri nationalist group, changed its name from Harkat-ul-Ansar after it was put on the state department's list of terrorist groups in 1997.

Mr Rubin declined to comment on a New York Times report which quoted US officials as saying that Pakistan might end up on Washington's separate list of "state sponsors of terrorism". Listed countries can suffer sanctions.

India claims that the Pakistani government helped in the Indian Airlines hijacking, which ended on December 31 when the hijackers freed 155 hostages in exchange for India's release of three members of Harkat-ul-Mojahedin.

But Mr Lockhart said: "We have no evidence that the gov ernment of Pakistan had foreknowledge of, supported or helped carry out the hijacking."

Apart from the hijacking and political violence, the US is concerned at the close ties between Pakistan and the Taliban rulers of Afghanistan, where the hijacked plane was landed. It wants to see a quick return to democratic rule in Pakistan, where General Pervez Musharraf took power in a coup in October, ousting the prime minster, Nawaz Sharif.

During a visit to Pakistan last week, US officials asked Gen Musharraf to cut off support for Harkat-ul-Mojahedin and other militant groups active in the campaign against Indian rule in mainly Muslim Kashmir.

US officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, compared Pakistani support for the Kashmiri groups to the broad support that some Arab governments might give to the Palestinian Islamist movement Hamas.

webTitle: Asylum seekers up 55% as backlog grows

fields.headline: Asylum seekers up 55% as backlog grows
fields.standfirst: Refugees in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: A record number of more than 71,000 asylum seekers arrived in Britain last year, according to official figures published last night which also show that the backlog of those already here waiting for their cases to be decided has broken through the 100,000 mark for the first time.
fields.body:
A record number of more than 71,000 asylum seekers arrived in Britain last year, according to official figures published last night which also show that the backlog of those already here waiting for their cases to be decided has broken through the 100,000 mark for the first time.

The statistics show the number of people seeking asylum rose to 71,160 in 1999, an increase of 55% compared with 46,015 in 1998. The increase is partly accounted for by the organised airlift of refugees from Kosovo last summer.

The figures were announced as a report from the Commons public accounts committee attacked the home office for allowing the backlog to build up and voiced concern that it will continue to grow.

The report said: "The continuing backlog of cases awaiting processing by the immigration and nationality directorate has caused enormous personal distress to hundreds of thousands of applicants and their families. It is deplorable that these have continued for so long and that, even if the directorate's present target for clearing asylum cases is met, these very large backlogs are likely to continue to grow in the immediate future rather than decrease."

The MPs blamed the delays on the home office being "too ambitious" and on inadequate management when it decided to move the directorate's headquarters at the same time as undertaking a complex computerisation project.

The figures show that 7,180 new applications were received in December but the number of decisions made fell to 2,320 with 22% of applicants granted refugee status or allowed to stay on compassionate grounds. A wait of 10 months is regarded as typical. The backlog now stands at 102,870 compared with 64,770 at the same time last year.

The former Federal Republic of Yugoslavia topped the list of countries from which applicants came, followed by Sri Lanka, China, Somalia and Afghanistan.

Downing Street blamed the rise on the conflict in Kosovo and said the increase in asylum seekers was "not a problem unique to Britain".

The immigration minister, Barbara Roche, acknowledged that outstanding applications had doubled under Labour but insisted the new asylum and immigration act, including a move to a "cashless" voucher system of support, would tackle the problem.

But the shadow home secretary, Ann Widdecombe, claimed the figures were "yet another hammer blow for Calamity Jack and his incompetent ministers".

The Refugee Council chief executive, Nick Hardwick, urged that the figures be seen in a "fair and realistic" context. The Kosovo conflict last year had been the most serious in Europe since the war and the rising number of asylum seekers reflected the rising levels of human rights abuse and political persecution.

Although the numbers coming to Britain had risen dramatically last year, UN figures showed that Britain still took far fewer per 1,000 population than many smaller European countries. Switzerland had 5.8 applications per 1,000 population compared with 1.0 per 1,000 in Britain.

fields.headline: Good day, bad day
fields.standfirst: Life in Parliament
fields.trailText: Odd day
fields.body:
Odd day

Buster Bloodvessel, the rotund lead singer of ska band Bad Manners announced he is to campaign as a candidate for mayor of London. "I take a dim view of those who dismiss my bid as publicity-seeking nonsense," he complained.

Good day

Prince Charles, who won a top environmental award as the "most inspirational figure worldwide" in the debate over genetically modified crops. The Green Ribbon Political Awards panel said his stand had "infuriated the current gvernment"."

Bad day

John Redwood, shadow environment secretary. He won the conservation booby prize for the politician who had done most damage to the green cause in the last year. "The judges felt that John Redwood had amply lived up to his reputation as a man who seems to understand little, and care less, about the future of life on earth."

Today

Commons: International development questions. Questions to the prime minister. Financial services and markets bill, report.
