webTitle: Wackford Squeers sent packing by Mary Poppins

fields.headline: Wackford Squeers sent packing by Mary Poppins
fields.standfirst: Life in Parliament
fields.trailText: I'm collecting mythical facts at the moment - many thanks to many readers for those you've sent in - and one of the most interesting is the story of George Washington and the cherry tree. "Father, I cannot tell a lie," he allegedly said when confessing that he had chopped the tree down.
fields.body:
I'm collecting mythical facts at the moment - many thanks to many readers for those you've sent in - and one of the most interesting is the story of George Washington and the cherry tree. "Father, I cannot tell a lie," he allegedly said when confessing that he had chopped the tree down.

The story was invented by Parson Weems, an early biographer of Washington, who strongly believed it was always wrong to hit children.

The point of his fiction was not that children ought to be honest, but that if parents didn't hit them, they would wish to tell the truth.

Parson Weems would have adorned yesterday's brief Commons debate on the parental authority bill, introduced by Andrew Robathan, the Tory MP for Blaby, and fiercely opposed by Hilton Dawson, who sits for Labour in Lancaster.

Mr Robathan's bill would "allow parents to use reasonable force or chastisement [there's a five dollar word you rarely hear in real life] when exercising authority over their children."

Both he and Mr Dawson had terrible visions dancing in their heads. Mr Robathan saw the Nanny State, led by Tony Blair and his PC stormtroopers, bursting through people's front doors, seizing fathers, hurling them into prison for the crime of laying a gentle and reproving hand upon their offsprings' bottoms, while the children themselves were dragged from the loving hearth and tossed into local authority homes where they would be subjected to bestial abuse. I paraphrase, of course.

Mr Dawson, by contrast, could see an evil, pop-eyed paterfamilias, moustache bristling, a heavy split-ended cane in his hand, preparing to mutilate his own child for the crime of scrumping an apple or stealing a sweet. (Self-abuse being subject to ritual disembowelment.) He even suggested that Mr Robathan should have turned up in Victorian fancy dress.

Mr Robathan was particularly unhappy about a government consultation document which, he says, would make it even harder for parents to smack their children legally.

"Page 14 sets out ways in which the defence of 'reasonable' chastisement might be further - yes further - limited!" he proclaimed.

The whole thing was, he said, "political correctness gone wild." (Nicholas Winterton, who may believe that we should have capital punishment in primary schools, though I might be slightly overstating his position here, kept up a strident chorus throughout the speech. "Quite right!" "Ye-e-e-e-s!" and, on occasion, with mock horror, "No!")

"This," Mr Robathan continued, "is one of the most trite and condescending documents which I have ever seen!"

webTitle: What I'd do to the dome

fields.headline: What I'd do to the dome
fields.trailText: We had equal trouble finding 101 items (101 uses for a dead dome, January 25) when our university newspaper sought a list of things to do with our cavernous, gloomy Students Union venue in August 1998.
fields.body:
We had equal trouble finding 101 items (101 uses for a dead dome, January 25) when our university newspaper sought a list of things to do with our cavernous, gloomy Students Union venue in August 1998. So we made it 20, instead. Among others, some perhaps too rude for this paper, you missed out: 1) flood it, freeze it, and make the world's largest ice rink; 2) rollerdisco is due for a comeback - any day now; 3) house MPs in the arena and turn parliament into a museum; 4) put up "capsule" scaffolding and market it as a Japanese-style budget hotel/student lodgings/refugee hostel.
Jacqui Hill
Oxford Jacqui@mireille1.freeserve.co.uk
 Your No 18: "Convert it into a vast mausoleum for Baroness Thatcher". I have long advocated this use for the dome. My plan has the tomb built into a dance-floor - but it won't be big enough.
Dr Richard A'Brook
Carnoustie, Angus r.abrook@dundee.ac.uk

fields.headline: Detainees are cut off
fields.trailText: I read with interest details of the report given by Sir David Ramsbotham in which he expressed "deep concern" at the poor conditions of asylum seekers held at Rochester prison (Prison 'infested by vermin', January 21).
fields.body:
I read with interest details of the report given by Sir David Ramsbotham in which he expressed "deep concern" at the poor conditions of asylum seekers held at Rochester prison (Prison 'infested by vermin', January 21).

One aspect of the regime appears to have been omitted. This is the telephone system, which does not permit calls to be made directly to the detainees.

When attempting to obtain vital instructions from detainees in order to prepare a bail application, it is necessary to leave messages on the Rochester prison answerphone. If these messages are passed on, and we can not be certain that they are, the detainee can telephone us from a public payphone inside the prison using a phonecard. It is common to be cut off at a crucial stage of the conversation.

We are then left with the prospect of leaving more messages and being unsure of when we may next hear from our client. Detainees are issued by the prison with one complimentary phonecard. Any further phonecards must be purchased from the prison canteen using money provided by friends or relatives. Those detainees who have no contacts, or no family and friends able to send money, have no means of communicating with people outside the detention centre.

The way the system operates is not only extremely frustrating but at times threatens the effective preparation of the detainee's bail application. Very rarely do we receive the immigration service's reasons for detaining a person (a document known as the bail summary) until the day before the bail hearing.

The telephone system at Rochester makes it almost impossible to obtain instructions from the detainee on any additional points that may be raised in the summary.
Tim Baster
Bail for Immigration Detainees

webTitle: Caught between baby and the boss

fields.headline: Caught between baby and the boss
fields.trailText: Angela Phillips (Not guilty, baby, January 25), is quite correct when she suggests that Sarah Powell, maker of Monday night's Panorama programme, selectively quoted research studies in an attempt to support the view that mothers who go out to work are harming their children.
fields.body:
Angela Phillips (Not guilty, baby, January 25), is quite correct when she suggests that Sarah Powell, maker of Monday night's Panorama programme, selectively quoted research studies in an attempt to support the view that mothers who go out to work are harming their children. As the co-author of three recent reviews of research in this area, I was contacted by the production team. I was able to point to the same inconsistencies in their interpretations of Professor Joshi's work as Angela Phillips highlighted. I was also able to tell the team about two recent studies, both of which failed to support the programme's hypothesis.

The first, from the highly respected National Institute of Child Health and Human Development study conducted in the US, cited evidence showing that young children fare best when mothers are able to follow their employment choices. The second, a large scale study conducted in New Zealand, concluded that no good evidence has been found linking employment behaviours of mothers of infants to adolescent academic achievement. The production team were provided with references and quotes from published papers describing both studies, but chose not to mention either in their programme.
Dr Tony Munton
Thomas Coram Research Unit tony.munton@ioe.ac.uk
 Why on earth should we consider it a crucial parent's right to be away from small children for 10 hours a day, five days a week? Are my husband and I some kind of freaks in that both of us find the idea of missing so much of our two-year-old's company intolerable?

Surely the outrage is that people (and not just parents of young children) are being persuaded to sacrifice even more time than this to an outside employer in order to achieve a tolerable standard of living and to secure their future prospects?

My family is lucky, in that by buying/sharing about 20 hours a week childcare and having our son, between us, the rest of the time, we manage to scrape into skint rather than destitute. We might even get off benefits soon.

We are appalled by what so many of our acquaintances and friends put themselves through, but at the same time, of course, we smart constantly about our relative lack of cash.
Kate de Selincourt
Lydney, Glos kate@blackrock.u-net.com

 Angela Phillips misses an important point. The most striking image of the programme was of the mother quietly shedding tears after coming home late from work to find her young daughter already asleep. Here was a woman who was not bewailing the potential impact of poor academic qualifications or the inadequacies of government legislation, but simply, and desperately, missing being with her daughter and seeing her grow up. For me, this was the programme's prime message: that the have-it-all society simply isn't working for a generation of working parents who feel they are missing out on an important part of their lives, can see no way out, and are suffering terribly as a result.
Tony Smith
Dublin

 The key to this seemingly intractable problem seems to be Angela Phillips's remark "Why isn't it equally acceptable to say that if a man wants to be a parent he should parent like a woman?" If a lot more fathers pointed out that their employers' expectations conflicted with bath time, helping with homework, taking children to the dentist, etc, we might see some change. How often does a working father with a working partner ring in to say they have to stay at home because their child is ill?
Paul Keleher
London

 One rarely hears about the dilemma faced by women employers and the juggling they are forced into, in order to live up to their own ideals while having to struggle to make their businesses survive. The cost - both financial and organisational - of maternity leave, maternal sick leave, parental leave, etc, is enormous to a small business.

I run a nine-person architectural office employing seven women. Five of us have children. It is very difficult to keep on being politically correct without support. Who is helping small businesses encourage women into the workforce?
Barbara Weiss
London

 Is it really so much of a problem? When employers receive job applications, why should they consider those that will give them only half the hours they need from a prospective employee. Should a woman be given a job that another person can do for twice as long each week just because she has had a baby? Very sweet, but is it a viable economic proposition?

Most companies need the most out of all of their staff and in some cases women who have recently given birth cannot provide this. Clearly, we need jobs which people can do full time, and those suitable for part time recent parents. Let us not suppose, however, that the two are, or should be, interchangeable.
Jon Cornthwaite
Adam Smith Institute jon@adamsmith.org.uk

webTitle: Social workers lost to Britain - and South Africa

fields.headline: Social workers lost to Britain - and South Africa
fields.trailText: Social work has become less attractive to students for a range of reasons (Leader, January 25). Grants, such as are available to students in other professions with recruitment problems, will help. However, the training crisis is not just about attracting students, but about the declining ability of the current childcare system to provide them with the necessary practical experience.
fields.body:
Social work has become less attractive to students for a range of reasons (Leader, January 25). Grants, such as are available to students in other professions with recruitment problems, will help. However, the training crisis is not just about attracting students, but about the declining ability of the current childcare system to provide them with the necessary practical experience.

Those who start out wanting to work in childcare are diverted either during the training, or after qualification. Expensively trained practice teachers typically move into management having supervised an average of just three students. Many local authorities indulged in a bout of early retirement schemes a few years ago, stripping out experienced staff who should have provided security for newcomers. Skill comes through the ability to learn through practical experience: this does not happen by accident. The best child protection workers will be those whose natural intelligence and sensitivity is honed through good academic and practical education.

We are locked into a downward spiral in which hard pressed team managers understandably prioritise the allocation of child protection cases at the expense of providing student placements. There is, as a consequence, no next generation. Turning this around requires some rather longer-term thinking than is represented by the importation of overseas staff.
Prof Laura Middleton
University of Central Lancashire
laura@midd16.freeserve.co.uk

 Why is England allowed to continue stealing the precious resources of former colonies? South African social workers, like physiotherapists, accountants and other professionals are a sought after commodity in the UK and for very good reasons: they have been well trained, they work hard (the absence of a social security system to fall back on means that people really don't give up when the going gets tough) and they are adaptable, creative and reliable employees.

Yes, the population of Essex will benefit enormously from the four years of excellent and subsidised training which those young women and men received. At the same time the brain drain from South Africa will deprive the very poorest people in the world of services which they desperately need.

South Africans will con tinue to respond to recruitment fairs because salaries paid in pounds, when converted into rand, seem like a fortune. Little do they know that their £15k per annum will buy them a damp room in a shared house in Chelmsford or Leytonstone or Southend. Their lives will be miserable and they will be locked into contracts with the agencies which employed them.

Late last year the NHS executive advised NHS trusts that they were no longer allowed to recruit South African nurses after Nelson Mandela intervened. In 1999, 600 nurses became economic refugees and left their beautiful country to work in the ailing NHS doing a job which few people here want to do.
Roslyn Cassidy
London

webTitle: Read Romano Prodi's mail. Or not.

fields.headline: Read Romano Prodi's mail. Or not.
fields.standfirst: The European Commission: special report
fields.trailText: EU citizens will soon be able to read Romano Prodi's post, or at least know what letters the president of the European Commission has been writing - under a new freedom of information initiative.
fields.body:
EU citizens will soon be able to read Romano Prodi's post, or at least know what letters the president of the European Commission has been writing - under a new freedom of information initiative.

Anxious to combat the commission's reputation for secrecy, Mr Prodi announced yesterday that he would shortly be making a register of his correspondence available on his personal website.

"Transparency is vital for the democratic health and accountability of the EU,' the former Italian prime minister said - apparently trying to set an example to colleagues.

Aides said this did not mean Mr Prodi's personal correspondence would be available, or that all official letters would be either - though it would be known whom he had written to on such and such a date.

"Outgoing correspondence will carry a warning to the recipient that all future correspondence will be publicly registered and may be made available to third parties," a statement said.

Mr Prodi's initiative was criticised as an attempt to divert attention from broader freedom of information proposals due to be published today, which have been criticised as a step back for open government.

Under an existing code of conduct, anyone may apply for any documents from the commission, the European Council of Ministers and European parliament and then the institution can apply exceptions.

But the new proposals, widely leaked in Brussels, create whole categories of papers that cannot be applied for - on the grounds that officials need protection for their "space to think to formulate policy".

Exceptions include "discussion documents, opinions of departments and informal messages". Other areas that are declared off-limits are "relations between or with member states or non-community institutions" and matters touching on the "stability of the community legal order."

"Prodi's announcement about his correspondence is clearly a diversion, as the latest proposals are taking us back to before Maastricht days," said Tony Bunyan of Statewatch, which monitors the state and civil liberties in the EU. "They are putting the clock back."

The council of ministers, where the 15 EU governments cooperate, is now less secretive than the commission.

Experts predict that the definition of what constitutes "space to think" will provide rich pickings for the European Court of Justice, which rules on the EU's treaties.

But today's proposals do not, as anticipated, include an order to member states that they must follow the same practice at their national level - an idea which provoked outrage in Sweden, with the most advanced freedom of information system in the world.

The proposals were drawn up after the 1997 Amsterdam Treaty called on the commission to "enshrine" the citizens' right of access to documents. They have to be adopted under the co-decision procedure by the council of ministers, the commission and the European parliament by June 2001.

"This is much more liberal than some had anticipated but still not liberal enough," said one diplomat.

fields.headline: Therapists in the pulpit
fields.standfirst:
Will anyone heed the church on divorce?
Religion in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: Anglican vicars, by and large, are  awfully nice people, always anxious to help, and touchingly surprised that you want to have anything to do with them at all. So the question of remarriage of divorcees in church has always been agonising for many.
fields.body:
Anglican vicars, by and large, are awfully nice people, always anxious to help, and touchingly surprised that you want to have anything to do with them at all. So the question of remarriage of divorcees in church has always been agonising for many.

At the proverbial coalface of parish life, Anglican priests find themselves confronted by the profusion of distress, lust, irresponsibility, disillusionment, boredom and tragedy which add up to marriage breakdown. Given that the Anglican church was founded by a king who married six times, it is hardly surprising that many priests find it hard to turn away couples who want to remarry in church. The result has been an inconsistent muddle of practice and theology which yesterday's report from the church is intended to clear up.

In practice, though, it replaces one muddle with another. How is a priest to decide that the remarrying couple are "emotionally stable" and "emotionally wise" and possess "good judgment"? Or establish a "clear distance" between the old and the new marriage, or be sure that a "former partner is not forced to endure the reopening of old wounds"? An enterprising therapist should set up an advice helpline on how to mug up on such subtle skills. Priests are no longer expected to hand out judgments on our morality, but on our emotional health. They have completed the transformation from theologian to ersatz therapist.

The report obviously attempts to soften a punitive morality, but ducks the central challenge to any religious institution in the west - that marriage is now perceived, for good or ill, as a matter for the dictates of the individual's own heart, and no deference is paid to any external authority. This is a difficult time for the church; it is damned if it does, and damned if it doesn't. It holds to its ancient role of telling people what to do and what not to do. But its efforts go unrewarded; most parishioners, it seems, have simply stopped listening.

The result has been an inconsistent muddle of practice and theology which yesterday's report from the church is intended to clear up. In practice, though, it replaces one muddle with another. How is a priest to decide that the remarrying couple are "emotionally stable" and "emotionally wise" and possess "good judgment"? Or establish a "clear distance" between the old and the new marriage, or be sure that a "former partner is not forced to endure the reopening of old wounds"? An enterprising therapist should set up an advice helpline on how to mug up on such subtle skills. Priests are no longer expected to hand out judgments on our morality, but on our emotional health. They have completed the transformation from theologian to ersatz therapist. The report obviously attempts to soften a punitive morality, but ducks the central challenge to any religious institution in the west - that marriage is now perceived, for good or ill, as a matter for the dictates of the individual's own heart, and no deference is paid to any external authority. This is a difficult time for the church; it is damned if it does, and damned if it doesn't. It holds to its ancient role of telling people what to do and what not to do. But its efforts go unrewarded; most parishioners, it seems, have simply stopped listening.

fields.headline: Republican drops out after polling 1%
fields.standfirst: The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: Monday's Iowa caucuses claimed their first political victim yesterday when Senator Orrin Hatch became the latest US Republican presidential hopeful to drop out of the race for the White House.
fields.body:
Monday's Iowa caucuses claimed their first political victim yesterday when Senator Orrin Hatch became the latest US Republican presidential hopeful to drop out of the race for the White House.

Mr Hatch's decision, due to be confirmed at a Washington press conference today, follows an abysmal showing in Iowa, when he trailed in last, garnering 1% in the state's Republican caucuses.

The Utah senator, who has been a powerful figure on Capitol Hill for 24 years, had earlier said he would reconsider his campaign if he finished last in Iowa. When only 820 Iowans voted for him on Monday night, he duly concluded that his cause was hopeless.

Mr Hatch joins a distinguished list of Republicans who have been unable to match the money and support gathered by party frontrunner George W Bush, who finished first with 41% of the vote in Iowa.

Others who have fallen by the wayside include former governor Lamar Alexander, Senator John Ashcroft, Elizabeth Dole, the former vice-president, Dan Quayle, and Senator Bob Smith.

The mystery about Senator Hatch's campaign is not so much why it failed to take off as why he ever undertook it at all. The veteran senator has a big reputation in Washington, where he is chairman of the senate judiciary committee and a leading proponent of tax reform.

But he joined the campaign late, had little organisation, could not afford to run television advertising and said he was only in the race in case Mr Bush, with whose policies he agrees, faltered.

Mr Hatch is now expected to run for re-election to the senate from Utah in November, a contest which he is almost certain to win.

webTitle: Gore and Bush shine in White House race

fields.headline: Gore and Bush shine in White House race
fields.standfirst:
Iowa caucus vote confirms party favourites as frontrunners

The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: Democrat Al Gore and Republican George W Bush were out campaigning for votes again at dawn yesterday in New Hampshire, only hours after convincing victories in Monday's Iowa caucuses which confirmed that they are the men to beat in the American presidential race.
fields.body:
Democrat Al Gore and Republican George W Bush were out campaigning for votes again at dawn yesterday in New Hampshire, only hours after convincing victories in Monday's Iowa caucuses which confirmed that they are the men to beat in the American presidential race.

The two Iowa winners, both backed by their party establishments, confirmed their frontrunner status by beating back their respective challengers by substantial margins, but the picture could be dramatically changed in next Tuesday's primary in New Hampshire, where much closer contests are likely.

The biggest winner in Iowa was the vice-president, Al Gore, who crowned an impressive recent campaign fightback by trouncing his only rival, former senator Bill Bradley, by an unexpectedly large margin of 63% to 35% in the Democratic contest. Mr Gore's performance was all the stronger for being based on clear wins among almost all categories of voters.

The vice-president watched the results come in from his Des Moines hotel headquarters with his wife Tipper. Later, he told cheering supporters that he had won "the biggest victory in the history of the contested caucuses in Iowa".

Within minutes, he was being driven to Air Force Two to fly to New Hampshire in the early hours to resume his contest with Mr Bradley. A poll yesterday showed Mr Gore and Mr Bradley level pegging there.

Mr Bradley's 35% slightly exceeded his camp's last-minute spin, but it was a poor return for a month of campaigning in Iowa in which he spent more than $800,000 (£500,000).

Before leaving Iowa, Mr Bradley made clear that his defeat would not cause him to throw in the towel or, more surprisingly, to change a style which has been criticised for being too aloof.

The former New Jersey senator told supporters that he had "a little more humility but no less confidence that I can win".

Mr Bush, the governor of Texas and the son of the former president, George Bush, claimed a "record-shattering victory" in the Iowa Republican race.

"This victory marks the beginning of the end of the Clinton era," Mr Bush told his supporters at a Des Moines rally. But although Mr Bush finished well ahead of any of his party rivals, the Republican result left many more unanswered questions than did the Democratic contest.

In a six-man Republican race, Mr Bush took 41% of the votes, followed by the millionaire publisher Steve Forbes, who finished second with 30%. The black anti-abortion conservative Alan Keyes was third with 14%, followed by family values campaigner Gary Bauer on 9%, Arizona Senator John McCain on 5% and Utah Senator Orrin Hatch in last place with 1%.

Mr Bush's clear but inconclusive victory means that the New Hampshire Republican contest is likely to become a crucial test for his reputation as an irresistible winner.

To pass that test Mr Bush must reverse the poll lead there of Mr McCain, who did not campaign in Iowa, and must simultaneously fight off the renewed strength of Mr Forbes and Mr Keyes. Mr McCain is ahead of Mr Bush in the nine most recent New Hampshire polls, including one yesterday giving him an 11-point advantage.

Mr Forbes's strong showing enabled him to lay immediate claim to the mantle of conser vative frontrunner in the Republican race.

"I am pumped," Mr Forbes told supporters. "This is a victory for ideas. New Hampshire is now a tight three-way contest with me fighting the conservative cause against two moderates."

The importance of Mr Forbes's second place was somewhat subverted by the strong showing of his fellow conservative Mr Keyes, a staunch Roman Catholic and former Reagan administration ambassador who has climbed from the bottom of the heap to a clear Iowa third place largely on the strength of his trenchant moral values and anti-abortion oratory.

As so often in the past, the Iowa caucuses are likely to winnow the field of candidates as well as boosting the winners. Senator Hatch yesterday withdrew from the race along with the social conservative, Mr Bauer.

webTitle: Anglicans ease line on church weddings for divorcees

fields.headline: Anglicans ease line on church weddings for divorcees
fields.standfirst: Religion in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: The Church of England, created 470 years ago so that Henry VIII could divorce Catherine of Aragon and marry Anne Boleyn, finally caught up with the reality of failed marriages among commoners yesterday by launching national   guidelines for clergy to remarry divorcees in church.
fields.body:
The Church of England, created 470 years ago so that Henry VIII could divorce Catherine of Aragon and marry Anne Boleyn, finally caught up with the reality of failed marriages among commoners yesterday by launching national guidelines for clergy to remarry divorcees in church.

But the guidelines offer little comfort to the survivor of another royal divorce, Prince Charles, should he seek a church wedding to his partner Camilla Parker-Bowles.

Two of the new rules explicitly militate against a cathedral ceremony for the prince, the future supreme governor of the Church of England.

Couples will not normally be remarried if their relationship contributed to the original divorce. And no priest should bless a second marriage which might cause "hostile public comment or scandal".

The guidelines, published yesterday as a draft and not to be finally approved by the general synod until 2001, address a characteristic case of muddled Anglican conscience whereby the church officially disapproves of remarriage but, in practice, condones it.

Since 1981, when the synod resolved that certain people "may be married in church during the lifetime of a former spouse", the number of church weddings where one or more partner is divorced has risen steadily. In fact, some Anglican clergy were marrying divorcees even earlier.

In 1996, there were 7,270 Anglican church weddings in England and Wales involving divorcees - almost 10% of all church weddings.

"Since very soon after the time of Jesus, every church in every situation has had to look at the question of what to do about the reality that, tragically, some marriages do break down and die," said the Right Reverend Michael Scott-Joynt, Bishop of Winchester, who led the church team which produced the guidelines.

"With some people, it is clear their past marriage has not been left behind, that its obligations have not been honoured. Some people, in asking the church to help them to make a second marriage, are asking us to approve of behaviour of which we cannot approve.

"We're not proposing indiscriminate further marriage. We are recommending a straightforward procedure whereby clergy may solemnise further marriages of divorced persons where the criteria have been met."

The bishop denied that the guidelines implied a shift in the church's position that marriage was for life.

But it does seem to have changed its stance. Previously, it maintained that marriage was theologically indissoluble. Now it says the key is whether a couple, at the time of marriage, sincerely believe they are making a lifelong commitment.

Critical to acceptance of the guidelines by clergy and lay worshippers is the stricture that the final decision on whether or not to remarry a divorcee will be left with the parish priest.

On the face of it, that is the position now. But the church hierarchy hopes that by giving a standard framework for second marriages it will encourage more priests to solemnise second marriages without alienating traditionalists.

Nearly one in two marriages in the UK now ends in divorce. An average of 150,000 couples divorce each year.

Second time around

Draft requirements for divorcees seeking a Church of England wedding:

 Parish priest to make final decision

 At least two confidential interviews with couple

 Report on case to be sent to diocesan bishop for advice

 Couples should understand that divorce is a breach of God's will

 Couples should be determined for new marriage to be lifelong

 Divorcee should be honest with self about the past; must forgive and repent

 Divorcee should have fully disclosed to new partner the background to divorce

 Children and spouse from previous marriage should be provided for

 "Reasonable" time should have elapsed between divorce and fresh marriage

 New marriage should not be likely to provoke "hostile public comment or scandal"

 Couple's relationship should not have caused divorce

 Two strikes and you're out: neither bride nor groom should have been divorced more than once

 Couple should show signs of "a developing Christian faith"

webTitle: Isle of Man to raise fishing boat

fields.headline: Isle of Man to raise fishing boat
fields.trailText: The parliament of the Isle of Man yesterday agreed to raise the Solway Harvester, the fishing boat which sank earlier this month with the loss of its seven crew.
fields.body:
The parliament of the Isle of Man yesterday agreed to raise the Solway Harvester, the fishing boat which sank earlier this month with the loss of its seven crew.

Following the Tynwald decision to meet the estimated £1m cost, it is hoped the operation will be under way by the weekend. Calm weather is forecast in the Irish Sea.

Donald Gelling, chief minister of the Tynwald, said the priority was to recover the bodies. Last week an underwater camera located one body and it is believed that the six others are still on board.

Once the vessel - which is lying in 100ft of water 11 miles from the Irish coast - is raised, investigators will try to establish what caused it to sink in conditons it had faced many times before.

The seven were the skipper, Andrew Craig Mills, 29; his brother, Robin Mills, 33; their cousin, David Mills, 18; John Murphy, 22; Martin Milligan, 26; David Lyons, 17; and Wesley Jolly, 17.

webTitle: Gay couple's twins win right to stay

fields.headline: Gay couple's twins win right to stay
fields.trailText: A gay couple were last night celebrating victory after their surrogate twins were granted indefinite leave to stay in the UK.
fields.body:
A gay couple were last night celebrating victory after their surrogate twins were granted indefinite leave to stay in the UK.

The twins were denied automatic entry last month when their "parents", Barrie Drewitt and Tony Barlow, from Danbury, Essex, flew into Heathrow from California, but yesterday Jack Straw, the home secretary, granted them indefinite leave.

A spokesman for the home office said Mr Straw had taken the decision outside normal immigration law, which did not allow for the unique circumstances of this case. The home secretary had taken into account the exceptional circumstances and the welfare of the children.

The case could only be seen as setting a precedent if a subsequent application was made in identical circumstances, and future cases would continue to be examined on their merits, the spokesman added.

Aspen and Saffron Drewitt-Barlow were born last month after the men contacted a surrogacy agency in Los Angeles following the rejection of an application to adopt in Britain. Four eggs were fertilised and then implanted in Rosalind Bellamy, 32, a married mother of four, using sperm from one of the men. The eggs were donated by a separate woman, Tracie Matthews, to ensure that neither woman could claim the children after birth.

Mr Drewitt and Mr Barlow, who have sold exclusive rights to their story to a Sunday newspaper, created legal history when the US supreme court acknowledged them as parents of the twins.

Mr Drewitt's mother, Veronica Drewitt, said she had spoken to her son, who was delighted at the decision.

Stonewall, the gay rights pressure group, welcomed the decision. "It is a shame that Barrie and Tony are not recognised in British law as their parents, but that is a battle to come." Paul Kelso

fields.headline: New photo of wanted Frenchman
fields.trailText: Police have issued another photograph of a Frenchman wanted in connection with the murder of his mother-in-law and a knife attack on his estranged wife.
fields.body:
Police have issued another photograph of a Frenchman wanted in connection with the murder of his mother-in-law and a knife attack on his estranged wife.

West Midlands police said they were trying to trace Cherif Doua, 37, a motor trader from the Paris area, in connection with the incident in Hateley Heath, West Bromwich, on Monday. His wife, Jayne, 27, was stabbed six times. Her mother, Valerie Brocklesby, 62, died.

Detective Chief Inspector Paul Williamson of West Bromwich CID said: "We found Jayne Doua lying in the hallway with multiple stab wounds and Valerie in the kitchen with multiple stab wounds to her head, face and upper body." Mrs Doua's injuries were not life threatening. A knife and another weapon were found.

Police have been in contact with the French authorities and Interpol. Ports and airports have been alerted.

"We have released a second photo which we believe shows him as he was with short dark hair," said Mr Williamson.

webTitle: Public figures and staff honour Hetherington

fields.headline: Public figures and staff honour Hetherington
fields.trailText: The spirit of Alastair Hetherington - fifth of only seven editors of the Guardian in the 130 years since CP Scott was appointed - was honoured yesterday with Gaelic songs amid a throng of personal and political memories.
fields.body:
The spirit of Alastair Hetherington - fifth of only seven editors of the Guardian in the 130 years since CP Scott was appointed - was honoured yesterday with Gaelic songs amid a throng of personal and political memories.

The Labour politician Tony Benn told a thanksgiving service at the Crown Court Church of Scotland, Covent Garden, London, that he was a truly great editor who had resisted demands by successive prime ministers for "absolute support and total silence".

Mr Hetherington, editor from 1956-1975, died in October, aged 79. He played a decisive part in saving the paper from collapse or merger with the Times during a mid-1960s financial crisis.

Peter Preston, his successor until 1995, said his spirit still inhabited the paper's work and thought. Its core message was that "there is no such thing as a fate that can't be challenged or a force which has to be accepted; that men and women, by their own efforts, can always make a better world. His voice, three decades on, is as fresh as ever."

The thanksgiving was a rare event at which a paper normally preoccupied with daily production wore some of its personal bonds and feelings on its sleeve in public.

As well as readers, the service drew an unprecedented turn-out of some 120 retired or former members of staff, some with links stretching back more than half a century.

Among the old Guards (or "the old Grauds", as a younger reporter called them) was a pioneering women's editor accused 40 years ago by management of producing pages obsessed with "unmarried women graduates"; and a leader writer who resigned over 1960s Vietnam policies.

Public figures included the writer Michael Frayn, an ex-Guardian diarist, the former BBC director general Sir Michael Checkland and Mr Hetherington's contemporary as Times editor, Lord Rees-Mogg.

Also there was Richard Scott, the only living person to have known all seven Guardian editors since his grandfather, CP Scott. Mr Scott, former chairman of the Scott Trust, which owns the paper, said: "Alastair was the first of the modern editors. For him, too, facts were sacred. He too believed a newspaper had a moral as well as a material existence. But Alastair never had it quite so easy. Power and authority within the paper had moved from the editor's to the manager's chair. Alastair had to fight and did fight. Indeed, had he not done so at one very low point in the paper's financial situation, it is more than likely that the Guardian as we know it would have ceased to exist."

The BBC's retired political editor, John Cole, who was Mr Hetherington's deputy, recalled his will, courage, "sheer animal stamina" and "sense of radical mischief. He never became an establishment figure and that was his personal choice."

His widow, Sheila, said: "Life with Alastair was like being part of a whirlwind, often unexpected but always full of delight." She added of his first wife, Miranda, the mother of his children: "He was rightly proud of them all and was an unfailingly loving father."

After leaving the Guardian, Mr Hetherington returned to his homeland to become controller of BBC Scotland, where he is cherished for promoting Gaelic culture. In recognition of this and his love of Scots islands - as well as of the sadness of the Alzheimer's disease which clouded his last years - the Gaelic singer Iseabail McTaggart sang the lament An Ataireachd Ard (The High Swelling of the Sea):

The roar of the sea is as was heard by me as a child,

Without change, without pity, shovelling the sand of the shore.

The everlasting swelling, listen to the sound of the swelling.

But I'll depart from you, I'll not move any more to meet you,

My age and my appearance tell the shortness of my day,

I am wrapped in the cold slumber of death.

Make up my bed behind the sound of the sea.

Power and authority within the paper had moved from the editor's to the manager's chair. Alastair had to fight and did fight. Indeed, had he not done so at one very low point in the paper's financial situation, it is more than likely that the Guardian as we know it would have ceased to exist." The BBC's retired political editor, John Cole, who was Mr Hetherington's deputy, recalled his will, courage, "sheer animal stamina" and "sense of radical mischief. He never became an establishment figure and that was his personal choice." His widow, Sheila, said: "Life with Alastair was like being part of a whirlwind, often unexpected but always full of delight." She added of his first wife, Miranda, the mother of his children: "He was rightly proud of them all and was an unfailingly loving father." After leaving the Guardian, Mr Hetherington returned to his homeland to become controller of BBC Scotland, where he is cherished for promoting Gaelic culture. In recognition of this and his love of Scots islands - as well as of the sadness of the Alzheimer's disease which clouded his last years - the Gaelic singer Iseabail McTaggart sang the lament An Ataireachd Ard (The High Swelling of the Sea): The roar of the sea is as was heard by me as a child, Without change, without pity, shovelling the sand of the shore. The everlasting swelling, listen to the sound of the swelling. But I'll depart from you, I'll not move any more to meet you, My age and my appearance tell the shortness of my day, I am wrapped in the cold slumber of death. Make up my bed behind the sound of the sea.

fields.headline: Home-alone girl, 3, 'critical' after fire
fields.trailText: Police are waiting to interview the family of a three-year-old girl who suffered 80% burns from a gas fire after she was left at home with her two-year-old brother while her mother collected an older child from school.
fields.body:
Police are waiting to interview the family of a three-year-old girl who suffered 80% burns from a gas fire after she was left at home with her two-year-old brother while her mother collected an older child from school.

Two builders alerted by a man found Farah Kauser on fire and stuck to a chair by her melted clothes after forcing open a window of the family's terrace house in Ravensthorpe, West Yorkshire.

The child was critically ill in intensive care at Pinderfields burns unit in Wakefield last night as police appealed for help in reconstructing events leading up to the accident on Monday. Detectives are keen to trace an unidentified man who ran up the street shouting "Smoke, smoke", bringing builders Ian Douglas and John Paxman from a nearby building site to the rescue.

They forced a window and carried the child to a neighbour's house, where she was doused with water to cool the burns until paramedics arrived. Mr Douglas, 35, and Mr Paxman, 39, both from Halifax, estimated the children had been left alone for over half an hour, but a neighbour, who did not want to be named, said the mother, Kauser Hussain, had been gone "for only a few minutes".

Charges were effectively ruled out last night by West Yorkshire police, who said that comforting the family and treating Farah were the priorities. Detective Inspector John Birkenshaw, of Dewsbury CID, said: "Our heart goes to the family and all the people closely involved. Police inquiries are continuing but this is being treated as a tragic accident."

The head of the inquiry, Detective Chief Superintendent Max McLean, said: "I would not expect any charges. This was a tragic accident. We have still got a little girl fighting for her life in hospital. I am more bothered about that at the moment."

Mr Douglas and Mr Paxman said they had run to the house and looked through the letter box to see flames coming from the front room. Mr Paxman said: "We heard a girl moaning. When we got in through the window, she was just sat there in front of the fire, which was on full. There were flames and she was so hot it was hard to pick her up."

Farah is being treated to burns to all parts of her body above her knees. Her brother was not injured in the fire. Their uncle, Mohammed Sabir, who lives in the neighbouring street, said: "It's all too much for us at the moment. We as a family are distraught. As you know, the child is in a critical condition. Her parents are at her bedside. She is not conscious and is knocked out with drugs for the pain."

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Jaundice boy's £1.8m
fields.body:
Jaundice boy's £1.8m

A boy left brain damaged at birth after doctors failed to diagnose jaundice has won £1.8m agreed damages following a hearing at the high court.

Jay Johnson, of Portsmouth, now 10, contracted jaundice the day after he was born at St Mary's hospital, Portsmouth, in 1989, but it was not diagnosed for 32 months.

Germans gag MI6 runaway

The renegade former MI6 officer Richard Tomlinson has been served with a German court order preventing him from disclosing information about the activities of the secret intelligence service, the foreign office said yesterday.

The order was made at the request of Lord Williams, the attorney general, after Mr Tomlinson, 36, threatened to reveal new information about MI6, officials said.

Shipman jury still out

The jury in the trial of Harold Shipman, the GP accused of murdering 15 women patients, was sent home again last night after a second day of deliberations at Preston crown court.

webTitle: Full exposure Censored pictures see the light

fields.headline: Full exposure Censored pictures see the light
fields.trailText: The least memorable photographs of the last century - deemed too shocking, embarrassing or politically awkward to be shown - are finally to go on display in an exhibition in London.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy  Arts and Heritage Correspondent
fields.body:
The least memorable photographs of the last century - deemed too shocking, embarrassing or politically awkward to be shown - are finally to go on display in an exhibition in London.

Underexposed, a Century of Censorship, includes a startling image of Adolf Hitler rehearsing rhetorical gestures while listening to a recording of one of his earlier speeches.

When he saw the picture, which exploded the myth of his oratorical spontaneity, Hitler ordered the destruction of the negative. But it was secretly preserved by his official photographer Heinrich Hoffman.

The exhibition demonstrates how difficult it is for even the most paranoid authority to obliterate an image. In 1989 Iranian authorities tried to confiscate every roll of film taken in a crowd estimated at 2m, after chaotic scenes at the funeral of Ayatollah Khomeini in Tehran.

One photograph survived, and was smuggled out of Iran. It showed Khomeini's corpse stripped near naked and almost pitched out of its coffin by frantic souvenir hunters.

The exhibition was devised by Index on Censorship, a charity dedicated to fighting international censorship and repression.

It was compiled in cooperation with the Hulton Getty Picture Collection and involved a trawl through many thousands of images.

Some pictures were censored by authorities, but some were never published by the magazines or newspapers which commissioned them. Photographs of London in the immediate aftermath of a second world war bombing were judged too sapping to public morale by Picture Post.

The collection includes images which were published after the photographers risked their lives to obtain them. Photographs of President Salvador Allende, emerging nervously into the daylight during the coup in Chile in 1973, were sent anonymously to the New York Times.

They were taken shortly before he was murdered, but proved he was alive when the Chilean military junta claimed he had already committed suicide.

Several light-hearted images are also included in the exhibition, including one taken in Rome in 1966 which only the paparazzi would have wanted banned.

It shows the notorious Rino Barillari, leader of a pack of scooter-riding celebrity-hunters - who inspired the Fellini film La Dolce Vita - getting his comeuppance from an ice cream cornet wielded with precision by the Yugoslav actress Sonia Romanoff.

Underexposed, a Century of Censorship, is at the Proud Galleries, Buckingham Street, London, from January 28 to February 25.

fields.headline: Beowulf slays the wizard
fields.trailText: Seamus Heaney, the Irish Nobel laureate, won the Whitbread book of the year award for the second time last night, when his ancient warrior Beowulf slew the upstart young wizard Harry Potter. It is the fourth year in a row that a poet has won the £22,000 prize.
fields.body:
Seamus Heaney, the Irish Nobel laureate, won the Whitbread book of the year award for the second time last night, when his ancient warrior Beowulf slew the upstart young wizard Harry Potter. It is the fourth year in a row that a poet has won the £22,000 prize.

Heaney's translation of the ancient Anglo-Saxon epic poem about a great warlord who comes to the aid of a king, stopped the steamroller of hype and expectation behind JK Rowling's phenomenonally successful children's book, Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban. Her trilogy has been credited with dragging a generation of children away from their Playstations.

Many in literary London had suspected that the rules of the Whitbread, which up until this year barred children's books from the main competition, had been changed for Harry Potter's sake.

But Dr Eric Anderson, the chairman of the judges, and Tony Blair's former English master at Fettes, said although the book came an unofficial second it did not go to a vote.

"Beowulf was the clear winner. There was no real disagreement. This was a master poet breathing life into a great work of art which has only been known to a small number of academics. He has retrieved a buried golden treasure," he said.

Heaney, 60, dedicated the winning book to his late friend Ted Hughes, who has won the prize for the last two years running. Dr Anderson said they had no qualms about choosing another book of poetry. "There was some argument over whether a translation was the same as a collection, but that was it. This has been a remarkable period for poetry. Two colossi have bestrode this narrow world in recent years. Hughes and Heaney are the greatest poets of the 20th century after TS Eliot."

The poet and critic Tom Paulin called Heaney's Be owulf a "timeless classic... a hymn to the deep North Sea energies and roots of the English language". Heaney, a scholar of Anglo-Saxon, first began the translation 15 years ago.

JK Rowling, the 2/1 joint favourite with Heaney, was struck down by flu and could not leave Edinburgh. She can draw some comfort, however, from the fact that her book won the £10,000 children's prize.

The snubbing of Harry Potter was not the only bit of controversy around this year's prize. The presence of model Jerry Hall on the judging panel was condemned by rival Booker Prize organiser Martyn Goff as "blatant dumbing down". She is known to be an avid Harry Potter fan and is believed to have argued for Rowling. But Dr Anderson said "all the judges had extremely pertinent things to say and brought freshness to the discussions".

Rowling's trilogy about the boy wizard Harry Potter has already sold more than 27.5m copies worldwide. Her fourth book, not yet finished, has already become an internet bestseller on advance orders alone.

The story behind the first book Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone has now passed into publishing legend. Rowling, a penniless single mother, wrote it by longhand in a series of cafes where she went to save money on heating bills.

The other books on the shortlist were Rose Tremain's novel Music and Silence, White City Blue by Tim Lott and the second volume of David Cairns's biography of Berlioz, Servitude and Greatness.

webTitle: Mystery of missing plane solved, 50 years on

fields.headline: Mystery of missing plane solved, 50 years on
fields.standfirst: Remains of passengers and crew found in wreckage of ill-fated Lancaster flight 5,500 metres up in the Argentinian Andes
fields.trailText: The mystery of a British plane which disappeared on its way to Chile more than 50 years ago is nearer being solved. Remains of the passengers and crew of a converted Lancaster bomber have been found 5,500 metres up in the Andean mountains of Argentina, preserved by the freezing temperatures.
fields.byline: Jonathan Franklin  and  Duncan Campbell  in Santiago
fields.body:
The mystery of a British plane which disappeared on its way to Chile more than 50 years ago is nearer being solved. Remains of the passengers and crew of a converted Lancaster bomber have been found 5,500 metres up in the Andean mountains of Argentina, preserved by the freezing temperatures.

The five-strong team which reached the crash site on the Tupungato peak have recovered a propeller, piece of a wing and an oxygen canister in "near perfect" condition. The fuselage of the aircraft, named Stardust, appears to have shattered into small pieces.

Raul Carduso, an Argentinian army sergeant who took part in the recovery expedition, speaking from the 11th mountain infantry regiment base on Tupungato, said: "The metal has turned all white and you could walk right by it without noticing. Then we found clothes, cans and some human remains. The impact must have been terribly strong because the remains were mutilated and spread out over a large area. Everything was perfectly frozen, including a woman's hand."

It was August, 1947, when the plane, operated by the now-defunct British South America Airways, took off from London for the Chilean capital via Ascension Island and Buenos Aires. On the final stage of the journey there were five crew members, all British, and six passengers, three British, one Palestinian, one German and one Swiss.

The crew was listed as Reginald Cook, 29, the pilot; Norman Cook, 31, the second officer; Donald Checklin, the radio operator; Dennis Harmer, 27; and Iris Evans, 26, the stewardess.

The passengers were Paul Simons, 44, a British diplomatic messenger who had boarded the flight in London; Peter Young, also British, who boarded in Buenos Aires; Eric Gooderham, British, who also boarded in Argentina; Martha Limpert, 67, a German; Said Atallah, the Palestinian; and Harold Pagh, a Swiss national.

The plane, converted for passenger use after the second world war, left Buenos Aires without the crew realising that they would be running into a fierce snowstorm as they crossed the mountains. The pilot told air controllers in Santiago that they were on schedule to arrive at about 2pm on August 2, 1947. That was the last that was heard of the plane.

A search involving planes from the UK, the US, Chile and Argentina was launched as airline officials believed that there was a possibility that there would be survivors. The plane was reckoned strong enough to survive an impact on snow and it was equipped with medical and survival supplies. Relatives of the Palestinian offered searchers a reward of 50,000 pesos but no trace was ever found even after a civilian pilot flew over the flight path in a Spitfire. A Chilean army ski patrol was also unable to find any trace.

Then in 1997, while on a posting to a remote Andean military base, Sgt Cardoso was handed a piece of metal. A group of mountain climbers from Buenos Aires had stumbled across the fragment while descending through a glacier field near the Tupungato mountain. Cardoso began an unofficial investigation and after sifting through newspaper clippings identified three missing planes which were presumed to have crashed in the Andean peaks.

In March, 1998, Cardoso joined a civilian-military search party which hiked into the mountains looking for the fuselage. The patrol was led by an aeronautical investigator, Juan Carlos Moise, who had narrowed down the area to be searched, but high winds and blinding snowstorms turned the 10-day trek into a test of survival. Earlier this month, a second expedition was launched. Thanks to a break in the weather the three-man expedition spent nine days scouring the flanks of Tupungato mountain. The wreckage was reached on January 19.

The grandson of Martha Limpert, Rodolfo Limpert, 74, was a teenager when the plane crashed. His grandmother had gone to Europe from Chile in 1938 because her husband had wanted to visit his native land of Germany before he died. The war intervened and her husband died in London. She was finally on her way home when the plane crashed. Mr Limpert said yesterday in Santiago that the family had learned that the pilot had been warned that there were risks to the flight but was a former RAF pilot and was used to flying in much more perilous conditions.

An Argentinian judge, Alfredo Manuel Rodriguez, is now in charge of the inquiry into what happened to the plane.

He said that it was not yet clear how many bodies had been recovered, although some reports said that the remains of three people had been discovered.

Harry Holmes, of the Avro Heritage Group, which celebrates the now-defunct Cheshire-based aircraft firm, said: "It's a very special find. Anything that clears up a mystery after all this time is fascinating and the occupants will finally be able to get a decent funeral."

The foreign office said a number of people had already been in contact, believing they were relatives of the dead.

Ricardo Bustos, commander of the 11th mountain infantry regiment, said: "Maybe the English government or the English courts will want to investigate this site and professionally close this chapter in English aviation history. We will fully cooperate."

webTitle: Belgium moves to halt Pinochet flight

fields.headline: Belgium moves to halt Pinochet flight
fields.standfirst: Pinochet on trial: special report
fields.trailText: Belgium was last night poised to ask the international court of justice to order Britain to halt any moves to return Augusto Pinochet to Chile.
fields.byline: Ian Black  in Brussels and  Jamie Wilson
fields.body:
Belgium was last night poised to ask the international court of justice to order Britain to halt any moves to return Augusto Pinochet to Chile.

Georges-Henri Beauthier, lawyer for six Chileans living in Belgium, said a decision by the cabinet was imminent after the foreign minister, Louis Michel, said he was determined that Pinochet should not walk free.

The necessary papers had already been sent to the Belgian embassy in the Hague, seat of the ICJ. "Everything has been done at the legal level, but the political decision still needs to be taken," Mr Beauthier said.

In the Netherlands, an ICJ spokesperson said no request had yet been made by the Brussels government, but a hearing could be held as soon as Friday if an application was filed formally today.

At the high court in London today, the Belgian government and six human rights groups will seek a judicial review of Jack Straw's announcement that he was "minded" to halt extradition proceedings against the general on health grounds.

Belgium, one of four countries seeking to extradite the former dictator, has entered the legal fray after it failed to get a reply from two requests to the home office for a new medical examination and access to the Pinochet files.

The ICJ case will argue that Mr Straw is in breach of international cooperation agreements because he failed to allow other states involved in the case access to Pinochet's medical reports, or to conduct their own independent medical tests of the 84-year-old general.

The case will also include an application for provisional measures to ensure the home secretary takes no steps to allow Pinochet to return to Chile while the matter is before the British courts.

In the wake of the Belgian move to the Hague, the home office said: "We take our international obligations very seriously, but the home secretary must comply with UK law and rulings in the UK courts."

Belgium has stepped to the fore in international attempts to stop Pinochet returning to Chile, a move which was commented on with some surprise and even pride in newspapers yesterday.

"Belgium is a little rebel, daring to defy the still imperial, though now Blairite, United Kingdom," commented Le Soir. "Now look who is raising the banner of justice in the face of reasons of state."

Although no side would confirm it, it is understood the Spanish and Belgian lawyers and Amnesty International's legal team have been working closely over the past two weeks to ensure Pinochet does not flee Britain for Chile.

webTitle: Ban on births from frozen eggs lifted

fields.headline: Ban on births from frozen eggs lifted
fields.standfirst: Treatment will benefit women threatened with infertility through illness and career women wanting to delay starting a family
fields.trailText: Women will now be able to stop their biological clock and put babies on hold until their forties or fifties if they choose, following the lifting of the ban yesterday on the use of frozen eggs in fertility treatment.
fields.body:
Women will now be able to stop their biological clock and put babies on hold until their forties or fifties if they choose, following the lifting of the ban yesterday on the use of frozen eggs in fertility treatment.

In a dramatic turnaround, the Human Fertilisation and Embryology Authority (HFEA), which is the regulatory body, said it would allow the procedure to be carried out in the UK.

At least 50 women have had eggs removed and frozen in this country - mostly before treatment for cancer which would have made them infertile - but until now the HFEA has refused to let those eggs be fertilised and replaced for fear any babies would have chromosomal defects.

Now, following a report from an independent expert, Sharon Paynter, on those babies born so far around the world from frozen eggs, the authority has concluded the procedure is safe although, in Dr Paynter's words, "not without risk". The HFEA stressed that this was an option that might help cancer patients.

"The HFEA has always been sympathetic to the plight of women suffering a serious illness, such as cancer, whose condition or treatment may prevent them producing eggs. We are pleased that we now have evidence giving hope to those women who could otherwise have been made infertile," said the chairman, Ruth Deech.

The lifting of the ban will also allow career women without partners to freeze their eggs while they are young and at their most fertile - and use them when they want a family and when their chances of a baby would normally be slim.

Yesterday's decision was greeted with delight by Mohammed Taranissi who runs the Assisted Reproduction and Gynaecology Centre in London. His clinic, which is one of only two licensed to freeze eggs in the UK, will now be licensed to thaw and use them.

'Success rate' Mr Taranissi had threatened to take legal action against the HFEA on behalf of one of his clients, Carolyn Neill, 34, whose eggs were frozen before she underwent cancer treatment and who now wants to use them to try for a baby.

"We're very pleased," Mr Taranissi said yesterday. "It confirms that what we have been saying all along is the right thing to do. We knew that the evidence was there."

At a sister clinic in the USA, the Florida Institute for Reproductive Medicine, Mr Taranissi's colleagues have already produced about 17 babies, he said.

"We have probably the highest success rate in the world with this technique. We're still looking at small numbers but if you compare them to anybody's else's they look very promising." He hopes there will be a baby born in this country from a frozen egg before the end of the year.

The HFEA says the procedure has very low success rates and would therefore appeal only to single women with no other option. Cancer patients with partners would be better off storing embryos, which freeze much more successfully than eggs.

Jane Denton, HFEA deputy chairman, said it was vital that patients should have accurate information about their chances. "It does appear that the chance of a live birth is between 1 and 10% - probably around 1%. It is vital people are fully appraised of that."

But Mr Taranissi disputes those figures. "Our pregnancy rate is about 50%," he said. "If you freeze good quality eggs, you will have a good chance of success." The women who wanted their eggs frozen were young and they were not infertile. The only danger is that the eggs will be damaged by the freezing and thawing process.

Mrs Denton agrees that is where the problems lie. "The eggs that reach the stage where they fertilise are likely to result in a pregnancy, but very few seem to be fertilising," she said. She thought any eggs that were damaged would not fertilise or if they did, would probably miscarry.

But the HFEA's fears that the freezing/thawing process could give rise to birth defects have been largely allayed by the evidence. Dr Paynter, from the department of obstetrics and gynaecology at University of Wales college of medicine in Cardiff, reported on 28 births - the first were twins in Singapore in 1986 - and found that all the babies were healthy. Even so, the HFEA says it will closely monitor the new technique.

For all the caution of the HFEA, there are already women in this country who have chosen to freeze their eggs because they are not yet ready for a family and worry that they may face fertility problems by the time they want a baby. "We have got about 10 career women in their early 30s who have frozen their eggs," said Mr Taranissi. "It is not something I am personally very keen on, but once the door is open people will use it for whatever they like."

He was surprised that the HFEA had lifted the ban completely. "I wanted it to be restricted to cancer treatment. The HFEA has gone from one extreme to the other." There is now no bar, he said, on women donating their young and fertile eggs which could be kept frozen for use by someone else in the future.

The next step for the scientists is the freezing and replacing of ovarian tissue or tiny, immature eggs, which would make it possible for pre-pubescent girls with cancer to have babies later.

'Before, I never thought about having children but it's a part of anyone's life'

Joanne Sprawson, 17, had hardly considered whether she would want children one day when she was faced with the dreadful possibility that she might never be able to have them, writes Sarah Boseley .

The A-level student from Stalisfield Green in Kent was diagnosed with breast cancer in October.

"Before chemotherapy came up, I didn't even think about having kids, but when it did, I realised it is part of anyone's life," she said.

It was a part she would have been denied if she had not been told of the egg storage facility at the Assisted Reproduction and Gynaecology Centre in London. In December, she had ten eggs removed and stored in liquid nitrogen.

"We were told about the law, but I thought I've got 10 or 15 years ahead of me before I want to have children. I thought the law might have been changed by then," she said.

Her mother, Elaine Sprawson, 51, said: "In Joanne's case, she has time on her side before she makes decisions about family life. But for women in their thirties it is vital that this opportunity is available to them."

Carolyn Neill, 34, wants a baby, but chemotherapy treatment for breast cancer has destroyed her fertility. Last May, before she embarked on chemotherapy, she had nine of her eggs removed and frozen.

She has now overcome the first hurdle to having children, her cancer is in remission. But there was a second - the ban by the HFEA on the use of frozen eggs.

"I was worried about infertility and thought this method would give me the chance to have children because I have always thought that I would have a family," she said at the time. "It is so stressful to go through cancer and then have to face this. It is not right that the government can decide whether I have children or not."

It was her case that Mohammed Taranissi of the Assisted Reproduction and Gynaecology Centre decided to fight, threatening to take the HFEA to judicial review. The authority maintains that it always had the situation under review, but public sympathy for Ms Neill's plight can only have been influential.

There are two clinics with licences to freeze eggs. The other, Care at the Park hospital in Nottingham, has not yet begun to offer cryopreservation services. Its medical director Dr Ken Dowell called the change"fantastic news".

His clinic is dealing with three women who have daughters born without ovaries. Their mothers, all in their mid-30s, want to give their daughters the chance of children when they grow up, by freezing their own eggs for donation later. If it works, the girls will give birth to their own half-brothers and sisters.

Dr Dowell, unlike Dr Taranissi, believes the freezing technique is still hit and miss. "If we were to collect 10 mature eggs, only half would survive freezing and thawing, and half of those would end up being fertilised. But like many other aspects of assisted reproduction, it will get much more efficient in the future," he said.

webTitle: Newspaper's hoax claim destroyed career of TV documentary maker, libel jury told

fields.headline: Newspaper's hoax claim destroyed career of TV documentary maker, libel jury told
fields.trailText: A television documentary maker had his career destroyed by newspaper allegations that a programme on a high level conspiracy between the security forces and loyalist paramilitaries to murder IRA suspects was a hoax, a high court libel jury heard yesterday.
fields.body:
A television documentary maker had his career destroyed by newspaper allegations that a programme on a high level conspiracy between the security forces and loyalist paramilitaries to murder IRA suspects was a hoax, a high court libel jury heard yesterday.

Sean McPhilemy, whose company, Box Productions, made the 1991 Channel 4 Dispatches programme called The Committee, was robbed of his livelihood when the Sunday Times said his programme was a deception, his counsel, James Price QC, told the London court.

The newspaper said the film makers "stand accused of producing little more than a collage of unsubstantiated rumours and fabrications".

Mr Price told Mr Justice Eady and the jury of six men and six women: "This accusation has meant that people who commission current affairs programmes no longer want anything to do with Mr McPhilemy."

The Sunday Times denies libelling Mr McPhilemy in its May 1993 article headlined Film on Ulster death squads a hoax.

Mr Price said the arrest of Brian Nelson, chief intelligence officer of the paramilitary Ulster Defence Association, who was also working for British army intelligence, revived widespread rumours that murders of IRA suspects were being committed with the collusion of the army, the RUC and the Ulster Defence Regiment.

"The question is whether it involved a few bad apples or was more widespread and institutionalised and reached into the higher ranks of the security forces," he said.

Mr McPhilemy's documentary was based on an interview with a loyalist "fanatic", James Sands, who was involved in the Ulster independence movement and said he had inside knowledge of collusion in the assassination of IRA men and in the revenge killings of Catholics.

In its article, the Sunday Times said Mr Sands claimed he was promised £5,000 to recite a prepared script and that he did not know whether what he was saying was true or not.

It also said another participant was also paid to recite a script.

Mr Price said Mr McPhilemy was convinced that Mr Sands was telling the truth and would give his reasons in the witness box.

"Sands may have been telling the truth or he may not have been telling the truth," Mr Price said.

"He might have succeeded in pulling the wool over the eyes of the programme makers. But that is a completely different question and is not what the libel trial is about.

"Did Sean McPhilemy and the other programme makers collude with Sands to produce a hoax, a charade, a fraud?"

He said the jury had to decide whether Mr McPhilemy was honest or whether he was a party to paying witnesses to recite a script.

In order for the programme to be a hoax, all those present would have had to have been in on it, Mr Price said.

The original film showed that there was no prompting of Mr Sands, Mr Price told the jury.

On the table in front of Mr Sands lay a copy of a magazine, not a script, he added.
