fields.headline: Out of the red
fields.standfirst:
For the first time in a decade public finance is in the black. But now the treasury is shifting its attention to 'resource accounting'

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown has spent the past two and a half years talking about the importance of prudence and stability in public finance. By squeezing budgets throughout Whitehall and implementing stealthy tax rises in Labour's first two years, he succeeded in putting the public finances into the black for the first time in nearly a decade.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown has spent the past two and a half years talking about the importance of prudence and stability in public finance. By squeezing budgets throughout Whitehall and implementing stealthy tax rises in Labour's first two years, he succeeded in putting the public finances into the black for the first time in nearly a decade.

He was expecting to stash a healthy £3bn away in his piggybank next year (that is to say, use it to pay off government debt) - but Tony Blair has now commandeered it for the health service.

As well as staging a smash and grab raid on Brown's surplus, his neighbour's move has also blown a hole in spending plans. When Labour came to power, the chancellor abolished the regular bunfight over spending where ministers used to vie with each other to grab a larger share of the government's £350bn annual budget.

Instead of planning spending year by year, the government now plans its spending in three-year chunks. The first comprehensive spending review (CSR), covered the financial years 1999-2000 to 2001-02. It was announced in July 1998. The next one, labelled Spending Review 2000, will cover the period from April 2001 to March 2004 (the first year of the new plan is the last year of the old). It is due to be announced this summer.

But treasury officials were forced to go back to their drawing boards this week. While large increases for education and health were almost certain to have been a feature of the next spending round, the size of the boost to the NHS required to fund the PM's pledge has caused consternation. An influential estimate of how much room the government has for manoeuvre will be made today in the Institute for Fiscal Studies' annual anticipation of the chancellor's options. The prime minister's impromptu pledge also throws into doubt the proposition that politics can be taken out of budget planning - which is what the chancellor hoped when he designed the CSR process. Alongside the introduction of commercial or "resource" accounting, Brown hoped the CSR would rationalise spending discussions and improve long-term planning.

The blueprint was written in New Zealand in the 80s, when its right-of-centre Labour party redesigned the relationship between treasury and spending departments. Accrual or resource accounting replaced cash accounting, enabling the treasury to measure the full costs of government activities.

Next departments were encouraged to match spending to objectives. The treasury shifted its attention away from the traditional focus on inputs - how much each department gets each year - to outputs or what the state gets for its money. Instead of giving a department a budget and letting it go away and do pretty much what it likes with it, the treasury began specifying the outputs it expected in return.

In New Zealand, the language of public sector management has become so commercialised that the treasury speaks of "purchasing" goods and services from department - for example, among the annual outputs it buys are firearms licensing services from the police, administration of benefit payments from the department of social welfare, even policy advice.

The approach is being borrowed by the United Kingdom, along with a large number of former New Zealand treasury officials. This year's CSR will bring in resource accounting, be based on outputs not inputs and will tie departments to implementing their public service agreements (PSAs), statements of aims agreed in advance with the treasury. According to one of our treasury people, the focus has become: "What does the money buy?"

Around Whitehall, departments are drafting their new PSAs and providing the treasury with the analytical information which will form the basis of discussions over the next few weeks. Each spending minister will appear in front of the cabinet committee on public expenditure, chaired by the chancellor, and be asked to justify themselves. Yet the political reality is rather different from the treasury rhetoric. This CSR is taking place as the Labour party starts its advance planning for the next election, which is likely to be held in the summer of 2001 (advance planning in fact began on May 2 1997).

Labour will want to reward its supporters for their patience over the state of public services during the first two lean years of the parliament. The public has shown this winter that it will not tolerate the NHS being run any further into the ground.

The name of the game is that in July Gordon Brown is able to get up and boast of how much is going into Labour's priority areas of health and education. Individual spending ministers go back to their departments to put together a wish list of what they want, which will be turned into a drip feed of good news stories for the government over the following 12 months.

All of this has nothing to do with inputs, outputs, outcomes and resource accounting. In output terms, it is unlikely the government will purchase very much more "health", whatever the boost to NHS spending. Instead what it will be buying is the end of mixed wards, more choice for patients about when they can have their operations, and no more overflowing hospitals when the next flu "epidemic" strikes.

All of which is perfectly worthy and is manifestly what the public wants. And what the public wants, the public gets from Labour, especially in an election year.

 Charlotte Denny is the Guardian's economics reporter

Labour will want to reward its supporters for their patience over the state of public services during the first two lean years of the parliament. The public has shown this winter that it will not tolerate the NHS being run any further into the ground. The name of the game is that in July Gordon Brown is able to get up and boast of how much is going into Labour's priority areas of health and education. Individual spending ministers go back to their departments to put together a wish list of what they want, which will be turned into a drip feed of good news stories for the government over the following 12 months. All of this has nothing to do with inputs, outputs, outcomes and resource accounting. In output terms, it is unlikely the government will purchase very much more "health", whatever the boost to NHS spending. Instead what it will be buying is the end of mixed wards, more choice for patients about when they can have their operations, and no more overflowing hospitals when the next flu "epidemic" strikes. All of which is perfectly worthy and is manifestly what the public wants. And what the public wants, the public gets from Labour, especially in an election year.  Charlotte Denny is the Guardian's economics reporter

fields.headline: The real extremists
fields.standfirst:
Mullin and Boateng were truly divisive leftwingers in the 80s. Now they're self-abasing ministers
New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Ken Livingstone, according to Tony Blair, represents the splits and extremism of the early 80s, hence Blair's extraordinary campaign to frustrate Livingstone's mayoral ambitions.
fields.body:
Ken Livingstone, according to Tony Blair, represents the splits and extremism of the early 80s, hence Blair's extraordinary campaign to frustrate Livingstone's mayoral ambitions. Which is odd, because those of us charged with the doomed task of trying to make Labour electable in the early 80s remember very clearly those politicians whose every utterance seemed designed to make our efforts pointless; and in our demonology, Livingstone comes below many people who are now ministers and New Labour advisers.

I was a Labour party press officer in 1983. (I have made an almost complete recovery now, and thank you for asking.) I was also part of the tiny team which ran John Silkin's unsuccessful leadership and deputy leadership bids, and of the much larger team which organised Neil Kinnock's successful 1983 leadership campaign. Ken Livingstone wasn't my favourite politician, but it was clear that his Fares Fair policy was one of Labour's few pluses among London voters.

Other politicians were far more divisive. Take Chris Mullin, who became editor of Tribune in 1982 (defeating Kinnock's candidate, who happened to be me). One week the paper broadly supported the leftwing Tribune Group and Michael Foot's leadership; the next it condemned Foot and campaigned to smash apart the Tribune Group because it had, apparently, proved itself unfit to carry the banner of the left by its failure to support Tony Benn, and was full of hopeless reactionaries like Foot and Kinnock. John Silkin led the fightback by the old Tribuneites, and Mullin embarked on a speaking tour of Silkin's Deptford constituency calling for Silkin to be deselected.

Mullin is now doing his penance in the form of privatising air traffic control. It is hard to resist the idea that the job was specially chosen to give this former rigid ideological socialist the chance to prove he was willing to abase himself. Or take Paul Boateng. One of the bitterest selection battles was in the Conservative marginal of Hemel Hempstead, held for Labour until 1979 by Robin Corbett. Corbett then lost a bruising two-year deselection battle to Boateng, who condemned Corbett for being a white, middle-class reactionary. By the end of the selection battle, he had used such immoderate language that no Labour candidate stood a chance: at the general election, Boateng came a poor third. Today you can see treasury minister Boateng nodding sonorously in the background whenever the prime minister speaks in parliament.

The lower ranks of government are stuffed full of people like Mullin and Boateng, who were fiercely partisan leftwing rebels during the early 80s; and many of Livingstone's old GLC colleagues are now New Labour trusties. Yet the hatred and fear of Livingstone is still raw.

Why? It is partly that he is a politician with enormous tactical ability, and therefore a real threat. It is partly because Kinnock loathes him, and Kinnock's old friends, including Alastair Campbell and several MPs, are driving the policy. The things Livingstone said about Kinnock in the 80s seemed to hurt more than similar remarks from other leftwingers, and Kinnock is capable of bitter and irrational dislikes.

But mainly it is because of Downing Street's control-freakery. Mullin and the rest have office because Blair gave it, and Blair can take it away. Livingstone threatens to have office which they did not choose to give him, and that is unbearable. Blair says: "He called for the resignation of the chancellor," as though hanging were too good for anyone who did that. We have heard that sort of intolerant ideological rigidity in the Labour party before, during the Bennite ascendancy of the early 80s. Anyone who argued against Tony Benn standing for deputy leader against Denis Healey would be asked rather nastily: "Don't you believe in democracy, then?" Miners' president Arthur Scargill said that anyone who criticised Benn was "sabotaging not only the candidature of Tony Benn but the principles of socialism which are basic to our movement" and the hard left applauded him.

The sharp-toothed young men and women who used to follow Benn are sometimes the same people, and often have the same intolerant approach to politics, as those who now follow Blair. Their weapons - the tight caucus meetings, the constant threat to MPs that they will be deselected - have been replaced by early morning faxes and pager messages designed to keep them on message. Political correctness is once again being used as a blunt instrument (wait until your enemy says "he" instead of "he or she" and then pounce). You hear the same grinding self-righteousness. You don't, these days, hear it from Ken Livingstone. Maybe he learned something from 18 years of Conservative rule.

That is why he has the capacity to turn an incoherent army of old Labour grumblers into a serious and dangerous political force. Livingstone's out of his cage now, and the desperate efforts of Labour's top brass won't put him back again. Every time the leader of my party urges me not to, I am more certain that I shall be voting for Ken - the unity candidate.

webTitle: Blair offers free vote on gay clause

fields.headline: Blair offers free vote on gay clause
fields.standfirst:
Olive branch to small band of likely Labour rebels

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair yesterday took the sting out of a small but potentially irksome rebellion of Labour MPs by offering the prospect of a free Commons vote on government plans to reverse a ban on the promotion of homosexuality in schools.
fields.body:
Tony Blair yesterday took the sting out of a small but potentially irksome rebellion of Labour MPs by offering the prospect of a free Commons vote on government plans to reverse a ban on the promotion of homosexuality in schools.

The olive branch came after Stuart Bell, a church estates commissioner, warned that many of his colleagues had expressed disquiet at the reversing of section 28 of the local government act.

"A free vote on a matter of conscience would prevent a fair and honest debate turning into a parliamentary rebellion," the Middlesbrough MP said.

With the government increasingly anxious about the political heat generated by section 28 in Scotland, where the executive's plans to overturn it are being opposed by a Keep the Clause campaign, among church leaders, and in the Lords, the prime minister's spokesman was happy to play along.

"It wouldn't be the first time something like that has happened. Nearer the time the chief whip [Ann Taylor] will have the usual discussions, but it's not impossible," he said. MPs have traditionally been allowed a free vote on issues such as the homosexual age of consent.

The expectation of government managers last night was that a free vote would be permitted when the bill returns to the Commons a few months from now. It would limit the impact of party opposition, which in any case they believed would be smaller than the 15 Labour MPs who rebelled against the majority on the last age of consent vote.

But William Hague said he expected the Tories would file through the division lobbies on a whipped vote. The issue last month provoked the resignation of Shaun Woodward as a Tory frontbencher shortly before he defected to the Labour party. "There are many of us who believe in an open and tolerant society and in people being able to make their own choices about how they live their lives, but that is a totally different matter from using taxpayers' money to promote homosexuality in our schools," Mr Hague said.

Even on a free vote, the government's plans are expected to pass through the Commons easily.

But a cross-party alliance in the Lords is expected to defeat the government on the issue in a vote next month. Baroness Young, the former Tory leader in the upper house, yesterday staged an exhibition in the Lords of Lords of supposedly pro-homosexual photographs and literature and a video being used in schools.

"This stuff is coming out at the taxpayers' expense. And when people see some of it they will astonished that it is directed at schoolchildren," she said.

webTitle: Labour sets pace for far-reaching change

fields.headline: Labour sets pace for far-reaching change
fields.standfirst:
Government makes radical progress on constitution, but its fate will be decided by bread and butter issues

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: If Tony Blair were to fall under the proverbial prime ministerial bus today, his admirers can rest assured that he will be remembered as one of Britain's most remarkable leaders. In the short space of time since he strode into Downing Street, the youngest prime minister of the twentieth century has forced irreversible change on the country which easily rivals the great constitutional reforms of the nineteenth century.
fields.body:
If Tony Blair were to fall under the proverbial prime ministerial bus today, his admirers can rest assured that he will be remembered as one of Britain's most remarkable leaders. In the short space of time since he strode into Downing Street, the youngest prime minister of the twentieth century has forced irreversible change on the country which easily rivals the great constitutional reforms of the nineteenth century.

Hereditary peers have at last been given their marching orders, Scotland has its own parliament and - perhaps most significantly of all - Northern Ireland appears to be heading towards a constitutional settlement.

80 years on

Judged simply on the basis of his constitutional reforms, Mr Blair stands at least as high as some of the great prime ministers of the last century. It took more than 80 years for a government to summon the will to face down the hereditary peers, while the prime minister has used Labour's massive majority to press on with the Northern Ireland peace process started - but then stalled - by John Major.

Constitutional reforms may secure Mr Blair a prime slot in the history books, but his future in Downing Street will be decided on bread and butter issues. For the moment, he is well on course to establishing a record of economic competence, something which has eluded most Labour governments.

Gordon Brown, who revels in his reputation as the "iron chancellor", has achieved this by ruthlessly sticking to the last government's spending plans for the first two years in office and maintaining Labour's pledge not to raise income tax.

Core worries

But while the prime minister and his chancellor have been feted in the city for their austerity, core Labour voters remain severely disappointed. Downing Street is said to be growing alarmed at supporters who complain that they have yet to see the promised improvements in public services.

The key reason for the slow pace of change, ministers admit, is the government's self-imposed Tory spending straitjacket. Conservatives now cheerfully confess that such targets would never have been kept to had they won the election; the Labour government stuck to them with grim determination and is now paying the price.

On health, in particular, the two-year squeeze merely stored up problems for later. So far, few patients recognise any improvement in the NHS, where government achievements to date have been largely structural: abolishing the internal market; introducing primary care groups to plan local care; launching the nurse-staffed helpline NHS Direct. The effect of those reforms has yet to be tested, together with the effectiveness of consumer power in boosting improvements in the service.

Education reforms, likewise predominantly structural, have yet to make a real impact on parents, though the government escaped an expected backlash over introducing tuition fees until the Liberal Democrats pushed the issue in Scotland. Cash is the real ingredient needed to convince voters and teachers, but the government's spending on education nudged below Tory spending as a proportion of GDP in the first two years after the election, and may not average out higher than the Tories over the whole parliament, despite a relatively steep increase now under way.

Crime conundrum

The home secretary, Jack Straw, has maintained his reputation for toughness during Labour's first 1,000 days, but crime has not proved the success story on which Labour hoped to out-Tory the Tories. While the Conservatives have still to get a foothold on attacking the government on law and order, the latest figures show the first increase in recorded crime for six years.

Transport, meanwhile, has proved an unexpected beartrap for Labour, as the Tories have seized on "anti-car" proposals such as congestion taxes being introduced before improvements are made in public transport.

Downing Street weighed in to ensure motorists were not unduly penalised, to the fury of the green lobby.

But, while core voters may feel disappointed at the lack of investment in cherished public services, there is no doubt that the government is the stronger for establishing a reputation for economic competence. This has had the double benefit of allowing the chancellor, behind the scenes, to be quietly redistributive, although Labour's fear of upsetting middle England "switchers" has meant that the government seeks credit for redistribution while shrinking away from boasting of it.

Key achievements of the Blair administration include the minimum wage - now virtually a consensual political issue with even the Tories reluctant to oppose it in the next manifesto - and the working families tax credit, the basis for the Blair-Brown mantra that the benefits system should reward, not penalise, those who work.

Backlash risk

The new deal for the young unemployed and lone parents also boasts strong results, though the government may yet face a backlash, particularly if the Tories exploit the issue, over seeming to coerce mothers away from their children and back to work.

The government also has more radical thinking to do over welfare - few believe it has achieved the promised fundamental reform, and vulnerable groups including the disabled and pensioners are still felt to have gained a rough deal.

In foreign policy, an area which is likely to have little impact on the election, Labour has shown both its radical and cautious sides. The prime minister became one of Nato's most decisive leaders during last year's operation in Kosovo, bolstering the alliance when other leaders took fright at the daily bombings. But he has struggled to live up to his promise to place Britain at the heart of Europe - by sounding enthusiastic over the euro - because of his fear that he would lose a referendum.

Low-key

Labour will mark its 1,000 days in office today with low-key celebrations, in contrast to the fanfare which greeted the government's first 100 days in August 1997. "Getting on with the job" is the uninspiring theme of the day as Labour steers clear of another glitzy relaunch to avoid upsetting heartland supporters so soon after the government's worst NHS crisis.

Labour MPs will welcome the celebrations, expressing delight that their party should be in such a strong position with less than two years to go until the next general election.

They will also be relieved that Labour has not so far become mired in scandals despite Ron Davies's "moment of madness" on Clapham Common and Peter Mandelson's difficulties over his home loan. Behind the back-slapping, however, is a growing feeling that the prime minister must be prepared to act more radically in the next 1,000 days if he is to capture the imagination of voters once again.

MPs reluctantly accepted the need for the chancellor to embrace "prudence" with such fervour for the first two years in office, but they are now saying he must be prepared to relax the purse strings. Whether their calls are falling on deaf ears in Downing Street will probably only be answered when Labour publishes its manifesto for the next election.

Public services

One school of thought hopes that, having proved himself as a radical over constitutional reform, the prime minister will consolidate his place in history by presiding over a massive increase in support for the public services.

Gloomy Labour MPs fear that Mr Blair is instinctively a conservative - his constitutional reforms were largely inherited - and that he will once again opt for the cautious route.

Every time that the prime minister reminds his MPs that Labour has never won a full second term in office, they fear that he will opt once again for a manifesto which is aimed primarily at middle England.

fields.headline: Has Labour kept faith?
fields.standfirst: What happened to the five election pledges
fields.trailText: What happened to the five election pledges
fields.body:
Pledge: Cut class sizes to 30 or under for five, six and seven-year-olds with money saved from assisted places scheme
What the government says: Number of children in infant classes over 30 fell from 486,000 at the last election to 171,000 at the start of the school year last September. The government says the pledge will be delivered in full by September 2001
Analysis: Getting there. Average class sizes for children over eight have increased slightly since the election. Labour did not make promises about class sizes for this age group last time

Pledge: Get 250,000 under-25s off benefit and into work by using money from a windfall levy on privatised utilities
What the government says: The New Deal has helped 169,000 people aged between 18 and 25 off benefits and into work. But many would have found jobs anyway because of strong economy
Analysis: A qualified success. A recent government study showed that of the then 145,000 who had found work, only 30,000 would still be on the dole without the New Deal. Supporters say the scheme is much better designed and funded than any predecessor

Pledge: Set tough rules for government spending and borrowing; ensure low inflation; strengthen the economy so that interest rates are as low as possible
What the government says: Independence for the Bank of England and a tough fiscal policy has ended the boom-bust cycle. Inflation has been consistently below the 2.5% target. Public finances are in the black and unemployment is at a 20-year low
Analysis: Doing well. Inflation is low and unemployment far lower than in other leading European countries. But Labour did inherit a solid economy from the Tories and considerable economic weaknesses remain

Pledge: Cut NHS waiting lists by treating an extra 100,000 patients as a first step by releasing £100m saved from NHS red tape
What the government says: Lists at first rose, peaking in April 1998 at 1,312,600 - more than 150,000 up on the total Labour inherited - but have since fallen gradually to 1,071,400 (at the end of last November) and amount to a net reduction of 87,000
Analysis: So So. Reducing lists has been at the expense of greatly lengthened queues for out-patient appointments. Numbers queuing at least 13 weeks more than doubled from 248,000 in March 1997 to 512,000 at the end of last September.

Pledge: Fast track punishment for persistent young offenders by halving time from arrest to sentencing from 142 to 71 days
What the government says: Average time was cut from 142 days in May 1997 to 106 days by December 1998. Fast track schemes now operate throughout the country and pilot schemes with new six month statutory time limits have seen cuts from 90 days to 38 days
Analysis: Varied progress. While Warwickshire courts cut the average time to 84 days by the end of 1998, it still took 163 days to deal with a persistent young offender in Sussex. Impact of the pledge is blunted by the new figures showing the first rise in recorded crime in six years

A recent government study showed that of the then 145,000 who had found work, only 30,000 would still be on the dole without the New Deal. Supporters say the scheme is much better designed and funded than any predecessor Pledge: Set tough rules for government spending and borrowing; ensure low inflation; strengthen the economy so that interest rates are as low as possible What the government says: Independence for the Bank of England and a tough fiscal policy has ended the boom-bust cycle. Inflation has been consistently below the 2.5% target. Public finances are in the black and unemployment is at a 20-year low Analysis: Doing well. Inflation is low and unemployment far lower than in other leading European countries. But Labour did inherit a solid economy from the Tories and considerable economic weaknesses remain Pledge: Cut NHS waiting lists by treating an extra 100,000 patients as a first step by releasing £100m saved from NHS red tape What the government says: Lists at first rose, peaking in April 1998 at 1,312,600 - more than 150,000 up on the total Labour inherited - but have since fallen gradually to 1,071,400 (at the end of last November) and amount to a net reduction of 87,000 Analysis: So So. Reducing lists has been at the expense of greatly lengthened queues for out-patient appointments. Numbers queuing at least 13 weeks more than doubled from 248,000 in March 1997 to 512,000 at the end of last September. Pledge: Fast track punishment for persistent young offenders by halving time from arrest to sentencing from 142 to 71 days What the government says: Average time was cut from 142 days in May 1997 to 106 days by December 1998. webTitle: Blunkett to beat drum for party's achievements

fields.headline: Blunkett to beat drum for party's achievements
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair's government will today mark its first 1,000 days in office by contrasting its achievements since May 1 1997 with the turbulent 1,000 days ushered in by Margaret Thatcher's election in May 1979.
fields.body:
Tony Blair's government will today mark its first 1,000 days in office by contrasting its achievements since May 1 1997 with the turbulent 1,000 days ushered in by Margaret Thatcher's election in May 1979.

Since the prime minister is avoiding any personal hint of triumphalism by having a normal working day, the task of blowing the government's trumpet will fall to the education secretary, David Blunkett, a trusted Blair lieutenant.

Sweeping aside the fainthearts, he will characterise the Blair administration as "more confident, more radical, delivering more than we said we would".

Mr Blunkett will parade the Blairites' pro-business, pro-European credentials by making his speech to the German/British chamber of industry and commerce at Claridge's Hotel in Mayfair.

That may niggle patient Labour loyalists and in the present climate of voter disappointment over key public services, Mr Blunkett will stress that there is still "a lot more to do".

William Hague will today liken the government to a vacuous Millennium Dome, saying: "It has all turned out to be talk." Last night shadow ministers attacked the government over stealth taxes, NHS waiting lists and Labour's "audit of failures, lies, sleaze and hypocrisy".

Yesterday Mr Hague revived the Saatchi advertising agency's classic 1979 election poster, the long queue and the slogan Labour Isn't Working. This time the jibe was directed not against unemployment but NHS queues.

Mr Blunkett will say that after 1,000 days in office, "the Conservatives were already dividing the country while we are working to bring the country together. I believe that after 1,000 days we can see this: that Tony Blair's New Labour government is changing more for the better than Margaret Thatcher did".

Mr Blunkett will cite social inclusiveness, constitutional reforms, welfare to work and competence in managing the economy - pointing to low inflation, falling unemployment and rising inward investment.

He will contrast all that to doubled inflation and unemployment (to 2.4 million) between May 3 1979 and January 28th 1982. Crime was up by a quarter, the country had been riven by strikes - including IRA hunger strikes - and was poised to face an Argentine invasion of the Falklands triggered by ill-considered defence cuts. There was even a U-turn in the face of militant miners.

The likely Tory retort will be that Mrs Thatcher inherited a country in deep economic and social crisis culminating in the winter of discontent - and that she set about creating the conditions for restored growth that Labour has inherited. But the narrow range of Mr Hague's complaints underline how Laboiur remains a hard a target to hit.

"For every day since (May 1 1997) an extra 264 people have joined the waiting list to see a hospital consultant; for every day an extra 39 people have become victims of violent crime, for every day £22 million has been added to taxes," Mr Hague will say.

There has also been lots more red tape and Whitehall special advisers, the Tory leader will tell an audience at the Centre for Policy Studies, the think tank behind the Thatcher Revolution, hatched when he was still in school. New Labour is like the Greenwich Dome because it has "an obsession with looking modern without actually doing anything modern in practice", he will say.

Labour published a modest "First 1000 Days in Context" paper.

The Lib Dems treasury spokesman, Matthew Taylor, said: "By tying themselves from day one to Conservative spending plans, the Government's 'early' pledges have not been worth the credit card they were written on. The pledges were modest in ambition and wrong in aspiration."

webTitle: Who's up in front of the judge

fields.headline: Who's up in front of the judge
fields.trailText: Just when you thought everything had gone suspiciously quiet on the Courtney Love front, along comes a hefty breach-of-contract lawsuit to remind you of the grunge-icon-turned-Versace-clothes-horse's still-magnetic knack for attracting grief. To wit, the legal heat came down on Love - and her Hole bandmate Eric Erlandson - in LA Superior Court last week with a Geffen Records application for unspecified damages, after the allegedly errant pair unilaterally abandoned their seven-album deal just two records in.
fields.body:
Just when you thought everything had gone suspiciously quiet on the Courtney Love front, along comes a hefty breach-of-contract lawsuit to remind you of the grunge-icon-turned-Versace-clothes-horse's still-magnetic knack for attracting grief. To wit, the legal heat came down on Love - and her Hole bandmate Eric Erlandson - in LA Superior Court last week with a Geffen Records application for unspecified damages, after the allegedly errant pair unilaterally abandoned their seven-album deal just two records in.

The problems began when Love, never shy of venting spleen across as much media as possible, publicly expressed her desire to ditch the suits and establish a modishly net-bound and entirely independent conduit for her musical talents; putting up rather than shutting up, she and Erlandson then formally notified Geffen of their intention to do just that. And that was promptly followed by her corporate paymasters' litigious return pass, demanding - besides the aforementioned damages - fulfilment of the contract in question and an injunction banning the band from recording elsewhere

Meanwhile, away from the polite machinations of contract law, pop-reggae daddy's boy Ziggy Marley boldly slapped the New Orleans Police Department with a federal brutality suit last week after his MC Hartnel Harley (otherwise known as Sky High) ran into a spot bother with the law. According to the suit, Hartnel/High was minding his own business outside a Louisiana nightclub when a pair of plainclothes officers ordered him to stand against a nearby wall for frisking; after asking to see their badges, however, he was promptly handcuffed and thrown into said wall with such force that his leg was broken in two places. The cops were later found to be genuine members of the force; Ziggy, meanwhile, was obliged to hire a replacement MC for the band's impending US tour

fields.headline: Black gold
fields.standfirst: Fiftysomething white Hollywood supremo Michael Ovitz has announced he's getting into hip-hop. It's not the first time the establishment has hijacked African-American culture for profit. And it won't be the last. By  Mark Morris
fields.trailText: Fiftysomething white Hollywood supremo Michael Ovitz has announced he's getting into hip-hop. It's not the first time the establishment has hijacked African-American culture for profit. And it won't be the last. By Mark Morris
fields.body:
Michael Ovitz is the Hollywood elite personified. At the age of 29, he founded the mighty Creative Artists Agency, and used "talent packages" to make agents as powerful as their clients. He's a friend of the stars, a noted philanthropist and the man behind an attempt to bring a new National Football League team to LA. He slipped up once, spending an unhappy year as president of Disney, but even then, he came away with a $90 million golden handshake and set up a new company - Artists Management Group - which looks after Martin Scorsese and Robin Williams.

But when you're as successful as Mike, you know that times change. At the age of 53, Ovitz has seen the future, and that future is hip-hop. He's taken a look at the US pop charts and seen: hip-hop. And riding high at the US box office? Ice Cube's Next Friday. Michael Ovitz wants in "I want to try to learn this whole urban marketing situation", Ovitz said stiffly last week, announcing the formation of AMG's new "urban entertainment division". "I see big crossover potential in films, in sports and everything else." Urban, in case you were wondering, is marketing speak for African-American. The man Ovitz has hooked with to help him show much love for the homies is Chris Lightly, head of Violator Management, who look after - among others - rapper duo Mobb Deep. Ovitz credits Lightly with being a genius at "guerrilla marketing".

The oldest myth in the music business is that black musicians come up with the all the ideas, and white people make all the money. And it has certainly happened enough times to have a ring of truth, although ask George Michael and he would be quick to point out that managers and record companies are out to stiff everyone, black, brown or white.

Niggaz With Attitude might have seemed the essence of cultural autonomy, with the late Eazy E doubling as rapper and president of their label, Ruthless. But the other members - including the formidable pairing of Ice Cube and Dr Dre - believed that the purse strings were controlled by Eazy's fiftysomething manager, Jerry Heller. Whether Heller was ripping them off or not, the feeling that he was tore apart the group. Dre joined up with former football player and gang member Marion "Suge" Knight, whose business methods allegedly included dangling people from hotel balconies. According to Ronin Ro's terrifying Have Gun Will Travel: The Spectacular Rise And Violent Fall Of Death Row Records, Knight threatened and harassed Heller until he let Dr Dre out of his contract. And although Dre later fell out with Knight, who is currently serving time for parole violations, the surviving members of the group remain convinced that Heller is the villain of the NWA story. Conspiracy theorists even maintain that Knight was brought down because he was a successful black businessman, not because he was - as Ro's book suggests - a sadist who tortured his employees.

But even a black-owned business like Death Row was reliant on a distribution deal with Interscope Records, run by Jimmy Iovine, bombastic rock producer to the likes of Bruce Springsteen and Simple Minds. Despite the high profile of black music business executives like Def Jam/Rush Management's Russell Simmons, No Limit's Master P and, of course, Bad Boy supremo Puff Daddy, a shrinking number of multinationals control the business, and their higher echelons remain predominantly white. As is the audience which buys hardcore rap's tales of bitches, blunts, beatdowns and AK-47s. The trick is making sure a performer is accepted as "keeping it real" by the trendsetting, impoverished inner-city black audience. Once this credibility is established, then white-owned companies can market young black men and women to the voyeuristic suburban white teens who keep the entertainment industry buoyant. Rappers resent it, the anti-semitic myths grow and grow, but the dollars keep flowing.

The spirals can give you a headache. On Brooklyn rapper Mos Def's recent album Black On Both Sides, there is a track called Rock N Roll, which tries to reassert guitar pop's African origins: "Elvis Presley ain't got no soul/Bo Diddley is rock'n'roll" Mos claims. Black On Both Sides is an intelligent, political album with a lot to say about racism and the accumulation of power by corporations. It is released by the "independent" New York label Rawkus, which was founded in the early 90s by three young men, including one James Murdoch. After a couple of years, Murdoch sold a stake in Rawkus to his dad. The best political rap records of recent times have come to us courtesy of Rupert Murdoch.

There was another unlikely hip-hop related product Murdoch funded: Bulworth, Warren Beatty's satire about an ageing Californian establishment figure whose complete breakdown is symbolised by the fact that he starts rapping. There's nothing - Warren was saying - more ridiculous than a rich white man gone ghetto fabulous. And as Michael Ovitz goes urban, he should know that while his new clients will appreciate his money-making powers, they'll never trust him.

webTitle: Watch this: satellite, cable and digital

fields.headline: Watch this: satellite, cable and digital
fields.trailText:
Evil Dead II (Sam Raimi, 1987)
1am, Sci Fi
fields.body:
Evil Dead II (Sam Raimi, 1987)
1am, Sci Fi

This could hardly be called a sequel to the original Evil Dead; following the success of their low-budget shocker, Raimi took the "if it ain't broke, don't fix it" approach and made the same film again, but with more money. A group of friends visit an old house in the middle of the woods and accidentally release some evil spirits who then spend the rest of the film tormenting the young weekenders in a variety of increasingly inventive ways. A rare example of a remake that improves on the original.

Liar Liar (Tom Shadyac, 1997)
8pm, Sky Premier

Workaholic lawyer Jim Carrey misses son's birthday and has to obey the boy's special wish: that Dad will tell the truth for 24 hours. Scenes in which he insults his bosses and is a little too honest in representing sexy divorcee Meg Tilly, are perfect showcases for Carrey's Jerry Lewis-like humour. The question is, who likes Jerry Lewis?

When Harry Met Sally (Rob Reiner, 1989)
9pm, UK Living

Despite the screen's most celebrated orgasm, there's an old-fashioned feel to Reiner's romantic comedy. It's sparky, funny and light of touch; so is the acting. Nice story too: the couple meet intermittently over 12 years, showing that it's possible for a man and woman to have a good platonic relationship. Then they shrug their shoulders and jump straight into bed.

Savior (Peter Antonijevic, 1997)
11.45pm, Sky Premier

This Oliver Stone production, set in the hell that was Bosnia in 1993, is as anti-war as movies get. It tells the story of a mercenary (Dennis Quaid) who arbitrarily decides to escort a young mother (Nastassja Kinski) and her baby to safety. But this is no Hollywood hero: Quaid is dead-eyed and almost beyond caring, a million miles from his usual twinkling charmers. And as a picture of war this is raw, unflinching, and utterly compelling.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: The House That Birt Built | Origins - The Human Factor
fields.body:
There has been curiously little official publicity about the BBC's hour-long programme on the reign of John Birt, its departing director-general. Never before has the boss's record received such close public dissection before he has even left the building. The House That Birt Built (8.0pm, Radio 4) includes an analysis of his controversial reforms by the BBC's own staff and a live debate in which Edward Stourton asks specially invited media experts whether "The BBC is failing as the nation's public service broadcaster".

That is followed by the first of a three-part series on the history of human evolution. Origins - The Human Factor (9.0pm, Radio 4) opens with the sad tale of the ape man who stumbled into a deep South African cave and slowly starved to death. Fortunately for paleoanthropology his body then lay safe from predators for 3.5 million years, allowing Dr Ron Clarke to uncover one of the world's finest evolutionary specimens.

fields.body:
Vets In The Wild (BBC1) came out the traps like Vic and Bob doing Out Of Africa. Trude Mostoe, Michaela Strachan without the training, led a wagon train across the Kenyan plain, in search of animals to castrate. Aided by Steve, her hunky fellow-vet, and "Bimby Dyer" - Meryl Streep playing Karen Blixen, but with the accent from Plenty, their plan was simple: to emasculate every creature in the animal kingdom before sunset.

"I do lots of carrrstrating for the area", Bimby confessed, as they bumped across the plain, in search of their first quarry. "Horses, ponies, camels, zebras. I once carrrstrated a cat following telephone instructions from my brother in Penzance." Bimby - it transpired - wasn't a vet at all, but loved getting her scalpel out and interfering with wild animals.

Conversation was interrupted by arrival in the Castration Zone. Trude, who looked worried whenever she was called upon to do anything at all, turned grey as Inderobo Tribe members, who had gathered specially to see the BBC vets make fools of themselves, presented her with a testosterone-fuelled camel. "Trudy, he won't hurt you", Bimby lied, the animal pawing the ground and spitting for Kenya, "he's as gentle as lambs."

But the camel wasn't as gentle as lambs, fighting with every last breath to save his manhood. Itchy-fingered, Bimby could stand it no longer, stepping in with her trusty knife to save both Trude and the camel from a fate worse than death. "I've only ever read about camels", Trude said, by way of apology.

Intentionally or not, Vets In The Wild humbled its star double act by showing them up to be little more than tourists on safari. "You've got a great place here", Trude said to a tribesman, gesturing to the Kenyan plain. "It's lovely! The perfect place for a gin and tonic."

Less brazen charlatans were at work on Behind The Crime: Fakers (C4), which failed to deal with the fastest growth area in fraud, the television documentary. Instead, we were treated to a number of traditional cons - an art forger, a businessman who changed his identity in the wake of a VAT scam, and - joy of joys, the gloriously incompetent Darius Guppy.

As with most half-hearted criminals, these men seemed far less concerned with carrying out a successful crime than with engineering a way in which they could be caught. "I suppose I wanted to be caught," mused Terry, the art forger and very possible fake himself, "because that's when Tom Keating got his recognition."

Motivated more by vanity and class war than a desire to make money, Terry relished his work as a chance to get one over on the toffs. "It's the thrill of the sting, of making experts - with their plum in mouth attitude - talk bull." Using a combination of staining the canvas in PG Tips and rubbing Nescafé granules into the pigment, Terry could knock off a Gaugin in the time it took to watch Antiques Roadshow (on which some of his best work had appeared). When Plod finally called, Terry was ready with his tea and coffee. Waiting in his cells, he knocked off a couple more fakes while waiting to be charged.

Darius Guppy - rich, handsome, not very bright - is the kind of man Terry would have relished selling a Gaugin to. Befitting the confidence of his class, Guppy went for a multi-million pound insurance scam involving diamonds, a stick-up in a New York hotel with an old school chum, and more bad acting than his mother had experienced in 10 years of school plays.

The NYPD took four sec onds at the scene to deduce it was a set-up. They had to stop themselves from laughing, as Guppy held his head in his hands and wailed "The diamonds! The diamonds!" webTitle: Two directors deny grant irregularities at TransTec

fields.headline: Two directors deny grant irregularities at TransTec
fields.trailText: Two directors of Geoffrey Robinson's engineering concern TransTec last night broke their silence over the circumstances of the group's collapse, defending the former paymaster general against accusations of "irregular" obtaining of government grants.
fields.body:
Two directors of Geoffrey Robinson's engineering concern TransTec last night broke their silence over the circumstances of the group's collapse, defending the former paymaster general against accusations of "irregular" obtaining of government grants.

A statement from Sami Ahmed and J A G Knight, who worked for the company up until 1994, said "grants were correctly and fully accounted for and all procedures relating to them were properly observed".

The move comes after the company's former chief accountant, Max Ayriss, claimed at the weekend that Mr Robinson obtained a £30,000 grant from the department of trade and industry to buy a factory building which he was not planning to occupy and simply wanted to let.

Mr Ayriss said that while the claim may not have been strictly illegal, it was clearly against the spirit of the DTI regional grants which were intended to help new businesses.

The DTI announced at the weekend that it would be investigating "serious allegations" made by Mr Ayriss and the company's former sales manager Peter Dickinson about the way it obtained DTI grants totalling £400,000 in the late 1980s.

However last night's statement said: "We write to refute the aspersions cast by Messrs Ayriss and Dickinson on the propriety with which DTI product development contracts were carried out whilst we were employed as directors of Transfer Technology Limited (TransTec) in the relevant periods. These grants were correctly and fully accounted for and all procedures relating to them were properly observed.

"The DTI not only inspected and approved all claims submitted, which were in turn vetted by our auditors, as required, but also thoroughly evaluated the work carried out and the equipment developed."

The Commons speaker Betty Boothroyd yesterday chided the DTI for dragging its feet over answering opposition questions about the collapse of TransTec. The first batch from a total of 19 questions ought to have been answered last Thursday. The DTI said it expected to supply answers today.

Receivers Arthur Andersen are drawing up plans for a meeting of creditors owed, on one estimate, £300m.

fields.headline: William Winter
fields.trailText: William Winter, who has died aged 92, was the first "Voice of America". The son of Vietnamese immigrant parents, he did not speak English until he was six, and drifted into the job through happenstance. But his wartime broadcasts across Asia made him a hero. Much later, he was sacked from ABC as a "pinko" during the Vietnam war.
fields.body:
William Winter, who has died aged 92, was the first "Voice of America". The son of Vietnamese immigrant parents, he did not speak English until he was six, and drifted into the job through happenstance. But his wartime broadcasts across Asia made him a hero. Much later, he was sacked from ABC as a "pinko" during the Vietnam war.

In 1941, the US state department launched the Voice Of America network, and Winter, who was in San Francisco - and able to reach East Asia via short-wave transmissions - was a natural choice as its first voice. He began his spots by reassuring Asians that Uncle Sam, though still a non-combatant, was concerned about protecting them from the Japanese, who were busy arguing to the contrary.

After America entered the war, Winter's daily broadcasts to the Pacific offered low-key explanations of democracy and freedom of expression, balancing his narrative with quotations from pro-war and isolationist factions alike. He accompanied General Douglas MacArthur back to the Philippines, and became, as far as Radio Tokyo was concerned, the vilest enemy. The station once broadcast a play in which three men were barred from heaven because of their wickedness: President Roosevelt, Winston Churchill, and William Winter.

He was honoured in the Philippines, Australia, Singapore and Malaysia, and became a sought-after speaker at universities and conferences. Later, he created a series of study tours, taking groups to rarely visited places in Africa, the Soviet Union, India and East Asia, and also worked as a foreign politics tutor at the University of California at Los Angeles.

Winter was born in North Carolina and, after high school, studied law the old-fashoned way - privately. While clerking in an attorney's office during the day, he took after-hours instruction from a retired Harvard professor. Four months before his 21st birthday, he passed the North Carolina bar examination to become the youngest lawyer in the US at that time. After a short period as an insurance company counsel in New York, he returned to practice in his home state.

One of Winter's clients was a radio network and, because of a grasp of international politics - an interest encouraged by his inventor father - he was invited to become a radio news analyst. By 1935 he had abandoned the law for broadcasting. His rich baritone was made for radio, and in 1941 CBS gave him a job in San Francisco broadcasting daily news analysis.

After the war, Winter covered the 1945 United Nations charter conference for Voice Of America and the Korean war for the UN. In 1955 he joined ABC as a television analyst, where he pioneered the use of maps and diagrams. Later, he was news director of KPFK, the most liberal Los Angeles radio station. After retirement in 1990, he combined his wartime memoirs, and an early history of VOA, in a book, Voice From America: A Broadcaster's Diary 1941-44.

He is survived by his wife Peggy, and two daughters.

fields.headline: Graham Bird
fields.standfirst: Renowned immunologist fighting HIV epidemic
fields.trailText: Until last autumn, Graham Bird, who has died of a brain tumour aged 49, was consultant immunologist and head of the immunology department at the Radcliffe Hospitals Trust, Oxford. He was also one of the success stories of modern immunology, and a world-class immuno-epidemiologist.
fields.body:
Until last autumn, Graham Bird, who has died of a brain tumour aged 49, was consultant immunologist and head of the immunology department at the Radcliffe Hospitals Trust, Oxford. He was also one of the success stories of modern immunology, and a world-class immuno-epidemiologist.

While most people recognise the benefits of polio, tetanus and hepatitis-B vaccination, immunology remains one of the most complex and challenging areas of medicine. Bird was not the best basic research immunologist in Oxford, but he did have first-author Nature papers, a definition of a top-flight scientist. He was not the best developmental immunologist, although he did develop new tests and unselfishly support others who wished to do so. He was probably not the best overall teacher of immunology in Oxford, although his clinical teaching was world class, and he was an enthralling speaker, whether in schools, seminars or international meetings.

Nonetheless, a good indicator of a clinician's true worth is the number of other clinicians who go to them personally or send their friends or relatives for diagnosis. And there is no doubt that Bird was the informed people's diagnostic choice; he was both a gifted diagnostician and, in turn, received a tremendous buzz from his many successes.

Bird was born in Newcastle-upon-Tyne and educated at St Peter's School, York. He graduated from St Catharine's College, Cambridge, and went on to Worcester College, Oxford, before taking a PhD at the Karolinska Institute in Stockholm. His ascent to national and international recognition began in 1983 with his appointment as consultant immunologist in Newcastle. At this time he set up the Immunology Travellers' Club, an important informal forum for consultant immunologists, which he chaired until last year.

After re-setting up the clinical immunology department at Newcastle, Graham, who had diagnosed the region's first HIV patient, established the HIV immunology unit in Edinburgh. It was there that he began working with the Medical Research Council biostatistics centre in Cambridge - alongside Dr Sheila Gore, whom he later married - and with the Scottish Centre for Infection and Environmental Health.

Devising a demonstrably anonymous way of taking samples for HIV and hepatitis surveillance in prisons enabled astonishingly high uptake rates to be obtained. Wider population surveillance studies also enabled high-level predictions to be made relating to the size of the HIV epidemic in Scotland.

Bird was a great lobbyist, both with prisoners, where he uncovered a thirst for knowledge as a tool for protection, and with politicians, where the thirst for knowledge was perhaps less. His innovative, and once controversial, immuno-epidemiology is now mainstream across the European Union.

He believed in casting aside the mystique and pomposity surrounding medicine. He also ensured that the views of trainees were taken note of in the highest quarters of the royal colleges of medicine and pathology, and was a member of important advisory and policy-forming college committees.

Before becoming ill late last year, Bird had been appointed to head the immunology department in Leicester. Here, with the integrated pathology service giving much improved opportunities for quality laboratory service, and a wider patient base, he was confident of making a centre of excellence for clinical and laboratory immunology and immuno-epidemiology.

Bird was a great classical-music lover - his electrostatic speakers occupied several square metres of wall space - a wine lover, an opera fanatic, a great bagger of Munros and a lifetime supporter of Newcastle United. His contributions will live on.

He is survived by his soul-mate and wife Sheila, and his son.

fields.headline: Thelma Whiteley
fields.trailText: Thelma Whiteley, who has died aged 65, was the original Susan in Mike Leigh's Abigail's Party, and a dedicated and versatile actress on stage, television and radio. She gave a terrific performance as Maggie Clayhanger in the ITV adaptation of Arnold Bennet's trilogy, and appeared in The Sweeney, Testament Of Youth, Shroud For A Nightingale, Boon and many other programmes.
fields.body:
Thelma Whiteley, who has died aged 65, was the original Susan in Mike Leigh's Abigail's Party, and a dedicated and versatile actress on stage, television and radio. She gave a terrific performance as Maggie Clayhanger in the ITV adaptation of Arnold Bennet's trilogy, and appeared in The Sweeney, Testament Of Youth, Shroud For A Nightingale, Boon and many other programmes. On radio, she was a memorable Flora Finching in Little Dorrit, Mrs Gaskell in Wives And Daughters and, last summer, played the redoubtable Bates in Nicholas Freeling's Arlette.

On Broadway, Whiteley played Eileen in Alan Aykbourn's Semi Detached, and returned to New York as Madame Mantolini, and other parts, in the Royal Shakespeare Company's Nicholas Nickleby, which she had previously played at the Aldwych Theatre.

Born in Luton, Thelma went with her parents to America as a child. She returned to train at the Royal Academy of Dramatic Art, after which she worked at the Nottingham Playhouse, Edinburgh Lyceum, the Royal Court and the Bristol Old Vic. In 1987, she was diagnosed as having a rare lung disease, and the following year, while she was filming in Czechoslovakia, one of her lungs collapsed. Her first lung transplant, five years later, was unsuccessful, but a second, two years afterwards, sustained her.

In 1995 she began to work again, firstly on radio, then on television, in Coronation Street, The Bill and, with great success, in the comedy series Big Bad World. Last summer, she joined the original cast of Abigail's Party on the stage of the Olivier Theatre stage, where a packed house gave a rapturous reception to a reading of several scenes from the play.

Thelma Whiteley was a real no-nonsense woman, and will be much missed.

fields.headline: Alphonse Boudard
fields.standfirst: Novelist whose experiences bred tales of French low-life
fields.trailText: Alphonse Boudard, who has died aged 74, was one of the most original and impressive French novelists of the last 40 years. He was not an intellectual writing novels which explored ideas. He wrote directly and forcefully about life as he had lived and witnessed it. All his works contain reminiscence. He was, as he put it, always wandering in the past, "en promenade rétro."
fields.body:
Alphonse Boudard, who has died aged 74, was one of the most original and impressive French novelists of the last 40 years. He was not an intellectual writing novels which explored ideas. He wrote directly and forcefully about life as he had lived and witnessed it. All his works contain reminiscence. He was, as he put it, always wandering in the past, "en promenade rétro."

It could hardly have been otherwise. Boudard was born in in the 13th arondissement of Paris - not the sort of place where tourists set foot. His mother was a 17-year-old prostitute, who packed him off to some peasants in the Loiret. Aged seven, he was brought back to Paris, where he was looked after by his grandmother. He went to a local school and became apprenticed to a typesetter. "I knew my letters before I knew my words," was how he described this achievement at the age of 14.

Boudard's wanderings in German-occupied Paris became organised when he joined the resistance, working under the command of Pierre Georges, known as "Colonel Fabien", the legendary communist martyr, whose unit was made up of working-class men, mainly from Paris, and sections of the army. After the liberation of the city, this force was taken under the command of General de Lattre de Tassigny, and moved towards Strasbourg and the Rhine. Boudard was twice wounded, and although he apparently refused to accept the Military Medal, he was decorated with the Croix de Guerre and cited several times for bravery.

He left the army as soon as he could, but seemed unable to settle to any occupation. He sold pornography, dealt in counterfeit money, and became a specialist in robbing funeral businesses. The result was prison and, although he was pardoned because of outstanding war services, he was to go back to jail later. But tuberculosis struck him and, from 1948 to the 1960s, he divided his time between prison and hospital. It was then that he began to read, widely and wildly. And it was in 1958 that he began to write his first novel.

Boudard's subjects were those that he knew - fighting, serving time in prison, being ill. The characters were the companions whom he remembered. Most important, perhaps, the language was that of his former companions. Boudard him self claimed to be bilingual in French and "argot", or French slang, a language that is particularly imaginative and picturesque. He wanted it to be recognised by the Académie Française and, in 1998, co-authored a book in which he explained his ideas about argot.

Boudard liked to go against the accepted idea. To him, not all bourgeois were selfish and unattractive, not all members of the resistance were heroic, not all beggars were to be recommended. This sometimes displeased readers. When, for example, he wrote about two young men in the resistance hitching lifts from "les Fritz", being searched by "le grand Teuton" for propaganda leaflets, admiring "les Amerlogues" who stank of chewing gum, petrol and special cigarettes, it was said that this was not how it really was in Colonel Fabien's unit. But this was Boudard's anthology of his experiences.

He won the Prix Sainte Beuve for his prison novel, La Cerise (1963), and the Prix Renaudot for Les Combattants du Petit Bonheur (1977), about the resistance. He wrote scenarios for films, and several of his books were adapted for the cinema.

A new novel, Les Trois Mamans du Petit Jésus, due to appear shortly, describes how Jesus, as a baby, is abandoned on the steps of a brothel and is tended by three mothers. It promises to be very Boudardien, since the brothel in question is one which he knew, and since the idea of motherhood was a fundamental part of his experience. He had visions of "Mademoiselle ma mère," the young blonde mother who had abandoned him and whom he hoped to meet in heaven.

Boudard is survived by his wife and two sons.

The result was prison and, although he was pardoned because of outstanding war services, he was to go back to jail later. But tuberculosis struck him and, from 1948 to the 1960s, he divided his time between prison and hospital. It was then that he began to read, widely and wildly. And it was in 1958 that he began to write his first novel. Boudard's subjects were those that he knew - fighting, serving time in prison, being ill. The characters were the companions whom he remembered. Most important, perhaps, the language was that of his former companions. Boudard him self claimed to be bilingual in French and "argot", or French slang, a language that is particularly imaginative and picturesque. He wanted it to be recognised by the Académie Française and, in 1998, co-authored a book in which he explained his ideas about argot. Boudard liked to go against the accepted idea. To him, not all bourgeois were selfish and unattractive, not all members of the resistance were heroic, not all beggars were to be recommended. This sometimes displeased readers. When, for example, he wrote about two young men in the resistance hitching lifts from "les Fritz", being searched by "le grand Teuton" for propaganda leaflets, admiring "les Amerlogues" who stank of chewing gum, petrol and special cigarettes, it was said that this was not how it really was in Colonel Fabien's unit. But this was Boudard's anthology of his experiences. He won the Prix Sainte Beuve for his prison novel, La Cerise (1963), and the Prix Renaudot for Les Combattants du Petit Bonheur (1977), about the resistance. He wrote scenarios for films, and several of his books were adapted for the cinema. A new novel, Les Trois Mamans du Petit Jésus, due to appear shortly, describes how Jesus, as a baby, is abandoned on the steps of a brothel and is tended by three mothers. It promises to be very Boudardien, since the brothel in question is one which he knew, and since the idea of motherhood was a fundamental part of his experience. He had visions of "Mademoiselle ma mère," the young blonde mother who had abandoned him and whom he hoped to meet in heaven. Boudard is survived by his wife and two sons. fields.headline: I-Roy
fields.standfirst: Jamaican star famed for fluid toasting style
fields.trailText: When Linton Kwesi Johnson first referred to dub poetry, it was the verbal artistry of the Jamaican toaster, I-Roy, that he had in mind. Roy, who has died of a heart attack aged 55, gained an international following with a series of classic 1970s recordings that mixed witty lyrics with a relaxed, fluid toasting style.
fields.body:
When Linton Kwesi Johnson first referred to dub poetry, it was the verbal artistry of the Jamaican toaster, I-Roy, that he had in mind. Roy, who has died of a heart attack aged 55, gained an international following with a series of classic 1970s recordings that mixed witty lyrics with a relaxed, fluid toasting style.

Born Roy Reid, he was a civil servant in Kingston when he first began toasting in 1966. His popularity prompted relocation to Spanish Town, where he later became the star deejay of the Supreme Ruler of Sound and Stereosound systems.

At the start of the 1970s, sound system deejays gained a new prominence after the success of recorded material by Ewart "U Roy" Beckford. U Roy's hits inspired I-Roy to launch his own recording career, and, with work for producer Harry Mudie, he began a meteoric rise. His 1973 debut album, Presenting I-Roy, became enormously popular in Jamaica and Britain, and was followed by the equally strong self-produced set Hell And Sorrow.

I-Roy spent many months in London in 1973, playing a regular spot at the Roaring 20s club alongside Sir Coxsone's sound system. The following year his Many Moods Of I-Roy album was released, and, backed by Matumbi, he made well-received British live appearances.

Back in Jamaica, I-Roy cut the thoughtful Truth And Rights album for producer Pete Weston, and in 1975 became Channel 1 studio's in-house producer. The result was some of the biggest hits by the Mighty Diamonds and Revolutionaries.

I-Roy was at the peak of his popularity in 1976 when he signed a five-album contract with Virgin Records. Each disc had strong performances over tight Revolutionaries rhythms, with Heart Of A Lion being the most inspired. The album African Herbsman (1979), recorded under Errol Thompson's direction, showed a continued strength, but while Doctor Fish (1981) had its moments, subsequent sporadic recordings lacked the earlier grace and wit .

In the early 1990s, I-Roy devoted himself to building a recording studio in Spanish Town. Sadly, his ailing health and mental illness meant it never opened. Then, as the retrospective Don't Check Me With No Lightweight Stuff album triggered a resurgence of interest in his career, I-Roy's condition deteriorated. Apparently homeless, he succumbed after learning of the violent death of an incarcerated son.

I-Roy (Roy Samuel Reid), recording and performing artist, born 1944; died November 29 1999

fields.headline: Days of reckoning lie ahead
fields.standfirst:
Northern Ireland: special report

The IRA has failed to hand in its weapons. The deadline looms
fields.trailText: In the long game of Anglo-Irish relations there is only one predictable certainty; Northern Ireland secretaries of state may come and go but the next crisis is never far away.
fields.body:
In the long game of Anglo-Irish relations there is only one predictable certainty; Northern Ireland secretaries of state may come and go but the next crisis is never far away.

We are already in the political foothills of the looming February deadline on IRA decommissioning. Peter Mandelson has barred Sinn Fein from using their new Commons' offices. David Trimble and his unionist cohorts have threatened they will walk out and collapse the Ulster executive unless the IRA hands over arms by the time the unionist ruling council meets on February 12. The chief constable, Ronnie Flanagan, says he sees no evidence of decommissioning. Newspapers are filled with fanciful speculation about how the IRA, with General John de Chastelain as the sole eyewitness, will destroy its weapons. And every outraged Sinn Fein spokesman robotically parrots the same line on the BBC about "IRA guns being silent".

Amidst all this blather it is worth remembering a few basic rules of the game. First, the principal protagonists in Ulster's long nightmare are the British government and the IRA (as represented by Sinn Fein). The Ulster peace process is predicated on a rough but well defined bargain between both sides; take away the IRA bombs and we will take away the Brits. The unionists, as they are now finding out to their political cost on issues like the RUC and its glorious but short-lived George Cross, run a poor but necessary third.

Second, we are not playing by Westminster rules and we never will be. Gerry Adams and Martin McGuinness have devoted much of their adult lives trying to destroy, with guns and bombs, the British state in Ireland. Many of their close friends have been killed in what they see as the historic struggle, others have spent decades of their lives in British prisons. Both men were members of the same republican leadership that tried to assassinate the entire British cabinet on two occasions - in 1984 at Brighton and in 1991 in Downing Street. Their fingers may not have been on the detonator but only a fool could believe they were not party to the act.

Both men are leaders of a political movement that has endured against incredible odds. They are adherents to an age-old political passion - the republican dream of a united Ireland - that rightly shows up Blairism as the trite, twisting doctrine it is. They are the same IRA men today as they were 30 years ago. British politicians underestimate them at their peril. Rising up through the ranks of the IRA in the face of the military onslaught of the British state is a wholly different political contest from charming a few old trade unionists at your selection committee.

The dark skeletons in Mr Adams's life will come as no surprise to Downing Street. The elaborate bugging of Mr Adams's car in a bid to obtain intelligence on his thoughts on the Good Friday agreement negotiations is a tactic rightly reserved for those deemed to be official enemies of the state (although Mr Trimble should now possibly check his own transportation). But Tony Blair can hardly be then shocked if one day Mr Adams reneges on his promises - that is what enemies do. We need to keep the jaw-jaw going to stop the war-war happening.

On one level Mr Blair's desire to peer into the mind of Mr Adams is perfectly understandable. Sinn Fein/IRA is not like any other political movement in Europe. It remains wholly immune to outside scrutiny. It does not leak and the leadership never squabbles in public. Its internal decision-making process is utterly opaque. To listen to one Sinn Fein interview is to listen to all of them. Its skilful media spokesmen Mitchell McLaughlin and Gerry Kelly, put New Labour to shame in terms of their rigid recitation of the current "message" while being interviewed. Clearly in this sense Sinn Fein is not a political party at all. It is the public relations division of the IRA and all of its political positions are pre-formulated somewhere beyond our gaze.

The third rule of Ulster politics is the oddest: that the IRA can generally be trusted to tell the truth. The IRA may have futilely murdered the innocent in great numbers but they do not lie about it. The other thing the IRA do not lie about is decommissioning; there is not going to be any. In statement after statement they have repeated this message. Yet the fiction that they agreed to do so, that they will do so, clutters up the news page and fills broadcasts.

The illusion of the promise of IRA decommissioning may at one stage been useful to the British government but it has become a deadlock of Downing Street's own creation. It is time for the latest secretary of state, Peter Mandelson, to pull a new trick out of the hat in Ulster to keep our vital bargain, no bombs, no Brits, with the IRA intact.

A new edition of Kevin Toolis's book on the IRA, Rebel Hearts, will be published by Picador in April

webTitle: Beijing denies top-level link to smuggling case

fields.headline: Beijing denies top-level link to smuggling case
fields.trailText: China has issued a remarkable denial that the wife of one of its politburo members is linked to a huge smuggling scandal involving high-level corruption.
fields.body:
China has issued a remarkable denial that the wife of one of its politburo members is linked to a huge smuggling scandal involving high-level corruption.

Beijing has also rejected widespread rumours that Jia Qinglin, who is both the mayor of Beijing and the senior Communist party secretary in the capital, has divorced his wife to distance himself from the affair.

A statement on an officially sponsored website yesterday said Lin Youfang remained Mr Jia's "steadfast companion" and was helping him in his work. It denied "slanderous reports" that Ms Lin was involved in the smuggling case in the southern coastal city of Xiamen, attributing the rejection to "authoritative government departments".

It is unprecedented for China to refer officially to leaders' family connections.

A team of several hundred government investigators has been working for months in Xiamen in Fujian province, trying to crack a case involving senior local officials, at least two of whom are believed to have fled the country.

Ms Lin is head of the Fujian Province Import and Export Corporation which is believed to have licensed several lucrative deals involving the import of cars, mobile phones, oil, tobacco and other high-value foreign products.

The import permits were sub-contracted to trading firms, which then allegedly bribed customs officials to allow the goods free entry. The customs duty which was saved was then shared out among those involved. Unofficial estimates of the value of the imported goods are as high as 80bn Renminbi (£6bn).

The Xiamen firm at the centre of the scandal, the Yuan Hua group, was set up by Lai Changxing, a former peasant who rose to fame as one of China's new-style entrepreneurs.

More than 100 Xiamen officials are said to have been questioned by the inspectors. At one stage it is claimed that the team found its own phones were being bugged - allegedly on the orders of Xiamen's chief of police. He too is said to be under investigation.

According to one rumour, the premier, Zhu Rongji, is in charge of the investigation and is spending half of his time on the case.

Only a few brief reports on the scandal have been published in the Chinese press. The Guangzhou Daily said this week that "as investigators dig deeper and deeper, they find not only more people involved but at a higher level of government".
