fields.trailText: Thai officials yesterday denied allegations that Burmese gunmen holding an estimated 700 hostages at a hospital were shot in cold blood.
fields.body:
Thai officials yesterday denied allegations that Burmese gunmen holding an estimated 700 hostages at a hospital were shot in cold blood.

Thai security forces stormed the provincial hospital where dissident Burmese gunmen had taken hundreds of people hostage a day earlier.

None of the estimated 700 hostages was hurt in the pre-dawn assault on the compound in central Ratchaburi yesterday, but 10 hostage-takers were killed and several policemen were injured.

It is not known if any of the gunmen, members of a militant Christian group of ethnic Karens called God's Army, managed to escape. The twin 12-year-old boys who command God's Army were not involved at the hospital.

Thai officials denied accusations that the gunmen were shot in cold blood. In a macabre victory celebration, they paraded corpses in front of the hospital for the media.

The bodies were wrapped in white sheets and it was not possible to see how the men were killed, but several bodies were still bleeding from the head, leaving bloodstains on the sheets and concrete where they were laid.

The security forces also exhibited the fighters' weapons, a collection of ageing M16 automatic rifles, hand grenades, equipment and boots.

The prime minister, Chuan Leekpai, said the rescue had been carefully planned and was "very successful".

Preparations for the rescue had begun hours after the God's Army fighters seized the hospital to draw attention to the plight of their people who are being squeezed between the Burmese and Thai military at their mountain hideaway on the countries' border.

Commandos and police moved in during the night. At 5.40am dozens of troops on foot and in jeeps stormed into the four-acre (1.6 hectare) site.

One hostage, a nurse, told Thai television that the security forces phoned the hospital before the attack, telling staff to turn off lights and not to move. "When the attack started we were half asleep," she said. "But we woke up suddenly and told everyone to keep quiet. There was fighting outside our room but we did not know who was who."

While shooting continued hostages began leaving the hospital. Many embraced the waiting soldiers before being taken to medical centres.

The regional army commander, Lieutenant-General Thaweep Suwannasingha, told reporters all the hostages were freed unharmed.

"It was a successful operation," he said. "The patients in the hospital needed help."

Lieutenant-General Anant Heamathanong said all the hostage-takers had died in the fighting, and none was executed. He said nine were killed at the scene and the tenth in a gunbattle after fleeing.

God's Army is one of several groups of ethnic Karens fighting the Burmese military junta. It was born three years ago after Johnny and Luther Htoo, then nine, reportedly led a counterattack on a Burmese military position.

webTitle: A new flag but the old ways continue

fields.headline: A new flag but the old ways continue
fields.trailText: Although apartheid is officially dead, everywhere in our society - in our homes, educational institutions and the workplace - racism still plagues us. We are only beginning to recognise that the problem of racism and prejudice based on race, ethnicity and sex, remains to be confronted.
fields.byline: Evidence wa ka Ngobeni in Johannesburg
fields.body:
Although apartheid is officially dead, everywhere in our society - in our homes, educational institutions and the workplace - racism still plagues us. We are only beginning to recognise that the problem of racism and prejudice based on race, ethnicity and sex, remains to be confronted.

Even though signs such as "No blacks allowed", which were common during apartheid, have vanished, a lot still has to be done to turn the racial wheel around.

I have had my own experiences of discrimination and racism, the most recent at the beginning of this year when I was looking for a flat.

After days of going over newspaper classified adverts I finally found a suitable bachelor flat. But although I had secured the flat on the telephone, when I arrived in person to pay for it, a white lady in charge of the office in central Johannesburg turned me away.

"All the flats have been taken," she said. I suspected that the problem might be the colour of my skin and asked a white colleague to phone the office and negotiate. She was told that a flat was available and that she was more than welcome to come and see it.

So when the Human Rights Commission revealed that more than 60% of complaints it received concerned racism, particularly discrimination in leisure activities and rented housing, it was no surprise to me.

A raft of legislation focusing on affirmative action and black empowerment has been introduced to address these problems. But six years down the line, racism is beginning to rear its head again.

A number of organisations still discriminate on racial lines. During my work as a journalist here I have met a number of black people who have complained of this situation. One of their concerns is that most companies continue to discipline blacks more harshly than whites, and to discriminate against blacks in the provision of staff benefits, despite legislation to prevent this.

Black people say that the companies are determined to keep their essential operations in the hands of whites.

In some cases people have failed to provide solid evidence to support their claims. But against that one must set the fact that in the past few years the number of complaints of discrimination has mushroomed all over the country.

The African National Congress government has been asked repeatedly to intervene and help to resolve these problems. But so far change has been only at the margins.

Black people are still frequently discriminated against at leisure resorts and restaurants, where the management uses "entrance reserved" rights to discriminate against people of colour.

I believe racism has not decreased in the past six years of democratic government. There is no sense that things are improving in this area.

There is a desperate need for the ANC government to act to improve our lives.

President Thabo Mbeki has indicated that one of the major challenges among others facing democracy in the 21st century is to eradicate racism. This includes the eradication of racism in the allocation of donor funds by organisations to the public. Some organisations continue to donate funds along racial lines.

Tertiary education institutions are not immune to this problem. Although many universities in South Africa have transformed in the past six years, a number of them are still failing to embrace diversity.

Highly qualified black staff are marginalised, appointed to lowly positions, paid far less than their white colleagues, and have to report to less well qualified whites.

Evidence wa ka Ngobeni is a journalist with the Mail & Guardian, Johannesburg

This includes the eradication of racism in the allocation of donor funds by organisations to the public. Some organisations continue to donate funds along racial lines. Tertiary education institutions are not immune to this problem. Although many universities in South Africa have transformed in the past six years, a number of them are still failing to embrace diversity. Highly qualified black staff are marginalised, appointed to lowly positions, paid far less than their white colleagues, and have to report to less well qualified whites. fields.headline: In Brief
fields.trailText: Cuba condemns failed Elian visit
fields.body:
Cuba condemns failed Elian visit

Cuba yesterday accused the Miami relatives of Elian Gonzalez of derailing a meeting between the boy, six, and his grandmothers.

Raquel Rodriguez and Mariela Quintana flew to Miami from New York on Monday but failed to meet Elian, found off the Florida coast on November 25, after his US relatives allegedly insisted the visit take place at their home.

The US immigration service ordered a new meeting to take place at a neutral site today. AP, Havana.

Rebels kill 12 in Algeria ambush

A Muslim rebel group in Algeria shot dead 12 civilians in the first massacre since a government amnesty offer expired 12 days ago, a newspaper said yesterday.

The daily La Tribune said the rebels forced an ambulance and bus to stop at a fake roadblock in the Defla area, about 75 miles west of Algiers. They fired at the passengers, killing 12 and wounding three, La Tribune said.

Wahid orders general out

The Indonesian president, Abdurrahman Wahid, has signed a decree retiring General Wiranto from the military, Reuters reported yesterday.

Gen Wiranto failed to resign, as required by law, when he was appointed coordinating minister for political and security affairs last October.

Many believe Gen Wiranto is plotting against Mr Wahid.

Tehran mayor given pardon

Iran's supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, has pardoned the popular former mayor of Tehran after seven months of a two-year sentence, state television said yesterday.

Gholamhossein Karbaschi was imprisoned on corruption charges he denied. The pardon was seen as part of efforts by hard-liners to improve their chances in upcoming elections.

Suspected war criminal held

Nato peacekeepers arrested a suspected war criminal in eastern Bosnia yesterday, UN officials and Serb police said. The man, arrested in Visegrad, close to the border with Serbia, was identified as Mitar Vasilievic.

webTitle: New ANC law to tackle ingrained prejudice

fields.headline: New ANC law to tackle ingrained prejudice
fields.standfirst: Years after apartheid, South Africa struggles for true equality with a series of controversial 'transformation' bills
fields.trailText: South Africa's parliament is expected to pass sweeping new legislation today that will outlaw many forms of racial, sexual and other discrimination in an attempt to stifle the bigotry that permeates the country long after the end of apartheid. The controversial law will also bar hate speech and harassment.
fields.body:
South Africa's parliament is expected to pass sweeping new legislation today that will outlaw many forms of racial, sexual and other discrimination in an attempt to stifle the bigotry that permeates the country long after the end of apartheid. The controversial law will also bar hate speech and harassment.

The promotion of equality and prevention of unfair discrimination bill bans discrimination on a wide range of grounds, from pregnancy and sexual orientation to age and language. But the focus of the law is race, gender and disability, and clauses specifically protecting the poor and people infected with the HIV virus were dropped at the last minute after heavy lobbying by insurance companies.

Special "equality courts" will hear accusations of discrimination. Judges will have the power to award compensation against individuals and strip businesses of their licences if, for instance, they refuse to employ or serve black people. The onus will be on the accused to prove that they did not abuse or discriminate.

Penuell Maduna, the justice minister, described the new law as long overdue.

"This legislation will go a long way in contributing to the total transformation of society from one characterised by the inequalities and injustices inherited from apartheid to one where the universal principles of equality, fairness, justice and human dignity apply to everyone," he said.

But, he added: "While government is committed to the eradication of discrimination, it is equally important that all South Africans change their attitude towards each other."

The bill, which declares apartheid a crime against humanity, is one of four "transformation laws" that must take effect by next week to meet a constitutional deadline. The others deal with affirmative action and access to information.

But the equality bill is the most far-reaching. Among its many provisions is a bar on "the dissemination of any propaganda or idea which propounds the racial superiority or inferiority of any person". Critics say that clause will stifle free political debate, for example about an Afrikaner homeland.

The new law also bars hate speech. The list of banned words include "kaffir", "coolie" and "hotnot" but not "boer", which was dropped.

Female circumcision is outlawed under the gender discrimination clause as is "traditional, customary or religious practice" which undermines the "dignity and well-being of the girl child".

One of the drafters of the legislation, Shadrack Gutto, a Kenyan lawyer, said that as the law currently stands, it is not illegal for a restaurant to refuse to serve people simply because they are black.

"It [the new legislation] will confront the daily discrimination which goes on the basis of race which remains a major problem in South Africa. Direct forms of discrimination manifest themselves in the workplace, in schools, on sports fields," he said.

"Some of them are very direct. A lot of racial abuse and harassment goes on. This law tries to prevent that. It will present a new value system that will have a major and immediate impact in combating unfair discrimination, hate speech and harassment.

"But you cannot say that behaviour and attitudes will change overnight."

The Democratic party, the official opposition in parliament, has dismissed the legislation as another form of apartheid and accused the ANC of a "programme of re-racialisation".

Critics say that a separate but complementary act, the employment equity bill, will require employers to go back to racial classification of their workforce to meet affirmative action requirements.

Meanwhile, the insurance industry is threatening to test the equality bill in the constitutional court because, it says, the law fails to recognise that by its nature it has to discriminate.

The South African bar council criticised the bill, saying some of its provisions "simply do not make any sense at all". Some lawyers and politicians have condemned the equality courts as political interference because it will be the justice ministry who selects the judges and magistrates to be trained to work in them.

But Mr Gutto says that parts of the judiciary have failed to adapt to the new South Africa.

"You are busy making a new constitution and new laws and you give it to a judiciary that is part of the old system and not really interested in enforcing them. Any court which is going to hear equality disputes must have judges and magistrates who understand the legislation and want to apply it.

"It's going to have a major impact and it's intended to do so," he said.

Main points of move to end bigotry

Prohibtition of hate speech that is 'hurtful, harmful or inciting to harm, promoting or propagating hatred' and the prohibition of any racial discrimination through articles or speeches advocating racial superiority, exclusion on basis of race or the provision of inferior services

Prohibition of sexual discrimination, including any bar on women inheriting property, traditional or religious practices which undermine female equality, discrimination on the grounds of pregnancy, discrimination at work

Prohibition of discrimination on grounds of disability, including failing to remove obstacles to employment

webTitle: Popular former US governor on trial for racketeering - again

fields.headline: Popular former US governor on trial for racketeering - again
fields.trailText: One of Louisiana's most popular and controversial former governors was accused of extortion, racketeering and lying under oath in court yesterday.
fields.body:
One of Louisiana's most popular and controversial former governors was accused of extortion, racketeering and lying under oath in court yesterday.

Edwin Edwards, who was state governor for four terms, faces 28 criminal charges for allegedly forcing companies to pay millions of dollars for riverboat gambling licences.

The prosecutor's office has also charged five former aides of the 72-year-old, including his lawyer son, Stephen.

The case has turned the spotlight on corruption in the southern US state, where the charismatic Mr Edwards remains a popular figure despite two previous government trials for alleged racketeering.

In bringing the latest charges, Eddie Jordan, the prosecutor, said: "Hopefully, our efforts to hold those accountable for the brazen acts of corruption described in the indictment will eventually bring about a heightened awareness among our citizens and those of other states that we will not tolerate political and economic corruption here in Louisiana."

First elected in 1971, Mr Edwards is considered by many to be Louisiana's most popular politician since Huey Long, a governor in the 1930s. A renowned womaniser and gambler, Mr Edwards garnered huge support from poorer voters by taxing the oil business and appearing to champion the weak.

But the prosecutor brought Mr Edwards to trial twice in the mid-80s. The first, in which he was accused of financially benefiting from the award of state nursing-home franchises, ended in a hung jury, and the second in acquittal. But the latest charges are potentially more serious.

They allege that Mr Edwards and his aides devised five schemes to extort money while he was governor and after he last left office in 1996.

The felony counts include mail fraud, money-laundering and illegal wiretapping. If convicted of all charges, Mr Edwards could face 350 years in prison and a fine of $7.25m (£4.3m).

Among a powerful array of government witnesses is Edward DeBartolo, the former chairman of the San Francisco 49ers American football team, who is expected to testify that Mr Edwards made him pay $400,000 for a casino licence.

Mr Edwards, who denies the charges, has been restricted from talking to the press by a gag order. But he is reported to have said on Monday that "they have not made a prosecutor yet who could ambush me".

The trial is expected to last about three months.

webTitle: Heavens open:  Heavy snow and ice bring parts of New York to a halt

fields.headline: Heavens open:  Heavy snow and ice bring parts of New York to a halt
fields.trailText: A powerful storm churned up the US east coast yesterday after battering the south-east with ice and heavy snow, leaving tens of thousands of people without power.
fields.body:
A powerful storm churned up the US east coast yesterday after battering the south-east with ice and heavy snow, leaving tens of thousands of people without power.

Snow fell heavily around New York City during the morning rush hour and up to 20cm (8in) were forecast to fall across New England by last night. The storm arrived with wind gusting to 30mph, making it feel well below zero from New Jersey to New England.

As much as 18cm (7in) of snow were forecast to fall in Virginia and the Washington suburbs. Schools and businesses were closed and travel disrupted across the region. Some airports, including New York's LaGuardia and Washington Reagan National Airport, were closed. Others faced delays and cancellations, including Boston's Logan International.

In Virginia hospitals called for volunteers with four-wheel-drive vehicles to take doctors and nurses to work.

Slippery roads caused hundreds of traffic accidents. Four traffic deaths were blamed on the weather in South Carolina, with one in North Carolina.

In Washington, most federal agencies were closed. Even Andrews Air Force Base in Maryland told non-essential workers to stay at home.

More than 200,000 customers in North and South Carolina were without power early yesterday. In north-east Alabama, 12,000 people remained without power after an ice storm that struck on Saturday.

North Carolina's governor, Jim Hunt, declared a state of emergency yesterday, urging everyone to stay at home, and the national guard was activated to help clear streets and rescue stranded motorists.

In Atlanta, about 70,000 customers were still without electricity after the weekend ice storm left approximately 500,000 without power. Energy companies say it may take a few more days to restore power to everyone. A preliminary statewide damage estimate was $25m (£15m).

In the west, the biggest winter storm of the season lingered across the Sierra Nevada. Storm warnings were issued for western Nevada and the Lake Tahoe region.

webTitle: Welcome to the home of Britain's internet

fields.headline: Welcome to the home of Britain's internet
fields.standfirst: Simon Rogers goes to London's Docklands to explore one of our most vital buildings
fields.trailText: Simon Rogers goes to London's Docklands to explore one of our most vital buildings
fields.body:
I have seen the information superhighway. It is tucked away in a small street off Saffron Avenue, near Nutmeg Lane. There is even a duckpond just over the way. From the outside there is little to give away the building's real purpose. Rising out of a featureless landscape, it is a matt-black block with a single entrance, surrounded by a fence and security cameras. Patrolled around the clock, it is designed to withstand the worst terrorist onslaught. It looks like the sort of Nevada desert facility that Mulder and Scully are always breaking into. But if the internet is characterised by any place in Britain, this is it.

Silicon Fen may be the creative home of the net, but this is the physical. This is Telehouse, in the murky middle of London's Docklands. It was the first place in Britain to provide a facility for net companies to house their servers - the boxes which contain the information that makes up the website. The building, open 24 hours a day, hosts 350 companies, hundreds of miles of wire, generators, emergency electrical supplies and without it, the British internet might not exist.

"It's not a people place," admits Telehouse sales and client support manager Michelle Reid. Once out of the small admin building (the only place where you actually see any of the 80 people who work there), you enter the main block through sealed capsules, a door closing behind you and another slowly opening in front. Inside, long corridors are empty of staff, bereft of posters and all but free of windows.

This is the way it works: when you log on to, for example, the net supplier Demon, your computer dials in to the Demon "server", which then takes you to the page you want to go. The server, normally a dull-looking grey box about the size of a small filing cabinet, lives in Telehouse. It is, if you like, a net warehouse.

Telehouse was the first and, of course, it happened by accident. Set up in 1990 as a disaster recovery centre for the finance world, it still houses a fully equipped dealing room ready to receive pinstripe-shirted traders evacuated from disaster-hit premises in the City. Then the net happened and now all the major UK internet service providers (ISPs) store their servers in the complex - companies such as Demon, for example and even the Guardian.

Although it may look dull, this is the future. You might be able to set up an e-commerce business in your bedroom, but as soon as you make any real money and you need to start storing real data about real people, your flat will no longer do. Computer equipment may be getting smaller, but it still uses the same power. The more computers you put in one room, the more power they need. Not forgetting telecommunication links, security and emergency power.

In the Telehouse basement, huge emergency diesel generators recall the engine room of a great liner. In one room there are banks of yellow batteries, in another, huge transformers marked "WARNING 11,000 volts".

Spencer Reynolds, the shift supervisor, is one of the few people around. In charge of the power supply, he works in an office with the generator switches, which live in wood-panelled cabinets. "This is one job that couldn't be done by computer," he says confidently. "If there's an emergency, you'll always need a human to override the system."

And the net itself? It's upstairs on huge floors divided by windowed walls - 165,000 sq ft across two buildings. Rows of cabinets house the servers, black units which look like the amplifiers on expensive stereo separates. Wires are everywhere - red, yellow, blue and green, contrasting with the battleship-grey of the cabinets and modems. It's all owned by the individual companies - all Telehouse provides is the location. Nobody knows how much wire is in the building, although one client did lay 7 miles in one weekend.

Demon stores some of its equipment at Telehouse for security reasons. "Telehouse is a very secure building," says the net supplier's internet expert Richard Clayton. And it's important - the memory chips alone (the official term is Random Access Memory, or RAM) are worth a fortune. "You can't drive a car bomb into it. But then there is a market in RAM. I imagine the memory in that building must be worth a lot of money."

In one of the sealed rooms, Keith Mitchell works on the LINX machines. LINX stands for London Internet Exchange and is owned by a cooperative of 90 British internet companies. If Telehouse is the equivalent of Clapham junction, LINX is the signal box. It provides the physical connections for service providers to talk to each other.

It's the busiest net exchange in Europe, and bases its equipment mainly at Telehouse. "We're a high- profile target," says Mitchell, who is chairman of LINX. "We had some Russian hackers poking around our servers on New Year's Eve." By "poking around" he means they tried to get in to the server to muck around with some of the companies who use LINX. They were swiftly ejected and wouldn't have been able to do much damage anyway, says Mitchell.

The business of storing the net is worth serious money. Telehouse charges around £5,000 a year for a rack, which is actually a big cabinet, just over 6ft high. New kid Redbus Interhouse, aiming specifically at small start-ups, charges £250 a month and allows users to rent space on a short-term basis.

But even in a place as controlled as Telehouse, the potential for disaster is ever-present. Not too long ago, one engineer flicked a switch in the wrong direction. Nobody died but servers and net companies went down for a short time. Reid is keen to point out that it couldn't happen again, but for such a new industry, people have long memories. "You need the experience to provide this sort of facility," she says.

But the reality is that it's not a regulated industry and nobody could have predicted the current popularity of the net in the UK. Telehouse didn't - it has reached full capacity and is frantically trying to expand. "They just didn't build it big enough," says one insider. It's a business that's only going to grow. As well as Redbus Interhouse, Telecity and London Switch have recently set up nearby.

But perhaps the most important feature of these places is that they remind us that the net is a tangible thing. You can see it and touch it and hear it hum.

New kid Redbus Interhouse, aiming specifically at small start-ups, charges £250 a month and allows users to rent space on a short-term basis. But even in a place as controlled as Telehouse, the potential for disaster is ever-present. Not too long ago, one engineer flicked a switch in the wrong direction. Nobody died but servers and net companies went down for a short time. Reid is keen to point out that it couldn't happen again, but for such a new industry, people have long memories. "You need the experience to provide this sort of facility," she says. But the reality is that it's not a regulated industry and nobody could have predicted the current popularity of the net in the UK. Telehouse didn't - it has reached full capacity and is frantically trying to expand. "They just didn't build it big enough," says one insider. It's a business that's only going to grow. As well as Redbus Interhouse, Telecity and London Switch have recently set up nearby. But perhaps the most important feature of these places is that they remind us that the net is a tangible thing. You can see it and touch it and hear it hum.

fields.headline: Tim Jeffries
fields.body:
Age: 37.

Occupation: Stockroom boy-turned-rich himbo, grandson of Green Shield stamps founder Richard Tompkins. Linked with almost every unattached supermodel in the past 15 years, now reportedly engaged to Claudia Schiffer.

Appearance: "Matinee idol looks", coo the tabloids, maintained by workouts at Mayfair's Bath and Racquets club (£3,000pa) and a wardrobe said to contain 120 Savile Row suits. "I adore luxury," he has said. "I love beauty in all its forms: in clothing, cars, houses and art."

Heir? By celebrity crimper Michaeljohn.

No, silly, how does he fund his extravagance? Sorry. A £500,000 windfall for his 21st birthday from his grandfather catapulted him from East Grinstead obscurity to the top of cafe society.

Trash with cash, then? Don't be mean. He was cut out of his grandfather's £35m will.

Shame. Not all happy families? No. Tim's engagement, aged 21, to soft-porn star Koo Stark angered his mother Hilary: "If Koo wasn't acceptable for Prince Andrew, I don't see why she should be good enough for my boy." Hilary's anger was not without foundation - Tim and his sister Nicola had refused to give their mother a share of the proceeds from the sale of the family home. Tim and Koo married, but split after a year.

Single again. Yes. And Koo was only the first in a line of silly names: Elle Macpherson, Max Factor's Ines Sastre, Belgian Ingrid Seynhaeve, and pop stars Lisa B and Kylie Minogue followed - all far removed from his first love, Judy Hughesdon, a dry cleaners' sales assistant.

You've got to hand it to the guy. Not if you're AA Gill, who once said: "He's the sort of man you want to take outside and do really appalling things to with acid and a baseball bat."

Nasty. Can he do no wrong? He's not exactly brain of Britain. An £8,000-a-year education brought two O-levels. But Claudia is said to be delighted to have found new love after magician David Copperfield.

Do say: "How do I look?"

Don't say: "Could it be magic?"

webTitle: 'When I'm mayor, I'll make sure the sun always shines'

fields.headline: 'When I'm mayor, I'll make sure the sun always shines'
fields.standfirst:
Simon Hattenstone follows Ken Livingstone as he fights for the right to run London

The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: Simon Hattenstone  follows Ken Livingstone as he fights for the right to run London
fields.body:
"Conversazione" at the Royal Society of Medicine, Wednesday, 6pm

"Bloody tube, sorry." It's not been the greatest of days for Ken Livingstone. The London Evening Standard's first edition leads on "Brown lays into wrecker Ken"; the second edition switches its focus to "Blair in crushing attack on Red Ken". Meanwhile, the Guardian has devoted two broadsheet pages to "the case against Ken Livingstone" - in short, why vote for a sad, lonely, conceited, economically illiterate monomaniac lefty?

Livingstone shambles in with his drone of an apology. You'd be forgiven for thinking he's crushed by the day's coverage. Depressed even, to borrow some black propaganda from this black farce of an election. Actually, he's elated. Anyway, this must be the only election where you score brownie points for being late. Transport is the issue.

As soon as he has named and shamed the tube and reeled off a couple of one-liners, he has the upwardly cerebral of the medical world eating out of his hand. He tells the audience gathered for tonight's "conversazione" that he's surprised they've turned out in such numbers when there's a far more exciting meeting going on across town, where the prime minister and chancellor are uniting to tell the electorate why Livingstone is a liability.

He quickly turns his attention to the NHS. Livingstone doesn't need to savage the health service because Blair's placemen have already done it for him over the past few days. He ingeniously weaves together health and transport to show how ill-prepared the government is for the unexpected. "It was the wrong kind of flu, wasn't it? Just like having the wrong leaves on the track... that's why the nearest intensive-care beds are in Sheffield."

"Do you remember the trolley buses - how clean they were?" asks an urbane chap swathed in gravitas. Livingstone is in his element. Transport, hygiene, and nostalgia all wrapped in one cosy question. "Trolley buses were clean because people cleaned them. The first thing they did when they privatised the buses was sack the cleaners."

He talks about the good old days when men in pinstripes and bowler hats shared the buses. "Now they can't go to work on the bus because they'd never be sure that they'd get there. Now the buses are for the poorest and powerless." The good old days when there were conductors, the good old days when every park had a parkie, when every tube had a guard, when there were no homeless on the streets and everyone had a proper job.

Rather than the hammer-headed revolutionary of Millbank mythology, Livingstone comes across as a mellow pub nostalgist. Perhaps it's not that surprising. He was born at the same time as the welfare state. Today Labour politicians talk of public-private partnerships, viable health insurance, compulsory work schemes. No wonder he looks back with anger and regret.

The journey to Wimbledon

"I've not been this knackered since the year they disbanded the GLC in 1986," says Livingstone. He has been campaigning to be Labour's candidate for mayor of London for 11 months now, and it's amazing he's still standing - in every sense. After all, the Labour party almost barred him from the selection process twice because he didn't support the then party policy on selling off part of the tube to Railtrack. Frank Dobson is expected to start with a 35% advantage (as well as virtually all the MPs, the AEEU engineering union and one Co-op party, both of which are refusing to ballot members, have pledged their support), but Livingstone is, astonishingly, the favourite to win.

He is gliding down the escalator, smiles to the left, smiles to the right, arms holding his newspaper aloft like a trophy: "Blair in crushing attack on Red Ken." Vanity isn't quite the right word. He is totally lacking in self-consciousness. This is Livingstone's home ground, everyday London. He is part of the furniture of the capital. People stop to say hello, or to wish him luck, or ask him about the bloody tube. No one looks surprised to see him. "If you don't like being recognised, if you don't like talking to people, there's no point in being in this game," he says.

I ask whether he prefers the Brown or Blair headline. "Oh definitely Blair. Always go for the boss man."

The man sitting opposite us wants to know if he can ask a question: "Have I got anything to fear from you, Ken?" We've reached Wimbledon, and it's time to get off. "How do I know you, personally, have changed?" the man asks as we leave. Livingstone apologises and says if he hadn't changed in 20 years, if he hadn't learned from his mistakes, there wouldn't be much hope for him.

But it's a good question. How has he changed? "If I go back and read the things I wrote, they're very jargony, economically illiterate, humorless. Twenty years on, I've got to have more confidence to tell those people who are idiots that they are being idiots." It's an arrogant, invincible answer. I ask him again how has he changed as a person, and he doesn't answer.

We are walking down Wimbledon Broadway. He says that when he first heard Dobson was standing for mayor he thought he didn't have a chance; as well as having the cabinet's backing, Dobson was popular among traditional Labour voters. But Livingstone believes the government's handling of the election has scuppered Dobson's chances. He asks if I received one of the letters Labour MPs sent out to constituents telling them why they had to vote for Frank. "They were sent out to all the London MPs, who were told that all they had to do was put their name to it and everything else would be sorted out by Downing Street. They even wrote to me asking if I'd send out a letter to constituents telling them why they had to back Frank, and why we didn't want a return to the bad old days. You know, we got £4,000 in small donations after they sent those letters out."

Has he been surprised by the vehemence of the campaign? "No, not at all. Frank and I are old political bruisers. But it's been different for Glenda... I've done a couple of things on the stage, and the thing is when people work on the stage they work together." Until recently, Glenda Jackson was a loyal Blairite. It is only since she realised Millbank was also waging war on her (at one point the media were deliberately misinformed that she was standing down) that she has become critical of the party machine. Livingstone says he thinks she has had the best campaign of the three of them. And it's certainly true that she has appeared both tougher and warmer since her eyes were opened to the mercenary side of politics. Now we remember what made her fiercely appealing as an actress. Livingstone has, somewhat presumptuously, offered Jackson the role of deputy.

Wimbledon, the Watershed, 8pm

A far cry from the salubrious wine and nibbles of the Royal Society. The club smells of sweat and stale beer. We're in the gents. I ask Livingstone what he's going to do for London's lavs. "When I'm mayor we're going to have loads more toilets. I'm going to reopen all the ones in the tube stations." Tug, tug. Zip, zip.

The audience are in hysterics. Livingstone is a terrific stand-up comic. One hand in his pocket, a smidge of sweat on the upper lip, one shabby brown shoe ahead of the other, he delivers giggles on demand.

"Jeffrey Archer, before his triumphant withdrawal from the race, was actually going round London saying, if you vote for me I'll introduce a £200 flat fine for everybody caught in the bus lane and three points on your licence. The Liberal Simon Hughes came up with the idea we'll impound your car for six months - bad news if it's not your car or you've lent it to your kids. I've learned from the success of Jack Straw... you can't outflank me on the law and order front, so I will introduce sharia law in the bus lane. Drive in the bus lane and we cut off your arms. I'm stumped about what to do for a third offence, but we'll come up with something."

A man with a white beard and intense eyes says when he read that Livingstone had suggested he would like to chuck the World Trade Organisation in vast stocks if it visited London, he almost withdrew his support. "Can you undertake not to make jokes and to keep your answers to matters about London?" he asks.

"I think it would be sad if the mayor couldn't make a joke... I've got a very good one about Salman Rushdie and Yasser Arafat."

"Do you remember Adlai Stevenson [the Democrat candidate who stood against John F Kennedy in 1960]?" asks the man with the intense eyes.

"Did you say Adlai Stevenson? Now he's sadly lost, but by God, he was a decent man wasn't he?"

"Yes, but he lost. Because he made jokes."

To be fair, the World Trade Organisation was a one-off. His jokes usually illustrate a political point. A couple of minutes later he cracks one about the time when the Tories were tempting council house buyers with any number of perks - the best scheme was buy two council houses, get one free. The man with the intense eyes is doubled in laughter.

Another question: "You're honest, you're inclusive, you follow most policies, so why isn't Tony Blair your friend?" It's a common thread from Livingstone supporters desperate for him to win but equally anxious to know there will not be a fallout that could cost Labour a second term.

Livingstone responds as he has done for years: when he and Blair meet in private they get on fine. He says he thinks Blair has been advised badly, that he should have never treated him like the Tory opposition. Yes, says the questioner, but how can we be sure you will be prepared to meet Blair half way - that you can work together?

Livingstone is not prepared to joke about this. One criticism that seems to be sticking from the Millbank campaign is that he is not a team player. The strange thing is that he has always prided himself on his pragmatism, his ability to compromise, to make deals, to please and displease people on both sides. He asks how he could have possibly held the Greater London Council together for five years with a majority of four if he couldn't work with people.

"Everybody has fond memories of the GLC as some great shining apex of socialism. All I remember is being denounced by leftwingers for not being leftwing enough. And I just know that this is going to happen. They'll be denouncing me within six months because you have to build a compromise and consensus. I have this sneaking thought that in about 18 months' time Tony Blair will be sitting round the fire at Number 10 with a nice brandy saying, why did we get into a tizzy over all that? He's not been at all unreasonable."

Livingstone says that while the Labour spin doctors recount the GLC's reign of terror, the people of London remember it differently. "The idea that they can tell people that their memory is wrong is bizarre. The reason I'm ahead in the polls is not my rugged good looks but because, on balance, people think I deserve another go. What people remember is that in the awful, long, dark night of Thatcher tyranny we were a little lamp shining in the gloom." The government, he says, seems to have forgotten that Livingstone had a reason for being oppositional in the GLC days - he was in opposition. The crowd applaud and tell him they remember a city that had an identity, a city in which it became possible to travel cheaply and efficiently.

What if he loses? He says both Jackson and Dobson would make fine mayors. While all around him have mewled and bawled, Livingstone has been positively presidential in this campaign. Occasionally, he allows his resentment to get the better of him. "If I lose I'm going to go out and work even harder for Glenda or Frank than if I was the candidate, just so I can tell those who doubted my loyalty to go and stick it."

John Madziva, a young Labourite, tells me why he is going to vote for Livingstone. Or rather, why he is not voting for Dobson. "The party has become dictatorial. Patronising. It refuses to be open to debate. Look at how we lost our majority in Wales by imposing an unpopular candidate."

Simon Gent has been sitting by my side throughout the meeting. Will he be voting for Livingstone? "Yes. I did think Dobson was a credible candidate at first." As we talk he begins to sweat. He seems uneasy. "It's been such a negative campaign." He pauses, embarrassed. "Actually, I was campaigning for Frank until recently, but I couldn't stand it. There's been so much double-talk, hypocrisy." He sounds like a member of Dobsons Anonymous. "Yes," he says parodying himself. "I did it once and never again. I've been off the Dobson for a month now."

What does he like about Livingstone? "I talked to him a bit ago, and he impressed me. I come from Mitcham, and he said as a kid he went down there to see his cousin and they went newt hunting. It gave me a warm feeling. I suppose it's just a gut thing."

The car to Newsnight, 9.30pm

Half an hour to get to the BBC. With Livingstone's proposed 20mph speed limit in built-up areas we'd be struggling. He's on the phone telling a friend the meeting went well. What pleases him most is that the audience challenged him. "They wanted reassurance I could work with Blair."

What has hurt him most about the campaign? For once, there's not a hint of a smile. "One former colleague who has been scathing in public assures me he doesn't believe a word of it. And there's one New Labour MP who has circulated the 'I'm backing Dobbo' letter, and he said to me he was so disgusted with what was being done he hoped I'd leave the party and take them on as an independent and defeat them to teach them a lesson. I said, but you circulated the Dobbo letter, and he said, 'Yeah, but I've got to look out for my future.'"

Livingstone's researcher Mark phones up a fellow campaigner who has been at the Brown-Blair meeting in town. He hears that when the cabinet colleagues attacked Livingstone they were drowned out by boos. Mark relays to Livingstone that Blair then changed his tack and said of course he would work with him if he had to.

Livingstone is delighted, but he reins himself in. "Why aren't you using your earpiece Mark? You're on the bloody phone so bloody much. You really must use the earpiece."

Livingstone asks the BBC driver if he'll turn the radio on. All we can hear is the hissing of the audience from the Blair-Brown meeting as we head for the studios.

Livingstone has only received the sketchiest outline of the meeting, but he talks about it with outrageous conviction. The Newsnight backdrop is a "New Labour New Problems" logo. Jeremy Paxman asks him what it's like to have the two most powerful people in the government meeting simply to rubbish you. "Oh, this was much less rough than the other times," he says. "It was positively friendly."

Paxman's eyebrow lurches towards the heavens. "What? They're close to endorsing you, are they? They say you're manifestly unfit to be mayor of London." Livingstone deadpans.

The rest of the debate with three other Labourites is curiously muted. On the way out Mark and I say it was a bit dull. "Well, that's because the three others can sense things are changing, that we're moving towards a deal."

So he really thinks the Labour party are on the verge of endorsing him? "Stop taking the tablets," he says. "They're clouding your judgment."

Young Labour meeting, Westminster Council House, Saturday 3.10pm

Of the three candidates, only Jackson has arrived so far. The meeting was due to start at 3pm. Livingstone runs in, breathless, apologetic, tangled in his mobile phone. Bloody tubes. "I'm just going to be ravaged by the youth." Twenty minutes later Dobson arrives. Over the past few months he has developed a knack of saying the wrong thing at the wrong time. He explains why he is late: his taxi got caught up in a demo and then broke down and he had to change cabs.

"He's the only one who's not come on public transport," whispers a young Labourite.

Young Labour should be Blair's second constituency - Dobson territory. I ask Melissa Mean, who has helped organise the meeting, whether she can find me a Dobson supporter to interview. "Erm. Try asking Frank. On second thoughts, I'm not sure he'll be voting for himself." Councillor Murad Qureshi, an unfeasibly young 35-year-old, tells me that the Labour leader was asked to join the "We support Dobbo" picture of council leaders, but he refused. "You know, this election has made me a bit cynical about politics," he says.

There is little to divide the candidates on policy. Livingstone wants bus conductors back, Dobson doesn't. Both Dobson and Jackson support public-private partnership for tube expansion, while Livingstone is in favour of a bond scheme. That's about it.

There is a difference in presentation, though. Dobson seems more old Labour than either Livingstone or Jackson. It's not simply the beard and body, it's his language - he often talks about socialism for one thing. Ironically, while Millbank has spun this as a contest between old Labour (Livingstone) and New Labour (Dobson), Livingstone has always thought of himself as a moderniser - he says he didn't only embrace Sinn Fein and anti-racist policies before the rest of them, he also embraced the tools of marketing.

The reality is that this is a fight between No Questions Asked Labour and the independent minded - not simply on the podium, but in the constituencies as well. Melissa Mean says it's a significant election - for so long, people have been brainwashed into believing that the only way to keep power is to keep schtum if you disagree. Now things are changing.

The tube back home

It's freezing. "When I'm mayor, I'm going to make sure the sun always shines, even at night," says Livingstone. We're accompanied by a photographer, and I wish he could have caught us the other day, when Livingstone was holding the Evening Standard aloft. Without being asked, he produces that day's Independent, with its "Livingstone's massive lead" headline, and smiles into the camera.

We hear a cry from a group of boys going the opposite way. "Ken Livingstone, move to the right please." As polite a heckle as you could wish for.

He never did give me a decent answer on what he's learned over the past 20 years. Is that because he didn't think he had anything significant to learn? "No. We tried too much change too quickly. In the first three months we launched everything. Before we got on to the more difficult and controversial areas, such as race and sexual orientation, we should have cut the fares first, so people could see we were doing something for everybody. My biggest failure was not to realise earlier that the centrally planned economy didn't work."

I have never been on a tube with so much laughter, so many smiles. "Is something amusing you?" Livingstone asks a stranger as the photographer snaps away. The woman sitting next to him moves away when she notices the camera. "You're not the lady who refused to smile at the prime minister, are you?" he asks.

The curious thing is that Livingstone is not a particularly warm person. When we meet he is quite impersonal; there is no small talk. But Livingstone is an incredibly warm politician. It almost feels like a form of hypocrisy, but it isn't. He is effortless with people - he genuinely doesn't seem to make an effort, doesn't seem to give two hoots whether we talk to him or like him; he doesn't play the politician.

Perhaps this is the real reason Blair fears him. The prime minister has surrounded himself with competent and colourless politicians. He likes to feel he is the populist, the one who can chat to Joe Public, the one who can make people smile even though the script will have been revised a dozen times. But Livingstone is a genuine populist. As we sit in the laughing tube, I can't help thinking of that picture of Blair standing in a virtually empty carriage beseeching the young woman studiously ignoring him for one little common or garden smile.

I've learned from the success of Jack Straw... you can't outflank me on the law and order front, so I will introduce sharia law in the bus lane. Drive in the bus lane and we cut off your arms. I'm stumped about what to do for a third offence, but we'll come up with something." A man with a white beard and intense eyes says when he read that Livingstone had suggested he would like to chuck the World Trade Organisation in vast stocks if it visited London, he almost withdrew his support. "Can you undertake not to make jokes and to keep your answers to matters about London?" he asks. "I think it would be sad if the mayor couldn't make a joke... I've got a very good one about Salman Rushdie and Yasser Arafat." "Do you remember Adlai Stevenson [the Democrat candidate who stood against John F Kennedy in 1960]?" asks the man with the intense eyes. "Did you say Adlai Stevenson? Now he's sadly lost, but by God, he was a decent man wasn't he?" "Yes, but he lost. Because he made jokes." To be fair, the World Trade Organisation was a one-off. His jokes usually illustrate a political point. A couple of minutes later he cracks one about the time when the Tories were tempting council house buyers with any number of perks - the best scheme was buy two council houses, get one free. The man with the intense eyes is doubled in laughter. Another question: "You're honest, you're inclusive, you follow most policies, so why isn't Tony Blair your friend?" It's a common thread from Livingstone supporters desperate for him to win but equally anxious to know there will not be a fallout that could cost Labour a second term. Livingstone responds as he has done for years: when he and Blair meet in private they get on fine. He says he thinks Blair has been advised badly, that he should have never treated him like the Tory opposition. Yes, says the questioner, but how can we be sure you will be prepared to meet Blair half way - that you can work together? Livingstone is not prepared to joke about this. One criticism that seems to be sticking from the Millbank campaign is that he is not a team player. The strange thing is that he has always prided himself on his pragmatism, his ability to compromise, to make deals, to please and displease people on both sides. He asks how he could have possibly held the Greater London Council together for five years with a majority of four if he couldn't work with people. "Everybody has fond memories of the GLC as some great shining apex of socialism. All I remember is being denounced by leftwingers for not being leftwing enough. And I just know that this is going to happen. They'll be denouncing me within six months because you have to build a compromise and consensus. I have this sneaking thought that in about 18 months' time Tony Blair will be sitting round the fire at Number 10 with a nice brandy saying, why did we get into a tizzy over all that? He's not been at all unreasonable." Livingstone says that while the Labour spin doctors recount the GLC's reign of terror, the people of London remember it differently. "The idea that they can tell people that their memory is wrong is bizarre. The reason I'm ahead in the polls is not my rugged good looks but because, on balance, people think I deserve another go. What people remember is that in the awful, long, dark night of Thatcher tyranny we were a little lamp shining in the gloom." The government, he says, seems to have forgotten that Livingstone had a reason for being oppositional in the GLC days - he was in opposition. The crowd applaud and tell him they remember a city that had an identity, a city in which it became possible to travel cheaply and efficiently. What if he loses? He says both Jackson and Dobson would make fine mayors. While all around him have mewled and bawled, Livingstone has been positively presidential in this campaign. Occasionally, he allows his resentment to get the better of him. "If I lose I'm going to go out and work even harder for Glenda or Frank than if I was the candidate, just so I can tell those who doubted my loyalty to go and stick it." John Madziva, a young Labourite, tells me why he is going to vote for Livingstone. Or rather, why he is not voting for Dobson. "The party has become dictatorial. Patronising. It refuses to be open to debate. Look at how we lost our majority in Wales by imposing an unpopular candidate." Simon Gent has been sitting by my side throughout the meeting. Will he be voting for Livingstone? "Yes. I did think Dobson was a credible candidate at first." As we talk he begins to sweat. He seems uneasy. "It's been such a negative campaign." He pauses, embarrassed. "Actually, I was campaigning for Frank until recently, but I couldn't stand it. There's been so much double-talk, hypocrisy." He sounds like a member of Dobsons Anonymous. "Yes," he says parodying himself. "I did it once and never again. I've been off the Dobson for a month now." What does he like about Livingstone? "I talked to him a bit ago, and he impressed me. I come from Mitcham, and he said as a kid he went down there to see his cousin and they went newt hunting. It gave me a warm feeling. I suppose it's just a gut thing." The car to Newsnight, 9.30pm Half an hour to get to the BBC. With Livingstone's proposed 20mph speed limit in built-up areas we'd be struggling. He's on the phone telling a friend the meeting went well. What pleases him most is that the audience challenged him. "They wanted reassurance I could work with Blair." What has hurt him most about the campaign? For once, there's not a hint of a smile. "One former colleague who has been scathing in public assures me he doesn't believe a word of it. And there's one New Labour MP who has circulated the 'I'm backing Dobbo' letter, and he said to me he was so disgusted with what was being done he hoped I'd leave the party and take them on as an independent and defeat them to teach them a lesson. I said, but you circulated the Dobbo letter, and he said, 'Yeah, but I've got to look out for my future.'" Livingstone's researcher Mark phones up a fellow campaigner who has been at the Brown-Blair meeting in town. He hears that when the cabinet colleagues attacked Livingstone they were drowned out by boos. Mark relays to Livingstone that Blair then changed his tack and said of course he would work with him if he had to. Livingstone is delighted, but he reins himself in. "Why aren't you using your earpiece Mark? You're on the bloody phone so bloody much. You really must use the earpiece." Livingstone asks the BBC driver if he'll turn the radio on. All we can hear is the hissing of the audience from the Blair-Brown meeting as we head for the studios. Livingstone has only received the sketchiest outline of the meeting, but he talks about it with outrageous conviction. The Newsnight backdrop is a "New Labour New Problems" logo. Jeremy Paxman asks him what it's like to have the two most powerful people in the government meeting simply to rubbish you. "Oh, this was much less rough than the other times," he says. "It was positively friendly." Paxman's eyebrow lurches towards the heavens. "What? They're close to endorsing you, are they? They say you're manifestly unfit to be mayor of London." Livingstone deadpans. The rest of the debate with three other Labourites is curiously muted. On the way out Mark and I say it was a bit dull. "Well, that's because the three others can sense things are changing, that we're moving towards a deal." So he really thinks the Labour party are on the verge of endorsing him? "Stop taking the tablets," he says. "They're clouding your judgment." Young Labour meeting, Westminster Council House, Saturday 3.10pm Of the three candidates, only Jackson has arrived so far. The meeting was due to start at 3pm. Livingstone runs in, breathless, apologetic, tangled in his mobile phone. Bloody tubes. "I'm just going to be ravaged by the youth." Twenty minutes later Dobson arrives. Over the past few months he has developed a knack of saying the wrong thing at the wrong time. He explains why he is late: his taxi got caught up in a demo and then broke down and he had to change cabs. "He's the only one who's not come on public transport," whispers a young Labourite. Young Labour should be Blair's second constituency - Dobson territory. I ask Melissa Mean, who has helped organise the meeting, whether she can find me a Dobson supporter to interview. "Erm. Try asking Frank. On second thoughts, I'm not sure he'll be voting for himself." Councillor Murad Qureshi, an unfeasibly young 35-year-old, tells me that the Labour leader was asked to join the "We support Dobbo" picture of council leaders, but he refused. "You know, this election has made me a bit cynical about politics," he says. There is little to divide the candidates on policy. Livingstone wants bus conductors back, Dobson doesn't. Both Dobson and Jackson support public-private partnership for tube expansion, while Livingstone is in favour of a bond scheme. That's about it. There is a difference in presentation, though. Dobson seems more old Labour than either Livingstone or Jackson. It's not simply the beard and body, it's his language - he often talks about socialism for one thing. Ironically, while Millbank has spun this as a contest between old Labour (Livingstone) and New Labour (Dobson), Livingstone has always thought of himself as a moderniser - he says he didn't only embrace Sinn Fein and anti-racist policies before the rest of them, he also embraced the tools of marketing. The reality is that this is a fight between No Questions Asked Labour and the independent minded - not simply on the podium, but in the constituencies as well. Melissa Mean says it's a significant election - for so long, people have been brainwashed into believing that the only way to keep power is to keep schtum if you disagree. Now things are changing. The tube back home It's freezing. "When I'm mayor, I'm going to make sure the sun always shines, even at night," says Livingstone. We're accompanied by a photographer, and I wish he could have caught us the other day, when Livingstone was holding the Evening Standard aloft. Without being asked, he produces that day's Independent, with its "Livingstone's massive lead" headline, and smiles into the camera. We hear a cry from a group of boys going the opposite way. "Ken Livingstone, move to the right please." As polite a heckle as you could wish for. He never did give me a decent answer on what he's learned over the past 20 years. Is that because he didn't think he had anything significant to learn? "No. We tried too much change too quickly. In the first three months we launched everything. Before we got on to the more difficult and controversial areas, such as race and sexual orientation, we should have cut the fares first, so people could see we were doing something for everybody. My biggest failure was not to realise earlier that the centrally planned economy didn't work." I have never been on a tube with so much laughter, so many smiles. "Is something amusing you?" Livingstone asks a stranger as the photographer snaps away. The woman sitting next to him moves away when she notices the camera. "You're not the lady who refused to smile at the prime minister, are you?" he asks. The curious thing is that Livingstone is not a particularly warm person. When we meet he is quite impersonal; there is no small talk. But Livingstone is an incredibly warm politician. It almost feels like a form of hypocrisy, but it isn't. He is effortless with people - he genuinely doesn't seem to make an effort, doesn't seem to give two hoots whether we talk to him or like him; he doesn't play the politician. Perhaps this is the real reason Blair fears him. The prime minister has surrounded himself with competent and colourless politicians. He likes to feel he is the populist, the one who can chat to Joe Public, the one who can make people smile even though the script will have been revised a dozen times. But Livingstone is a genuine populist. As we sit in the laughing tube, I can't help thinking of that picture of Blair standing in a virtually empty carriage beseeching the young woman studiously ignoring him for one little common or garden smile.

fields.headline: Shadowlands
fields.standfirst: A Country Diary
fields.trailText: Wenlock Edge
fields.body:
Wenlock Edge

On the night of the lunar eclipse, the hours were small but everything else was huge. A vast, deep sky, whirling with stars, was crystal clear. The moonlight had soaked into the long horizons of this landscape. When the eclipse took hold, everywhere was quiet, except for the owls, a cockerel and water trickling under the hedge.

Since the first photographs from space were taken, we are used to seeing the Earth as a beautiful thing, but its shadow tells us something else. In Macbeth, the witch's cauldron contained ". . . slips of yew Silver'd in the Moon's eclipse", but in this shade the yew would be bloodied.

Cast across the face of the moon, the Earth's shadow looked bloody, bruised; a congealing scab.

The rational explanation for the reddish colour may be that it has something to do with volcanic ash in the atmosphere or other stuff floating about up there but, as often happens in natural phenomena, the explanation and the experience belong to two separate worlds. The Earth's shadow had a weird, neurotic effect on the moonlight - it became fraught with fears and anxieties, holding a wounded expression of pain.

The eclipse held until a bright silver blade cut through the shadow and just as it was about to lift, low cloud slipped over the sky; and before long the Edge was lost in thick fog.

The following night the sky was clear as a bell and the moonlight even brighter. Like a summer's night, the landscape was illuminated in a soft lunar glow, and bloodless.

The morning after, I saw the colours of the eclipse again. Walking the path which runs above the hanging woods along the Edge, the wind roaring through the trees, I watched a fox run from the wood and spin quickly into a hole.

In just a glimpse this was a re-enactment of the lunar eclipse: the muddy red of the fox's pelt - the bleeding Earth-shadow; the silver white tip of its tail vanishing into the darkness - the moonlight swallowed by night; gone to earth.

webTitle: Now Kingston needs a good deal

fields.headline: Now Kingston needs a good deal
fields.trailText: The Labour government's first privatisation has performed very nicely, thank you. Proceeds from the partial sale of Hull telecommunications firm Kingston Communications are funding a new community sports stadium to house Hull City FC sharing with Kingston Rovers, and created a pile of cash to upgrade housing and schools.
fields.body:
The Labour government's first privatisation has performed very nicely, thank you. Proceeds from the partial sale of Hull telecommunications firm Kingston Communications are funding a new community sports stadium to house Hull City FC sharing with Kingston Rovers, and created a pile of cash to upgrade housing and schools.

The pricing of the offer last July was coloured by political concerns. Hull city council was treading a delicate line of gaining a windfall for the city without attracting too much disquiet from Westminster.

The consequence is that the army of private investors who bought into the flotation have found little to complain of and the council is in the vaguely embarrassing posi tion of sitting on a stake worth almost £1.3bn which it is now free to cash in.

From the offer price of 225p, the shares reached a high of 880p this week, though concerns over the growth of the business caused the price to fall back to 800p yesterday after a 16% rise the previous day.

Kingston reported group EBITDA (earnings before interest tax depreciation and amortisation) falling from £25.4m to £21.2m for the first nine months of the year. Its Torch subsidiary, which serves business customers and has driven the growth of the company, enjoyed a 72% increase in sales in its core Yorkshire region over the nine months while EBITDA almost doubled. The chief cause for concern was a 22% fall in revenues during the third quarter at Torch.

"The numbers are not appalling but the only way to justify these valuations is by high growth, and they are just not hitting it," noted one analyst.

Chief executive Steve Maine said the figures stemmed from a decision to turn away low margin but high turnover traffic. EBITDA for Torch had doubled in the third quarter and orders would translate into a strong performance. The company is also planning to launch a mobile phone operation with an existing network.

Insiders said Kingston had been planning to issue new shares for a significant acquisition though the deal fell through. It is hard to escape the sense that Kingston needs a deal or will become part of another organisation.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Express Dairies cuts 460 jobs
fields.body:
Express Dairies cuts 460 jobs

Express Dairies is to axe 460 jobs at dairies and distribution centres following its takeover of milk business Glanbia UK last year, the firm announced yesterday.

The company is to close the Perry-Barr dairy in Birmingham, which it acquired as part of its takeover. It also plans to close its Soho Street depot in Birmingham, which supplies small shops and business. Its distribution business in Salisbury will close. Express said 90 jobs would be created as work was moved to other sites.

Gent claims majority

Vodafone-AirTouch chief executive Chris Gent yesterday claimed that a "shadow book" detailing how investors would vote in the hostile takeover bid for Germany's Mannesmann spelt victory for the British firm.

Mr Gent said the records compiled by advisers Goldman Sachs and Warburg Dillon Read indicated that the company would win a majority when the offer ends on February 7.

"They indicate to us that we have a majority, we are definitely ahead, with more than 50 percent. But we are not complacent," he said.

Norwich's 50% leap

Norwich Union beat its rivals yesterday by reporting a 50% jump in new life and pensions business in 1999, double that reported by most of its competitors.

The group, which demutalised two years ago, is yet to report its profits for the year, which will be scrutinised for evidence that the business has grown at the expense of margin.

Its shares defied yesterday's downward trend, ending at 397p.

M&S investors change plan

All investors in Marks & Spencer Financial Services' (M&SFS) personal pension plan were transferred into its new stakeholder type pension yesterday, a move which cut their annual charge from 0.75% to 0.7%.

The new stakeholder-friendly personal pension plan will take monthly premiums starting from £10, carries no initial charge, no transfer fee and no monthly policy fee. This final change will save customers £144 a year on the old product. M&SFS claims the pension is the cheapest of its kind. Chartwell Investment Management launched a similar product this month with an annual fee of 0.65%, but with an initial charge of up to £99.

130 Filofax redundancies

Filofax, the personal organisers maker, yesterday announced a shake-up that will result in about 130 redundancies. The group is closing two manufacturing plants at Burgess Hill and Littlehampton in West Sussex by the end of June.

Racal chair retires

Racal Electronics said Sir Ernest Harrison, chairman and chief executive, is to retire at the end of this month. He will be succeeded by Colin Chandler, who will assume the role of chairman until the completion of the proposed acquisition of Racal by Thomson-CSF.

webTitle: Inflation rise follows year of living cheaply

fields.headline: Inflation rise follows year of living cheaply
fields.trailText: Inflation dropped to its lowest level for 30 years in 1999 despite a booming economy. Official figures published yesterday showed mortgage rate increases following November's base rate rise forced the annual inflation rate up to 1.8% in December from the previous month's 1.4%.
fields.body:
Inflation dropped to its lowest level for 30 years in 1999 despite a booming economy. Official figures published yesterday showed mortgage rate increases following November's base rate rise forced the annual inflation rate up to 1.8% in December from the previous month's 1.4%.

That left the average for 1999 at 1.5%, the lowest since 1960, said the office for national statistics. The government's preferred inflation measure, which strips out mortgage rates, stood at 2.2% last month, the same as in November. The annual average was 2.3%.

The Bank of England is required by the treasury to limit underlying inflation to 2.5%. Since it has been below target for nine months in a row, some City economists are questioning the assumption that interest rates will need to rise from 5.75%.

"We have a housing boom, oil prices up 17% and tobacco up 10% but inflation is still below target. That is quite some thing," said Darren Winder, analyst for Warburg Dillon Read.

On the European Union measure of prices, excluding housing, UK inflation fell to 1.2% last month from 1.3% - joint lowest with Sweden.

British Chambers of Commerce said yesterday there were already signs that the economy was slowing in response to higher interest rates. Business growth has levelled off, and export orders remained fragile in the last quarter.

fields.headline: 'Wonder drug' setback for British Bio
fields.trailText: Shares in British Biotech fell 42% yesterday after management admitted its key compound, Marimastat, considered a potential "miracle cure", might not make it to market.
fields.body:
Shares in British Biotech fell 42% yesterday after management admitted its key compound, Marimastat, considered a potential "miracle cure", might not make it to market.

This is the latest setback for a past flagship of the emerging British biotech sector which began to fall from grace 18 months ago amid allegations of overhyping its products.

It increases the chances that the company could be taken over at a time when there has been speculation of a tie-up with rival Biocompatibles.

British Biotech management disclosed yesterday that third-stage trials on advanced sufferers of pancreatic cancer with Marimastat had been "disappointing".

This is the third set of adverse clinical trial results in less than 12 months compounding the failure of its Zacutex treatment for pancreatitis.

British Biotech officials insisted that seven more phase-three trials would be completed on Marimastat and these continue to offer hope of finding a successful treatment for sufferers in less advanced stages of cancer.

But Tony Weir, the company's finance director, admitted: "Two years ago Marimastat was hailed as a messiah, but that's been proved not to be the case. It is certainly a possibility, but not a certainty, that Marimastat won't make it to market."

The plummeting share price - it ended the day down 19p at 28p - underlined the depth of disillusion among many investors about the future prospects of the company.

One analyst said: "There is pretty much nothing in the British Biotech locker without Zacutex and now Marimastat. The only other cancer potential products are three years away from the market."

Others were less pessimistic, pointing out that the British Biotech price had only ended the day much where it began before Christmas.

webTitle: NTL's stake in Villa opens way to bid for live football

fields.headline: NTL's stake in Villa opens way to bid for live football
fields.trailText: NTL has underlined its determination to challenge BSkyB's grasp on British football by confirming its intention to bid for the next contract to broadcast live Premier League matches and making its second major investment in a leading club.
fields.body:
NTL has underlined its determination to challenge BSkyB's grasp on British football by confirming its intention to bid for the next contract to broadcast live Premier League matches and making its second major investment in a leading club.

Geoffrey Hamilton-Fairley, managing director of NTL subsidiary Premium TV, speaking yesterday after announcing a £26m investment in Aston Villa, said: "We don't yet know how the Premier League rights will be packaged but we would certainly expect to bid for some or all of the packages deployed.

"We hope the rules of engagement will be clearly laid out soon. It is possible, but unlikely, that we will partner other broadcasters when making any other bid."

NTL is understood to have held talks with other Premier League clubs, plus Scotland's Rangers and Celtic, about taking further equity positions in leading clubs.

"It is no secret that a lot of the clubs have asked a number of us [media companies] to present to them," Mr Hamilon-Fairley said. "We all have different approaches and any choosing to take up our offering would be most welcome."

The Premier League is expected to publish a draft tender document for its next rights contract by the end of next month. BSkyB currently has a £670m four-year exclu sive contract to broadcast live Premier League matches which expires in 2001.

Under the terms of the Aston Villa deal, NTL is making the club an interest free loan of £26m to act as its exclusive agent for the sale of media sponsorship, advertising and publishing rights across all media platforms.

NTL will also replace LDV as the club's shirt sponsor from the start of next season. The loan is repayable after five years when NTL is expected to be issued with new shares representing a 9.9% stake.

After stripping out sponsorship costs and agency rights, insiders say the deal values the Birmingham-based club at around £170m. Shares finished unchanged at 500p.

webTitle: Chief executive ousted in Forward takeover battle

fields.headline: Chief executive ousted in Forward takeover battle
fields.trailText: The long-running battle for control of engineering group Forward Technology took another twist yesterday as victorious US bidder Crest relieved chief executive Ken Cobley of his executive duties and called a special shareholders meeting to throw him off the board on Tuesday.
fields.body:
The long-running battle for control of engineering group Forward Technology took another twist yesterday as victorious US bidder Crest relieved chief executive Ken Cobley of his executive duties and called a special shareholders meeting to throw him off the board on Tuesday.

Three non-executive directors at Forward - Brian Chilver, Gordon Allen and James Everitt - resigned last week when Crest declared its £17.7m takeover unconditonal having gained just over 50% acceptances.

But Mr Cobley is thought to have refused to go. Neither he nor his lawyer was available for comment and it remained unclear if he intended to take legal action.

A spokesman for investment bank CCF Charterhouse, which advised Crest, said: "There were fairly hostile relations right to the end so we took the precaution of convening an extraordinary general meeting to oust directors if they chose not to resign."

Crest launched a hostile bid for Forward last October, rivalling a proposed management buyout which was later backed by conglomerate Black & Decker.

A game of oneupmanship ensued as both sides raised their offers several times. Crest's final cash offer of 50p to shareholders of Forward in December was the final blow to Black & Decker's competing 47p bid.

Forward's independent directors eventually recommended the offer to shareholders.

Crest learned during its bid that Forward had insufficient cash resources to meet some debts it had incurred in fighting off the Americans and the British company had to ask Crest to cover the shortfall until the offer became unconditional.

Forward makes machinery that welds together plastic parts, while Crest manufactures equipment for cleaning.

Forward shares were steady at 48p yesterday with the offer open until July 18.
