fields.headline: A&L faces tribunal over sacking
fields.trailText: A dispute between Peter White, the former chief executive of Alliance & Leicester, and his employer for 18 years moved closer to the public arena yesterday after A&L refused to give ground to his grievances.
fields.body:
A dispute between Peter White, the former chief executive of Alliance & Leicester, and his employer for 18 years moved closer to the public arena yesterday after A&L refused to give ground to his grievances.

Mr White, who could not be reached for comment yesterday, was sacked from A&L's board in October when the bank said it was seeking a more "consensual style of leadership".

His sudden removal led to his highly unusual move to put in a claim for unfair dismissal and A&L had until yesterday to respond.

A&L said it had submitted a "full and detailed" response to Mr White's claim which seems likely to be pursued at an industrial tribunal.

"The submission outlines the reasons for the board's decision last October to terminate Mr White's employment. We are fully prepared to defend the board's action at a tribunal," the bank said.

A spokesman refused to disclose any further information or the detail of the submission.

The bank has yet to replace Mr White and is continuing its search through headhunters Spencer Stuart. John Windeler, formerly the non-executive chairman, is now filling the chief executive's chair too.

It is unclear how far Mr White is prepared to pursue his claim and whether the two sides will eventually settle out of court. Neither Mr White nor the bank has revealed much detail of the events which led to his surprise departure.

The bank said in October that he was leaving following "a divergence of views with the board over the management of the group".

However, it has since been claimed that Mr White was jettisoned after the A&L held merger talks with its closest rival, the Woolwich, without including him.

The suggestions have never been been confirmed.

Industry sources also believe that he was blamed for the breakdown in the bank's takeover talks with Bank of Ireland last year.

webTitle: There were these two men pushing wheelbarrows...

fields.headline: There were these two men pushing wheelbarrows...
fields.standfirst: Peter Brook is one of the world's most influential directors, but he has never cared for political theatre. So why is he staging a play about apartheid? He talks to  Brian Logan
fields.trailText: Peter Brook is one of the world's most influential directors, but he has never cared for political theatre. So why is he staging a play about apartheid? He talks to Brian Logan
fields.body:
Peter Brook's influence on modern theatre is so pervasive that, when he says a production influenced him, you can't help but take notice. The renowned director - whose 1970 Midsummer Night's Dream is considered a milestone in theatre history, and whose book The Empty Space is a bible for many young directors - was certainly affected by the 1973 production of The Island. South African writer Athol Fugard's play describes life on Robben Island, Nelson Mandela's long-time prison. Brook's rapt account of its opening moments is practically a work of theatre itself.

"Not a word spoken, nothing on the stage, for 40 minutes - just two men with imaginary wheelbarrows, in an imaginary space." The two men were Winston Ntshona and John Kani, co-creators of the piece with Fugard. "Gradually," Brook continues, cobalt blue eyes gleaming, "the audience went through a whole cycle. First amazement, then the beginnings of irritation - 'We're an audience, we've come for something, what's going on here?' - then impatience. And then suddenly the whole audience was transformed by a deep feeling of shame for having dared to think to themselves, 'Come on, get on with it.' Because we were not only witnessing actors showing something about people who at that moment were living that life on Robben Island; they were living it themselves."

We're in the front room of Brook's London flat. He's speaking in a holy whisper and the ever-so-delicate return of teacup to saucer seems suddenly cacophonous. "When one saw the reality of their sweat," he goes on, "the reality of the weight of the imaginary objects they were lifting, the audience dropped any expectation of the play 'starting'. They realised this was the play, and waited, with respect and absolute involvement, for whatever was coming next."

What came next Brook has never forgotten, which partly explains why this fiercely independent director has lent his expertise to - and is "proud to be associated with" - a revival of that same production. Last year he invited Ntshona and Kani, now in their fifties, to perform the play at his Parisian space, the Bouffes du Nord. Now he has coaxed that Market Theatre of Johannesburg production back to life for its final run, opening this week at the National Theatre in London. He remains excited by it. "What is extraordinary to this day," he enthuses, in his meticulous, thoughtful way, "is that you can see that the performers are not playing for themselves. They really are the spokesmen for their nation, and that is the ancient idea of what any artist and any poet is." In 1995 the duo performed The Island for President Mandela.

The circumstances in which Kani and Ntshona return are a far cry from 1973. Back then, the illegal production fled South Africa and Kani - now the artistic director of the Market Theatre - had to present himself as Fugard's gardener to gain entry to the UK. In theatre terms, too, that world was a world apart. In those days, says Brook, "all experimental groups - including my own - were struggling to free theatre of the old complexes by which all that mattered was the text. I know it's almost unimaginable today, but the body" - he pronounces the word with infinite care - "was ignored.

"Then suddenly into the Royal Court came two actors who had reached the end of this process, not through artistic study, but through suffering and social conditions. For them, communicating an experience could only happen through the total involvement of the body." Brook attributes this to the repressive South African Pass Act, which "by dividing up the people into townships that were controlled and circled by the police, made instant and vivid communication very necessary and important" - because it could be violently interrupted at any moment.

The London audience was stunned by this physical expressiveness. "Here was what, in a way, mime was meant to be: the silent speech of the body - taken to such a point that the audience was forced to recognise that this was stronger than a documentary film." Brook is famously uncomfortable with "political theatre", but South African politics were a humanitarian issue. The Island was at the same time political and essentially human - its "other miracle", says Brook. "Political theatre, when it was about serious themes, tended for that reason to be dramatic. Here you found that people who were right at the source, who had lived this and whose families had lived this, could portray the situation with humour.

"These two men had a powerful way of living without meanness. Anger was there, but it wasn't a mean anger; bitterness was there, but it wasn't a bitterness that took away from the joy of living. The play did an enormous service for South Africa, which was to make the suffering South African not an object of white liberal compassion, but a rich human being to be respected and admired."

Of course, white liberal compassion has long since moved on from South Africa, and so I ask of this revival the question Brook himself demands in The Empty Space we ask of theatre: what for? Brook described in the book how, in his own anti-Vietnam production US, "the liveliness of the actors waned as the immediacy of the relation to their theme lessened". Today, he admits that Ntshona's and Kani's - and the audience's - relation to imprisonment and apartheid has changed: hence the revival.

Since its debut The Island has taken on an internationalist resonance - one Paris performance reportedly left two Kosovan refugees in the audience distraught. On a more practical level, its exhausting opening sequence "is even more moving", says Brook, "with older men committing themselves to the effort. But while it's tragic to see young people's lives ruined by being imprisoned for life, it's as tragic in a different way to see elderly men humiliated and forced to work in this way. So something has been transformed; something has been gained and has matured."

Perhaps Brook intuits a personal parallel between the characters' Sisyphean toil and his own quest, continuing into his 76th year, for the theatrical holy grail. Certainly, it's easy to see why The Island caught his imagination. It deals with theatre: its characters prepare to perform Antigone at a prison concert. Fugard, Ntshona and Kani devised the play-within-a-play motif after a colleague, due to perform in a production of Sophocles's play, was arrested and imprisoned on Robben Island. The effect is that "this realistic play takes on a mythical stature, it becomes an epic play" - classic Brook territory. "Suddenly you identify the actor with the woman he is playing, who is prepared to die rather than yield one bit of her conviction." It's a startling parallel, by which Brook, whose life has been dedicated to exploring theatre as a self-expressive ritual, remains forcibly struck.

But if one aspect of this remarkable production reflects Brook's passions, it's the heroism behind its creation. It accords with his belief that "you have to be prepared to fight for what you want.

"You have to sense what the pressures are and choose," he adds. "Either you go along with those pressures or you find all the possible ways of making a space for yourself." Making a space for himself - in Paris - and finding empty spaces to call theatres are the dominant, intertwining threads of Brook's career.

While that career, and productions such as The Island, have helped liberate theatre, that crucial choice must still be faced. "Nowadays," says Brook, "there are new sorts of pressures. Today, the cost of making theatre is so enormous it's become a new form of institutionalising. Right now, the most important thing to recognise is that money has to be spent on the right to fail.

"When John, Winston and Athol were working they had the freedom that it cost nothing at all, so they could take all the risks that they wanted to take; but a system existed - apartheid - that made it almost impossible." They struggled and won, securing a lifetime's respect from Brook. "That need, to break out of whatever is the established system and take risks, is always there," he insists now, in a clarion call to his, and Kani's, and Ntshona's, and Fugard's inheritors. "But there will always be new ways to hold it back."

 The Island is in rep at the National Theatre, London SE1 (0171-452 3000), till February 26.

fields.headline: Short and sweet
fields.standfirst: Tired of long evenings in the dark? You're not alone.  Lyn Gardner on the rise of the mini-play
fields.trailText: Tired of long evenings in the dark? You're not alone. Lyn Gardner on the rise of the mini-play
fields.body:
Tonight, if you live within striking distance of London's West End, you can take your pick from Yasmin Reza's hit comedy Art, which lasts about 80 minutes, Athol Fugard's The Island, which lasts around 85, or Conor McPherson's Dublin Carol, which comes in at a bulky hour and a half.

If these sound daunting, less demanding alternatives are available. Gradiva at the Purcell Room lasts about 45 minutes, and Krapp's Last Tape at the New Ambassadors slightly less.

But those with busy schedules will be heading for the Isle of Dogs, where the experimental theatre company Stan's Café is performing a new show, It's Your Film. It lasts just 180 seconds.

This is by no means a record. Samuel Beckett, a playwright who always found brevity a virtue, wrote a play called Breath that lasts just 30 seconds. And The End Part 2, which was performed at one minute past midnight at the Arches in Glasgow to usher in the year 2000, took around seven minutes to chart the entire human life cycle. Talk about your life flashing in front of you.

There was a time, not so long ago, when a night at the theatre was rather a hefty undertaking. I remember when it was common to see those who lived out of town creeping out of West End plays before the end of the performance in order to guarantee their transport home. Not any more. Walk down Shaftesbury Avenue or St Martin's Lane after 10.15pm and most of the theatres are already locked up for the night.

There is a theory among the more cynical that however long any theatre show is, it is always 10 minutes too long, but certainly the past few years have seen a trend towards brevity. Who wants to sit through four hours of Hamlet when you can see all 37 plays in 97 minutes with the Reduced Shakespeare Company? And have a meal and go to a club.

"Theatre is like a Tardis - it gets shorter or longer depending on how much you are enjoying yourself," says Mike Bradwell of the Bush Theatre, although he agrees that audiences' attention spans are getting shorter. Bradwell points out that playwrights are also increasingly drawn to the idea of short, sharp shocks: he has new plays by Enda Welsh and Hilary Fannin coming up, neither of which last more than an hour and a quarter.

Helen Lannaghan of the London International Mime Festival, which specialises in oddities such as It's Your Film, says audiences and theatre managers out of London are more likely to be unhappy if the experience is over too quickly.

"In rural areas people can travel a long way to the theatre, and some do find it upsetting if they spend two or three times as long getting there and back as they do in the theatre," she says. From the theatre manager's point of view, short performances mean loss of revenue from interval bar sales.

Lannaghan makes sure that the length of shows is clearly stated in advance publicity and, on occasion, offers a lower seat price for shows that come in under 45 minutes. fields.headline: Movers
fields.trailText: After Monday's respite, leading blue chips resumed their downward path yesterday, finishing close to their lowest level of the session.
fields.body:
After Monday's respite, leading blue chips resumed their downward path yesterday, finishing close to their lowest level of the session.

Interest rate uncertainties continued to weigh on sentiment in Britain and across the Atlantic. The FTSE 100 index closed down 105.7 points at 6,274.1, not far from an afternoon low of 6,262.9.

The other main indices also registered big falls. About 1.5bn shares changed hands, strong trading in Vodafone AirTouch again proving to be a big feature.

With inflation slightly above forecast and a dull British Chambers of Commerce report on the manufacturing and services sectors adding to the gloom in the morning, hopes that a rally on Wall Street might pull London out of its spin proved unfounded.

The financial sector was a notable weak spot. Lloyds TSB lost 27p to 619p, Barclays fell 56p to £13.79, while Standard Chartered eased 18p at 799p.

Among the insurers, Prudential shed 19p to £11.00, with Royal & Sun Alliance down 19p at 413p. But Norwich Union benefited from a good set of 1999 new business numbers and managed to crawl forward 3p to 398. The strength in Allied Zurich, up 10p at 603p, reflected the release of further details of Zurich Financial Services' plans to spin off its property holdings.

Drug stocks continued to suffer after big falls overnight in New York, prompted by news that talks on a three-way merger between Warner-Lambert, American Home Products and Proctor & Gamble had been abandoned. SmithKline Beecham shed 25p to 696p and merger partner Glaxo Wellcome lost 41p to £15.35.

ICI was down 18 at 499-1/2, still reeling from US paint litigation fears and some advice from Lehman Brothers on Monday telling clients to switch into Germany's Bayer.

Having raced ahead earlier in the day, Sage Group lost all of its gains to close 2p lower at 747p, ignoring news of a Merrill Lynch profits upgrade and an accompanying 900p price target. Fellow tech blue chip Misys also gave back earlier gains, easing 2p to 789p, with dealers said to be nervous ahead of first half results on Thursday.

After Monday's burst of takeover speculation, Cable & Wireless suffered see-saw trading conditions as pundits weighed the ramifications of the news that its 54% HKT in Hong Kong is in merger talks with Singapore's SingTel.

The bulls won the day, with the price closing 47p firmer at £12.37.

fields.headline: Merrill Lynch
fields.trailText: Conventional new new business thinking says traditional stockbroking should be annihilated by the web. The cocktail of new technology and fresh competition from a thousand unlikely directions should crush margins, while the proliferation of free sources of investment advice can only erode the value of premium stockbroking services such as company research.
fields.body:
Conventional new new business thinking says traditional stockbroking should be annihilated by the web. The cocktail of new technology and fresh competition from a thousand unlikely directions should crush margins, while the proliferation of free sources of investment advice can only erode the value of premium stockbroking services such as company research.

But there is no sign yet of any erosion at Merrill Lynch, the world's biggest broker, not even the faintest crushing sound. On the evidence of yesterday's fourth quarter figures, annihilation has been postponed.

There was the sound of jaws hitting the pavement on Wall Street in the morning as the Thundering Herd turned in figures showing earnings up 120% in the last three months of 1999 - way above analysts' expectations, which had already been inflated by top drawer figures from rivals Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley over the past fortnight.

The Merrill machine produced profits of $2.6bn (£1.6bn) last year, up 70% on 1998. Its return on equity is close to 25%.

"Investors embraced our 'new choice' platform combining technology with advice and guidance, and brought new assets to Merrill Lynch at an accelerating rate," said the chairman and chief executive, David Komansky.

In fact, private investors are throwing money at Merrill to invest at the rate of $500m every business day.

Even the Asset Management Group, which includes our home-grown Mercury Asset Management, looks pretty perky, with assets under management up 11% for the year. And in investment banking, predictably, fees from underwriting and corporate finance advice surged by more than a third in the fourth quarter compared with autumn 1998, topping $1bn. Merrill was the number one adviser in European flotations last year.

It is clear this business is managing to harness the web, rather than let the web snaffle its client base. No wonder the shares jumped 5% to $80 yesterday - almost double their autumn 1998 low.

webTitle: Funk, techno and all that jazz

fields.headline: Funk, techno and all that jazz
fields.standfirst: One day Ashley Slater was playing trombone with Loose Tubes, the next he was jamming with Norman Cook. He tells  John Fordham  why he can't bear to be pigeonholed
fields.trailText: One day Ashley Slater was playing trombone with Loose Tubes, the next he was jamming with Norman Cook. He tells John Fordham why he can't bear to be pigeonholed
fields.body:
"I think I must have played to all the Guardian readers in the UK when I was with Loose Tubes," says Ashley Slater, the garrulous, bone-domed American who helped found that much-missed jazz collective.

That was a decade ago; since then this trombonist-cum-vocalist has explored techno and pop as much as jazz. At the head of his new Big Lounge band, he's become involved with an outfit that's just as happy crossing genres as he is.

Big Lounge's appearance at London's Spitz this week is the latest in the Serious Sampler series of events run by the producer/promoters Serious Productions. Conceived 15 months ago, the scheme intermingles jazz improvisation, dance-club technology, world music, mixed media and plain suck-it-and-see optimism. The events it has backed include Andy Sheppard and Claude Deppa's jazz-improv experiment with DJs Max Reinhardt and Rita Ray, and Orlando Gough's The Shout, which put classically trained singers alongside gospel, blues and rock-influenced vocalists.

For Slater, none of this genre-jumping is new. In the late 80s, while still with Loose Tubes, he often toured with Microgroove, a high-energy funk band that he describes as "somewhere between an 80-year-old black blues musician and Andy Williams on acid." Then came four years of working with Norman Cook and Freakpower, which spawned the hit Turn on Tune In.

Since then Slater has been making "weird, acidy techno stuff" in his home studio under the name of Walter Ego and Dr Bone, but itching to play live in the company of musicians who value spontaneity.

Brought up in California, Slater adopted the UK in the 80s. A fine big-band jazz trombonist with a broad, expressive sound, he always aimed to reach a bigger audience. He won a record deal with Antilles when he was overheard singing with Loose Tubes; the parallel career sprang from that. Slater knows the jazz world can pass harsh judgments on good players who jump ship for commercial music, but he never heard it as a betrayal.

"Microgroove wasn't a formula funk band - it was a jam band," Slater recalls with affection. "I'd rant, sing, rap, play trombone. Nothing was the same from one night to the next. And it never felt like selling myself short. I just saw it as a golden opportunity to get to an audience I wanted to get to. I love jazz and I think most of my jazz contemporaries bear me no ill will. Sometimes they'll even ask, 'How can I make my sound a bit hipper?' For me, if I can play something that has improvisation but also great singalong tunes, grooves, humour, jazz horn parts and some political commentary too, I'm happy."

Big Lounge is typical of the kind of eclectic ensemble that plays at Serious Sampler: it includes a Loose Tubes jazz nucleus in drummer Steve Arguelles and guitarist John Parricelli, but also decks-operator Req 1, who will shuffle pre-recorded Slater brass parts and DJ with him before the show. The repertoire will run from Freakpower pieces to Carla Bley.

Serious Productions won Arts Council cash for the Sampler project on the grounds that it would offer a practical, live engagement with the cross-fertilisations of recent times. Involved since the 70s with musicians operating in the cracks between genres, Serious was well placed to see all this coming long before the mainstream promoters. It also distrusted the simplistic policies that emerged when the penny did drop that audiences were getting harder to pigeonhole. "Dumping the Smith string quartet into the Ministry of Sound and hoping for the best," Serious's David Jones calls it. "We wanted to commission, not only promote," Jones recalls, "but being the kind of operation we are, that meant commissioning a process, not simply notes on paper. We would also record and video the artists, so that would give them something tangible at the end.

"It's one point where club culture and live music meet" he continues. "People accuse us of not being interested in jazz, but I'd say we concentrate on the intensity of jazz. It's less valuable viewed as a separate category, more as a source of players who are using that incredible virtuosity, sense of community and spontaneity to make live events where things change from night to night. We're moving away from artists with master plans."

"Musicologists should be ecstatic about what's happening today," Slater agrees. "There's just so much to hear out there. The dance field has the vitality and the central place jazz had in the 40s. It's what people want to hear when they go out. And jazz that goes that way doesn't have to sell out."

 Ashley Slater's Big Lounge is at the Spitz, London E1 (0171-392 9032), tonight.

fields.headline: Whitehall leaks reveal ethics row
fields.standfirst:
Ministers urged to shelve policy

Labour's ethical foreign policy: special report
fields.trailText: A battle is raging across Whitehall over whether human rights and environmental considerations should play any part in deciding whether the government should underwrite billions of pounds worth of exports worldwide.
fields.body:
A battle is raging across Whitehall over whether human rights and environmental considerations should play any part in deciding whether the government should underwrite billions of pounds worth of exports worldwide.

Confidential documents - leaked to the Guardian and Channel 4 - reveal that an internal review ordered by the trade secretary, Stephen Byers, has revealed an establishment riven by pressures from civil servants, who want the government to abandon ethical criteria in favour of commercial considerations.

The documents show the difficulties confronting some Labour cabinet ministers who are trying to retain an ethical dimension to export policy while multinationals and British firms demand that they back large arms, power and oil and gas projects.

Multinationals are reportedly saying they may move production out of Britain and will apply for export aid from countries such as Italy, the US and Belgium, which have less rigorous criteria.

Last year, amid concern about the role of the shadowy export credit guarantee department - part of the department of trade and industry - Mr Byers launched a fundamental review over its future, particularly over whether it should help the poorest developing countries emerge from debt. The inquiry will report in March.

The government has underwritten £17bn worth of contracts over the past five years to countries including China, Saudi Arabia, Pakistan, Indonesia and Zimbabwe.

The leaked documents indicate that Whitehall favours relaxing blanket bans on regimes such as Argentina, Nigeria and Venezuela, and replacing this with cover provided to exporters on a "case by case" basis.

The disclosures follow rows over arms sales to Pakistan, Indonesia and Zimbabwe after cabinet office minutes were leaked to the Guardian.

Four departments are at the centre of the Whitehall battle, revealed in documents to be shown on tomorrow night's Mark Thomas Product. The ministry of defence and the DTI are on one side, calling for few restrictions, and the department of environment, transport and the regions and Clare Short's department of international development are on the other. The foreign office appears to be far more guarded in its support of an ethical policy.

In two submissions to the inquiry, Malcolm Rickson, a senior MoD civil servant with the defence exports sales organisation, states that a unilateral ethical foreign policy puts Britain in "a lose-lose situation".

"There is nothing to be gained by, for example, imposing environmental or human rights criteria on the acceptability of business for ECGD cover unless these criteria are internationally agreed and applied in practice. Unilateral action over such criteria merely allows others to win the business without taking any account of environmental, human rights or other wider factors."

He adds that on defence sales, in particular, a decision to refuse a country export credits can "have very long term consequences on the UK's prospects for winning business".

"Decisions taken today, driven by a particular situation, can have an effect long after the situation in the country has changed many of our customers have long memories. They do not forget those who support them in times of difficulty but neither do they forget those who failed to support them.

"If ECGD is unable to underwrite export business or give competitive terms then companies will look elsewhere and eventually place production accordingly."

Graham Rowcroft of the DTI's export arm, British Trade International, makes the same point. "International companies thinking long term about business development are increasingly looking at moving their value added operations outside the UK due to the ongoing uncertainty over export credit," he says.

The strongest case for more ethical considerations is made by Ms Short. In a two-page letter to the review panel, she demands that the ECGD consider whether developing countries' economic policies include sustainable development aimed at relieving poverty.

She calls for damage to the environment to be a key consideration in helping countries and calls on the ECGD to take a lead in encouraging private business to invest in countries that follow such a policy, citing Uganda, which has received debt relief, as a good example.

She is backed by Penny Brooke, a senior civil servant in the department of the environment, transport and the regions, who says: "Our needs must not be met by treating others, including future generations and people elsewhere in the world, unfairly."

The foreign office itself is more lukewarm saying the "core criteria should be financial" in supporting British firms but "there is scope at the margins for introducing other considerations".

fields.headline: Deutsche to float internet business
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Deutsche Telekom yesterday revealed plans to cash in on the boom in internet stocks by floating its T-Online business in mid-April. Analysts are already putting a price tag of between €20bn (£12bn) and €30bn on T-Online, which is Europe's biggest internet service provider.
fields.body:
Deutsche Telekom yesterday revealed plans to cash in on the boom in internet stocks by floating its T-Online business in mid-April. Analysts are already putting a price tag of between €20bn (£12bn) and €30bn on T-Online, which is Europe's biggest internet service provider.

Deutsche Telekom, which owns the One2One mobile phone business in Britain, said that it would be keeping a "clear majority stake" in T-Online, with indications that it may offer a 10% stake to investors.

The German telecoms operator is also lining up a flotation of its T-Mobil mobile phone business towards the end of the year.

Though the sales, plus the disposal of the 10% stake in the American telecoms company Sprint, are bound to raise speculation that Deutsche Telekom is bolstering its coffers before hitting the acquisitions trail, the proceeds of the T-Online float are expected to remain with the internet business.

The stake on offer is expected to come from issuing new stock, however, allowing T-Online to use its own shares to make acquisitions without Deutsche Telekom having to give up control.

"By offering T-Online shares on the stock market, Deutsche Telekom is broadening the basis which exists for its subsidiary's growth strategy," the group said.

The T-Online sale will be at least two months ahead of the sale of the next tranche from the 66% of Deutsche Telekom shares still controlled by the state. Under the terms of its most recent sale, the government cannot sell any more shares before June. News of the T-Online sale boosted Deutsche Telekom shares by 4% on the German market as investors digested the likely value of T-Online.

"The value of internet stocks is rising by the hour," according to analyst Theo Kitz at Merck Finck and Co.

At the press conference yesterday Deutsche Telekom's chairman Ron Sommer refused to be drawn on the likely value of T-Online. "It depends on what the stock market does,"he said.

Deutsche Telekom said that T-Online had doubled its customer base to 4.2m subscribers in the past two years. Monthly growth had been running at around 100,00 a month for most of 1999 but had doubled in the last quarter of the year.

Traffic volumes had also risen sharply. Though Mr Sommer refused to be drawn on the Deutsche Telekom's acquisition strategy in the face of the rapid consolidation in the industry, the group is known to be keen to expand in both fixed and mobile telephony in Europe.

In addition to One2One, it also owns max.mobile in Austria and made an unsuccessful bid for Telecom Italia last year with the German group's position as a state controlled company proved a key stumbling block.

Analysts are looking to Deutsche Telekom to make international acquisitions to offset tough conditions in its home market.

Last week the group reported profits last year had fallen by 45% to €1.2bn - broadly in line with expectations, largely as a result of price cutting in the fiercely competitive and recently deregulated German market.

Revenues were disclosed as virtually unchanged at €35.3bn.

fields.headline: Le Quatuor
fields.standfirst:
Queen Elizabeth Hall, London
Rating: ***
fields.trailText: Le Quatuor look much like any classical string quartet: four solemn-faced, middle-aged men dressed in tails. The illusion holds as they strike up a tune for a couple of bars. Then everything goes wrong: lights explode, leaving the quartet in darkness; candles set a fiddle alight; three seats are mysteriously removed, launching the players into a slapstick game of musical chairs. All the while, they keep up a brilliant medley of melodies.
fields.body:
Le Quatuor look much like any classical string quartet: four solemn-faced, middle-aged men dressed in tails. The illusion holds as they strike up a tune for a couple of bars. Then everything goes wrong: lights explode, leaving the quartet in darkness; candles set a fiddle alight; three seats are mysteriously removed, launching the players into a slapstick game of musical chairs. All the while, they keep up a brilliant medley of melodies.

The French ensemble, appearing in London's International Mime Festival and fresh from a year's run in Paris, are startlingly multi-talented. They can play (the cellist, Laurent Cirade, comes off particularly well), sing close harmony, dance with vigour and co-ordination - and do all three at once. Theirs is a very sophisticated form of old-fashioned clowning.

Le Quatuor don't hold with complicated props: their instruments and four chairs do them fine, thank you. Did you know that if you unscrew a bow and let the horsehair hang loose from the tip you can achieve a very passable fishing rod? Have you contemplated the possibility of four people playing one cello? It can be done, especially if someone has the presence of mind to bow the cello spike. One particularly effective turn saw the portly viola player, Pierre Ganem, transform himself into a chanteuse by whipping off his tails to unfurl a splendid, spangled gown straight from Shirley Bassey's wardrobe.

The act moved at such a pelt that promising routines felt underdeveloped. As you were wondering how a quartet could replicate so exactly Jimi Hendrix's The Star-Spangled Banner, they galloped on to the next thing. An intriguing scene in which the apparently abandoned instruments started to chat (the viola expressed an interest in contemporary music, and was promptly laughed down by the violins - how like life) was frustratingly brief. Still, it was a charming show, and judging by the entranced kids, fun for all the family.

fields.headline: Credit card firms face $24.3bn suit
fields.standfirst: US retailers sue over transaction fees in landmark action
fields.trailText: Some of America's biggest retailers are claiming damages that could amount to as much as $24.3bn from Visa and Mastercard after accusing the credit card companies of forcing them to pay high transaction fees which then increase consumer prices.
fields.body:
Some of America's biggest retailers are claiming damages that could amount to as much as $24.3bn from Visa and Mastercard after accusing the credit card companies of forcing them to pay high transaction fees which then increase consumer prices.

A group of powerful companies led by Wal-Mart, the world's largest retailer, originally filed their lawsuit in 1996, alleging that the two credit card companies had violated anti-trust laws through their anti-competitive behaviour.

The US Justice Department followed this private lawsuit with its own legal action launched more than a year ago. In recent weeks, Judge John Gleeson has handed the retailer a preliminary victory by allowing the US Justice Department to review evidence with Wal-Mart's lawyers.

Retail groups including Sears Roebuck, Safeway and Circuit City have accused Visa and Mastercard of abusing their dominance of the credit card industry by forcing them to pay high prices for debit cards.

In a case with echoes of the landmark case against Microsoft, the credit card companies are accused of forcing stores to take both their debit and credit cards.

The lawsuit, filed in the US District Court in Brooklyn, is aimed at preventing the two card companies from bullying their way into new markets. The charges could be particularly challenging for Visa and Mastercard as they seek to take advantage of the growth in online shopping and greater need for electronic payments.

Visa, which is owned by 21,000 banks, is the world's largest consumer payment system with around 800m cards in circulation. MasterCard, the world's second largest, is owned by more than 23,000 financial institutions.

Together they control more than 75% of the world's credit card market.

In its lawsuit, the US Justice Department accuses the two companies of preventing banks from dealing with Amex, a competitor. It alleges that the companies do not effectively compete against one another through advertising and that they have slowed down the development of new card products and technologies such as smart cards and secure systems for the internet.

Janet Reno, the US Attorney General, said: "Visa and Mastercard's anti-competitive behaviour has stifled competition between these two dominant networks and has thwarted competition from smaller networks."

Neither company, which have both denied any wrongdoing, returned calls to discuss the case yesterday. A trial date has been set for the end of November.

fields.headline: Edifice over simplicity
fields.standfirst:
Nikolai Demidenko
Royal Festival Hall, London
Rating: ***
fields.trailText: Nikolai Demidenko's sumptuous virtuosity is usually associated with the supercharged showpieces of the Russian romantic tradition. So it was surprising to find that the most memorable feature of his all-Chopin recital at the Royal Festival Hall was a limpid stillness that was by turns scintillating and soporific.
fields.body:
Nikolai Demidenko's sumptuous virtuosity is usually associated with the supercharged showpieces of the Russian romantic tradition. So it was surprising to find that the most memorable feature of his all-Chopin recital at the Royal Festival Hall was a limpid stillness that was by turns scintillating and soporific.

In the D flat major Berceuse, one of those weightless pieces that Chopin seems to have created from thin air, Demidenko was mesmerising. The left-hand ostinato provided a feather-light foundation for the lofty fantasy of the right-hand figuration. Many of the works were indebted to Chopin's translation of his skills as an improviser into his concrete compositions. It's hard to explain the quixotic episodes of a piece like the F minor Fantasy without thinking of it as an elaborate extemporisation on a cornucopia of themes.

Demidenko's half-veiled tone created a primordial murk in the Fantasy's introduction, out of which a shifting, uncertain melody gradually emerged. In fact, Demidenko was persistently murky throughout, even in the forthright march that dominates later on in the piece. Although his languorous tempi and distended phrasing caught a suitably overwrought atmosphere, he also stalled the mercurial progress of Chopin's overall structure.

In the F minor Ballade, Demidenko was even more concerned to linger upon individual phrases and gestures, until the release of the work's bravura conclusion. As a large-scale edifice, the interpretation was impressive, but his continual rubato threatened to overwhelm the simplicity of Chopin's melodic lines. It was as if Demidenko was adding a further layer of improvisation to the music, obfuscating Chopin's already abundant inspiration.

But there was no doubting the sensual stasis that Demidenko found in Chopin's own arrangement of the Larghetto from his second Piano Concerto. The work's fantastical roulades were dispatched by Demidenko with magnificent nonchalance. On the other hand, the F sharp minor Polonaise was an energetic illustration of Chopin's extrovert invention. And in the Polonaise-Fantasy, Demidenko achieved a genuine balance between the soft-focus privacy and pyrotechnical brilliance that limits Chopin's musical world.

fields.headline: Heavy on the 70s metal
fields.standfirst:
Smashing Pumpkins
Dominion Theatre, London
Rating: ***
fields.trailText: "Help a sick man sing!" pleaded Billy Corgan, as the Smashing Pumpkins thrummed their way through a nifty unplugged-style version of 1979. "I'm sick! I can't even speak!" Down in the stalls, Pumpkins zealots shrieked sympathetically.
fields.body:
"Help a sick man sing!" pleaded Billy Corgan, as the Smashing Pumpkins thrummed their way through a nifty unplugged-style version of 1979. "I'm sick! I can't even speak!" Down in the stalls, Pumpkins zealots shrieked sympathetically.

Engaged on a whistle-stop "if it's Tuesday this must be Belgium" European visit to plug their new album, Machina/The Machines of God, the last thing the Pumpkins needed was for their frontman to be sandbagged by the flu, but the suffering Corgan decided that the London show must go on. His nagging whine of a voice has never been the Pumpkins' strongest asset, but here it sounded like a handful of rusty razor blades clattering round inside a waste-disposal unit. So this wasn't the perfect opportunity to get a first live earful of the new songs, which aren't the most accessible the band have ever recorded. A boomy sound mix didn't help either. Nevertheless, it was still possible to detect Corgan's familiar preoccupations in the music. The Crying Tree of Mercury (lucky this tour was confined to western Europe, because his ludicrous prog-rock song titles could get him arrested by several of the world's less tolerant regimes) is steeped in The Cure's meandering gloom, while Heavy Metal Machine takes its cue from the ear-rupturing excesses of 70s heavy metal. Corgan even recruited Sharon Osbourne, wife of Ozzy, as his manager, but the arrangement disintegrated acrimoniously.

A 70s vibe was also apparent in a spooky, atmospheric arrangement of the David Essex hit Rock On, while the electro-shuffle of Ava Adore mutated into a thundering Zeppelin-style juggernaut. Part of the reason for this may be the return to the Pumpkin fold of drummer Jimmy Chamberlin, now forgiven for his transgressions with banned substances and back to lay down some mammoth grooves. New bassist Melissa Auf Der Maur slotted unobtrusively into the band's barrage of gigawatts.

Second guitarist James Iha promised that the new songs are "really nice", and I of the Mourning showed that there is some Top 40 potential. But the crowd were grateful for back-catalogue highlights like Tonight, Bullet with Butterfly Wings and Cherub Rock. The ghoulishly bald and black-clad Corgan may resemble a Transylvanian grave-robber, but at the end, he paid his respects by spending a few minutes bonding with the crowd and pinging plectrums into the front rows. He's canny enough to recognise the value of a display of humility.

fields.headline: Freedy Johnston
fields.standfirst:
12 Bar Club, London
Rating: ***&#42
fields.trailText: For a moper, Freedy Johnston does "in love" surprisingly well. His best album, 1997's Never Home, was also his most upbeat and content. I'd tell you that it was a brilliantly sloppy, corny rock-out mixing the spunk of Paul Westerberg with the bittersweet mush of Matthew Sweet, but that might put you off, and I wouldn't want to do that since Johnston needs all the help he can get right now.
fields.body:
For a moper, Freedy Johnston does "in love" surprisingly well. His best album, 1997's Never Home, was also his most upbeat and content. I'd tell you that it was a brilliantly sloppy, corny rock-out mixing the spunk of Paul Westerberg with the bittersweet mush of Matthew Sweet, but that might put you off, and I wouldn't want to do that since Johnston needs all the help he can get right now.

Johnston receives almost no coverage in the UK, was ignored in last year's "acoustic revival" pieces, and doesn't have the bucolic twang to fit in with the alternative country mafia. A stuffed 12 Bar is testament to his word-of-mouth following, but I've seen wardrobes bigger than the 12 Bar; and it's unlikely that he won any new converts with Blue Days, Black Nights, his relentlessly introverted follow-up to Never Home.

The ostensible theme of Blue Days, Black Nights is loss of love. The subtext is more along the lines of "I made the most life-affirming record of my life, and I still couldn't get anyone to buy it; I may as well retreat into my own anguish." In Underwater Life, the opener from the album, the narrator decides that, all things considered, he'd be better off swapping places with a drowned body he finds on a sailing trip. When he plays it, the bloke standing next to me, who's never heard Blue Days, Black Nights, says: "Bloody hell, that's a bit dark, isn't it?" I haven't the heart to tell him it's a party anthem compared with the remainder of the album.

Johnston's no killjoy, though. He's awkwardly funny between songs, and what his music communicates is not so much "life is shit", but "life can be shit, but as soon as we admit that, we can actually have quite a good time". There's a relaxed crowd-performer rapport in the air, possibly heightened by the precision of Johnston's self-loathing lyrics ("I look like Jeremy Irons's ghost"), the recognition that he sounds like Tom Petty might if someone stole his Heartbreakers, and, most of all, the sense that the whole room is keeping an intimate, golden secret from the outside world.

fields.headline: Primary colour
fields.standfirst:
Bruce McLean, Works 1969-1999
Talbot Rice Gallery, Edinburgh
Rating: ****
fields.trailText: Right at the heart of a seat of learning - a large, imposing university building - Bruce McLean has placed a radically different pedagogic vision. At Edinburgh University's Talbot Rice Gallery they are holding a mini-retrospective of this endlessly challenging, tirelessly questioning Scottish artist's work.
fields.body:
Right at the heart of a seat of learning - a large, imposing university building - Bruce McLean has placed a radically different pedagogic vision. At Edinburgh University's Talbot Rice Gallery they are holding a mini-retrospective of this endlessly challenging, tirelessly questioning Scottish artist's work.

You can see documentation of his performance projects, paintings from the 70s and 80s and small-scale architectural models such as his proposal for Argyle Street in Glasgow, a long, narrow, brightly coloured concoction like a pinball machine. All this is fascinating enough, showing McLean's iconoclastic approach to the process and place in art over three decades. But it is really a walk-through, 3-D, almost life-size model of a proposal for an Ayrshire primary school that steals the show.

If Rudolph Steiner were to dream up an educational building, it would look like McLean's plans for Lawthorne Primary School. Worked up with critic Mel Gooding and Willie McLean, Bruce's architect son, the vision is the antithesis of most schools. It is transparent, built from a child's perspective, and all the fixed points (desks, blackboards) are suddenly up for grabs.

Tables totter on high, suspended from the ceiling; a sandpit is a graceful Zen-inspired table complete with quotes from Nam Gaubo; the board says "schools out" (sic), and it most emphatically is. The three Rs are superseded by elliptical phrases projected on to a high screen: "train of thought", "primrose path".

At the private view, toddlers roamed far and wide through the model, looking more at home in this school building, however provisional, than most of us could imagine. Who knows if the school will ever materialise as McLean envisages? That's not really the issue. This is a blueprint - a madcap, dreamy, utopian blueprint - from an intellect that knows no limits.

 Until February 26. Details: 0131-650 2211

It is transparent, built from a child's perspective, and all the fixed points (desks, blackboards) are suddenly up for grabs. Tables totter on high, suspended from the ceiling; a sandpit is a graceful Zen-inspired table complete with quotes from Nam Gaubo; the board says "schools out" (sic), and it most emphatically is. The three Rs are superseded by elliptical phrases projected on to a high screen: "train of thought", "primrose path". At the private view, toddlers roamed far and wide through the model, looking more at home in this school building, however provisional, than most of us could imagine. Who knows if the school will ever materialise as McLean envisages? That's not really the issue. This is a blueprint - a madcap, dreamy, utopian blueprint - from an intellect that knows no limits.  Until February 26. Details: 0131-650 2211

fields.headline: Tricks of the trade
fields.standfirst:
How I beat the fear of public speaking

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Karen Morris, 36 Housing manager
fields.body:
Karen Morris, 36 Housing manager

I did a work placement at a bank as part of a local business initiative. At the end I had to give a speech on the financial side of our company to these City types. It was important to get all the jargon right, and to do thorough research. I didn't want to come across as fluffy. Also, you have to know what your audience wants. Mine only wanted the financial facts, not the social implications of my work. Humour is good: I asked questions at the end, finishing with "Who's your favourite Spice Girl?" and offered them a bowl of mints. They all went mad for the sweets.

Louise Price, 53 Company director

Public speaking stages are set up for men. As a woman, the microphone will always be too high, the sound check is set for a man's voice so women usually sound squeaky, and I never have anywhere to put my handbag. I've learnt to take my time. I put my handbag over the back of my chair, adjust the microphone to my height and speak slowly and in a deeper voice than usual. The important thing is to appear self-possessed and confident. People only listen to 20% of what you're saying; the other 80% is concentrating on your body language, the way you're standing and what you're wearing - particularly if you're female.

Michael Leith, 47 Financial director

I've always dreaded public speaking. In particular, it was the way I never seemed to get the timing right that really bothered me. In the end I went on a course, where I learnt to divide my speech into three parts. If I'm doing a 15-minute speech I work out beforehand where I should be after five and then after 10 minutes, and keep my watch on the table in front of me. It slows me down and also makes me think anew about what I'm saying. Also, I've now realised that you have to take a gentle breath rather than a deep breath at the start of your speech. It makes you speak more slowly and clearly, rather than just trying to get the whole thing out in one go.

A few years ago I gave a speech to 400 people about the charity organisation I work for. I prepared little prompt cards because I'd read that's what you do. I began and promptly lost the order of my cards, so I put them back on the table and simply talked. It sounds dangerous, but I just took off and spoke with passion. Afterwards, an MP in the audience told me I was really good. Since then I never use prompt cards, but always take them with me as a security blanket. Ad-libbing gives your speech conviction: there's nothing worse than a monosyllabic tone.

Daniel Williams, 31 Financial manager

My parents were in the Salvation Army, and the congregation were always asking us children to sing on stage. It has helped with public speaking, because I don't get fazed when I'm the focus of attention. Before my first speech I spent three nights worrying about what I was going to say, rather than how I would behave. On the day I felt relatively comfortable. I'm a self-help fanatic and I've got one of those books which teach you how to relax. I didn't look at anyone directly - I fixed on a couple of points in the room. That way you don't look so wooden when you speak.

webTitle: EU car prices still at sixes and sevens

fields.headline: EU car prices still at sixes and sevens
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: A Rover 214 is now more than 60% dearer to buy in Britain than in France, according to figures published by European consumer groups yesterday.
fields.body:
A Rover 214 is now more than 60% dearer to buy in Britain than in France, according to figures published by European consumer groups yesterday.

A Ford Focus costs 56% more in Britain than in Denmark and UK buyers of a VW Golf are paying nearly 54% more than Finns.

The figures confirm that the price gap for the same car in different markets remains as wide as ever. They prompted BEUC, the European Consumers' Union - a body which includes the Consumers' Association - to call on the commission to end exclusive car distribution and dealership arrangements. Car firms argue that a supermarket-style selling system with all brands under one roof would not be good for consumers.

The exemption permitting this expires in October 2002, and consumer lobbyists say it should not be renewed, because it enables car manufacturers to set prices in different markets and inhibit motorists from shopping around elsewhere in Europe.

The latest figures show that commission pressure on car makers to keep the price gap between models in different markets to less than 12%, in return for the exclusive dealership rights, has failed.

fields.headline: Toyota wooed in internet struggle
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: The battle for supremacy between the burgeoning internet global car parts supply networks heated up yesterday when Toyota became the target of rival offers from General Motors and Ford.
fields.body:
The battle for supremacy between the burgeoning internet global car parts supply networks heated up yesterday when Toyota became the target of rival offers from General Motors and Ford.

The world's two largest car-makers, both from the US, confirmed that they were wooing their Japanese rival, the number three manufacturer, to join their competing system.

The potentially hugely lucrative e-commerce market, which enables companies to slash costs and administration, has seen General Motors forge a link with Commerce One

Ford has also linked up with Oracle to develop rival systems connecting manufacturers to suppliers: TradeXchange and AutoXchange.

Carmakers have for the past decade put the squeeze on components-suppliers, with BMW the latest to cut their numbers and source parts from overseas in an effort to turn around its ailing UK unit Rover.

Toyota, which pioneered the just-in-time parts supply system in the 1980s that has been copied by all its rivals, may be unwilling to join an internet-based system dominated by its US competitors.

It is developing its own internet-based system and has been talking to Volkswagen, Europe's biggest car manufacturer, about standardising parts for sale in Europe.

The US groups are also wooing Nissan, Renault, Honda and others to join their system, with Toyota offered an equity stake in GM's website as a sweetener.

But Tadaaki Jagawa, the Japanese group's IT vice-president, said Toyota was extremely sceptical about the benefits of a cross-company scheme. It was notably worried that corporate secrets such as quality could be hacked into via components orders posted on the net.

fields.headline: Desk therapist
fields.standfirst: We showed desk therapist Donna Dawson the desk of Channel 5 director of programmes Dawn AireyWork Unlimited
fields.trailText: We showed desk therapist Donna Dawson the desk of Channel 5 director of programmes Dawn Airey
fields.body:
This desktop reminds me of a teacher's desk in a primary school - the bright colours of the folders and intrays, the multicoloured pens, markers and post-it notes. This person spends a lot of time at her desk, and it helps to see her work as fun. A red pen is prominent: this person is bold and forthright. A coloured note from her is designed to stir up drama; in fact, she often likes to put the cat among the pigeons! Like a teacher, she may have favourites.

She feels she has nothing to hide (note the transparent boxes). She can be stern, but also has a childlike sense of fun. She is a mistress of communication, and her job requires her to range over a variety of media. Her computer is not so important: she probably does most of her communication over the phone or face to face. Personal contacts are very important to her, and she may use them shamelessly. Her mind is restless, but she has a deep-seated need to be in control: her desk is a battle station, with everything she could need.

She's fun-loving, but ruthless; easy-going, but don't mess with her. Her diplomacy skills may need honing. She may be emotionally vulnerable, but tries to hide it. She is fashionable and funky, while still knowing there is always a right and a wrong way to do things. Because she is multitalented, she expects a lot, both from herself and others. Janet Street-Porter comes to mind!

Did our expert get it right?

Dawn Airey responds

This is really perceptive, though I don't like being referred to as a schoolteacher. If I meet Donna, I'll give her five of the best!

fields.headline: Nuclear option means mutual obliteration
fields.standfirst: Another outing for the slide rule
fields.trailText: Peter Ellwood, chief executive of Lloyds TSB, has made little secret of his tendency to pull out his slide rule and run it over anything that moves in the world of banking - or insurance, for that matter. But one story travelling around the Square Mile suggests that Mr Ellwood's slide rule has been out of his pocket on a more or less permanent basis recently, working an extraordinary plan to rid the entire country of building societies in one fell swoop.
fields.body:
Peter Ellwood, chief executive of Lloyds TSB, has made little secret of his tendency to pull out his slide rule and run it over anything that moves in the world of banking - or insurance, for that matter. But one story travelling around the Square Mile suggests that Mr Ellwood's slide rule has been out of his pocket on a more or less permanent basis recently, working an extraordinary plan to rid the entire country of building societies in one fell swoop.

Officials at Lloyds will neither confirm nor deny what would amount to the ultimate carpetbagging offensive and it may prove to be pure market tosh.

Yet an alleged codename for this supposed plan to offer the members of every society a cash bung with or without the blessing of the incumbent board is even doing the rounds - "Operation Hoover."

Lloyds knows a bit about the mutual sector, given that its successful courtship of Cheltenham & Gloucester prompted a wave of demutualisations. And any day now it will complete the takeover of Edinburgh's Scottish Widows. But the assumption has got to be that the political storm which something like Operation Hoover would unleash would end up stripping Mr Ellwood and his colleagues of their jobs - whatever the smarty-pants corporate finance thinking behind such a move.

At the same time, given what is going on among its quoted competitors, it is a sure bet that this latest £7bn Scottish Widows mouthful has not satisfied Lloyds' appetite. It is said to have tried to lure Abbey National, while there is also a very believable tale that, looking for a route round the competition commission blockade, Lloyds and Royal Bank of Scotland even had a chat about the English bank taking half of NatWest off the Scottish bank's hands, should its bid prove successful.

This, no doubt, ended in the file marked "bin" in the same way the two Scottish banks failed in their attempts to take parts of NatWest between them.

The permutations are endless and so are the pitfalls, but the competitive frenzy in the sector has got the City's creative juices flowing.

In a year's time, we may look back at the messy three way fight between NatWest and its two Scottish assailants as nothing more than a piece of primary school maths.

Messy merger

The idea that the merger of Britain's two biggest cooperative societies will somehow save the descendants of the Rochdale Pioneers from the competitive threat of global supermarket-isation beggars belief. Yet this appears to be the strategy underpinning the proposed marriage of the smaller and less prosperous Cooperative Retail Services with the Cooperative Wholesale Society, bringing 1,100 small-to-medium-sized convenience stores together.

After four months of silence on the issue, the CWS and CRS have now decided that members should vote on the matter on March 4.

At the operating level, CRS lost almost £60m last year, while the CWS produced profits of £113m, thanks to its well run banking and insurance off-shoots. So the plan now is to somehow kick start a merged group with a £12m advertising package, extend its loyalty programme and, er, hope that shoppers abandon out-of-town hypermarkets.

Then there are the cost savings, which all mergers are supposed to bring but which rarely materialise. Savings here look especially distant when there is little overlap in the CWS and CRS store chains, with the former relatively strong in the north and the latter in the south.

And on top of this come the politics of bringing together two bodies which seem, to outsiders at least, to have spent the best part of 20 years working against each other. This promises to be a very messy marriage, if the two even turn up at the ceremony.

Dotty precedent

There is a view that investors have been attracted to the dot.com phenomenon in part because they do not quite understand it.

Web-based services all sound so promising - so futuristic and glitzy - they must be world-changing and therefore a sound share punt.

So the latest flop to strike the biotechnology field should act as a warning to those who have recently switched en masse from internet stocks into this equally turbulent outpost of the pharmaceutical empire.

Potential cancer cures with names such as BB-3644 all sound very exciting as men in white coats offer health to patients and wealth to investors.

British Biotech admitted yesterday that its latest trials on the marimastat anti-cancer compound had been "disappointing". It was a lot worse than that. The shares plunged 42% because this was pretty much the last shot in the locker for a company which was an equivalent to Freeserve two years ago.

webTitle: Fears for Link grow after talks falter

fields.headline: Fears for Link grow after talks falter
fields.trailText: The countrywide Link cash machine network continued its fight for survival last night after a fiery meeting of its board failed to agree fundamental changes to the way customers are charged for taking money from machines.
fields.body:
The countrywide Link cash machine network continued its fight for survival last night after a fiery meeting of its board failed to agree fundamental changes to the way customers are charged for taking money from machines.

If the board fails to reach any agreement when the dispute is put to a vote at Link's next meeting at the end of next month, there is a fear that the Link network, founded by the building societies in the 1980s, could be torn apart.

The issue, which has arisen because of a move by Barclays to try to impose a £1 surcharge on its rivals' customers using its machines, has caused anger among some of the founding members of Link. Though Barclays has agreed not to impose the surcharge until after next month's vote - after the threat of legal action by Nationwide Building Society - it has stopped charging its own customers a "disloyalty" fee for using its rivals' machines, at a cost of £2m a month while the debate continues.

The Nationwide insisted yesterday that it would not back any motion put to the board which allowed the introduction of a "surcharge". And while yesterday's board meeting split up without a decision on the detail of the motion to be put to next month's vote, sources acknowledged last night the surcharge looked likely to be on the agenda.

One of the proposals on the table is that members of Link will vote on allowing members to introduce a surcharge on rivals' customers, provided they do not also charge rival financial firms the "interchange" fee - paid between firms for processing the transactions - which currently averages a little more than30p.

Link refused to disclose details of the the proposals discussed at yesterday's meeting but it is understood that big changes to the way the interchange fee is structured could be put to the vote later this month.

The changes would see those members which do not impose a "surcharge", charging and paying each other fees ranging from 15p to 70p. The larger fees will be received by those firms with the larger cash machine networks from the smaller members of Link.

"These are not definitive proposals and members have a week to come up with alternatives," a source said last night. "It is untrue that the Link network is under threat and most members agree that these are good proposals".

Any motion will need 80% support from the board to be passed and Brian Davis, chief executive of Nationwide, called on members of Link to make public which side they have backed.

"Its a wonderful opportunity for consumer pressure," Mr Davis said.

He argued that even if the "interchange" fee structure is altered, banks and other financial firms charging customers "disloyalty" penalties will be making a profit on any charge they make.

webTitle: I'm afraid the pheasant's off, Sir

fields.headline: I'm afraid the pheasant's off, Sir
fields.standfirst: When a restaurant worker's temper reaches boiling point in the kitchen, it's time to duck before your goose is well and truly cooked...
fields.trailText: When a restaurant worker's temper reaches boiling point in the kitchen, it's time to duck before your goose is well and truly cooked.
fields.body:
They are murderous places, restaurant kitchens. The heat, the speed, the presence of knives. And whenever I have a case about a kitchen misdemeanour, it strikes me that the (mostly it seems) men who work in these kitchens are a special breed; often huge, always physically tough and with a glow on them as if they have just retreated from tending vast ovens - like labourers in Hell.

Big Bistro Restaurant had sacked Mr D for hurling a pheasant at a waiter, who pointed out that the bird in question was stone cold. The day before the case I had already lost some face with the Big Bistro Restaurant solicitor whilst reading back extracts from the witness statements over the phone:

Me: "And then when we get to the bit where Mr D is alleged to have said 'I tripped over and the pheasant flew off the plate and hit Ramon in the face'"

At this point, a horrible explosive sound issued from my roommate who was expelling air from his nose in a demented fashion.

Me (strangled tones): "Uhh, terribly sorry, could I ring you back in five minutes? Something urgent has just arisen."

Roommate was still tittering as I put down the phone. A scene of mindless violence ensued.

When we arrive at the tribunal, Mr D's solicitor, who has written numerous irritable letters demanding a settlement, has dematerialised.

Tribunal Chair: "Mr D, I see that there are solicitors on the record for you but I gather that no one is here with you today?"

Mr D, who is sat at the applicant's table with precisely no papers in front of him, retrieves a folded letter from his rear pocket and hands it up to the chair.

Tribunal Chair: "Ah, I see, Mr D, they say you haven't paid them. Is that right?"

Mr D: "Yeah."

Tribunal Chair: "Well, then. I'd better explain to you what will happen today."

He proceeds to intone the spiel which tribunal chairs give to unrepresented parties.

Perhaps it is slightly more long-winded than usual because I manage to complete mini-portraits of the two other tribunal members on my little stack of yellow Post-it notes. Mr D sits with his eyelids at half mast like a lizard dozing.

The tribunal chair gets to the bit where he explains that the tribunal is not interested in whether Mr D threw the pheasant or not but in whether it was reasonable for the employer to think that Mr D threw the pheasant.

Mr D (eyelids jerking open): "You what?"

fields.headline: Left on the shelf
fields.standfirst:
The suit used to signify tradition and status; now even accountancy firms let employees dress down and wearing jeans could become a human right. Gary Younge bids a formal goodbye

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: The suit used to signify tradition and status; now even accountancy firms let employees dress down and wearing jeans could become a human right. Gary Younge bids a formal goodbye
fields.body:
Richard Branson doesn't; Martin Bell does. The unemployed have to if they want to find work, but for those in work it may soon become a thing of the past. Women are still fighting for the right to wear them - but we are all about to win the right not to. The British suit is about to be left on the shelf.

Some bars in the City ban customers from wearing suits, while they are already passé among successful businessmen such as Bill Gates and Gerald Levin, the chairman of Time Warner. And on Monday the business consultancy firm Arthur Andersen made them optional when it informed its 7,000 staff by email that a more relaxed dress code was being introduced with immediate effect.

Paul Clarke, spokesman for Arthur Andersen, said the new dress code was already in evidence, with around half the staff now wearing "business casual" clothes.

"I can see from just looking around the office that people are wearing more casual clothes. There are people without ties and in casual shirts or funnel-neck jumpers."

Clarke explained that the move fitted in with many of Arthur Andersen's clients, especially e-commerce and internet companies, which tend to have more relaxed working practices. The new code was part of the global relaunch of the company and was about giving staff a choice. "If someone gets up in the morning and knows they do not have any appointments with clients, they can look more casual."

The move was greeted with relief by the firm's staff. "We're all very excited," said Clarke. "I'm not going to stop wearing suits completely, but I will no longer have to dress up if I'm not meeting a client."

Elsewhere there were mixed reactions. The head of campaigning in the Industrial Society, Debra Allcock, believes the suit reinforces outdated notions of what the business world is - or should be - about. "When everyone is wearing suits they are reinforcing the stereotype that the culture in an office is white, male, middle-aged and affluent," she says. "By expanding the dress code you open up the possibility for people to reflect their diversity."

But the managing director of one Savile Row tailor believes allowing people to wear casual clothes could send off the wrong signals to prospective clients. "A lot of people feel more comfortable in a suit and with people in suits," said Hugh Holland of Kilgour, French and Stanbury. "The trouble with casual clothes is that there aren't any boundaries to indicate what is and what is not appropriate. One person might understand it to mean khaki trousers and a sports jacket. Another might think it means a Mickey Mouse jumper."

This is a particular problem with British men, says Holland, who are among the worst dressers in Europe. "Italian men take the same amount of care over what they wear as British women," he says.

The answer, says Clarke, is trust. "We're saying that the company has confidence in its employees to decide for themselves how to look. But people can carry on wearing suits all the time if they prefer to. It's a question of flexibility."

It's also a question of inevitability. Thanks to the European Union, by October not wearing a suit could effectively be a human right. "This is a great piece of marketing on Andersen's part," says Allcock. "They are giving this impression of being up-front and forward-thinking, but they are doing something they will have to do in the end anyway."

Under the European legislation, which will be enshrined in British law in October, staff may be able to argue that their boss's insistence on a company dress code is a violation of their freedom of expression and right to privacy. But even without the law, the trend towards casual wear at work was already taking hold.

"The whole thing is changing," says Chris Scott-Gray, the director of the Menswear Council, which oversees Britain's suit market, worth £590m a year. "Dress-down Fridays, for instance, have become dress-down weeks. More and more companies are adopting dress-down policies - but they are still prescriptive about what can and can't be worn. It is certainly not being driven by European policy - it is being driven by people's desire to be more comfort able at work and to present themselves in the way they see best."

The absence of guidelines is a problem, admits Allcock. "I think it is up to the employer to say what is appropriate professional wear and to set a few parameters. But the idea that without guidelines people are going to turn up in bikinis is absurd."

The trend towards casual office wear, which started in the US and is yet to reach most of continental Europe, cements rather than dispels inconsistencies about what we can wear in the workplace. Earlier this month, jobseekers were told they had to wear a suit to interviews or risk having their benefits cut.

"First impressions count, and the standard dress for interviews is a suit for men and something equally smart for women," a spokesperson at the employment department said. "We will make funds available for people who have no smart clothes, although it might be possible to get them on loan."

Last week Judy Owen, a former training manager with the Professional Golf Association, won an industrial tribunal after they banned her from wearing trousers. Her victory came only two months after Eurostar caved in to legal pressure and announced that female security guards could choose to wear skirts or trousers when screening passengers and performing other duties; Debbie Sheen, 37, and Lynn McKay, 35, had been sent home the previous month from the Waterloo terminal in London for refusing to wear skirts.

But the end of suits does not necessarily mean the end of uniforms. As one Andersen employee said yesterday: "I'll probably end up wearing the same old stuff, but just without a jacket." When formal dress codes are relaxed, informal ones simply take their place. "What often happens is that people will just turn up in another uniform," says Allcock. "They still want to be identified as part of the tribe."

And at the end of the day, it is not as though staff at companies such as Andersen are known for their wild tastes outside work. "Accountants have always had a uniform," says Cary Cooper, an organisational psychology professor at the university of Manchester's institute of science and technology. "It makes them feel secure. This is going to be a real shock."

fields.headline: Net a Range Rover, save £14,600
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: An internet service yesterday reignited the "rip-off Britain" accusations by slicing £14,600 off the price of a Range Rover imported from Holland.
fields.body:
An internet service yesterday reignited the "rip-off Britain" accusations by slicing £14,600 off the price of a Range Rover imported from Holland.

Totalise Eurekar is promising buyers they can purchase a Range Rover 4.6 Vogue, built at Rover's Longbridge plant and exported to Holland, for £39,395. The UK list price of the vehicle is £53,995 .

There are also £11,958 savings on Land Rover Discovery seven-seaters and big cuts on a range of other cars, from Peugeots to Fords. Part of the reason for the cheaper prices is that dealers on the continent can buy in bulk, while re-importing cars into Britain offers major currency gains with the pound soaring.

But Peter Gregory, a former medical doctor who established www.totalise.net last year, says Britons have also got used to paying higher prices.

He said: "This is another example of the kind of savings that UK consumers can enjoy with Totalise Eurekar and another example of how UK consumers are being ripped off."

But car manufacturers hit back, insisting that British buyers were not getting a raw deal from them. A spokesman from the Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders said: "Manufacturers, through dealers here, often offer a range of extras such as trade-ins for old models, free servicing and long warranties."

He insisted that prices ebbed and flowed all the time, with a Citroen Saxo being cheaper in Britain now than it is in France. The SMMT official pointed out that web-based services had none of the costs associated with showrooms and servicing areas.

Mr Gregory insisted there were no catches to Totalise Eurekar's on-the-road prices. The cars are all right-hand drive and the same as offered in the UK but they are sourced through a network of dealers on the Continent.

Customers buying cars - all checked by an inspector from the Green Flag breakdown service - are being given 500 free shares in Totalise worth around £400.The shares started trading this summer at 20p but yesterday hit 80p.

fields.headline: It was different for girls...
fields.standfirst: Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: An excerpt from the July 1943 issue of a trade magazine called Transportation has been circulating around office emails. Entitled "Tips on Getting More Efficiency Out of Women Employees", it is a 10-point guide to welcoming women into the wartime workforce. The likelihood of it being genuine is diminished by the odd modern idiom - if it is not parody, perhaps former readers of Transportation would come forward and verify its authenticity.
fields.body:
An excerpt from the July 1943 issue of a trade magazine called Transportation has been circulating around office emails. Entitled "Tips on Getting More Efficiency Out of Women Employees", it is a 10-point guide to welcoming women into the wartime workforce. The likelihood of it being genuine is diminished by the odd modern idiom - if it is not parody, perhaps former readers of Transportation would come forward and verify its authenticity.

 Pick young married women. They have more sense of responsibility and are less likely to flirt.

 When you do use older women, try to get ones who have worked outside the home. Those who have never contacted the public are inclined to be cantankerous.

 "Husky" girls - those who are just a little on the heavy side - are more even-tempered and efficient than their underweight sisters.

 Stress that a minute or two lost here and there makes serious inroads on schedules, or service is likely to be slowed up.

 Give her a schedule of duties so she will keep busy without bothering management for instructions every few minutes. Women make excellent workers when they have their jobs cut out for them.

 Let the employee change from one job to another during the day. Women are inclined to be less nervous and happier with change.

 Give every girl an adequate number of rest periods. A girl is more efficient if she can keep her hair tidy, apply lipstick and wash her hands several times a day.

 Be tactful. Women are often sensitive; they can't shrug off harsh words the way men do.

 Never ridicule a woman - it diminishes her efficiency.

 Be considerate about strong language. Though a girl's husband or father may swear vociferously, she'll dislike a place of business where she hears it.
